Earlier guesses at the identity of ``Z'' included Zbigniew Brzezinski and Henry Kissinger, the foreign policy gurus of previous administrations; Robert Gates, the former No. 2 CIA chief who works at the White House; and retired Lt. Gen. William Odom, former head of the supersecret National Security Agency. All four men hold doctorates in Soviet studies or related fields and have expressed doubt over Gorbachev's prospects of success. All four either have denied authorship or refused to comment. And scholars who have scrutinized the text say it does not reflect the style of any of the most prominent candidates. Stephen R. Graubard, editor of Daedalus, refused to comment on the identity of the author, saying he agreed to keep it secret ``for compelling reasons.'' The mystery has heightened interest in Daedalus, which devoted the entire winter issue to the turmoil in Eastern Europe. Malia, a specialist on 19th century Russian intellectual history, could not be reached through the day Thursday at his home or office, and he was quoted in the Financial Times of London as denying authorship. A colleague of Malia's at Berkeley, historian Nicholas Riasanovsky, said he doubted Malia was the author, adding, ``Professor Malia has a distinctive and distinguished style, but this is not it.'' Malia's previous work includes a book on Aleksandr Hertzen, a 19th century Russian intellectual credited with inspiring generations of revolutionaries. Balzer of Georgetown said Malia ``is known only to historians, like myself.'' A well-placed administration source and expert in Soviet affairs said, ``Malia is a good guess.'' ``No one in the U.S. government I know could write that,'' said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It's too scholarly. No one in government would write it because the mindset is that of an historian, or someone trying to analyze the problem from a distance and not trying to propose a solution, the way someone in government would,'' he said. The article says that ``it is clear that 1989 will enter history as the beginning of communism's terminal crisis, and not just in Russia but from the Baltic to the China Sea, and from Berlin to Beijing.'' ``It is also clear that perestroika and glasnost, welcome in their intention, have in their application only aggravated the systemic crisis they were intended to alleviate. They have done so because, like all forms of soft communism, they go against the logic of the system they are trying to save,'' it said. ``Mikhail Gorbachev has been trying to promote soft communism through structures and a population programmed for hard communism. But the latter is the only variety of Sovietism that is the genuine article, for the essence of all varieties of Sovietism is party supremacy. Thus, the instrument of Mr. Gorbachev's reform _ the party _ is the basic cause of Sovietism's troubles,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Panama
DOC.TEXT: The following are steps President Bush proposes to help Panama with its economic recovery in the wake of the U.S. military invasion and the two years of U.S. economic sanctions. _$42 million for housing in the Chorillo area, which was destroyed by fire during the invasion; for emergency public works in Panama City, Colon and rural areas; for rehabilitation for small businesses damaged and looted, and for technical assistance to the government. _$400 million in short- and medium-term guarantees from the Export Import Bank and the Foreign Credit Insurance Association to finance sales of American products to Panama. _$15 million in Agency for International Development private-sector loans. _$50 million in Overseas Private Investment Corp. programs to support U.S. private investment in Panama. _$30 million in Agriculture Department programs. _$28 million to restore Panama's suspended sugar quota for 1989 and 1990. _$500 million for balance-of-payment support, public investment, economic restructuring and development support, including $150 million toward helping Panama pay its foreign debt of some $534 million, officials said. In addition to the money items, Bush announced: _Encouragement of other countries to help Panama clear its debt to international financial institutions. _Urging the so-called Paris Club of major debtor nations to enact an early and generous rescheduling of Panama's debt. _Easing of air travel restrictions to and from Panama. _Plans for a tax agreement with Panama so that U.S. firms could deduct expenses of conventions held in Panama. _Establishment of discussions on exchanging information with Panama on money laundering that occurs there. _Resumption of preferential buying of Panamanian products by the U.S. military there.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release at 10 a.m. EST; time set by source
Survey Finds Support for Government Long-Term Care Coverage
DOC.TEXT: A majority of Americans favor a federal long-term program that would cover the high costs of nursing home care through a plan similar to Social Security, according to a private study released today. The study, commissioned by the American Association of Retired Persons, found a majority of people of all ages would be willing to pay $50 a month for a long-term care package that offers nursing home protection for all Americans. The report was prepared by the Daniel Yankelovich Group research company, based on a survey of 1,490 Americans ages 18 and older. Those surveyed identified coverage of nursing home costs as the most important part of any long-term care package, with home care benefits seen as less important. Sixty-seven percent of those surveyed expressed strong support for a federal program, with the level of support fairly consistent among different age groups in the sample. The study also found a need for more public education about long-term care. Thirty-three percent of older Americans incorrectly thought long-term care costs were covered by Medicare, which pays for less than 2 percent of the nation's nursing home expenditures. Nursing home costs average more than $20,000 a year, with roughly half paid for directly by individuals and the other half by the government, mainly through Medicaid, the welfare program for the poor. Medicaid coverage of nursing home costs is available once people exhaust most of their private resources, with eligibility standards varying from state to state. The fledgling market for private nursing long-term care insurance has grown in recent years, with about 1.3 million policies sold by mid-1989.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Researchers Say Flu at Epidemic Levels
DOC.TEXT: A flu epidemic has hit the United States with outbreaks reported this winter ``just about everywhere,'' a Centers for Disease Control researcher said. A key indicator _ a deaths-from-flu index _ is at its highest level in at least eight years, CDC researchers said Thursday. Flu is reported ``widespread'' in 18 states and ``regional'' outbreaks are reported in 17 more states, the CDC said in its weekly report. Last week, 7.6 percent of 15,090 deaths reported to the CDC from 121 major cities were blamed on flu or pneumonia. That ``significantly exceeds'' expected levels for the second straight week, said Dr. Walter Gunn, a CDC viral disease specialist. ``This qualifies in our definition as an epidemic,'' Gunn said. The CDC's epidemic level is 6.7 percent. The 7.6 percent figure is the worst since the winter of 1981-82, Gunn said. Most of the flu samples reported to the CDC this winter have been the type which researchers call A-H3N2. That was the predominant type in the 1984-85 flu season, when an estimated 57,000 Americans died from flu _ 37,000 more than in the typical winter, Gunn said. ``As far as how many people will die'' this flu season, ``that depends on how long this peak is sustained,'' Gunn said. ``With any luck, it will come right back down.'' Flu has been reported this winter ``just about everywhere,'' Gunn said. The serious flu season, he said, points to the importance of flu vaccinations for those at greatest risk of serious complications from flu, including older people and patients with heart or lung disease. ``There's still time,'' he said. ``It only takes two weeks to build up your immunity.'' Gunn also stressed that parents whose children or teen-agers have flu symptoms should be careful not to treat them with aspirin, which has been linked in flu cases to Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially deadly disease.

DOC.HEAD: Spain's First Private Newscast Begins
DOC.TEXT: Spain's first private TV station to begin regular programming broke the state's 33-year monopoly with a newscast that immediately took the government to task. Antena 3 de Television is one of three private companies that gained a license in August from the government of Socialist Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. During the first broadcast Thursday, beamed only to Madrid and Barcelona, announcer Miguel Angel Nieto wasted little time in showing the new station will follow the strongly anti-government line of its national radio network. ``We cannot ask your forgiveness for not appearing in all of Spain,'' Nieto said. ``The government simply will not let us.'' Antena 3 and the other two private stations, all legally required to begin regular programming by April 3, are broadcast through a state-owned telecommunications network, which officials say is to cover the entire country by late 1991. Parliament voted to create three private stations in 1988. Until Thursday, most Spaniards received three channels, two run by the Spanish government and a third run by their regional government.

DOC.HEAD: States with Flu Troubles
With PM-CDC-Flu
DOC.TEXT: The Centers for Disease Control says figures for the week ending Jan. 20 have 18 states reporting ``widespread'' flu activity _ outbreaks of flu or flu-like illness in counties combining for more than half the given state's population. The 18 states are Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Missouri, South Dakota, Nebraska, Virginia, North Carolina, Georgia, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Texas, Montana, Idaho, and Arizona. These 17 states reported less pervasive ``regional'' flu outbreaks: New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Iowa, Delaware, West Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama, Arkansas, Louisiana, Wyoming, New Mexico, Utah, Nevada, Washington, and Alaska. These 13 states reported only ``sporadic'' cases of flu: Maine, Vermont, Rhode Island, Illinois, North Dakota, Kansas, Maryland, South Carolina, Florida, Colorado, Oregon, California, Hawaii. Indiana and New Jersey reported no flu activity.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Say Report of TV Mayhem Shows Need for Action
DOC.TEXT: A new report showing an upsurge in television violence on kids' shows could give a boost to a congressional move to curb violent programming, say the bill's sponsors. Children's weekend daytime programs contained more than 25 acts of violence per hour in each of the last three seasons, many of them set in a ``humorous'' context, said the study by University of Pennsylvania and University of Delaware researchers released Thursday. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., a sponsor of legislation limit the television violence, joined Rep. Dan Glickman, R-Kan., to release the study and say it shows how important the bill is. The bill to grant an antitrust exemption to the TV industry to address the issue is mired in a House-Senate committee. Several network officials have said the bill is not necessary. The bill contains no sanctions, but would reflect ``a clear message from Congress that we're dissatisfied,'' Simon said at a press conference. Simon, who first introduced the legislation five years ago, said the report could help ``boost prospects'' for final congressional action. He first introduced the measure five years ago. The study traced the rise of kids' TV violence to broadcast deregulation of the early 1980s. ``The most significant difference seems to be the dismantling of codes pertaining to violence during children's programming,'' the study said. It said the rate for violent acts during weekend daytime children's programs was 18.6 per hour before 1980, and 26.4 acts per hour after 1980. ``Violence essentially demonstrates who can dominate or terrorize whom, and humor is the sugar coating on the pill,'' said George Gerbner, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School for Communication and an author of the study. The study tracked TV violence occurring in a realistic or humorous context, but does not count verbal abuse. It said exposure ``cultivates a sense of relative insecurity, vulnerability and mistrust.'' Violence on prime time seems to have stabilized, Gerbner said. About half of all major characters are involved in violence and 10 percent in killing, as they have been since the first ``violence profile'' was prepared at the Annenberg School in 1967, he said. There were 5.9 violent acts per prime time hour in 1967, compared with 6.2 in 1988. The study addressed the three major networks. Cable television was not included. The House voted in August to give television networks, local stations, producers and the Cable TV industry a three-year antitrust exemption to formulate guidelines for depicting non-news violence on television. Currently, such discussions would violate the Sherman Antitrust Act. The Senate version of the bill was approved last May with an amendment by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that would also allow the TV industry to discuss ways to curb scenes that glorify drug use and portray sexually explicit material. A House-Senate conference committee has yet to begin working on the final bill. The Helms amendment ``is a sticking point. My hope is we can get a compromise,'' Simon said. He said the industry-wide guidelines made possible by the bill ``can begin at least to reverse the trend toward violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Family of Carol Stuart Announces Fund to Help Inner-City Residents
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Offers of donations poured in after the family of Carol Stuart announced a scholarship fund in her memory to aid residents of the inner-city neighborhood where she was fatally shot. Giusto and Evelyn DiMaiti announced the fund Thursday in their first appearance before reporters since they learned that their son-in-law apparently plotted their daughter's slaying. The DiMaiti family said they want their daughter to be remembered as more than just the victim of a sensational killing. They also said they hope to begin a healing process in the Mission Hill neighborhood where she was fatally shot Oct. 23 in an elaborate hoax. More than 40 people telephoned the family's lawyer immediately after the televised news conference, offering to donate money to the Carol DiMaiti Stuart Foundation Inc. Giusto DiMaiti, 64, who stood up to read a brief statement to reporters, choked up during the end of his remarks. ``She was truly the brightest of lights in our lives,'' said DiMaiti, who was flanked by his 62-year-old wife and 37-year-old son Carl. ``She will always and forever be with us. ... Mere words cannot express the emptiness we feel or how much we miss her now and will miss her for the rest of our lives.'' Mrs. DiMaiti, who dabbed at her eyes throughout the news conference, and Carl DiMaiti, did not comment. The scholarship fund has been established for residents of Mission Hill, the area where a manhunt was launched after Charles Stuart told police that a black mugger had shot him and his wife. The case drew wide attention and the badly wounded Stuart's dramatic call for help on his car telephone was broadcast nationally. His wife died hours later. Their son lived just 17 days after being delivered by Caesarean section. Ten weeks after the shootings, Stuart apparently committed suicide after one of his brothers implicated him in the shootings. In announcing the scholarship, attorney Marvin Geller recalled the ``old scars of racial tension'' opened by the hoax. ``The DiMaiti family believes that Carol would not have wanted her death to be remembered as the cause of such divisiveness,'' he said. Black community leaders in Boston applauded the announcement but tempered their remarks with lingering concerns about the damage done Mission Hill's residents. ``I think it's a magnanimous gesture on their part,'' said Louis Elisa, president of the Boston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``Given what they had to suffer from the cruel hoax, without proper protection from the city. Maybe they can prevail on the mayor to make an apology so the real healing can start.'' In a less conciliatory development, black state legislators announced a bill Thursday that would establish a special commission to investigate police work in the case. The commission, which would have limited subpoena power, would examine how police built a case against William Bennett, a black man who has since been exonerated. The panel also would try to determine where the media got information about Bennett.
Eds: Foundation address is: Shawmut Bank N.A., P.O. Box 11029, Boston, MA 02211.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Launches Drive for $25 Million White House Endowment
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush, saying the White House holds ``a special place in the hearts of Americans,'' is asking them to find $25 million in their pocketbooks for the executive mansion. Mrs. Bush on Thursday announced the start of a private fund-raising drive to raise an endowment for the famed public rooms of the mansion where every American president except George Washington has lived. The goal is to raise the money over the next three years to provide for future refurbishing and improvements of the State Dining Room, East Room, Blue Room and other salons that draw tens of thousands of visitors each year. The first lady said there is nothing crying out for repair or replacement right now but a $25 million endowment would help ensure for all time ``the best care and upkeep of all (the) splendid public rooms.'' Former first lady Nancy Reagan refurbished the family quarters of the White House with privately raised moneys and helped win accredited museum status for the public rooms of the mansion. The endowment would only go for the upkeep of those public rooms. The money will be raised by a new White House Endowment Fund, an offshoot of the White House Historical Association founded during the Kennedy era. Spearheading the drive will be an old friend of the Bushes from Midland, Texas, Dorothy M. Craig. ``Some of my friends at home think I'm going to redecorate the White House. That is not the case,'' she told reporters. ``I'm simply a fund-raiser.'' ``We are starting from scratch,'' said Mrs. Craig, a professional volunteer whose husband, Earle M. Craig Jr., is a retired oilman. Ms. Bush, announcing the membership of the new Endowment Fund, called the announcement of the fund-raising drive cause for ``a celebration ... for this splendid house.'' ``Throughout our history the White House has always held a special place in the hearts of Americans, even those 19th century miscreants who cut little pieces of the curtains as souvenirs,'' Mrs. Bush said. The drive was announced in the State Dining Room with several dozen members of the Historical Association, the new Endowment Fund and an existing Committee for the Preservation of the White House on hand, including former Kennedy and Johnson administration Cabinet member Clark Clifford. ``As Clark Clifford told me, Jackie Kennedy said the White House should be the first house in the land, and that's what we're hoping to keep it,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters. The move comes 12 years after an attempt during the Carter administration to raise a $20 million preservation fund failed. Over the years money has been raised privately from benefactors to buy furniture, paintings and other items for the executive mansion. Just this week the White House announced installation of a new rug, drapes and other furnishings in the Oval Office at a cost of $62,000. Mrs. Craig has participated in past preservation efforts at the White House, and helped raise about $200,000 for refurbishing of the vice presidential mansion when the Bushes lived there. She also played a role in raising funds for the new Oval Office rug.

DOC.HEAD: Educators Offer Views on Education Goals
DOC.TEXT: Agreement is nearly unanimous that goals should be set on what students should know during their school years, but officials say there are numerous problems in developing standards that cut across the entire nation. Mike Cohen, education director of the National Governors' Association, told a public forum Thursday the governors are frustrated on several issues as they put together national education goals. ``A couple of issues we've been wrestling with (deal) with the conception of national standards,'' said Cohen, explaining the governors haven't decided whether to set fixed standards nationally or set various targets for student performance. Cohen said targets could be set, for example, for top performing students, average students and low-achieving students with the idea of ``moving more people forward.'' Another issue is how to set national goals that will complement statewide and local standards. ``We want to set goals in such a way ... that they give every state and city an opportunity to be successful. How you do that is not entirely clear,'' he said. Recent Gallup polls indicate most Americans want national standards, national tests and a national curriculum. Cohen spoke to the governing board of the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a federal testing program that periodically samples what American children know _ popularly known as the Nation's Report Card. The congressionally mandated board decided in December to establish national tests graded on standards of what children should know by grades four, eight and 12. The grade-level goals will ``represent solid academic performance, not minimum skills,'' the panel agreed. The panel approved a recommendation for single standards for the fourth and eighth grades and that two standards be used for the final year of high school _ one measuring satisfactory performance goals and another for goals tied to college-level courses. Panel Chairman Chester Finn said the board's efforts would complement the president and governors national goals, slated to be approved at the NGA's February meeting. ``These goals by no means span the whole curriculum,'' said Finn. ``They certainly do not prescribe how major subjects should be taught. Indeed, by setting outcome goals rather than detailed procedures for teaching, we wish to encourage the initiative of schools and teachers, of local school boards and state in devising different means to reach common ends.'' Several people, including American Federation of Teachers President Albert Shanker, urged the board to move slowly in setting the goals. ``We're so close ... it would be a damn shame if we don't do it right,'' said Shanker.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant Pleads No Contest in Shootout
DOC.TEXT: A man charged in a shootout that ended a daring helicopter escape from a prison pleaded no contest to attempted murder. Ralph P. Brown, 31, entered the plea Thursday under an agreement reached just 10 days before he was scheduled to stand trial in Adams County District Court. Brown, his wife, and another couple were arrested Aug. 18 after a bullet-punctuated chase through this south-central Nebraska town of 5,600. The shootout came about eight hours after the women swooped into the Arkansas Valley Correctional Facility near Ordway, Colo., in a hijacked helicopter and carried the men away. The four landed and transferred to a rented truck, and were finally caught in Holdrege, about 400 miles from the medium-security prison. Brown was wounded in the hand in the gun battle. In return for Brown's no-contest plea, the prosecution dropped charges of use of a firearm to commit a felony and being a felon in possession of a firearm. Phelps District Court Judge Stephen Illingworth ordered a pre-sentence investigation and scheduled sentencing for Feb. 9. Brown faces several charges in Colorado, including escape. Brown's wife, Rebecca L. Brown, 26, pleaded no contest earlier this month in Phelps County to charges of using a firearm to commit a felony and resisting arrest. She is awaiting sentencing. The other couple, Fedrico Gonzales, 21, and his wife, Patricia Gonzales, 41, reached plea agreements last fall. Gonzales pleaded guilty to being an accessory to a felony and was sentenced to 20 months to five years in prison. Mrs. Gonzales pleaded no contest to being an accessory to a felony and was sentenced to one to three years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say Barry Made Sexual Advances to Woman Before Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry made repeated sexual advances to the woman reported to have helped the FBI lure him into a cocaine trap, law enforcement sources say. Barry, whom the FBI says it videotaped buying and smoking crack cocaine, repeatedly asked Rasheeda Moore to make love during the visit last week to her hotel room that ended in his arrest on a misdemeanor drug possession charge, the sources said Thursday. Barry kissed and touched Rasheeda Moore, but the former model rebuffed his advances, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. FBI agents used a surveillance camera to watch Barry purchase crack cocaine and smoke the illegal drug during the 45-minute visit to Ms. Moore's hotel room on Jan. 18, according to an affidavit filed in the case. Ms. Moore's refusal to have sex with the mayor was in accordance with instructions she received before the undercover sting began, sources said. She also was told to let the mayor suggest any drug use to avoid a defense claim he was entrapped. Ms. Moore was told not to use drugs, the sources said. Barry, who this week checked into a Florida drug rehabilitation clinic after turning over his mayoral duties to the city administrator, conducted city business on the telephone in Ms. Moore's room, said one source. Ms. Moore, a former model who has posed in national magazines, had a longstanding romantic relationship with Barry that included frequent cocaine use, law enforcement sources say. She agreed to cooperate with the FBI's year-long investigation of Barry's alleged drug use following her arrest Jan. 1 in North Hollywood, Calif., on a driving while intoxicated charge. Local police turned her over to the FBI, which had lodged a ``material witness warrant,'' authorities in California said. Ms. Moore's cooperation began after she was confronted with her sworn denials to a federal grand jury last spring of allegations she used drugs with the mayor, sources said. Ms. Moore, 38, has since told investigators about using cocaine with Barry, an account that conflicts with the mayor's sworn denial to a federal grand jury last year of allegations he used illegal drugs, the sources said. Her account corroborates those provided by convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, who has testified that he sold crack cocaine to the mayor and smoked it with him, sources said. Lewis, who had known Ms. Moore only by the initials ``R.C.,'' told investigators she was present when he and the mayor used drugs during a March 1988 weekend in the Virgin Islands, sources said. Lewis identified Ms. Moore in a photograph after he began cooperating with the investigation, one source said. Prosecutors are trying to piece together a perjury case against Barry, according to law enforcement sources. The grand jury has called additional witnesses, including four members of the mayor's around-the-clock security detail, said law enforcement and city government sources. The investigation includes possible obstruction of justice by police assigned to guard the mayor, one source said. A native of the nation's capital, Ms. Moore attended modeling school here. In 1987 and 1988 she was employed as a social worker for the District of Columbia government.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chairman Warns Congress Against Tax Moves on Foreign Investors
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan acknowledges foreigners are not paying the full taxes owed on their U.S. investments but he's cautioning Congress not to tinker with the law. ``It's a tricky tradeoff ... to the extent it would divert to other countries'' foreign money financing both the U.S. government's budget deficit and private investment, Greenspan told the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee on Thursday. Until the United States became dependent on foreign investment in the early 1980s, the government withheld a portion of the taxes owed on interest payments to foreigners on their U.S. bank deposits, Treasury securities and private bonds and notes. Greenspan admitted there is a ``dilemma'' in trying to collect taxes from foreigners without driving their investments elsewhere. However, he nodded agreement when asked by Rep. Jim Moody, D-Wis., if a study was needed to measure the ``sensitivity'' foreign investors would have to various possible withholding rates. That prompted the Bush administration to issue a statement through the Treasury Department saying it opposes any attempt to remove the exemption on withholding taxes for foreign investors. The congressional Joint Commission on Taxation has estimated that just a 5 percent withholding tax on portfolio interest to foreigners would raise $300 million a year in new revenues. ``We're so dependent on the torrential flow from abroad that we can't even consider withholding a third of a billion dollars in duly owed taxes because we're afraid the tax dodgers will roll their money someplace else,'' Moody said. Greenspan said the United States remains heavily dependent on an ``inflow of savings from abroad ... to finance both the gaping budget deficit and growing private investment in the face of a declining private savings rate.'' ``If we did not have that foreign investment, we would be looking toward a significant slowing and perhaps a stagnation of living standards,'' he added. However, he acknowledged the dependence is putting ``substantial upward pressure on U.S. interest rates,'' particularly when rates in other countries rise, as they have in Japan and West Germany in recent days. ``The United States has become more vulnerable to disturbances originating outside its borders,'' Greenspan said. But he said any effort ``to insulate'' the country from what he called an increasing globalization of capital markets ``could be very costly to our standard of living.'' Several members of the committee expressed fears the recent surge in interest rates abroad could trigger a recession or depression. ``What's the flash point that might worry you the most?'' asked Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich. ``I don't even dare answer a question like that,'' the Fed chairman replied. ``We worry about everything.''

DOC.HEAD: Tetanus Drops 95 Percent in Four Decades
DOC.TEXT: U.S. health researchers say the nation's tetanus rate has dropped 20-fold in four decades, to the point where the disease now strikes only about 50 Americans a year. Fifty-three tetanus cases were reported in 1988, five more than in 1987, the Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. The unofficial total for 1989 was 47 cases. The nation's tetanus rate, 39 cases per million people when tetanus records began in 1947, was 2 per million by 1988, the CDC said. The decline in tetanus ``has resulted from the widespread use of tetanus toxoid'' since the mid-1940s, coupled with improved techniques for treating wounds, CDC researchers said. Most cases occur when tetanus bacteria enter the body through an unclean wound. ``In the United States, tetanus is primarily a disease of older adults,'' the CDC said. Detailed information was available on 99 of the 101 cases reported in 1987-88; 67 of those patients were 50 or older. ``Tetanus immunization efforts should be especially emphasized'' for people 50 and over, the CDC said. The CDC said tetanus vaccine is ``highly effective'' if given according to the recommended schedule: three doses in the primary series, usually given to children, and booster shots every 10 years. Five of the 99 patients studied in 1987-88 had received primary tetanus shots. Two had received their latest doses more than five years before they became ill, one had his last dose more than 20 years earlier, and for the other two, it was unknown when their last dose was. Only ``an extremely small number'' of vaccine failures occur, said Dr. Peter Strebel, a CDC immunization specialist. Otherwise, the disease is considered preventable.

DOC.HEAD: Republican to House: Brace for Expulsion Vote if Lukens Loses Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A Republican congressman is warning House members to brace themselves for ``the unenviable task of voting on the expulsion of Barney Frank and Buz Lukens.'' Rep. William Dannemeyer of California said he plans to force an on-the-record expulsion vote if Rep. Donald Lukens, R-Ohio, loses his appeal of a sex-related conviction, and plans to seek an expulsion vote on Frank if the House Ethics Committee recommends lesser action against the Massachusetts Democrat. Frank, an acknowledged homosexual, is being investigated because of allegations he knew about a prostitution business being run from his home and that he engaged in sexual activity in the House gymnasium. ``All members should expect a vote on expulsion of Mr. Frank and Mr. Lukens at any time,'' Dannemeyer said in a letter sent to fellow House members. ``A recorded vote on expulsion, in one form or another, will occur ... Members should be prepared.'' Frank spokesman Doug Cahn said the Dannemeyer letter was ``simply a recast of what he said last fall.'' ``Barney is confident to leave this matter in the hands of the House Ethics Committee,'' he said. William Jarrell, Lukens' chief of staff, said, ``No comment.'' Dannemeyer's press secretary, Paul Mero, provided a copy of the letter on request Thursday but said the congressman did not wish to discuss it. ``We're pretty much just waiting for the (ethics) committee report to come out,'' he said. The 10th Ohio District Court of Appeals is considering the case of Lukens, who was convicted in May of a misdemeanor, contributing to the unruliness of a minor, for having sex with a 16-year-old girl. He has been sentenced to 30 days in jail and a $500 fine, but is free on bond. The girl had charged that Lukens knew she was underage when he paid her to have sex at his Columbus apartment in 1988. Lukens, who did not testify at the trial, denied the allegations, but after his conviction fellow Republican members of Congress and the Ohio Republican Party said he should resign. When he ignored that advice the chairmen of the Republican Party organizations in his district said Lukens would be officially shunned if he showed up at any GOP gathering. At the request of House Republicans, the House Ethics Committee opened an investigation into whether Lukens violated any House rules. The investigation of Frank was triggered by allegations by Steven Gobie, a male prostitute whom Frank admitted paying $80 for sex in 1985. Frank also has admitted hiring Gobie, with personal funds, to work as his housekeeper and driver, but said he fired Gobie when he learned his apartment was being used for the sex-for-hire business. ``The (Ethics) Committee may choose from several options in addressing these members, including not to do anything at all,'' Dannemeyer's letter said. ``After the committee has reported to the House on the case of Mr. Frank, I will offer a resolution of expulsion if the committee recommendation fails to do so. I will do the same if Mr. Lukens' appeal fails.'' In his letter, Dannemeyer didn't specify how he planned to force an on-the-record vote, but listed a few options. ``The vote may come in the form of an appeal of the chair, a motion to table or on the actual question. But the vote will occur,'' he wrote. ``Those who will remember back only a year ago will remember how a motion to adjourn was used as a vote on the pay raise. Anything goes.''

DOC.HEAD: Rostropovich Prepares to Visit Soviet Union After 16-Year Exile
DOC.TEXT: ``Welcome home!'' Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin shouted over a champagne toast, and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich responded with bear hugs and kisses as he prepared to return to his homeland after 16 years of exile in the West. The emotional exchange took place Thursday night at a bon voyage party at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts honoring Rostropovich and members of the National Symphony Orchestra, who leave Monday on a three-week tour of Japan and the Soviet Union. As guests sipped Russian vodka and nibbled on Beluga caviar, Rostropovich said the dismantling of the Berlin Wall was a ``symbol of a new era for our life,'' uniting his old family in the East with his new family in the West. He said his ``greatest joy'' was to ``see one family on this planet.'' Rostropovich and his wife, soprano Galina Vishnevskaya, fled the Soviet Union in 1974 because of government harassment and curbs on their artistic freedom. Soviet authorities announced last week that they had restored the citizenship stripped from Rostropovich and his wife in 1978, the year after he was appointed music director of the National Symphony. Rostropovich said Thursday night, ``I am so excited, I am so emotional'' at the prospect of returning home with music that bridges East and West with the language of friendship. ``Capitalism, communism _ it's all garbage,'' Rostropovich declared. Dubinin, toasting the exiled conductor with champagne, said Rostropovich's four-day concert tour of Moscow and Leningrad with the orchestra in mid-February was ``a sign of new times'' and proof that ``dreams come true.'' The ambassador said the tour ``will be an exceptional manifestation of (Soviet) Chairman (Mikhail S.) Gorbachev's policy of perestroika, the new political thinking and new relations between the Soviet Union and the United States.'' ``Welcome to the Soviet Union,'' he shouted. Turning to Rostropovich, he added: ``Welcome home!'' The two then embraced for a long moment and turned to kiss their wives. Rostropovich said earlier this week that the restoration of his citizenship would not persuade him to abandon his new life in the West and return permanently to the Soviet Union. But one result of the Soviet government's action was to prompt his wife, Galina, to drop her earlier objections and consent to accompany her husband on the tour. The couple's daughter, Olga, who lives in New York, also will make the trip. Orchestra officials disclosed Thursday night that Rostropovich will take about 600,000 disposable medical syringes with him as a gift to the Soviet people, who reportedly are threatened by an AIDS epidemic in Siberia. The officials said the conductor is paying for the syringes, which are in short supply in the Soviet Union, out of his personal concert fees. The purchase was arranged by industrialist Armand Hammer, who donated $100,000 to underwrite the costs of the orchestra's tour. Hammer, 91, said he will be in the audience when Rostropovich conducts the orchestra's first concert on Feb. 13 in the Bolshoi Hall of the Moscow Conservatory. On the program for that concert will be Tchaikovsky's 6th (``Pathetique'') Symphony, the last piece that Rostropovich conducted _ and on the same stage _ before he sought exile in the West.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The stork may visit one of the seven courting California condor couples at the Los Angeles Zoo. Cachuma and Cuyama have produced a 5-inch by 3-inch egg that scientists hope holds the birds' second offspring in captivity. Scientists should know in seven to 10 days whether the egg is fertilized. If it is, the chick would hatch in 55 to 66 days. Fewer than three dozen California condors are known to exist. All are in captivity. After discovering the egg Thursday, zoo officials placed it in an incubator. The egg will be kept at a constant 97.5 degrees and turned every two hours. Pulling the egg from the nest may encourage the condors to produce another egg, officials said. When condors existed in the wild, they usually reared one chick every two years. Four California condor chicks have been hatched at the zoo, including Kaduka, the firstborn to Cachuma and Cuyama.

With the motto ``What God gives, no orthodontist should ever take away'' and a beaver for a mascot, gap-toothed Dale Hempel serves as president of the International Diastema Club. Hempel, principal of Tonasket High School, was superintendent of the Moses Lake School District in 1981 when he and a secretary formed the lighthearted club for themselves and other staffers with diastema, a marked gap between two teeth. The gap-toothed are a vanishing breed, he said. ``We're living in a day when most people have perfect teeth,'' Hempel said, flashing a grin. ``It's a society of perfect people, and we're not.'' The 600-member club's symbol is a red slash through an otherwise perfect set of choppers. To qualify for membership, prospects must certify they have at least a toothpick-wide gap between their front teeth. They cannot wear braces. They also must promise to leave at least some kernels on an ear of corn, never cover the gap and to enter all spitting contests.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Students Upset With Senate's Failure to Override Veto
With PM-Bush-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chinese students said they feared being shipped back to their homeland after the Senate upheld President Bush's veto of a bill protecting them from deportation when their visas expire. ``Many students fear they will be sent back. I'm scared for all my friends,'' said Yuan Liu, 30, a Chinese student enrolled at Brandeis University. ``I think it's a sad day for us,'' said Pei Min Xin, 33, a doctoral student at Harvard University who led the pro-democracy protests in Beijing last spring. ``I'm afraid that the president will continue his policy of accommodating the Chinese dictators.'' Bush said the bill to eliminate that requirement was unnecessary because he has signed an administrative order allowing Chinese students to stay in the United States. The president said the legislation could have damaged U.S. relations with China, which has condemned the action and threatened to curtail exchange programs if it becomes law. The Senate voted 62-37 Thursday to override the presidential veto, four votes short of the two-thirds necessary. The House voted overwhelmingly Wednesday to reject Bush's veto. Xiaxia Gong, 33, a Harvard graduate student, was among several Chinese students gathered at the China Information Center in Newton who said the failed legislation would have given them a sense of security. Many of the students fled to the United States after the Chinese government cracked down on the protests in Tiananmen Square. Under the visa's requirements, bearers must return to China when their visas expire and live there for two years before they can apply for a new one. The students fear that the president's order could be reversed someday, leaving them vulnerable to deportation to their homeland where they might be jailed. ``I don't believe Mr. Bush,'' Gong said. ``How can we believe someone who has already cheated and sent high-level officials to China when he said he would not? We don't want our destiny put in someone else's hands.'' In Salem, Ore., Chinese students at Oregon State University said they couldn't understand the Senate vote. ``It did send a message to China, but it did not stand for human rights,'' Wang De Qian, co-vice president of the university's Chinese student association. Shu Ouang said the student association ``did not want to override the president, but the veto. We want to send a stronger message to the Chinese butchers.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates closing Nikkei, dollar
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed lower against the Japanese yen Friday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange declined moderately. The dollar finished the week at 143.97 yen, down 1.33 yen from Thursday's close of 145.30 yen. It opened at 143.65 yen and ranged between 143.50-144.25 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which posted a 190.13-point gain Thursday, shed 95.04 points, or 0.25 percent, closing the week at 36,874.07. Currency dealers said the dollar's weakness reflected its sharp decline overnight in New York. A report that U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan had expressed ``cautious interest'' in reinstating a withholding tax on foreign investors in the United States helped knock the dollar lower in New York. Such a move would slow foreign investment, which has been an important stimulus for recent U.S. economic growth, analysts say. The report notwithstanding, Greenspan in fact cautioned a Congressional committee Thursday against placing any new impediments on foreign investment. ``The impact of the Fed chairman's reported remark lingered in the market,'' said Masaaki Shikada, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Shikada also attributed the dollar's decline against the yen to local news reports that Japan's long-term prime rate is likely to be raised by 0.7 percentage point to 7.5 percent on Feb. 1. A banking source, who spoke anonymously, said some Japanese long-term banks, including the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, will announce their rate hike later in the day. The prime rate is a preferential rate of interest charged by commercial banks on loans to their most credit-worthy customers. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei index started higher in a favorable reaction to the yen's strength against the dollar and higher bond prices, but later turned weak, securities dealers said. ``After a round of buying orders, the index lost steam'' as many market participants retreated to the sidelines due to uncertainty about the outcome of a major national election here slated for Feb. 18, said a Nomura Securities' analyst who spoke anonymously.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Jetliner Down, 10th Ld Writethru, 1st Add, a0479,0678
DOC.HEAD: COVE NECK: he said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of 2nd take, `The area...,' to add detail on crash site. SUBS grafs 8-9, bgn `A spokeswoman...,' to UPDATE with officials told Avianca has no passenger list, officials interviewing family and friends to get names.
DOC.TEXT: ``I happened to see a plane going very low,'' said another witness, David Johnson. ``At the altitude it was at I really could not hear any engines. So I am assuming the engines had conked out but there really was no fire or anything.'' The crash occurred on a narrow peninsula jutting into Oyster Bay, just south of the Sagamore Hill National Historic Site, home of President Theodore Roosevelt. It is an isolated, wooded area of expensive homes. Nick Fisher, a cameraman for WCBS-TV, said there were ``maybe hundreds'' of rescue workers and volunteers caring for the injured. ``The plane is laying on an incline in a wooded area adjacent to a house,'' Fisher said. The New York City Emergency Medical Service, asked for help by Nassau County police, sent five ambulances and a Mobile Emergency Room Vehicle to the crash scene, an EMS spokesman said. According to Radio Colombiana, Flight 52 left Bogota with a stopover in Medellin, the city known for its notorious cocaine cartel, en route to New York. The control tower at Bogota's El Dorado International Airport said the Avianca airliner left Bogota at 1:30 p.m. EST, arrived at Medellin 2:02 p.m., then left Medellin at 5:30 p.m. and was scheduled to land in New York at 10 p.m. EST. A spokeswoman for Avianca at El Dorado said the company would have no immediate information or statement. Alan Morrison, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said the airline had informed officials that there was no passenger list for the flight. At Kennedy, officials were attempting to compile a list by interviewing families and friends of the passengers. They were taken to first-class lounge room at the Pan American Airways terminal, where the Avianca hangar is located. One anxious relative, John Bedoia, 30, of Queens, said he had gone to the airport to meet his brother, Guillermo Bedoia, 28, and sister-in-law, Magnolia, 26. ``A worker told me the plane was not landing because of the weather,'' he said. ``When I went home I saw the news. I came back to see what's happening but they won't tell me anything.'' ``People are worried and crying and calling their relatives,'' said Leonora Valencia, 28, of Queens, who had gone with her son to meet her cousin, Maria Maraugenin, 41. Boeing officials in Seattle said the Avianca plane was 23 years old, having been first delivered to Pan Am in January 1967 and transferred to Avianca in February 1977. Avianca owns two 707s, they said. According to Jane's All The World's Aircraft, Boeing produced the 707 model jetliner for commercial use from 1955 until 1982. Last Nov. 27, an Avianca Boeing 727 was bombed out of the sky minutes after takeoff from Bogota on a domestic flight to Cali. The explosion killed all 107 people on board. The Extraditables group, made up of drug traffickers fearing extradition to the United States, claimed responsibility for the bombing in a phone call to the Colombian radio network Caracol. Matt Murphy, the duty agent at the federal Drug Enforcement Administration office in New York, said the DEA did not know of any threats to the plane and had not received any general threats against Colombian airliners recently. ``I don't see it as being any drug cartels involved at this time,'' he said. ``If we find out later you never know, but at this time there's no indication of that.'' Murphy also noted that the plane was close to its destination when it crashed, which he said was an indication that sabotage was not involved. In Washington, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board, Ted Lopatkiewicz, said the agency would ``be sending a full team'' to investigate.

DOC.HEAD: Kim's The Biggest Landowner, But Not The Boss
DOC.TEXT: Although actress Kim Basinger now owns a big chunk of the town of Braselton, she still needs government approval before building a planned movie and recording studio complex. The star of ``Batman'' closed a $20 million deal Wednesday to buy about one-third of this northeast Georgia town of 500 from the Braselton family, descendants of the town's founders. But like any other developer, Miss Basinger will have to present her plans to the mayor and city council. ``She'll be considered just like any resident,'' saidHenry Edward Braselton, the town's mayor. ``We'll get the county building inspector to look at (her plans). He'll make recommendations to the council, and we'll either accept it or reject it. ``Anything good, we're not going to turn down,'' he said. ``I expect she could convince you of most anything. She's a beautiful girl. I think I'd have to vote for her if she ran against me.''

DOC.HEAD: Anxious Relatives and Friends Fear Worst in Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `At Kennedy...,' to UPDATE with reports of as many as 50 dead, scores injured.
DOC.HEAD: With Jetliner Down
DOC.TEXT: Anxious friends and relatives fretted over scant news at Kennedy International Airport while rescue workers struggled on Long Island's heavily wooded north shore to find survivors of Avianca Flight 52. Local television showed pictures of dazed survivors being pulled from the wreckage, some bloodied. Some people appeared to be trapped in the twisted metal and some lay motionless. Others, including several children, were carried away crying by rescuers. Amanda Pinzon, 27, of Elizabeth, N.J., who was waiting at Kennedy with relatives who had come to meet the plane, cried with joy when she saw her husband, Jesus, and 2-year-old son, Brian, on television, among the survivors being taken to hospitals. ``I feel great, I'm so happy _ happy, crying, everything,'' she said. Her 13-year-old niece, Jo Ellen Pena, said her uncle and cousin were bandaged and bloody but seemed to be OK. Dr. Bruce Rebold, who lives in the affluent, sparsely populated area near the crash site, said he was reading the newspaper and a movie script when a picture fell off the wall and some pottery fell down. He didn't hear anything but he felt the impact of what he later found out was the crash. He looked out his window and did not see anything and ran out to the site. Rebold said he saw a portion of the fuselage with the red lettering ``Avianca.'' ``It looked like it hit a hill and cracked in half. I saw people trying to scramble out of the plane. I didn't see any bodies,'' he said. ``It was shocking. It was like being on a movie set.'' At Kennedy Airport, about 200 anxious relatives and friends waited in the first class lounge of Pan American World Airways, but complained that they received very little information from the remote site. Late reports had possibly as many as 50 dead and scores more injured. Mark Marchese, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said, ``They know it's a crash but it's a very eerie calm, very little hysteria.'' He said priests and rabbis were offering emotional support to those waiting. Others, however, sought comfort in finding out as much information as they could. Several of the relatives wandered over to a bank of pay-for-view miniature television sets in the airport and watched for the latest information. Among those waiting for word of survivors was Jairo Perez, who said he saw his sister, Elena, on television. He said Elena had gone to Colombia to adopt a girl. He said the child also survived. In tears, he said in Spanish: ``They're alive.'' The Boeing 707 crashed at about 9:45 p.m. near Oyster Bay Harbor in an affluent area just south of the Sagamore Hill National Historic Site, home of President Theodore Roosevelt. It is a isolated, wooded area of expensive homes on two-acre lots whose residents include the parents of tennis pro John McEnroe. Rescue efforts were hindered by the narrow road that leads to the crash site. The road was clogged with rescue vehicle and many of the rescue crews had to park far away from the crash site and carry equipment to the injured passengers.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Suspends Stock Trading of Generic Drug Maker
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended for 10 days trading in the securities of Bolar Pharmaceutical Co., the generic drug maker accused of falsifying safety claims. The SEC said it temporarily suspended Bolar trading Thursday due to ``the lack of adequate current information concerning the recent public disclosure that certain false documents were submitted to the Food and Drug Administration.'' On Tuesday, a House subcommittee disclosed a letter from Bolar's attorneys that indicated the Copaigue, N.Y.-based generic drug maker apparently falsified documents about safety tests for its version of the popular blood pressure-controlling drug Dyazide, made by SmithKline Beecham. The SEC said suspension began at 9:30 a.m. Thursday and would continue until 11:59 p.m. on Feb. 3. ``The SEC made their decision to suspend trading because the company did not disclose enough information, and when we can, we will,'' said Bolar spokeswoman Patricia Shukri, refusing to comment further. Bolar's anti-hypertension drug is the only generic version of Dyazide on the market. Another company pulled its version after it admitted cheating on tests required for FDA approval.
DOC.HEAD: FDA Warns About Dangers of L-tryptophan Supplement
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is cautioning consumers against buying potentially dangerous L-tryptophan dietary supplements distributed nationally by a California company. The company _ NutriCology Inc. of San Leandro, Calif., which also markets under the name of Allergy Research Group _ has not complied with an urgent FDA recall request, the agency said Thursday. A woman answering the company's telephone refused to relay repeated calls to a company official or supervisor. The FDA said 334 other manufacturers, repackers and distributors have complied with the Nov. 17 request for recall of products that would result in a total dietary intake of 100 milligrams or more of L-tryptophan a day. The FDA requested the recall because L-tryptophan, an amino acid, has been linked to eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, which is marked by severe muscle and joint pain, swelling of the arms and legs, skin rash and sometimes fever. The Centers for Disease Control has reports of 1,143 cases of the syndrome, including nine deaths _ one of which has been confirmed to have been ``clearly associated'' with L-tryptophan. Public health experts have not been able to identify a specific lot, brand, manufacturer or supplier of the supplement as the cause of the outbreak. They also have been unable to pinpoint a specific chemical or microbial contaminant that could be responsible, the FDA said.
DOC.HEAD: Researchers Find Compound Effective Against AIDS In Test Tube
DOC.TEXT: Researchers say a synthetic compound has been shown in laboratory experiments to prevent reproduction of the AIDS virus in a way different than AZT, the only anti-viral drug now approved for use against AIDS. The compound, a manmade peptide called U-81749, appears to block the final stage of a process the AIDS virus uses to reproduce itself in human cells. AZT, or zidovudine, attacks an earlier stage in the life cycle of the virus. ``It (U-81749) drastically slows down and reduces the number of mature viral particles you get in an infection,'' Leonard Post, director of infectious disease research at the Upjohn Co., where the compound was developed, said Thursday. The compound works by inhibiting the action of protease, an enzyme used by the AIDS virus to process proteins during the final stages of its reproduction, Post said. The result is that the virus cannot make mature copies of itself, and this prevents the spread of infection to other cells, he said. Post emphasized that the compound has been used only in test tubes on cultured cells and that it will be years before such a compound will be ready for human tests. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. When this virus invades a human cell, it takes over the cell's protein-making machinery to reproduce itself. During this process, the virus directs the creation of a number of different proteins. Protease is an enzyme the virus uses to chop up a large protein molecule, called p55, into several different types of smaller protein molecules needed to make a mature HIV particle. Post said that by blocking the action of protease, the p55 molecule is not processed and the viral particle does not mature.
DOC.HEAD: Texas Congressmen Question Bush's Commitment to Supercollider
DOC.TEXT: Texas congressmen are questioning President Bush's commitment to the super collider now that he has requested $318 million instead of the expected $393 million for second-year construction funds. Bush's budget, to be unveiled Monday, will ask for $75 million less than what had been anticipated for the giant particle accelerator being built in Ellis County, Texas, Sen. Phil Gramm said Thursday. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said he had hoped for a higher starting point, ``since I have no doubt, with our budget deficit situation, that Congress will whittle away at it. ``Only a few days ago, a White House spokesman was warning that Congress might make cuts in the president's budget for the SSC (supercollider). What he didn't warn us was that we'd see substantial cuts before Congress even gets its turn,'' Bentsen said. Bush last year requested $250 million for the SSC; Congress allocated $225 million. Rep. Jim Chapman, D-Texas, said the new request ``certainly shows less than the full commitment of the administration to the project.'' Gramm, R-Texas, said he was assured by Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore that the $318 million represents as much as the DOE believes it could actually spend in 1991 on the collider. The collider would be in far greater danger in Congress from the ``sticker shock'' of a higher price tag should the Energy Department recommend the cost exceed $5.9 billion, Gramm said. He said Moore told him the lower figure would not have any impact on the project, which if completed would be the largest, most complicated scientific instrument ever built. Scientists hope to use it to test theories about the building blocks of the universe.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with official saying dead number in `high 50s,' UPDATE with quotes from doctor at scene, DELETE outdated material. SUBS 17th graf pvs, `The plane...,' to restore first reference to Bergen. Picks up 18th graf of 1st take, `Control tower...' ^Colombian Airliner Crashes Near Kennedy; About 50 Dead
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MLV1, MLV2, NY68; LaserColor MLV3; LaserGraphics NY69, NY18
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian Boeing 707 with more than 140 people aboard crashed in fog and rain Thursday night while on approach to Kennedy International Airport, killing about 50 people and injuring scores more, authorities said. Avianca Flight 52, en route from Bogota, crashed at about 9:45 p.m. in this isolated, exclusive hamlet on the north shore of Long Island, Kennedy airport officials said. The jetliner had reported losing power in one or two engines and was on its second approach to Kennedy when it crashed, breaking into several pieces, officials said. Witnesses said there was no fire or explosion. ``There were just dead bodies all over the place. ... It was the worst thing you ever saw,'' an unidentified young man who arrived at the scene told WNBC-TV. ``Kids were screaming for their parents. Parents were screaming for their kids,'' said Robert LaBella, a Long Island resident wh helped remove six people from the wreckage. After that, ``I just couldn't take it anymore.'' Early Friday morning, Dr. George Dunn of Glen Cove Community Hospital, who was on the scene, said rescuers had counted 40 to 50 dead. But Chuck DeGaetano of the New York City Emergency Medical Service said those killed numbered in the ``high 50s.'' By early Friday, 92 people had been transported from the scene to hospitals, said Sgt. James Callahan of Nassau County Police Emergency Medical Bureau. WCBS radio said that of those 92, one died en route and one died at a hospital. Callahan said there were no other living survivors at the scene. ``There's a lot of confusion going on,'' EMS spokeswoman Lynn Schulman said. ``Our medical director is at the scene. ... It's very dark. It's a wooded area.'' Dunn, asked about the number of survivors, said, ``It's amazing. And many of the injuries were not all that major.'' One of the reasons for the high survival rate was that the aircraft didn't burn, he said. Some of the injured were in critical condition with multiple fractures and shock, hospital officials said. Of the injured, at least nine were children. Many ambulances and helicopters were at the scene, where bloodied victims were lined up on stretchers. Some passengers were seen lying motionless. Others, including children, were dazed but conscious and apparently not seriously hurt as they were helped from the wreckage. ``There were some people trying to get out through the windows,'' said a nearby resident, Dr. Bruce Rebold. Eyewitnesses said that many of those who survived the crash spoke only Spanish. Kennedy's control tower lost contact with Flight 52 at 9:34 p.m. when the 23-year-old Boeing 707 was about 15 miles northeast of the airport after a five-hour flight, said Port Authority Police Officer Phil Montouri. Montouri said ``there was no radio communication at all to the tower. It just went down.'' The plane had missed one approach to Kennedy and gone around a second time, according to Kathleen Bergen, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. CNN reported that the plane ran out of fuel before it crashed. Control tower officials said the plane may have lost power in one of its four engines. Bergen said the agency had reports the plane lost a second engine as well. A ham operator monitoring an aircraft scanner at his home in the Bronx reported hearing a brief radio message from a crew member calling for help just before Flight 52 disappeared from radar screens, The New York Times reported. ``Avianca 052. We have just lost two engines. Dumping fuel. Requesting emergency assistance,'' the message said, according to ham operator Anthony Rosati. The jet broke into four pieces upon impact, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Jeff Crawley. There was less than half a mile of visibility and it was raining at the time of the crash, according to the National Weather Service. Steve Ulman, a Cove Neck resident, said the plane narrowly missed a house and crashed three houses away from one owned by tennis star John McEnroe. The airliner went down in the town of Cove Neck, located at about the same place where the tower lost contact, said Officer Peter Franzone of the Nassau County police. The plane carried 142 passengers and a crew of seven, authorities said. Caracol Radio in Colombia, however, reported there were 151 people aboard, but did not differentiate between passengers and crew. Crawley said several cutters and boats were en route to the area just in ase some debris or victims were in Oyster Bay Harbor, next to the crash site. Peter Whitelaw, who lives down a hill from the crash site, said he could see a small portion of the downed plane through the trees. He said there were few homes in the area. ``I heard a rumbling, a very loud rumbling,'' said Whitelaw, who was on an indoor tennis court at the time. ``It sounded as if your car was gearing back and you were stripping the gears, and the typical rumble you get from a jet plane going over.'' ``Normally in bad weather they circle out here but this was louder than normal. Then we heard the crash,'' he said, adding that through the woods ``I see no flames or smoke, or smell anything.'' He said the road leading to the crash site was clogged with emergency vehicles. ``These are very narrow roads,'' Whitelaw said. ``They're trying the best they can to get to where it crashed. They're running up the road with stretchers and medical equipment.'' Most phone lines were down and power was cut off, he said.
DOC.HEAD: Picks up 1st graf of 10th Ld-Writethru, 1st Add, a0484
US Navy Ships Rescue 14 Chinese Seamen, Recover Four Dead at Sea
DOC.TEXT: Four U.S. Navy ships rescued 14 Chinese seamen and recovered four bodies from a merchant ship that sank off Luzon island, a U.S. Navy spokesman said today. A fifth body was caught in the wreck, and the last of the 20 crewmembers was missing, the spokesman said. Lt. Joseph Gradisher, spokesman for the U.S. Navy's 7th Fleet, said the Chinese vessel Huazhu sank before noon Thursday about 40 miles off the north coast of Luzon. He said the survivors and the dead were picked up after more than three hours of searching aided by U.S. Navy helicopters. Gradisher said the USS Lake Champlain, the USS Stein, the USS Lockwood and the USNS Navasota were sailing in the area when they heard a distress call from the Chinese ship. He said the ship was en route from Malaysia to Japan when it began taking on water. The survivors and the dead were brought to the U.S.-run Subic Bay naval base, 50 miles west of Manila, by the USS Champlain early today, Gradisher said. He said two survivors were in serious condition, while the rest were treated for slight injuries. The survivors will be turned over to representatives of the Chinese Embassy in Manila, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Agent Alleges FBI Coverup In Miller Spy Case
DOC.TEXT: The key witness against Richard Miller, the only FBI agent convicted of spying, alleged that the agency may have covered up information that would have helped Miller's defense, court papers show. Retired FBI Agent John Hunt also said in documents filed Thursday that the agency knew Miller wasn't the only FBI agent sexually involved with Soviet informant Svetlana Ogorodnikov. Miller, a 20-year FBI veteran, was convicted of passing classified documents to Mrs. Ogorodnikov, with whom he was having an affair. His conviction was overturned by a federal appeals court last year based on the admission of lie-detector evidence at his trial. He is free on bail awaiting his third trial, expected to begin come spring. Hunt's allegations, in a letter to FBI Director William Sessions last summer, were among volumes of documents filed by Miller's lawyers Thursday as part of a motion to dismiss the charges against Miller. Hunt was a key witness in the 1985 and 1986 trials. Miller's first jury deadlocked; the second convicted him. In his 10-page letter, Hunt alleged the bureau covered up ``in order to divert public and congressional attention away from the FBI's own administrative mishandling of Miller prior to his arrest.'' At his trials, Miller was portrayed as an overweight, inept FBI misfit who turned to spying out of vengeance. But he maintained he was trying to redeem a lackluster career by recruiting Mrs. Ogorodnikov as a double agent and infiltrating the Soviet spy network. The letter was recently obtained by the defense lawyers who subpoenaed it over government opposition. The Hunt letter requested a meeting between Hunt and Sessions, but a response showed that Sessions refused because of ``pending litigation.'' In a letter to Sessions, Hunt's lawyer, Lynn Lincoln Sarko, said: ``Mr. Hunt believes that the FBI may have engaged in a cover-up of this affair by concealing certain information and by failing to follow up leads in the espionage case ... and by knowingly falsifying the results of its own investigations.'' Sarko's letter and other documents suggested that another FBI agent assigned to the Foreign Counterintelligence Squad with Miller had a sexual affair with Mrs. Ogorodnikov. The agent's name was blacked out of classified documents attached to the motion. Hunt has denied defense claims that he had an affair with Mrs. Ogorodnikov. Hunt's lawyer raised the question of whether FBI mishandling of the case ``may have deprived Miller and Ogorodnikov of their most logical and powerful defense to the charges against them.'' Defense attorneys Stanley Greenberg and Joel Levine alleged that Miller was the victim of prosecutorial misconduct in a cover-up of evidence helpful to the former agent's defense. ``Defendant Miller has always insisted that his objective in the relationship with Svetlana was to benefit the FBI,'' said the defense motion. ``The fact that other agents on the very same squad may have had (a) similar relationship with her and (similar) objectives certainly bears on the reasonableness of conduct.'' Messages were left Thursday for Assistant U.S. Attorney Russell Hayman and Sessions, but they did not return calls. A hearing on the motion was set for March 26.

DOC.HEAD: `In the Blood': A Movie in Defense of Hunting
DOC.TEXT: Is it a contradiction to love animals and still shoot them dead? A new movie says no, and depicts hunters as naturalists. Likely to become one of the year's more divisive films, ``In the Blood'' is a feature-length documentary arguing that big-game hunting plays an integral role in conservation. Written and directed by George Butler, a hunter from age 6, ``In the Blood'' takes the position that ``one does not hunt in order to kill.'' It shows hunting as a bonding rite and a fundamental privilege. The movie, opening Feb. 16 in Houston, was shown Thursday in the documentary competition of the Sundance United States Film Festival. ``I had a tremendously difficult time making this movie,'' Butler said. ``The prejudice against hunting is so powerful in the film industry.'' Butler released his ``Pumping Iron'' bodybuilding films independently because Hollywood frowned upon that topic, too. ``I make films about unfashionable subjects,'' Butler said. Five years in the making, ``In the Blood'' was backed by 20 investors, including the hunting-wetland preservation group Ducks Unlimited. In a creative fund-raising move, President Theodore Roosevelt's Holland & Holland rifle was purchased and resold by the production company to help make ends meet. Among the more noteworthy organizations not sponsoring the film: the National Rifle Association. ``I'm sure that I could have gotten all the money I needed from the NRA,'' Butler said. ``But I have no association with them. ... They're a gun lobby, not a hunting lobby.'' Indeed, Butler said he has tried not to arouse undue controversy. He prefers to let the film speak for itself. Wherever the movie has been shown, a few people have walked out, Butler said. Although the film does not glorify hunting _ it shows a young hunter's errant shot causing a buffalo to die a slow death _ it does state: ``No animal in Africa dies of old age.'' If a bullet doesn't kill an older lion, something else will. The film's premise is that hunting, when well-conceived and well-executed, improves the cycle of life. In remarks after the film's showing, Robin Hurt, a veteran hunting guide who appears in the movie, said: ``We have interfered so much in the balance of nature (in the past) that we need to keep interfering to balance the scales.''

DOC.HEAD: Australia Launches Its First War Crimes Prosecution
DOC.TEXT: The Australian government today opened its first prosecution of a suspected Nazi war criminal, accusing a 73-year-old pensioner of complicity in the deaths of at least 850 Jews in World War II. Ivan Timofeyevich Polyukhovich was charged in Adelaide's Magistrate's Court with murder in connection with 24 deaths and complicity in hundreds of other deaths between 1939 and 1945. Polyukhovich, standing quietly, entered no plea. He was released on $160,000 bail and ordered to report to police three times a week pending a March 2 appearance to set a trial date. Prosecutors refused to divulge any information about the case, including details of the charges, the man's former nationality, the year he arrived in Australia or other history. ``He's entitled to a fair trial,'' said the prosecutors' spokeswoman, Leone Kennedy. The Adelaide Advertiser newspaper said Polyukhovich settled in Australia at age 41 and worked as a forest warden. It said that in 1986 several hundred people in the Rovno district of the Ukraine had demanded his extradition. It cited a Soviet news agency report. Two years ago, Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke ordered the establishment of a Special Investigations Unit to investigate whether any former Nazis were living in Australia. His action followed a report by the government-funded Australian Broadcasting Corp. that hundreds of Nazis had taken refuge in Australia. Bob Greenwood, head of the team prosecuting Polyukhovich, had said about 450 people were under investigation and some were suspected of atrocities. Although the charges were not read in public today, court documents allege that Polyukhovich killed five men, 12 women, three girls and four boys, including a 1-year-old. The documents obtained by The Associated Press also allege that Polyukhovich was ``knowingly concerned'' with the deaths of 850 Jews from the Serniki ghetto in Rovno District, Ukraine, between August 1941 and May 1943. The documents did not elaborate. A total of nine charges were brought under Section Nine of the War Crimes Act of 1945. The names of some of the victims were given in court documents, but the identities of many of them were unknown. Magistrate Grantley Harris suppressed the home address of Polyukhovich, who also had reportedly used the names Ivan Ivanechko, Jan Jan Poluchowicz and John Poluchowicz. He was ordered to surrender any passports, to stay in the country and make no contact with prosecution witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Rebels Claim Gains
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels claimed today they killed more than 3,900 government soldiers, wounded more than 5,200 and downed three aircraft in renewed fighting in a northwestern province. The rebels' clandestine radio, ``Voice of the Tigre Revolution,'' said the three-day battle in Gondor Province ended Wednesday near Debre Tabor, a major garrison that the rebels claimed to capture in mid-December. It was not clear whether government forces were trying to reclaim the garrison, but the rebel radio said the army had sent in four divisions and numerous aircraft. The government has said nothing about new fighting in Gondor, and the rebel claim could not be independently confirmed. Reporters have been barred from the region. The clandestine station is the voice of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, a combined force of the Tigre People's Liberation Front and the Ethiopia People's Liberation Movement, a much smaller group. The rebels said they killed 3,912 soldiers, wounded 5,210 and captured 270, ans also downed two Soviet-built MiG fighter planes and a helicopter. They gave no details. Earlier this week, the rebels claimed to have killed or wounded more than 8,000 government soldiers so far this month in Wollo Province, south of Gondor. That claim also could not be confirmed. The Tigrean rebels have been fighting since 1974 to overthrow the Marxist government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. They say they want a government patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Communist state in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Appeal Will Last at Least a Year; Officer's Career Over
DOC.TEXT: A police officer facing a 7-year sentence for manslaughter in the deaths of two black men will be spared any prison time for at least a year while his appeal and a novel legal issue are considered, attorneys say. But the police career of William Lozano, 30, is over because of the felony conviction, his attorney said. His fatal shooting of a speeding motorcyclist and the passenger's death triggered three nights of rioting a year ago. Lozano, who was on the police force four years, faces firing, most likely at a departmental disciplinary review board hearing in May, department spokesman Raymond Lang said Thursday. Lozano also stands to lose his state certification as a police officer. ``His job as a police officer is finished,'' defense attorney Roy Black said. ``He's going out to look for a job.'' Black said Lozano would not comment. On Wednesday, the jury that convicted Lozano sentenced him to seven years in prison, but let him remain free on bond while his lawyers appeal. Black expects the case to continue for at least a year _ the usual time frame for a case before the 3rd District Court of Appeals in Miami. Richard Shiffrin, a Dade County prosecutor who will supervise the state's appeal, suspects it could go much longer. ``If we prevail, I'm sure the defense will take it further. If we lost on an issue that was reviewable by the Florida Supreme Court or the U.S. Supreme Court, we would certainly pursue our avenues also. I would expect this case to be around for a while,'' he said. ``There are a number of issues that are litigable. All he has to do is win one'' to overturn the conviction or strike down the sentence, Shiffrin said. ``We have to win them all.'' The least-explored legal question is the decision by Dade Circuit Judge Joseph Farina to seat a black juror after the defense tried to oust him with a peremptory challenge _ normally an uncontestable way of removing unwanted jurors. Postal union executive Ezra Simmons was seated on the judge's order and went on to become the jury foreman. A few other states accept the forced seating of a juror when race is the only factor for removal, but the current Florida standard is to throw out the jury pool and start all over again, Shiffrin noted. ``We'd be there all year if we were forced to strike the panel, so the judge did the only possible thing,'' he said. The U.S. Supreme Court hasn't considered the issue of forced seating.
