Among other issues raised by the defense are: the judge's failure to move the trial out of Miami after the rioting; his refusal to hear witnesses on the change-of-venue issue; the introduction of police regulations as evidence on the use of deadly force by an officer; and the exclusion of evidence about the backgrounds of the two dead men.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Missing With 19 Aboard
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine airplane with 19 people on board disappeared in strong winds on a flight between Indonesian islands, an official said today. The airport on Lombok island lost contact without warning with the British-made Hawker Siddley-748 Thursday over Lombok Strait, 750 miles southeast of Jakarta, according to Salam Susanto of the Communications Ministry. The turboprop plane is owned by P.T. Airfast, an Indonesian company. The flight began in the city of Uujungpandang on south Sulawesi island. It was headed for Lombok, about 500 miles to the southwest, Susanto said. He said two helicopters had been sent to search for the missing plane. He speculated the plane might have struggled with strong winds in the area at the time it disappeared.

DOC.HEAD: Eye Doctors Confront AIDS-Related Blindness
DOC.TEXT: Eye doctors, traditionally immune from much of the despair their colleagues in the medical profession face, increasingly are being confronted with the cruel realities of AIDS patients going blind before death. At a conference Thursday on vision impairment among AIDS patients, ophthalmologists and medical and social workers were cautioned they not only must steep themselves in the latest medical treatments, but learn to deal with the distinct emotional crises of people with the immune-destroying disease. ``You have the double challenge of not just making (medical) theory alive, you are bringing hope alive,'' the Rev. William Barcus told the group. Barcus, who has had AIDS for five years, slowly is losing his sight. ``There are two things we live in deadly fear of: the first is blindness ... the second great terror is dementia. While these may be theory to you, to us they are terribly real, nerve-shattering, heartbreaking,'' the Episcopal minister said. There are no precise figures on how many people with AIDS suffer from some sort of vision-related problems, but various medical studies range in estimates from 10 percent to 40 percent. As of Nov. 30, there have been 115,158 cases of AIDS reported in the United States. As well as despair, ophthalmologists also must deal with self-pity, panic and even terror in AIDS patients. Psychologist Marsha Young, who works with visually impaired AIDS patients in Oakland, described their loss or impairment of sight as often mentally devastating. It sometimes leads to contemplation of suicide. ``It is normal for a person to mourn the loss of sight, but ... for a person with AIDS to start to mourn is sometimes a way of giving up, and it's accompanied by all the feelings that go along with that frustration, hopelessness, powerlessness,'' she said. Until the last few years of the AIDS epidemic few eye doctors had to face the death of their patients, Dr. William Shekter, chief of the Department of Ophthalmology at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Francisco, told the conference. Not since the end of World War II, when thousands of U.S. soldiers returned home with vision-related injuries, has the ophthalmology industry faced such a dramatic change in clientele, he said. Besides finding previously unseen eye diseases in young adults with AIDS, ophthalmologists are ``learning how tenaciously and ferociously a healthy young person with AIDS will fight to retain vision,'' Shekter said. Vision problems associated with AIDS, which destroys the body's ability to fight even common infections, were first documented in 1985. More vision problems are being treated in AIDS patients because earlier diagnosis and improved treatment has prolonged their lives, according to officials of the conference, sponsored by the American Foundation for the Blind and The Lighthouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired. Vision problems appear to be associated with later stages of AIDS. Professionals at the conference were cautioned that few agencies now providing traditional services to the blind and visually impaired are prepared to offer rehabilitative and counseling assistance that may be needed for many of the estimated 1 million to 1.5 million Americans already infected with the AIDS virus.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Socks Northwest, Great Lakes, and More to Come
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf, `On Thursday ...', to ADD power outages, airport and road closings; pickup 8th graf pvs, `In severe ...'
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: A major snowstorm moved toward Canada today after socking the mountains of the Northwest and the central Great Lakes states with as much as 17 inches of snow, knocking out power lines and crippling air and road traffic. ``It was real close to a blizzard,'' National Weather Service meteorologist John Haase said. Accumulations would continue today, he said. More snow and winds were forecast through the weekend as a cold front churns from the Rockies to the Appalachians. Arctic air was expected to follow the front southward into the upper Plains. The Southwest, however, looked today for above-normal temperatures, mostly sunny skies and an end to the dense fog that has lingered in the valleys all week. Westerly winds preceding the cold front were predicted to lash the eastern Rockies _ at an average of more than 40 mph _ from southeastern Montana to central Colorado. Gusts near 100 mph were possible. Gale-force wind warnings were posted for much of the Great Lakes and from the central New England coast to the Virginia coast. On Thursday, high winds ripped roofs off buildings in Michigan and lightning injured 12 people in Illinois. Electricity was interrupted to at least 138,000 customers in Wisconsin, Michigan and Illinois; airports in Milwaukee, St. Louis, Detroit closed and Chicago airports canceled at least 50 percent of their flights; and several highways were closed in Illinois, while scores of minor accidents were reported throughout the region. In severe weather elsewhere, a tornado tore through a trailer park in Centenary in south-central Alabama, injuring 28 people and causing an estimated $2 million in damage. In the Washington Cascades, 17 inches of snow fell at Stevens Pass on Thursday, half of it in 4 hours during the afternoon. Snowfall in Illinois ranged from 6 inches near Moline to 12 inches in Chicago's northern suburbs. Snowfall in northern Michigan included 8 inches at Sault Ste. Marie, 10 inches at Pellston and about 11 inches at Traverse City. The northeastern mountains of Washington state and Oregon's coastal range and Siskiyous were advised to expect more snow today. Winter storm warnings were posted over the Washington Cascades and Olympics and for Wyoming's northwestern mountains. Snow advisories were in effect today for the Lake Tahoe-Truckee area, northeastern California and parts of the Sierra Nevada. Winter storm watches remained over Wyoming's southwestern and central mountains today and in Colorado's northern and central mountains through Saturday. Winds gusting to 50 mph in downtown Indianapolis on Thursday blew out windows from the 21st and 36th floors of the INB National Bank Tower, injuring a 54-year-old woman who received a cut from falling glass. The storm lashed southeast Iowa with 45 mph winds that whipped 5 inches of snow into a treacherous near-whiteout on roads slick with ice. Winds gusted to about 70 mph at Beaver City, Pa., Laramie, Wyo., and Livingston, Mont. Gusts of 91 mph were recorded at Peru, Ind. Thursday was unseasonably warm for much of Florida. Record highs were set in Jacksonville, with 83 degrees; West Palm Beach with 84 and Orlando's 85. High temperature for the Lower 48 states Thursday was 87 at Melbourne, Fla.; the low was minus 10 at Gunnison, Colo. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST today: _EAST: Albany, N.Y., 47 rain; Atlanta 35 fair; Boston 57 cloudy; Buffalo 32; Charleston, S.C., 48 rain; Chattanooga 35 fair; Cincinnati 29 cloudy; Cleveland 30 snow; Detroit 30 windy; Hatteras 68 windy; Jacksonville 50 cloudy; Key West 72 partly cloudy; Knoxville 35 cloudy; Macon 42 fair; Miami 71 fair; New York 46 foggy; Philadelphia 50 showers; Pittsburgh 30 snow; Portland, Maine, 35 foggy; Richmond 54 rain; Tampa 58. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 33 fair; Bismarck 30 cloudy; Chicago 19 fair; Denver 35 partly cloudy; Des Moines 19 fair; Fort Worth 37; Indianapolis 26 cloudy; Kansas City 27 fair; Little Rock 32 fair; Louisville 33 partly cloudy; Memphis 34 fair; Nashville 30 fair; New Orleans 41 fair; North Platte 22 fair; Oklahoma City 32 fair; Omaha 26 fair; Rapid City 42 partly cloudy; St. Louis 32 partly cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 14 fair; Sault Ste. Marie 24 snow. _WEST: Albuquerque 23 fair; Anchorage -6 fair; Boise 44 cloudy; Casper 32 windy; Fairbanks -28 fair; Great Falls 39 windy; Honolulu 74 cloudy; Las Vegas 37 fair; Los Angeles 59 fair; Medford 39 showers; Pendleton 36 showers; Phoenix 49 fair; Portland, Ore., 37 cloudy; Reno 46 fair; Salt Lake City 39 cloudy; San Diego 59 fair; San Francisco 49 partly cloudy; Seattle 37 cloudy; Spokane 34 cloudy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 28 windy; Montreal 41 cloudy; Ottawa 37 windy; Regina 32 windy; Toronto 34 snow; Winnipeg 18 snow; Mexico City 43; San Juan 74.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Drop
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed lower against the Japanese yen today after an overnight fall in New York, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost moderately. After opening at 143.65 yen, the dollar ranged between 143.50 yen and 144.25 yen before closing the week at 143.97 yen, down 1.33 yen from Thursday's close of 145.30 yen. ``The dollar was traded in a relatively narrow range,'' following its slide to 143.925 yen from 145.71 in New York Thursday, said Akihiko Hori, a dealer with Mitsui Bank Ltd. He said he believed the sharp plunge of the dollar was a temporary move in response to U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's call Thursday for a withholding tax on foreign investors in the United States. Such a move would slow foreign investment, which has been an important stimulus for recent U.S. economic growth, analysts say. Other traders attriuted the dollar's decline to local reports that Japan's long-term prime rate would be raised by 0.7 percentage point to 7.5 percent, starting on Feb. 1. A banking source, who spoke anonymously, confirmed the reports in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a major economic newspaper, and the mass-circulation Yomiuri Shimbun. He said, however, that some Japanese long-term banks will unofficially announce their rate hikes earlier. The prime rate is a preferential rate of interest charged by commercial banks on loans to their most credit-worthy customers. ``The planned raise in the prime rate was already factored into foreign exchange trading,'' Hori said. But he said the measure will work as a ``stabilizing factor'' in yen-dollar trading. Higher interest rates tend to push up a country's currency. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which rose 190.13 points Thursday, shed 95.04 points, or 0.25 percent, closing the week at 36,874.07. The index gained 20.49 points shortly after the market's opening. ``It played a tug of war the whole day and the Tokyo market proved to be strong,'' said an analyst with Daiwa Securities Co., who spoke anonymously. He said fluctuations in the Nikkei index under 100 points would be too small to judge the market's direction. The index started higher, encouraged by the yen's strength against the dollar, even though the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged 43.46-points in New York overnight, he said. But the market gradually lost steam as traders showed increasing concern over the amount of Dow Jones slide.

DOC.HEAD: Five ``Frontline'' Programs Receive Broadcast Award
DOC.TEXT: Five documentaries on subjects ranging from the My Lai massacre to child prostitution won top broadcast journalism awards for ``Frontline,'' the Public Broadcasting Service series. Jurors awarded the series a Gold Baton, the highest honors in the Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards, for outstanding documentaries aired during the year ending in June. The five programs honored Thursday were: ``Remember My Lai,'' a look back at the massacre of civilians in Vietnam in 1968; ``The Spy Who Broke the Code,'' about the espionage activity of the Walker family; ``Who Profits From Drugs,'' a look at drug-money laundering by respectable people and institutions; ``Children of the Night,'' about the death of a middle-class boy who became a prostitute; and ``The Choice,'' campaign biographies of George Bush and Michael Dukakis. Eleven other broadcasters were honored with Silver Batons, three of which went to networks for coverage of the uprising in China and events in Tiananmen Square. The winners were CBS News; Cable News Network; and ABC News and Koppel Communications. Another prize for a network effort went to Gardner Productions and WETA of Washington, D.C., for the PBS broadcast ``Arab and Jew: Wounded Spirits in a Promised Land.'' The awards were presented at Columbia on Thursday night, with Robert MacNeil of PBS' ``The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' as host. In major markets, an award went to KCET of Los Angeles for two programs, ``Expecting Miracles,'' about trying to overcome infertility, and ``For the Sake of Appearances,'' an investigation of cosmetic-surgery abuses. Another major market award was won by Byron Harris and WFAA-TV of Dallas for ``Other People's Money,'' a report on savings-and-loan failures. Other winners were: _Radio broadcasting, National Public Radio for ``AIDS and Black America: Breaking the Silence,'' a series of 16 reports about the reluctance of blacks to acknowledge an epidemic in their midst. _Independent television production, Appalshop of Whitesburg, Ky., for ``On Our Own Land,'' an account of landowners fighting mining companies. _Medium market television, Maryland Public Television for ``Other Faces of AIDS,'' about the disproportionate impact of the disease on blacks and Hispanics. _Small-market television, WJXT of Jacksonville, Fla., for ``Crack Crisis: A Cry for Action,'' and WBRZ of Baton Rouge, La., for ``The Best Insurance Commissioner Money Can Buy.'' The annual awards honoring excellence in broadcast journalism were established in 1942 by Jessie Ball duPont as a memorial to her husband. They have been administered by Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism for the past 22 years.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Strengthens, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened in European trading this morning after closing sharply lower against the Japanese yen in Tokyo. Gold prices rose. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.97 yen, down from 145.30 yen on Thursday. Later in London, the dollar traded at 143.55 yen. Akihiko Hori, a dealer with Mitsui Bank Ltd. in Tokyo, said he believed the sharp plunge of the dollar was a temporary move in response to U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's call for a withholding tax on foreign investors in the United States. Other traders attributed the dollar's decline to local reports that Japan's long-term prime rate would be raised by 0.7 percentage point to 7.5 percent, starting on Feb. 1. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.6885 West German marks, up from 1.6870 _1.4915 Swiss francs, up from 1.4870 _5.7380 French francs, up from 5.7305 _1.9025 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8975 _1,256.00 Italian lire, up from 1,254.75 _1.1935 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1903 In London, the British pound sold for $1.6595 compared to $1.6570 late Thursday. London bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price this morning of $419.10 a troy ounce, up from $416.25 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $419.00, up from $413.50 bid late Thursday. Hong Kong markets were closed for the Lunar New Year holiday. Trading will resume Tuesday. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $5.27 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $5.22.

DOC.HEAD: Hijack Foiled on Domestic Flight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with all four hijackers reported killed; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Security guards on a domestic Iran Air flight foiled a hijacking and killed all four hijackers in a shootout, the official news agency reported today. The Islamic Republic News Agency, quoting a statement from the Islamic Revolution's Guards Corps, said four ``armed terrorists'' tried to hijack the Boeing 727 on Thursday night on a flight between the southern cities of Shiraz and Bandar Abbas. The corps, the internal security force, said all four hijackers were killed in a shootout with agents who were on board the plane. An earlier report by the news agency said only that two hijackers were wounded. The hijackers had taken a crew member hostage to force the pilot to fly to an unspecified destination. The shootout occurred 90 miles outside Shiraz, said the report, monitored in Nicosia. None of the passengers were wounded, and the plane returned to Shiraz after the attempt, said the new agency, which was monitored in Nicosia.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Kids were screaming for their parents. Parents were screaming for their kids. I just couldn't take it anymore.'' _ Robert LaBella, who helped remove six people from the wreckage of the fatal crash of a Colombian Boeing 707 Thursday night on New York's Long Island.
``Surprised you, didn't it?'' _ President Bush after the Senate failed by four votes to override his veto of a politically popular bill protecting Chinese students from deportation.

``Capitalism, communism _ it's all garbage.'' _ Mstislav Rostropovich, Soviet-born conductor who fled the Soviet Union in 1974 because of government harassment. He leaves Monday with his Washington-based National Symphony Orchestra on his first trip to his homeland after 16 years of exile in the West.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Parties, Opposition Debate Coalition With Communists
DOC.TEXT: More than a dozen political parties and reform groups are debating how to share power with Communist Premier Hans Modrow before free elections on May 6. Late Thursday, one of the four small parties aligned with the dominant Communists announced it was resigning from Modrow's 27-member Cabinet, deepening the crisis of confidence facing the interim premier. Opposition groups like the Neues Forum pro-democracy movement and the newly formed Social Democrats have demanded a role in Modrow's transitional government, but they are at odds with each other over how much power and responsibility they should take on. As living standards have worsened along with the declining economy, pressure for reunification with prosperous West Germany has surged. The decision by Deputy Premier Lothar de Maiziere and two fellow Christian Democrats to pull out of the Communist-led coalition was presented as a move to make way for opposition groups to enter the government. He said the other minority parties, who hold 11 seats in the Cabinet, were likely to resign as well. But the pullout, effective Feb. 9, also distances the Christian Democrats from the embattled Communist Party it served with over the past 40 years. Communists now hold 16 ministerial posts, the Liberal Democrats four, the Christian Democrats three, and the National Democrats and farmers' party two each. Steffen Reiche, whose Social Democratic Party currently has no representation in the government or parliament, called the Christian Democrats' announced departure ``the crowning irresponsibility of its 40-year service.'' The Social Democrats and other opposition groups fear that if the Christian Democrats succeed in cutting themselves off from the Communists and, therefore, responsibility for the current state of the nation, they would likely outpoll all other opposition groups in the May elections. Modrow, a respected Communist who has attempted to stay above the fray of the mounting political crisis, flew to Austria today for a one-day official visit. The premier will travel to Moscow on Tuesday for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, ADN said late Thursday. Modrow has been battling a groundswell of anti-Communist sentiment in his nation of 16 million, as East Germans lose faith that the economic crisis can be fixed and flee to the West at the rate of about 2,000 a day. West Germany has promised financial aid and solidarity with East Germany's drive for democracy in hopes of slowing the emigration wave that threatens to send a million East Germans to the West this year. Rudolf Seiters, chief of staff for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, told reporters after his visit here Thursday that it was in Bonn's interest to help stabilize the East German political and economic situation. Seiters also announced that Modrow will visit Bonn on Feb. 13-14 to discuss the volatile situation in East Germany. He urged East Germany to create ``perspectives that entice them to stay at home.'' Modrow told reporters at the start of his meeting with Seiters that the ``solidarity of West Germany in this difficult situation is absolutely necessary.'' Meanwhile, Economics Minister Christa Luft and East German government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer met with reporters Thursday to announce broad concessions to the demands of Western investors. Both Luft and Meyer referred repeatedly to the need to stabilize the economy and political situation in East Germany, and acknowledged the urgent need to institute reforms that could halt the damaging exodus of East Germans. ``We should have spent a couple of weeks better planning what we would do after we opened the borders,'' Ms. Luft conceded. She said the government has scrapped plans to limit foreign ownership of joint ventures to 49 percent. East Germany also plans to lift all restrictions on competition among private industry and craftsmen, effectively opening the national economy to free enterprise, according to Meyer.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Americans Unworried About Unified Germany
DOC.TEXT: Americans are generally unworried about the prospect of a unified Germany, but the idea concerns some Europeans, according to a joint poll by the Los Angeles Times and The Economist. The survey conducted by the California newspaper and the British magazine asked 2,677 adults in the United States, France, Great Britain and Poland the same list of questions. Results were published in the Times today. Of the 502 Poles surveyed, 69 percent said they would worry about a reunified Germany becoming ``the dominant power in Europe.'' Among 504 British and 511 French people surveyed, about 50 percent said they would be disturbed by a dominant Germany. In the United States, where 1,160 people were surveyed by telephone Saturday, 29 percent said a dominant Germany would worry them. Sixty-two percent said a reunified, dominant Germany would not bother them. The Europeans were surveyed by the Economist during an overlapping four-day period. The margin of sampling error for the U.S. poll is plus or minus 4 percentage points. The margin in the European poll is plus or minus 5 points. In the United States and France, 61 percent of those surveyed said they favored a reunited Germany. In Great Britain, 45 percent responded in favor of a reunited Germany and 41 percent of the Poles said reunification would be best. Forty-four percent of Poles surveyed opposed any plan to reunify the two German nations, while 30 percent of the British subjects queried also opposed German reunification. In France, 15 percent opposed reunification. Most Americans and Britons said they want to preserve U.S. military levels in Europe. The French and Poles were split on the issue. More than 300,000 U.S. troops are based in Europe. When asked whether democratic reform in Eastern Europe depended on Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev retaining power, 50 percent of British respondents said it did. Thirty-eight percent of U.S. citizens surveyed agreed, followed by 32 percent in France and 23 percent in Poland. Seventy-two percent of the Poles surveyed said their fledgling democratic reforms would gain strength even if Gorbachev loses control of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: First Rescuer's Grim Sight: ``Bodies on Bodies on Bodies''
With PM-Jetliner Down, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A grim sight greeted New York City paramedic Jeff Race, the first rescuer on the scene of the Avianca jetliner crash a half-mile from his family's home: ``Bodies on top of bodies on top of bodies.'' ``Some were alive, some were dead,'' Race, who was alerted to the crash when the lights blinked off and on at his house, recalled this morning. ``Limbs were bent every way you can imagine.'' He went to work. First, Race sent his only predecessor at the scene _ a neighbor with a flashlight _ to get all the blankets she could. He took the flashlight and approached the crumpled Boeing 707 airplane in the woods of his isolated suburban neighborhood. The plane, on its second approach to John F. Kennedy International Airport about 15 miles away, crashed at about 9:45 p.m. Thursday, killing at least 67 of the 158 people aboard. ``People were screaming, some of them in different languages. They were all screaming, `Help me. Help me. Help me,''' said Race, whose father is a pilot for American Airlines. ``Most of them were still strapped in their seats. It was just mangled, twisted metal.'' Race, a lieutenant with the city's Emergency Medical Service and volunteer firefighter in nearby Oyster Bay, said he pulled about six children and a dozen adults from the wreckage, then set up a triage area as other rescuers started to arrive. ``One things that sticks in my mind was a little boy who was crying with a guy pinned underneath him in the wreckage,'' he said. The man spoke, said Race: ``Get the kid out first.'' The plane appeared to have skipped along tree tops before it crashed into a hillside at the end of Tennis Court Road, where it lay broken in pieces. ``I think it was a miracle for anybody on that plane to have lived,'' said Race. ``It's a gift from God.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Islanders to Remain Faithful Through Economic Hardship
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II today urged Cape Verde's Catholics to guard their Christian faith as the island nation struggles to overcome poverty. Speaking to 35,000 chanting islanders in Mindelo, the former Portuguese colony's cultural and economic capital on Sao Vicente island, John Paul praised the islanders for their faith in the face of ``adverse conditions.'' Cape Verde's 10 islands are part of West Africa's impoverished Sahel region, which for years had been plagued by drought, famine and encroaching deserts. ``Without natural riches, your country is searching ... with some success, for the paths to steady progress,'' the pope told the town's packed sports stadium. He said shortages of rainfall and food as well as storms in the archipelago off the West African coast were a ``trial of suffering'' that had strengthened the islanders' faith. To the delight of the crowd, a light drizzle marked the pope's arrival on Sao Vicente. ``Never hesitate to sacrifice everything to stay faithful to Christ,'' the pope implored the crowd in Portuguese. The archipelago, colonized by the Portuguese in the 15th century, has Africa's highest concentration of Roman Catholics, over 90 percent of its 360,000 inhabitants. While stressing that the church supported progress that guaranteed human integrity and harmony, the pope urged: ``Don't let yourselves be chained by the myth of economic progress.'' ``Fight against religious indifference _ the dangerous temptation of modern times...to abandon religious practices when you become too concerned with material interests, success, or professional and social advancement,'' he said. The Polish-born pontiff received a clamorous welcome on Sal island and in the capital, Cidade da Praia, on Thursday after he urged rich countries not to abandon the needy Third World in favor of Eastern European countries emerging from years of Communist rule. During John Paul's eight-day tour of the region, the sixth African voyage of his pontificate, he will also visit Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Burkina Faso and Chad. Though Cape Verde is one of the more prosperous nations in the region, many islanders have left in search of better living conditions. An estimated 400,000 Cape Verdians live and work abroad, mainly in the United States, Portugal, France and the Netherlands. The pope also mentioned emigrants' problems in his Mindelo address, advising them not to lose their cultural identity and Christian faith.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow, High Winds Pummel Upper Midwest
DOC.TEXT: The upper Midwest was digging out today from a fierce storm with high winds that dumped up to 15 inches of snow, blacked out at least 138,000 power customers, blew roofs off buildings and closed three major airports. Four people died of heart attacks while shoveling snow from Thursday's storm, authorities said. Three of them were in Wisconsin, one in Illinois. Lightning injured 12 people in Illinois, and snow made driving treacherous from Iowa to Ohio. ``This is the rural mailman's worst nightmare,'' said Tanis Lehmann, postmaster in Cedar, Mich. ``I worry like a mother hen until my carriers come back.'' Up to 15 inches of snow fell in Michigan's Lower Peninsula. Heavy snow also fell in the Cascades and Olympic Mountains of the Pacific Northwest, with more forecast for today. Stevens Pass, 60 miles east of Seattle, got 17 inches Thursday on top of a foot already on the ground, and forecasters predicted an additional 1 to 2 feet of snow there today. In Alabama, meanwhile, twin tornadoes ripped through two mobile-home parks Thursday, destroying about 15 homes. Authorities said 28 people were injured, including three boys who suffered serious head injuries. Lesser winds caused damage in the Detroit suburbs. Gusts reaching 60 mph ripped the roofs off a motel in Auburn Hills and a video store in Livonia. No one was injured there, but in Indianapolis, a 54-year-old woman was cut on the leg by flying glass when winds gusting to 50 mph blew out windows on two floors of the INB National Bank Tower. Utilities reported at least 84,000 customers lost power in Michigan, 44,000 in Wisconsin and 10,000 in Illinois. In most cases, power was back on today. Mitchell International Airport in Milwaukee, which got nearly 10 inches of snow, was closed for 13 hours Thursday because of drifting snow and poor visibility. ``It was real close to a blizzard,'' said National Weather Service meteorologist John Haase in Milwaukee. Airports in St. Louis and Detroit closed for shorter periods of time, while O'Hare and Midway airports in Chicago remained open but had at least half their flights canceled. Eleven people were struck by lightning in a factory parking lot in Crystal Lake, Ill., 35 miles northwest of Chicago, and a 12th person was struck in nearby Palatine. None was seriously injured. ``I feel lucky to be alive,'' said Apolonio Pena, 37, one of the Precision Twist Drill Co. workers struck by lightning as they were trying to help push cars out of 6 inches of new snow. The bolt hit a telephone pole next to the plant and traveled through the snow. ``There was a big, loud boom and then a flash,'' Pena said. ``I felt like I had been knocked down, but I was really standing up. It was really strange. Sparks came out of my fingers.'' Illinois state police closed 35- to 40-mile stretches of Interstate 90 near Elgin and I-88 outside Aurora for two hours at midday Thursday, said Sgt. Tami Haukedahl. The storm lashed southeastern Iowa with 45 mph winds that whipped 5 inches of snow into a treacherous near-whiteout on roads slick with ice. ``Not only is there zero visibility, but you can turn left and not go left,'' said Bob Wilson, district manager for the American Automobile Association's Motor Club of Iowa. Near Toledo, Ohio, two U.S. marshals were injured, one seriously, when a tree fell on their car. But the storm also brought some benefits, drenching much of northern and central Illinois with 1 to 2 inches of rain. ``That's a heavy rain for this time of year and we've been quite dry ... so the farmers were happy to see the rain and snow,'' said weather service forecaster Richard Koeneman.

DOC.HEAD: India Tightens Security in Restive State
DOC.TEXT: Government troops ordered people to stay off the streets today and searched houses for Moslems waging a violent campaign for Kashmir's secession from India, witnesses reported. At least 70 people, mostly militant Moslems, have been killed since Saturday, when the government launched a harsh crackdown on Kashmiri separatists to halt escalating violence. Moslem boys defied the curfew and burned Indian flags after daybreak today. A few hours later, a state government official presided over a poorly attended ceremony on the 40th anniversary of the founding of the Indian Republic. Journalists were confined to a hotel and warned that they would be arrested and risked getting shot if they tried to leave. In downtown Srinagar, where earlier in the week Moslem crowds frequently defied the curfew confining them to their homes, troops refused to let anyone outside. People who started to open their windows were ordered to shut them. Only security forces and a few top officials were allowed outdoors. The stepped-up security coincided with the weekly Islamic holy day, often a boiling point for militant Moslems, and the 40th anniversary celebration. On Jan. 26, 1950, newly independent India forged together under one constitution an assortment of provinces once ruled by Britain and princely states headed by maharajahs and nawabs. The holiday was denounced as a ``black day'' by the Moslem separatists, who want to secede from predominantly Hindu India and become independent or join neighboring Pakistan, an Islamic nation. From various vantage points in Srinagar, a city of 1 million people, only heavily armed troops and an occasional government official could be seen on the streets. United News of India quoted an official spokesman as saying nine people were killed and 14 wounded on Thursday in Handwara, 40 miles northwest of Srinagar. Unofficial sources has said Thursday night that three people were killed when troops fired on a rioting mob. Sources who were contacted by telephone from Jammu, the state's winter capital, said troops conducted house-to-house searches in several parts of Srinagar and the nearby towns of Anantnag and Baramulla. Several Moslem youths were detained, the sources said, stipulating that they not be identified further. Kashmir is the toughest challenge Prime Minister V.P. Singh has faced since he took office Dec. 2. Six days later, Moslem extremists abducted the daughter of Singh's home minister, Kashmiri Moslem Mufti Mohammad Sayeed, and held her until the government freed five jailed Moslem militants. The separatist violence escalated as the miliants attacked patrols and set fire to government buildings. An around-the-clock curfew was imposed Saturday in Srinagar and surrounding towns. Hundreds, if not thousands, of troops were dispatched. The federal government last week appointed Jagmohan, a Hindu who uses only one name and who is known as a tough administrator, as governor in Jammu-Kashmir and gave him authority over elected state officials. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority.

DOC.HEAD: Asia Celebrates Coming of the Year of the Horse
DOC.TEXT: Asians began welcoming the Year of the Horse today with family gatherings and predictions of surging gold prices and global instability. Across mainland China, people hurried home from work early to begin the four-day holiday, China's biggest festival. The Year of the Snake gives way to the Year of the Horse on Saturday. The eve of Lunar New Year is the only day of the year that Chinese police are allowed to drink on the job, and those who patrol the streets around the Beijing Train Station joined the rest of the nation today in celebration. Hong Kong's noisy street markets were jammed with last-minute shoppers buying food, flowers, watermelon seeds, nuts and candy from merchants happily charging up to three times normal prices before the city shuts down for the weekend. Hong Kong astrologer Andrew Yau predicted the coming year will bring more rainfall, some instability, and _ for local businessmen always looking for an investment tip _ rising gold prices. After fluctuating for the first half of the year, ``the gold price definitely will rise very much, perhaps more than 50 percent. On the other hand, the dollar is to devalue,'' Yau said. President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan forecast in his New Year's message that the Communist rulers of mainland China will face the same fate as their counterparts in Eastern Europe. ``Several Communist authoritarian regimes were overthrown in the past year. We believe Chinese Communists will face the same fate soon,'' Lee said. In Beijing, tens of thousands of people turned out for the first day of the Longtan Park temple fair, which offered a variety of ``Beijing-style snacks'' from spicy pancakes to small eggs deep-fried on a stick and candied crab apples. Gamblers could try their hand at roulette, and children could ride in a dog-drawn cart for 20 cents. But by nightfall, the city train station was nearly empty, with uniformed and plainclothes police outnumbering travelers. Many stores had begun to close as families gathered for traditional holiday meals. Police at the station passed around the ``white liquor,'' 120-proof firewater, during their Lunar New Year lunch. In preparation for the holiday, China's leaders have made visits to the provinces, bringing greetings to workers in coal mines and factories and visiting soldiers to thank them for helping to put down spring's pro-democracy movement. Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin, during a six-day tour of Shanxi province, in northern China, emphasized the role of the working class and said socialism will triumph in China if ``we learn from (their) spirit of fearing no hardship and quietly contributing to the country and the people.'' Such exhortations have been common since last year's pro-democracy movement, which was violently crushed by the military. Hong Kong buildings were decorated with colorful New Year's greetings while tangerine trees, narcissus and other plants considered auspicious adorned many doorways. Hundreds of thousands of the British colony's 5.7 million people jammed the airport, ferry terminals and the border crossing into China as they left the territory to visit relatives or take vacations.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Says U.S. Observers Won't Be Welcome at its Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with heavy fighting reported between government troops and Karen rebels on Thai border. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The military government, which has barred several top opposition leaders from running in Burma's next election, said today that American observers will not be allowed to monitor the balloting. The announcement came as students in the country's two largest cities demonstrated this week to support an opposition leader who was banned from participating in the elections, Western diplomats said today. Heavy fighting, meanwhile, was reported between government troops and Karen rebels along the Thailand border. Sixty fighters were killed and 25 injured in five days of fighting in which government troops overrun one rebel base and part of another, police said today. Thousands of civilians fled the fighting. The elections set for May 27 are to be the first multiparty parliamentary vote since 1960. But in the past month, the three main opposition figures have been excluded from running. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., asked for a U.S. team to be allowed to witness the election, the U.S.-funded Voice of America reported Thursday. Asked about the report, a government spokesman, Col. Aung Thein, told a news conference today: ``Where is the need to come and observe the election, since he has already presumed that it will not be free and fair?'' The spokesman said 2,392 candidates were contesting the election because they believed it would be fair. ``It is futile and meaningless to say the election would not be free and fair simply because one or two of the candidates are not participating because they infringed the election law,'' he said. On Jan. 16, Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, co-leader of the National League for Democracy, was disqualified after being linked by the government with a student rebel group. She has been under house arrest since July. Also barred has been Tin Oo, the group's other leader. He was sentenced by a military tribunal to three years imprisonment on charges of subversion. U Nu, the last democratically elected premier, was put under house arrest and also banned from the balloting. The Western diplomats said groups of students on bicycles held rallies in the country's second most populous city, Mandalay, in recent days to back Ms. Suu Kyi. The protesters waved the flag of her party and shouted slogans, the diplomats in Rangoon said in telephone interviews, speaking anonymously. Young people also assembled in groups of 30 or 40 in violation of martial law, which prohibits gatherings of more than five people, one diplomat said. Mandalay, 350 miles north of Rangoon, was a center of the huge pro-democracy demonstrations that lasted several months in 1988 before the military crushed them. Hundreds of people were killed. One diplomat reported that there were also street protests in the capital on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. He cited unconfirmed reports that at least 50 protesters had been arrested. Burma has been ruled by martial law since September 1988, when Gen. Saw Maung seized power in a coup and suppressed the pro-democracy movement. Since then, thousands of dissidents have been detained, casting doubt on the regime's pledge of a free and fair election. In the fighting along the border, 1,500 Burmese troops began attacking the Karen bases of The Ba Bow and nearby Maeng Ka Ra on Saturday, border police sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They captured Maeng Ka Ra and part The Ba Bow, the sources said. Both camps are close to Thailand's northwestern border. About 30 fighters on each side were reported killed and 20 Burmese and five Karen rebels wounded, the police said. Fighting has raged in the surrounding area since Jan. 17 and has sent 5,000 Karen civilians fleeing across the Thai border. Thai villagers living on the frontier also have fled to escape the fighting, the sources said. The Karens are one of the largest of the diverse ethnic groups fighting the Burmese government. They have resisted the integration of the the Karen state into the Union of Burma since Rangoon gained independence from Britain in 1948.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 67 Dead From Colombian Airliner Crash in New York
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 30 grafs to UPDATE with Avianca confirming 158 aboard, FAA giving details of engine going out and of tower communications, ``black boxes'' recovered, rescuer quoting survivor. Picks up 33rd graf pvs, `Matt Murphy...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY19,20,21,MLV1,2,4,5; LaserColor MLV3,6; With LaserGraphics
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian jetliner on a landing approach radioed that an engine had gone out before it crashed in heavy fog and rain, killing at least 67 of 158 people aboard and scattering bodies across a wooded hillside, authorities said today. Helicopters lifted bloodied passengers to hospitals as a priest gave last rites on the ground early this morning. ``I gave them rosaries and said little prayers,'' said the Rev. Daniel Ahern of St. Pius V Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay. ``They were crying and asking about their family members.'' Avianca Flight 52, a Boeing 707, was carrying 149 passengers and nine crew members when it crashed Thursday night on its second approach to John F. Kennedy International Airport, the airline said in a statement from Bogota. ``There were bodies on top of bodies on top of bodies,'' said Jeff Race, 26, a New York City paramedic who lives a half-mile away. He said he was the first rescuer at the scene. ``Some were alive, some were dead. Limbs were bent every way you can imagine.'' ``People were screaming. ... Most of them were still strapped in their seats,'' he said. ``It was just mangled, twisted metal.'' The 23-year-old jetliner, more than 90 minutes late from Bogota after a stop in Medellin, Colombia, broke into at least three pieces. Rescuers arrived to find passengers scrambling out of exits. Dr. George Dunn of Glen Cove Community Hospital said the number of survivors was so high because the airplane didn't catch on fire. Authorities this morning could not confirm a Cable News Network report that the plane ran out of fuel before it crashed. National Transportation Safety Board investigators were on the scene but had not commented. Boeing spokesman Tom Cole said the 707 model is capable of carrying about 24,000 gallons of fuel, which gives it range of 6,000 miles. ``It has plenty of capability to fly from Colombia to New York.'' Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman Diane Spitaliere said the plane pulled away from a landing approach at 9:24 p.m. for unknown reasons. At 9:32 p.m., she said, the plane reported to the Kennedy tower that its No. 2 engine had gone out. At 9:34 p.m., the tower lost contact with the plane, and the crash occurred moments later, Spitaliere said. The death toll as of midmorning was 67, and it was not clear how many crew members survived, said Port Authority Police Officer Michael Palermo. The plane's flight and voice recorders were recovered, Thomas Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, said. Authorities created a makeshift morgue on the front lawn of a mansion owned by the parents of tennis star John McEnroe, about a quarter-mile from the crash. The bodies were wrapped in white plastic and lined in rows. Aleta Heidt of Wyckoff, N.J., said her husband was on the plane, bringing home two adoptive children. The husband and at least one child survived, she said. She said she believed several children being adopted were on the flight. Race said most of those killed or severely injured were ``from the front of the plane, where the fuselage had separated apart.'' By early today, 92 people had been taken to hospitals, according to Sgt. James Callahan of the Nassau County Police Emergency Medical Bureau. Nassau County Police spokesman Officer Peter Franzone said at least 78 people survived the crash. Among those hospitalized were 15 children, many carried from the crash scene crying. ``What a way to come to America,'' one of the passengers told rescue worker Jay Krul, 30, of Oyster Bay. The plane went down about 15 miles northeast of the airport after a five-hour flight, said Port Authority Police Officer Phil Montouri. The crash occurred just off Oyster Bay Harbor in an exclusive Nassau County hamlet on the north shore of Long Island. It's near the former home of President Theodore Roosevelt, now a national historic site. Rescuers laid ladders up the steep wooded hillside, where part of the fuselage came to rest, then passed the survivors down. ``The fuselage was cracked open near the top of the plane. That's how we got access to the survivors,'' said firefighter Tom Czajkowski. ``You could hear people crying and screaming. ``A lot of passengers were dead and a lot were in shock. Some of them were talking to us _ we told them to hang in there, we'd get them out.'' Alfred Williams, an off-duty New York policeman, said one passenger told him that the plane's engines went dead and the aircraft crashed soon after. ``As soon as they hit the ground he flew out the front of the second part of the fuselage and started running in fear that the plane was going to blow up,'' Williams said. ``And he realized that he had to go back for his wife and his daughter, he said. ``And he said he just couldn't. He collapsed. He had two broken legs.'' Anxious relatives waiting at the airport viewed television news pictures of the crash. Amanda Pinzon, 27, of Elizabeth, N.J., who was waiting in the Pan Am terminal lounge with relatives who had come to meet the plane, cried with joy when she saw her husband, Jesus, and 2-year-old son, Brian, on television, among the survivors being taken to hospitals. ``I feel great, I'm so happy _ happy, crying, everything,'' she said. Matt Murphy, agent on duty at the federal Drug Enforcement Administration office in New York, said the DEA has not received any threats against Colombian airliners recently. He noted that the plane was close to its destination when it crashed, which he said was an indication that sabotage was not involved. On Nov. 27, an Avianca Boeing 727 was bombed out of the sky minutes after takeoff from Bogota on a domestic flight to Cali. The explosion killed all 107 people on board. The Extraditables group, drug traffickers fearing extradition to the United States, took responsibility for the bombing in a phone call to the Colombian radio network Caracol.

DOC.HEAD: Rescue Workers Toiled Amid Passengers' Screams
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with scene this morning, add detail. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `You could...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Jetliner Down, Bjt
LaserPhoto MLV15
DOC.TEXT: Shrill sirens pierced the fog-shrouded skies and helicopters hovered overhead as rescue workers scrambled to pull survivors from the wreckage of a Colombian jetliner. Minutes after the Avianca Boeing 707 crashed Thursday night on a hillside in this exclusive Long Island village, word went out to dozens of volunteer fire departments, sending a stream of fire-fighting apparatus and ambulances to the site. The plane's nose smashed into the deck of the home of Sam Tiesenbaum and his wife. They said the house shook and there was a sound like thunder. ``We thought it was an earthquake,'' they told authorities. Arriving rescue workers heard the screams of trapped passengers, who moaned in pain and cried out to loved ones in Spanish. ``Kids were screaming for their parents. Parents were screaming for their kids,'' said Robert LaBella, a nearby resident who helped remove six people from the wreckage. After that, ``I just couldn't take it anymore.'' Larry Rubinstein, a rescue volunteer, said the scene was ``very chaotic.'' But he and others said an odd sense of order set in as passengers realized they had survived, and rescue crews went to work. ``It was very crazy at first but the police got things under control and everybody started the task of getting everyone, the survivors, out of the aircraft,'' Rubinstein said. Morris Benny of the East Norwich Fire Department said some survivors ``were already sitting on the plane. A couple were trying to walk out.'' Scores of the passengers aboard the Avianca flight from Bogota, Colombia, to Kennedy International Airport were injured. At least 67 of the passengers and crew among the more than 140 aboard were killed. After a hectic night of life-and-death urgency, rescuers this morning worked in a cold drizzle, using pneumatic chisels to pry away wreckage. First word of the crash reached the Nassau County Fire Communications Center at 9:44 p.m., said supervisor Paul E. Simon. The center quickly dispatched 20 of the county's volunteer fire departments to the scene. Eight others were on standby. Units from the Emergency Medical Service came from New York City. ``As far as how many people were involved, I couldn't say,'' Simon said. The plane, broken in three places, came to rest on a steep, wooded hillside on a peninsula that juts into Long Island Sound, a neighborhood dotted with million-dollar estates. Trees 60 to 80 feet tall and thick as a telephone pole had been snapped off. The remote location complicated the rescue effort. Rescuers laid ladders up the hillside to reached the splintered fuselage and formed a human chain, passing survivors down the hillside. They set up a makeshift morgue on the front lawn of a home owned by the parents of tennis star John McEnroe. ``You could hear people crying and screaming,'' firefighter Tom Czajkowski said. ``A lot of passengers were dead and a lot were in shock. Some of them were talking to us. We told them to hang in there, we'd get them out.'' Simon said the crush of rescue equipment and onlookers clogged the windy, two-lane road leading to the crash site. ``We had a gridlock problem. ... We couldn't get the ambulances in,'' he said. Workers tried to reassure passengers as they worked to free them from the crushed seats inside the plane. ``I told them in my broken Spanish that they were lucky and we would get them out,'' said Dr. George Dunn. ``They were not hysterical, just mostly in shock.'' Soon, helicopters were shuttling the injured from the crash site and caravans of ambulances made their way to and from the scene. Peter Dowd of the Syosset Fire Department said he worked his way into the plane through the rear and spent 1{ hours inside while about 25 passengers were extricated. He said he helped support an American passenger who was having difficulty breathing. The passenger told him the aircraft had been circling before the crash, then suddenly lost lighting and power. ``They went down like an escalator,'' Dowd said the woman told him.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Students Report They're Abused; Many Considered Dropping Out
DOC.TEXT: Medical students are often shouted at and occasionally physically threatened in the course of their training, according to two studies. ``It's a lot like child abuse,'' said Dr. DeWitt Baldwin, who directs medical education research for the American Medical Association. He co-wrote one of two studies in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``We knew it was there, but we somehow couldn't believe it.'' In a survey of 75 third-year medical students, 85 percent said they had been ``yelled or shouted at'' at least once during training, wrote Baldwin and researchers at the University of South Florida in Tampa. In some cases, the yelling came from patients, but most frequently, it was another medical staff member or a teacher doing the yelling, the survey found. The same percentage also said they had been humiliated or subjected to inappropriately nasty or hostile behavior, the researchers reported. More alarming, 24 percent of the students said they had been physically threatened, most frequently by patients, and 16 percent said they'd actually been physically abused _ either slapped, kicked, hit or had things thrown at them. Most women students, 81 percent, said they had been subject to sexism, most often by clinical faculty and residents or interns. More than half _ 55 percent _ said they had been targets of unwelcome sexual advances. Half of the non-white students said they had endured racial or ethnic slurs, though none reported being denied opportunities because of race or ethnicity. More than two-thirds of those surveyed felt that mistreatment in their training had interfered with their emotional health, and 37 percent seriously considered leaving medical school as a result, the study said. Co-author K. Harnett Sheehan conceded that verbal abuse of medical students is an ``age-old problem,'' but suggested the studies may prompt efforts to make the ``medical school environment a more pleasant, more attractive place.'' Dr. Henry Silver, co-author of an accompanying study, said he found students were abused far more often than he had expected. Silver, an associate dean for admissions at the University of Colorado School of Medicine in Denver, and his colleagues surveyed 431 students. Four out of every five students reported mistreatment at some time during their medical education. Sixteen percent said they had been so affected by the abuse that they would carry it with them for the rest of their lives. Silver's study defined abuse as avoidable treatment that is harmful, injurious or offensive, and included such things as verbal attacks. The study recounted the experience of one student who asked his superior to allow him to stop examining the eye of a fellow student who ``was in obvious pain.'' ``When I explained this to the supervising physician, he said, `Oh good, this gives us an opportunity to learn how to force a patient to cooperate even if they are in pain.''' Researchers in both studies emphasized that the schools they surveyed _ the University of Colorado School of Medicine and the University of South Florida College of Medicine _ were typical of medical schools. They said both schools have started to amend their programs so that future students may not be mistreated. In an editorial in this week's Journal, Dr. Jerald Kay urges medical schoools to educate their faculty and staff on students' rights and to make provisions for those who abuse others.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Guerrillas Clash with Israelis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with claim of nine casualties in ambush, army confirming bomb incident. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian guerrilla group claimed it killed or wounded nine Israeli soldiers today after ambushing an Israeli patrol in south Lebanon. The Israeli army denied any of its soldiers were hurt. Also today, an Israeli soldier was wounded in a separate attack when a roadside bomb exploded under his tank in south Lebanon. The Marxist-oriented Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine said it ambushed the Israeli patrol at 6 a.m. in a narrow valley near the village of Taibeh in Israeli's self-declared security zone. ``The Zionist enemy and its surrogates of the South Lebanon Army militia rushed tank-led reinforcements to the confrontation region in an effort to encircle our comrades, who had succeeded in wiping out the Israeli patrol,'' the Palestinian group said in its statement. A later statement from the group sent to The Associated Press in Cyprus said nine Israelis were killed or wounded in the ambush and that the attack was in retaliation for an Israeli air raid Thursday on Palestinian targets in Lebanon. One man was killed and three people wounded in that raid. The Israeli army said today's battle was ``not a major incident.'' A military statement said the Israeli soldiers ``came under light arms fire. Soldiers in the force sustained no casualties and returned fire at the source of the shooting.'' In the southern village of Barachit, also in the security zone, an Israeli soldier was wounded when a mine went off near his tank, the Israeli army and Lebanese security sources said. Israel radio said the officer was slightly wounded. Israel has controlled the security zone, a strip of land six to 10 miles wide along the border, since its invasion of Lebanon in 1982. It kept the area as a buffer against border attacks when it withdrew most of its army in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Three Inmates Seriously Injured in Jail Riot
DOC.TEXT: An argument between two inmates escalated into a full-scale brawl between black and Hispanic prisoners at an overcrowded county jail, and three inmates were seriously injured, officials said. Prisoners wielding hand-made knives and other crude weapons attacked each other for about 15 minutes Thursday before jail deputies forced them back into their cells, sheriff's Capt. Ben McLaughlin said. It was the second such disturbance in as many months in the same cellblock at the El Cajon Detention Facility. The jail is designed to hold 120 prisoners but held more than 500 inmates Thursday. Inmates retreated to their cells when deputies entered the cellblock armed with electronic stun-guns and a weapon that fires rubber bullets. One injured inmate was flown by helicopter to Sharp Memorial Hospital, where he was listed in critical condition with head injuries, said spokeswoman Melanie Bruce. Two other inmates were admitted to the UCSD Medical Center with head injuries, one in serious condition and one in fair condition, said spokeswoman Jane Swett. Both spokeswomen declined to release the names of the prisoners. Nine other inmates suffered cuts, scrapes and other minor injuries and were returned to jail after treatment at eastern San Diego County hospitals, officials said. Deputies said they saw a black inmate arguing with a Hispanic inmate moments before their confrontation turned violent. ``It was a racial issue, but we're not sure yet what sparked it,'' McLaughlin said. On Dec. 13, feuding black and Hispanic inmates tore apart furniture in the same cellblock and used the pieces of furniture as weapons. Four inmates were seriously injured in that melee. El Cajon is 20 miles east of downtown San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Miners March at Site of Violence
LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: More than 500 United Mine Workers members marched two miles up Rum Creek Hollow today to protest non-union work at a coal preparation plant. The half-hour rally was held at a private bridge leading to the Rum Creek Coal Sales Inc. plant, the site of confrontations earlier this week. It was the largest gathering of UMW miners since June, when a rally in Charleston attracted more than 1,000 miners, the union said. That march triggered wildcat strikes the next day, which eventually idled 43,000 miners in 10 states. Today's march came one day after the UMW celebrated the 100th anniversary of its founding. ``Our focus is to bring public attention and bring justice to people in the coal fields,'' said Bob Phalen, president of UMW District 17. Cars and pickup trucks lined West Virginia 10, about 70 miles southeast of Charleston, and state police escorted the miners two miles from a parking lot to the bridge. No violence was reported. Miners struck Rum Creek in mid-August after the A.T. Massey Coal Co. subsidiary re-opened the preparation plant with non-union contractors. Union men had run operations there. The march temporarily disrupted traffic on a side road leading from West Virginia 10, but miners cleared the road and allowed traffic to flow. State troopers had advised the miners not to block the public road. The union already was under court order not to block an adjacent private road leading to the plant. Many miners wore camouflage clothing to show their solidarity. They said they were prepared to be arrested. ``If that's what they want us to do, we'll do it. It's one for all and all for one in the United Mine Workers,'' said Bill Humphrey of Whitesville, who carried a framed copy of the Declaration of Independence. Humphrey works at New Beckley Coal Co., where the UMW has been on strike for nearly a year. About 100 of his co-workers also attended the rally. ``I get emotional over stuff like this,'' said Bill Ingram, a 40-year veteran of the Rum Creek plant. Miners picketing the Rum Creek plant have blocked the road with cars and trucks. On Monday and Tuesday, company coal trucks plowed the vehicles out of the way. On Wednesday, federal marshals had them towed away. Two UMW members were arraigned in Charleston Thursday on charges of assaulting federal marshals Wednesday and freed on $25,000 secured bonds. A third UMW member was freed on $10,000 unsecured bond after being charged with violating the court order. On Thursday about 60 pickets gathered at the site but allowed the trucks to pass without incident. The Rum Creek strike is not related to the 9-month-old strike against the Pittston Coal Group, which was tentatively settled Jan. 1. The proposed pact has not yet been submitted for ratification by the rank and file.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Agreement Reached In Violent Railway Strike
DOC.TEXT: Striking black railway workers and management have reached a tentative agreement in a 12-week-old walkout that has claimed more than 30 lives and resulted in millions of dollars in property damage, a mediator said today. Charles Nupen, director of Independent Mediation Services, said management of the state-owned South African Transport Services and officials of the South African Railways and Harbor Workers Union would review the document today and planned to sign it Saturday. Nupen said in a statement that the company has agreed to recognize the union, which has been one of the demands by the 25,000 strikers. However, the statement made no mention of a pay hike. The strikers, who walked off the job Nov. 2, wanted the minimum monthly wage increased from $240 to $600. The company and the union declined to comment on the tentative accord. The company fired almost all the strikers, but it has agreed to rehire them, Nupen said. The strike has been one of the most violent ever in South Africa, with numerous battles between strikers and non-strikers and dozens of incidents in which railway coaches and track have been sabotaged. The company says it has suffered property damage of $16 million. The strike is illegal under legislation that bars industrial action against essential services. The transport company employs about 170,000 people and runs rail and harbor operations nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leaders Agree to Multiparty System, Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Communist leaders, under pressure to end one-party rule in Bulgaria, hurriedly adopted a new platform embracing a multiparty system and social democracy, the BTA news agency said today. The program was drawn up late Thursday during a meeting called after several days of labor unrest, the official news agency said. BTA gave few details of the hastily convened Central Committee meeting. It said only that 20 members spoke and heard a concluding speech from party leader Petar Mladenov, the former foreign minister who took over after hard-liner Todor Zhivkov was ousted Nov. 10. The report said the platform commits the Communists, who have ruled alone since the late 1940s, to pluralism and social democracy and is to be voted on at a party congress next week. A showdown between reformers and more orthodox Communists is expected at the congress. The Communist Party in Bulgaria, drawing on a century of tradition and facing a relatively weak opposition, has not collapsed or abandoned power as swiftly as others in Eastern Europe. But labor unrest, virtually unknown in Bulgaria since World War II, has spread since Zhivkov's ouster. Sofia bus drivers and coal miners were among those on strike this week, demanding higher pay or better working conditions. Finance Minister Belcho Belchev appealed on national television Thursday night for an end to the strikes and said Bulgaria will face ``disastrous losses'' if they continue. Productivity dropped 13 percent in December compared with 1989, he said. Zhivkov was arrested last week on allegations of abuse of power during his more than three decades in power. No date for the trial of the 78-year-old former leader has been announced. The party daily Rabotnichesko Delo said today that while Zhivkov was in power, he ordered charges to be filed against his daughter-in-law, Maroussya Mirchevska, who was accused of trying to defect with her young son. It said Mrs. Mirchevska was forced to live in the Soviet Union for five years. It did not say what had happened to the child, now 10 years old, but printed what it said was a plea from the woman to be reunited with her son.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Schools Lead Nation in Westinghouse Science Finalists
DOC.TEXT: New York's Stuyvesant High School has again led the nation in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, after almost missing the contest when entries were misplaced by Federal Express last month. Stuyvesant had 39 of the 303 semifinalists announced Thursday in the national contest and five finalists. New York City schools again did well, with 109 semifinalists and 14 of 40 finalists. ``We have extraordinarily gifted kids and we try to cater a program to their skills,'' said Stuyvesant principal Abraham Baumel. Hundreds of students work on projects and 161 from the school entered this year. Federal Express mislaid 71 of the school's entries, causing them to miss the filing deadline. But Westinghouse officials allowed them, saying it wasn't the students' fault. ``It's marvelous _ everyone is just thrilled that such a wonderful result did take place,'' said Baumel. He said it was not known how many of the semifinalists or finalists were from the late entries. Bronx High School of Science also had five finalists, out of only 35 entries. It had 19 semifinalists. The 40 finalists will compete for $140,000 in scholarships in Washington from March 1-5. The top prize is a $20,000 scholarship. Stuyvesant, Bronx Science and Brooklyn Technical High School attract the city's best science students through competitive tests. Brooklyn Technical had two finalists. Midwood High School in Brooklyn and Van Buren High School in Queens had one apiece. ``It must be the water system,'' joked Charles Carroll, a spokesman for the search. By comparison, the entire states of California and Maryland landed four finalists apiece. Among the finalists from Stuyvesant were Alexander Sragovich, 17, who studied the genetic alteration of antibodies; Esther Chen, 17, who investigated a gene that triggers cell multiplication; and James Chien-Hsun Liao, 18, who studied a genetic agent in bacteria. Stuyvesant has had the largest number of National Merit Scholars of any single school in the country, 77, and set the record for Westinghouse semifinalists, 47, two years ago, Baumel said. The school with the next-largest number of semifinalists was Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology in Alexandria, Va., with 14.

DOC.HEAD: France Suspends Aid to Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ France suspended aid to Haiti and broke off talks on a new $500 million aid package to protest human rights violations by the Caribbean country's military government, French officials said today. French Minister of Cooperation Jacques Pelletier canceled a visit scheduled for last Monday after the president, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, decreed a 30-day state of siege, a French Embassy spokesman said on condition of anonymity. More than 50 political leaders have been arrested since the weekend. Most have been released, but several have been exiled to the United States or France, and a radical political leader was reported missing on Thursday. France, which once controlled Haiti, was the most generous international donor to Haiti in 1989, giving $50 million for financing development projects. Aid continued at about the same level this year, although an aid package valued at $500 million during the next two years was to have been negotiated at the suspended meeting of the Haitian-French Cooperation Commission, said a Haitian official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said current payments to Haiti also were being cut. France took the action because of ``the scope of human rights violations and the interruption of public liberties in Haiti,'' the ministry said in a statement. French officials will be consulting with other aid donors ``to examine measures that might lead Gen. Avril to respect his promises to restore democracy,'' it said. It said France has intervened to obtain the release of some people who were arrested and to try to make sure they were not physically mistreated. ``France asks the Haitian government urgently to re-establish the suspended provisions of the Constitution, to reverse the measures of detention and banishment of opposition leaders and to guarantee the restarting of an authentic election process,'' the statement said. When reporters asked Avril on Thursday when he would lift the state of siege, he frowned and said: ``It could be tomorrow.'' He commented after a brief ceremony at the National Palace in which Guy Mendes Binheiro Vaconcellos, the new Brazilian ambassador, presented his credentials. Avril also repeated his promise to hold elections, now scheduled for October. ``We are on the way to elections,'' he said, without elaborating. Critics accuse Avril of using the killing on Saturday of Col. Andre Neptune, his wife and a servant by unidentified assailants as a pretext to crack down on the opposition and renege on elections. Avril did not say whether seven prominent civic leaders and militants expelled since Saturday would be allowed to return if the state of siege is lifted. Rockefeller Guerre, head of the leftist Union of Patriotic Democrats Party and an outspoken critic of Avril, was reported missing by his wife. ``I haven't heard from my husband since Monday and I am worried because he always told me he would never go into hiding,'' Mrs. Guerre said in an interview. She said she thought he may have been arrested. Haiti received $154 million in international assistance in 1988, but had been the object of international ostracism since the Nov. 29, 1987, election-day massacre staged by thugs working with the army. The U.S. government cut off about two-thirds of its $90 million aid package after the 1987 massacre. Haiti still receives about $40 million in U.S. aid through numerous private voluntary organizations. To encourage the government's stated commitment to democracy, the U.S. government granted $10 million in free wheat under the Food for Peace Program last year. The United States also granted $500,000 to assist the Avril government in fighting drug smuggling.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Criticizes Moscow's Handling of Azerbaijan Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with confirmation of Moscow raid, more on opposition group; new material in grafs 2,7,8,18. Pickup 18th, ``In Baku...''
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Soviet parliament's opposition group condemned the government today for failing to quell ethnic violence in the Caucasus and for relying on force instead of more negotiations. Azerbaijani activists, meanwhile, said commandos raided the republic's mission in Moscow overnight and arrested a nationalist leader. A Moscow police spokesman confirmed the raid and said it was being investigated. A newspaper also reported today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was warned by two senior Soviet military leaders not to send troops into Azerbaijan just hours before the soldiers were deployed. Thirteen members of the Inter-Regional Group of progressive deputies in the Soviet Congress issued a declaration saying authorities took action ``too late'' in the simmering conflict between Azerbaijanis and Armenians. They proposed an emergency session of the Supreme Soviet, the government's standing legislature, to mediate the dispute, and called for a deadline for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Azerbaijan. The unrest and the government's delayed, armed reaction to it ``represent a threat to perestroika,'' the Kremlin's program of reforms, deputy Sergei Stankevich said. The opposition group claims about 400 members of the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies. Its leaders include reformer Boris N. Yeltsin, who was not at the news conference, and historian Yuri N. Afanasyev. It was created largely under the inspiration of late Nobel-Prize-winning, human rights advocate Andrei D. Sakharov. Although the group represents a clear minority in the Congress, its initiatives occasionally have won majority support. The group's declaration said the Azerbaijani government was at fault for losing people' trust, and added: ``We are categorically against the use of force for the artifical preservation of such regimes.'' Soviet troops moved into the Azerbaijani capital, Baku, on Saturday to quell the nationalist uprising and attacks on Armenians there. The violence was the culmination of a two-year dispute between mainly Christian Armenians and Moslem Azerbaijanis over their respective claims to Nagorno-Karabakh, an Azerbaijani enclave populated mainly by ethnic Armenians. The dispute has fueled the independence movements in the neighboring Soviet republics, which are among several seeking automony from Moscow. Two senior Soviet officers in Baku warned hours before Gorbachev sent troops to Azerbaijan that an assault would turn the population against the army and ethnic Russians, a newspaper reported today. The two Afghan war veterans said in a telegram sent Jan. 19 that bringing in troops would lead ``to a total break in relations and put their families in danger,'' as well as ``creating a growth in the anti-Russian mood.'' That same night, Soviet troops raided the Azerbaijani capital. By latest count, 101 people have died since then, and more than 171 overall in the unrest that began with anti-Armenian attacks in Baku two weeks ago. The dangers predicted by Cols. A. Savelyev and A. Rusakov, top officials in a Baku military academy, have been realized and more than 30,000 family members of Soviet soldiers have had to be evacuated, said the youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. Meanwhile, Azerbaijani activists said today that police twice raided the Azerbaijani government's building in Moscow during the night and arrested a leader of the nationalist Azerbaijani People's Front, Ekhtibar Mamedov. Moscow Deputy Police Chief Lev Belyansky confirmed the raid but said he would give no more information until the investigation was done, Tass reported. Activist Shain Gajiyev said commandos charged into the government mission at 3 a.m., searched it and herded about 40 Azerbaijani men into buses. He said all were released except Mamedov, who has gained attention recently by pushing Azerbaijani claims that there were far more people killed in the troops' assault on Baku than the official death toll. In Baku, military commandant Lt. Gen. Vladimir Dubinyak said today the situation was ``relatively calm,'' the Soviet news agency Tass reported. In the last 24 hours, 147 people had been detained in Baku either for breaking curfew or other violations, Tass said, and two newspapers were banned by military authorities. The agency said troops did not use weapons Thursday, but Komsomolskaya Pravda reported two people killed in Baku when an armored personnel carrier ran over a car. Shooting also continued around a barracks where, according to some reports, Azerbaijani troops are fighting Soviets. Military authorities denied Azerbaijani soldiers turned against the army. Komsomolskaya Pravda ventured some of the first criticism in the official Soviet press against the troops in Baku. It noted that dozens of people had been hospitalized with accidental shooting wounds blamed on the soldiers. ``We don't presume to advise the military, but after all, there are other means of `imposing order,''; it said. Strikes continued to paralyze much of Baku, but Soviet media said many stores had opened for the first time since the Jan. 20 assault. Azerbaijanis have pledged not to end their strikes until Soviet troops withdraw. A cease-fire agreed to Thursday by belligerents in the Azerbaijan's Nakhichevan region was being observed, said journalist Ashot Gazarian of the Armenian news agency Armenpress. He said Azerbaijan's rail blockade of Armenia was continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Ends Debate on Nationalizing Communist Property
DOC.TEXT: Parliament today heeded warnings to avoid vindictiveness and dropped consideration of a law that would have allowed the government to take control of the Communist Party's considerable wealth. The Sejm, or Parliament, voted 246-29 to withdraw the draft law, which was submitted by legislators who advocated radical moves to regain for the national treasury the buildings, companies, cars and other property amassed by the Communists during four decades of rule. Communist Party buildings in several cities have been occupied by members of the public who want to regain the property. The occupiers, often young members of radical opposition groups, have demanded that the property be given to universities or other public use.
