Aleksander Hall, the Cabinet minister responsible for political parties, denounced such action. ``We will not build a democratic Poland, we will not build a democratic state, if the law is not the law,'' Hall said. He told legislators that accepting the draft law would be ``reminiscent of the road chosen by Communists after World War II.'' The prime minister of the Solidarity-led government, Taduesz Mazowiecki, urged that the temptation for revenge be rejected. The status of the wealth now will be decided by a commission established by Mazowiecki. The commission met for the first time Thursday and elicited a promise from the Communist Party's Central Committee to submit a list of holdings by mid-February. Nearly 100 Solidarity members of Parliament had sponsored the draft law to reclaim Communist Party holdings, but most withdrew their backing after a lengthy caucus meeting Wednesday. Deputy Zygmunt Lupina said Thursday most deputies accepted arguments presented by Hall during the caucus and bowed to the prime minister's position that the question should be resolved in a more orderly fashion. The Communists reacted to the draft law with a barrage of commentaries in their daily newspaper and speeches contending they were being unfairly attacked. ``The problem of party assets should be solved in a reasonable way, not by robbery,'' First Secretary Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski said Tuesday. Communist leaders have said they want to find new ways to use their buildings and other property to support the party. They said ownership disputes should be resolved in court. Opponents contend many holdings are not legally owned by the party, which was able to accumulate property through its control of the government. The property issue came to the fore as the Communists prepared for the opening of their 11th national congress Saturday. The party, formally called the Polish United Workers Party, is expected to be revived under a new name and given a new platform as leaders try to find a place for it in Poland's democratic future. More than 40 years of Communist Party rule ended Aug. 23, 1989, when Parliament approved a Solidarity-led coalition government headed by Mazowiecki, a former opposition activist. The Communist Party in June lost control of the Parliament in the freest elections in the East bloc in more than four decades.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Appeals to Mayors to Support Drug-Fighting Strategy
DOC.TEXT: President Bush appealed to the nation's mayors today to support his drug-fighting strategy and said he would use ``the bully pulpit'' of the White House to ask Americans to volunteer money and time for the effort. One day after proposing a $1.1 billion increase in antidrug efforts, Bush said, ``I ask you to support our strategy to take back the streets from crime and drugs.'' Bush's address before a convention of the U.S. Conference of Mayors drew muted applause. Democrats have complained that Bush's package, totaling $10.6 billion, is not enough. The president said a recent poll demonstrates that Americans are willing to volunteer more than 500 million hours per week in antidrug efforts and $5 billion nationally. ``They want to serve. They want to give but they have to be asked before they can do either,'' Bush said. ``I promise I will use the bully pulpit to ask them to do both and I urge you to do the same thing. ... We need to get more involved. ``Together, let's defeat public enemy No. 1.'' Bush also renewed his call for mandatory prison terms for firearms offenses and expansion of the death penalty for drug-related crimes. ``Let's work together to stop the hooligans and the thugs,'' the president said. Bush also called for support for his proposals for child care, clean air, a capital gains tax cut, educational programs and efforts to help the homeless. While acknowledging differences with the mayors over spending levels, Bush said, ``The main thing is there is this willingness of the heart, among Democrats and Republicans, the White House and the mayors, a willingness to put aside partisan concerns. ``Let us sit down together and do what needs to be done to achieve the promise of America,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Most-Sought Panama Fugitive Detained
DOC.TEXT: A close associate of ousted military leader Manuel Antonio Noriega who topped the U.S. military's list of most-wanted fugitives in Panama has been detained, officials said today. American troops found Lt. Col. Luis ``Papo'' Cordova at a hotel Thursday night after receiving a tip from neighbors, said Bill Ormsbee, a U.S. Southern Command spokesman. After Noriega surrendered Jan. 3, Cordova became the fugitive most sought by U.S. troops that invaded Panama on Dec. 20 to capture Noriega and bring him to Miami to face federal drug charges. Another fugitive also was detained Thursday night, Ormsbee said by telephone today. He identified him as Romulo Escobar Bethancourt, who served as an adviser to a former Defense Forces chief, Gen. Omar Torrijos. Noriega inherited command of the military after Torrijos, who seized power in 1968, died in a plane crash in 1981. Ormsbee said law enforcement agents of the new Panamanian government participated in arresting both men. He said they were ``in custody'' but did not say if charges had been filed. Cordova was transit director in Noriega's now-dismantled Defense Forces. The new Panamanian government has accused him of involvement in the 1985 assassination of Noriega opponent Hugo Spadafora. All the high military officials in Noriega's government are under arrest at Fort Clayton, a U.S. military base. Southern Command sources have said that 60 Panamanians, most of them military officials, are being held.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Lobbied Senators for Bush Override
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates 2nd graf to say Nixon spoke with five senators, subs last graf with 2 grafs of detail from Taylor
DOC.TEXT: Former President Richard Nixon's long involvement in U.S.-Chinese relations extended to the congressional battle over the bill to allow Chinese students to remain in the United States. Nixon, whose dramatic trip to Beijing in 1972 reopened American ties with China, made telephone calls to five Republican senators asking them to sustain Bush's veto of the bill. The veto was upheld Thursday by a vote of 62-37, short of the two-thirds majority needed. Among those receiving calls from the 37th president was Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., who also was called by President Bush while on the phone with Nixon, said McCain's spokesman, Scott Celley. ``Yesterday afternoon he (Nixon) called the office and the senator returned his call,'' Celley said. He declined to discuss the details of the conversation. McCain voted to support Bush's override. Senate Minority Whip Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., said Nixon ``was involved'' in seeking support for Bush's veto. ``It's a very important issue to him,'' he said. ``He made two calls that I'm aware of and he furnished me some information.'' Nixon spent six days in Beijing last fall and said he had more than 20 hours of discussions with Chinese leaders. He said he gave the Bush administration an 18-page report on how to improve relations in the wake of Chinese government's brutal crackdown in June of pro-democracy dissidents. The former president discussed China ``in some detail'' with a group of senators and former senators that he met with at a dinner senators Robert Byrd, D-W.Va, and Bob Dole, R-Kan., had for him in December, Nixon aide John Taylor said. In the two days before the vote, Taylor said, Nixon spoke with five senators, all of whom he said voted against the veto override.

DOC.HEAD: Some Workers Honor Strike; Police Block Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with details on strikes, group protesting police crackdown, authorities blocking demonstrations. Pickup 6th, `We want'
DOC.TEXT: Workers stayed home in the restive province of Kosovo today after activists called a general strike to protest alleged mistreatment of ethnic Albanians. The state news agency Tanjug said work stoppages occurred in 20 Kosovo companies, including at the Stari Trg mine near Titova Mitrovica, 25 miles north of Pristina, and at Trepca mine near this provincial capital. Tanjug did not say how many workers were on strike. ``Swift police actions'' prevented hundreds of ethnic Albanians from staging protests in Titova Mitrovica, Podujevo and several other Kosovo towns, Tanjug said. Strikes and demonstrations at the Stari Trg and Trepca mines in January led to the arrest of Azem Vlasi, the region's former Communist leader, on charges of ``anti-revolutionary activity.'' He is being tried and could face a maximum penalty of death if convicted. Demonstrators in Kosovo have been demanding an end to alleged discrimination against the Albanian majority and free elections in the province. Meanwhile, an independent Kosovo human rights group issued a statement protesting what it termed ``brutal police action against innocent citizens'' who peacefully demonstrated in Pristina on Wednesday. The Committee for the Protection of Human Rights also demanded the lifting of a state of emergency in Kosovo, free elections and the release of hundreds of ethnic Albanian political prisoners. Up to 100 riot police guarded the local Communist Party headquarters in Pristina today and 500 Pristina University students gathered in front of their dormitories, under the watch of additional security forces. ``We want our legal rights, like all other people in Yugoslavia,'' a student, who refused to give his name, told journalists. ``We want a change of leadership, the release of all political prisoners and free elections.'' Police on Wednesday used a water cannon to disperse 40,000 ethnic Albanians demonstrating in front of the party headquarters against a state of emergency declared in the province. At least 28 people died in violence that occurred in the province last year, after constitutional changes that limited the region's autonomy and gave Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, near-total control over the region. Hundreds of ethnic Albanians, who make up about 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million population, were jailed in the police crackdown that followed the unrest. A partial state of emergency, which authorities assert is necessary to protect the Serbian minority in Kosovo, remains in force in the region. The student praised the Democratic Alliance of Kosovo, a newly formed political movement, saying it represented the interests of all people in Kosovo, both the majority Albanians and minority Serbs. Democratic Alliance leader Ibrahim Rugova claimed today that more than 100,000 people had joined his movement in the past month. Rugova said the group, which has been criticized by authorities as hostile and separatist, had applied for official registration and expected a reply by next week. He said the alliance was cooperating with other movements promoting human rights in the region, and he denied allegations by Serbian leaders that the movements were linked to opposition parties in Slovenia. ``Our demands were raised long before the Serbian-Slovenian split,'' Rugova noted, referring to ongoing tensions between the reformist province of Slovenia and Serbia, whose hard-line Communist leaders want to slow the pace of democratic reforms sought by the Slovenes. Slovenian Communists, backed by their Croatian counterparts, Monday split from the federal Communist Party, citing irreconcilable ideological differences, and leaving Serbian Communists in effective control of the party. Vlasi, Kosovo's former Communist leader, was arrested after conservative Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic charged that he had incited the miners to violence in the January 1989 strikes. International human rights organizations and the media in Yugoslavia's liberal northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia have claimed that human rights violations were common in Kosovo, and indicated that Serbian authorities were to blame.

DOC.HEAD: Black Muslim Shot by Deputy Mourned
DOC.TEXT: Mourners at a memorial service for a Black Muslim killed in a clash with sheriff's deputies called for an investigation into the man's death. ``We must say to Sheriff (Sherman) Block we demand justice in this matter, state Assemblywoman Maxine Waters told the crowd of about 400 at the First African Methodist Episcopal Church Thursday night. NFL Hall of Famer Jim Brown, City Councilman Nate Holden and homeless activist Ted Hayes also attended the service. Oliver Beasley, 27, was shot and killed early Tuesday by sheriff's deputies in the second confrontation this month between Black Muslims and authorities. In the incident, two deputies, one a trainee, pulled over 18-year-old David Hartley's car for a traffic violation near suburban Compton. Some men emerged from a nearby apartment and gathered around Hartley's car, sheriff's spokesmen said. The men, who like Hartley were Black Muslims, twice refused to go back inside the building and the deputies claimed they were jumped as they took Harley's arms to walk him back to their patrol car, the spokesmen said. One man disarmed the trainee, identified in news reports as Deputy David Dolson, 24. His partner, identified as Deputy William Tackaberry, 39, fired one shot, which did not hit anyone, sheriff's officials said. As the group retreated, one man still had Dolson's gun. The deputy drew a backup weapon and fired, striking Hartley in the shoulder and Beasley in the head, officials said. Khallid Muhammad, a special assistant to Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan, claimed sheriff's deputies began to beat Hartley when he refused to lie face down on the ground. ``We have a prayer position in which we go down on our knees and touch our forehead to the floor,'' he said. ``We don't bow down to anyone except Allah.'' Hartley, 18, pleaded innocent in Inglewood Municipal Court on Thursday to charges of attempting to take a gun from a peace officer, battery on a peace officer, and interfering with a peace officer. Four men and a teen-age boy who had been held in the incident were released because the deputies could not identify them, authorities said. On Jan. 3, two dozen officers and 13 Nation of Islam members clashed in southwest Los Angeles, with injuries on both sides. The confrontations have increased interest in a scheduled speech by Farrakhan on Feb. 2 at the Los Angeles Sports Arena.

DOC.HEAD: Undercover Probe of Cactus Thefts Nets Indictments against 21
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, ``Seventeen,'' to UPDATE with arrests up to 19.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one people accused of illegally collecting and selling protected cactus plants worth thousands of dollars have been indicted on federal charges as a result of a four-year undercover investigation. ``We live in a very fragile environment in Arizona, and we intend to do what we can to maintain that environment,'' U.S. Attorney Steven McNamee said. ``We intend to prosecute vigorously anyone involved in stealing cacti.'' The indictments alleged thousands of cacti _ primarily barrel cactus but also including towering saguaros, some hundreds of years old _ have been uprooted and stolen since 1986 from federal, state or private lands throughout Arizona. Healthy saguaros can sell for hundreds of dollars and prized ``crested'' plants sell for as much as $15,000. The saguaro cactus is not listed as endangered but is protected under Arizona's native plant law and under a federal law that prohibits the interstate trafficking of protected plants. It's also Arizona's state plant. Nineteen of the 21 people charged in the Fish and Wildlife Service investigation had been arrested as of early today. They were named in indictments issued Wednesday by federal grand juries in Phoenix and Tucson, officials said. Charges include theft of federal property, conspiracy and illegal interstate transportation of protected plants. The charges carry a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. ``This action demonstrates that the federal government takes very seriously its responsibility to protect plants,'' Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said in a statement issued in Washington. Lujan, who is from New Mexico, called the saguaro ``a cherished part of our Western landscape'' and said ``those who collect them illegally are stealing from the public for their own personal profit.'' ``People come from all over the world to see these giant saguaro cactus. This is a big part of our tourist industry, like the Grand Canyon,'' McNamee said. Investigators said the defendants allegedly removed saguaros from remote areas during the night and sold them to nurseries, development companies and collectors in Arizona, Kansas, Nevada, California and such foreign countries as Canada and Japan. The investigation was characterized as the largest federal case ever undertaken involving a protected plant. Fish and Wildlife agents, alerted to the cactus theft problem by Arizona officials several years ago, set up a phony business in suburban Scottsdale in 1986 and began posing as cactus dealers. ``We saw what we felt was a very flourishing business when we first started,'' said Richard Marks, the Fish and Wildlife Service agent who headed the investigation. The saguaros cactus is is protected by Arizona state law because it is highly vulnerable to damage by vandals and because the plants do not begin to reproduce until they are 50 to 75 years old. Officials said approximately 150 large saguaros, from 12 to 20 feet tall, and nine crested saguaros were sold to federal agents. Marks said it wasn't yet known what will happen to them. Cactuses legally obtained from public lands have a tag and a government seal. The Sonoran Desert in southern Arizona and Mexico is the only place saguaros grow naturally, Marks said.

DOC.HEAD: Avianca 707 Was 23 Years Old
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ``The number,'' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with 3 grafs background and Boeing detail.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Jetliner Down, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Avianca 707 that crashed in northern Long Island in New York with more than 140 people aboard was nearly 23 years old, Boeing Co. officials said. Jack Gamble of Boeing Commercial Airplanes said the plane, the 592nd of its kind made for commercial use, originally was delivered to Pan American World Airways on Jan. 30, 1967, and was transferred to Avianca on Feb. 25, 1977. Gamble said today the plane had 61,193 flight hours and 22,764 landings, ``neither one of which is very high for an aircraft of that age. What it indicates is that it has been used a lot for long-haul flight.'' Gamble did not know if the plane had recent problems. He said the investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board will get that information from the plane's maintenance log. Boeing sent a safety investigator, a pilot and a fuel systems expert to help the NTSB in its investigation, Gamble said. The flight, en route from Bogota, crashed in Cove Neck, N.Y., about 9:45 p.m. while on approach to Kennedy International Airport. Avianca has two 707s and two 720s, a 707 derivative, and may lease others, he added. Of 878 Boeing 707s delivered between 1955 and 1978, 454 were still in commercial use as of June, Gamble said. Another 122 models using the 707 airframe have been ordered for military uses, including the E-3 airborne warning and control systems; the E-6 Navy airborne communications plane and the C-135 military transport. The 707 was Boeing's first commercial jetliner. The first version, rolled out in May 1954 as the prototype Dash 80, was accepted in 1972 by the Smithsonian Institution as ``one of the 12 most significant aircraft of all time.'' The first order was placed in October 1955 by Pan Am, and the four-engine jet went into the airline's trans-Atlantic service on Oct. 26, 1958.

DOC.HEAD: Miliary Parade Celebrates Anniversary of Founding Republic
DOC.TEXT: Tanks, artillery guns, military regiments and children paraded in the capital Friday to celebrate the 40th anniversary of India becoming a republic. President Ramaswamy Venkataraman took the salute at the parade, which marched about 15 miles through the city from the Presidential Palace to the 16th century Red Fort. Visitors to the ceremony were frisked and were directed through metal detectors as authorities mounted stringent security measures to guard against possible attacks by Moslem or Sikh militants fighting for independence. Security men in plain clothes, mounted police and paramilitary commandos surrounded the gallery where Venkataraman, Prime Minister V.P. Singh and members of the Cabinet were seated. Massed bands, groups of tribal dancers and children doing rhythmic exercises followed the military section.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Drops Debate on Nationalizing Party Property
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted Friday to drop a volatile proposal to nationalize Communist Party wealth, bowing to the Solidarity-led government's argument that a commission should review the property's status. The Sejm voted 246-29 to accept the withdrawal of a draft law submitted by members who advocated radical moves to regain for the national treasury buildings, companies, cars and other assets amassed by the Communist Party in four decades of control. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who has warned against the temptation to take revenge on the Communists, had asked that the bill be withdrawn. Mazowiecki, the first non-Communist to lead a government in the East bloc, had ended public subsidies to political parties and banned the further sale or lease of state property to parties. But a potentially divisive public clamor grew when the government did not move to regain the Communists' holdings. Aleksander Hall, the Cabinet minister responsible for political parties, said nationalizing the Communist Party assets would be ``reminiscent of the road chosen by Communists after World War II.'' Addressing the lower house of parliament before the vote Friday, Hall criticized the occupations, mostly by students, of local Communist Party buildings in several cities nationwide. ``We will not build a democratic Poland, we will not build a democratic state, if the law is not the law,'' he said. The occupiers, often young members of radical opposition groups, have demanded that the property be given to universities or other public use. In some cities, the party has agreed while in others municipal commissions have been set up to decide the disputes. In a resolution adopted Friday, the Sejm approved of the national commission established by Mazowiecki while requiring monthly reports on the panel's progress. During the national commission's first meeting Thursday, the Communist Party Central Committee agreed to submit a tally of party property by Feb. 15. Nearly 100 Solidarity parliament members had sponsored the draft law to reclaim Communist Party holdings, but most withdrew their backing after a lengthy caucus Wednesday. Sejm Deputy Zygmunt Lupina said Friday the group agreed to drop the proposal at Mazowiecki's request. The Communists had reacted vigorously to the nationalization drive, calling it an ``attack'' that amounted to ``robbery.'' Party First Secretary Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski said a total takeover would deprive the reformed Communist Party of the means to survive. The property issue came to the fore as the Communists prepared to open their 11th national Congress Saturday. The Polish United Workers Party, as the party is formally known, is expected to be dissolved and reformed with a new name and program that leaders hope will salvage a place for it in Poland's democratic future. Without subsidies from the government budget, the Communists are counting on finding new ways to use their property to support the party.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Seek $4.8 Billion for Star Wars, Sources Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 16th graf, _Fort McClellan, with new closing report
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will propose increasing spending for the Strategic Defense Initiative to about $4.8 billion in fiscal 1991, despite Congress' success last year in slashing funds for Star Wars, say congressional sources. The budget total for SDI is about $1 billion more than last year when the Democratic-controlled Congress approved $3.8 billion for the anti-missile shield, marking the first decrease in the program since President Reagan introduced it six years ago. The fiscal 1991 budget total includes between $4.5 billion and $4.6 billion for the Pentagon work on Star Wars, congressional sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Thursday. Approximately $300 million more is earmarked for the Department of Energy and military construction. Lawmakers already are eyeing the SDI total as a ``cash cow'' for other programs, particularly as democracies emerge in Eastern Europe, lessening the Soviet threat to the West, and the budget deficit increases. President Bush will unveil his proposed budget Monday, spelling out the details in his State of the Union speech Wednesday. Congressional sources said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney would push for full-scale development of SDI that favors the ``brilliant pebbles'' plan, a system composed of many small ground- and space-based interceptors that would sense enemy ballistic missiles. The interceptors would ram the missiles, causing them to explode. A number of Democrats on Capitol Hill have instead supported long-term research on directed energy weapons. Cheney also is proposing a sweeping list of military base closures and reductions at home and overseas, just one year after Congress agreed to 86 base closings and five realignments, said Pentagon and congressional sources. Among the bases targeted are: _The Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, a shipbuilding and repair center that has 9,000 military and 20,000 civilian workers. _In California, the San Francisco's Treasure Island Naval Station, the Alameda Naval Air Station, the Oakland Naval Supply Center and the Oakland Naval Hospital, as well as the Long Beach Naval Shipyard. _The Army's Fort Monroe, a training center in Hampton, Va., reportedly was on the list. However, a spokesman for Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said today that the senator has been assured the site will not be closed. ``There are no significant base closures in Virginia, although there are several minor realignments,'' said spokesman Phil Smith. He said he had no information about the exact nature of those changes. _The Army's 2nd Armored Division at Fort Hood, Texas, would be disbanded under the plan. About 10,000 soldiers, one-fourth of Fort Hood's troop population, are connected with the armored division at the base, the largest military installation in the free world. Part of the division is stationed in Europe and Pentagon officials stressed that any reduction in forces there would be along the lines of superpower arms control reduction pacts. _Fort McClellan, Ala., would be closed in 1993 and its military police and chemical weapons schools relocated to other bases, according to members of the Alabama congressional delegation. _Fort Ord, Calif., would be closed, and the 7th Infantry Division stationed there would be transferred to Fort Lewis, Wash. _The 9th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis is slated to be sharply cut back. _Besides the reductions in Europe, several military installations in the Pacific are also on tap for closure, the sources said. Cheney is slated to formally unveil the list on Monday, but officials have already begun notifying congressional delegations of the proposed shutdowns and changes, congressional sources said. Sources warned that last-minute changes could be made, given the volatile political nature of the suggested cuts. Among the other budget proposals expected in Bush's fiscal 1991 plan is production of five B-2 stealth bombers. Last year, Congress approved funds for components for five of the radar-evading aircraft in fiscal 1991. The administration, however, will scale back the program, which initially had the Air Force acquiring 132 bombers at a cost of $70 billion, sources said. Over a three-year peak period for the bomber, the Pentagon proposed spending about $24 billion _ $7.8 billion in fiscal 1992, $8.4 billion in fiscal 1993 and $7.7 billion in fiscal 1994. Members of Congress told Pentagon officials last year that the likelihood of one program receiving that amount of money in a single year was slim. A rancorous fight is expected on Capitol Hill over spending for the bat-winged plane. Sources said they expect Bush to continue spending for two land-based nuclear missiles _ the multiple-warhead, rail-garrison MX and the single-warhead Midgetman. Among the other budget proposals are cancellation of the M-1 tank after this year, the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft and the Apache helicopter. The proposal also calls for mothballing the battleships USS Iowa and the USS New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: East German Leader Offers Israeli Ties, Meets Waldheim
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to CORRECT that East Germany has never had ties with Israel. Pickup 6th pvs, `Modrow spoke...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany said today that his country wants to establish diplomatic relations with Israel and is prepared to discuss reparations for Nazi victims. East Germany has never had full diplomatic relations with Israel because it refused to accept any responsibility for the Holocaust. But Modrow told a news conference after meeting with Austrian leaders that East Germany had proposed negotiations on establishing ties. ``There will probably be negotiations and the problem of reparation will be aired,'' he told reporters asking about ties with Israel, now being revived throughout East Europe as more liberal governments take over from orthdox Communist regimes. Unlike West Germany, East Germany has refused to pay reparations for Nazi atrocities and confiscations, claiming that its people constituted the anti-Nazi resistance during the war and bore no responsibility for Hitler's actions. Other Eastern Europe nations that had ties with Israel broke them off after the 1967 Arab-Israeli War. Romania was the only nation with ties that refused to sever relations. Modrow spoke of the possibility of resuming ties with Israel hours before paying a formal call on Austrian President Kurt Waldheim, who is criticized by Israelis and Jews worldwide for concealing his past as a soldier in the German army in the Balkans in World War II. A panel of historians appointed by the Austrian government issued a February 1988 report that presented no evidence to clearly back allegations Waldheim committed atrocities. But it said he was ``in close proximity'' to some Nazi atrocities, knew they were going on and made no attempt to prevent them. Modrow, a respected Communist reformer chosen to lead a provisional government after massive protests ousted the hard-line regime last year, faces serious problems at home. A worsening economy, the continued exodus of his citizens to the West and growing dissent among opposition groups have threatened the fragile stability of the country. Asked about his problems at home, Modrow refused to specify that he would quit the ruling Communist Party, as some opposition groups have demanded. The Communists have promised to hold free elections on May 6. Modrow said he was prepared to discuss his position with the party once he has succeeded in building a coalition government that includes the opposition. Modrow also criticized the revamped Communist Party for being too slow in moving away from its Stalinist past and the abuses of Erich Honecker's corrupt rule. Modrow, who will visit Moscow on Tuesday for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, faced a new crisis of confidence at home today following the announcement by one of the four small parties governing with the dominant Communists that it will pull its three ministers out of the 27-member Cabinet. The small Christian Democratic Union said it made the move to indicate to the opposition and other parties that the three ministerial posts it held were free for distribution to any other group. Modrow said he shared that view and stressed that he was making a ``fair offer'' of a coalition to East Germany's emerging opposition groups, who are divided over whether to join any Modrow-led cabinet. The East German premier held talks today with Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, with the two agreeing to a three-month experiment in lifting visa requirements for citizens of each country.

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Bases to be Closed In Greece
DOC.TEXT: The United States will close two of its four major military installations in Greece, political party leaders said today. The disclosure came after leaders of the three parties that support the coalition government met with Premier Xenophon Zolotas. Constantine Mitsotakis, leader of the conservative New Democracy grouping, confirmed a report by Athens newspaper Ethnos that U.S. envoy to Athens Michael Sotirhos advised the Greeks on Thursday of the U.S. decision to shut the bases. Panhellenic Socialist Movement leader Andreas Papandreou told reporters that Zolotas had discussed the U.S. advisory at their meeting. Communist Party chief Harilaos Florakis told reporters that if the bases were closed it would be a ``significant development.'' The Ethnos report said that Sotirhos passed on a letter from U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney to his Greek counterpart Tzannis Tzannetakis. The letter said that Hellinikon Air Base, which is adjacent to Athens International Airport, and the U.S. Navy communications station at Nea Makri, 20 miles southeast of the capital, would be removed. The closure of the bases is considered part of the U.S. Pentagon's plan to shut down dozens of military installations in the United States and abroad. Cheney is to present the Pentagon's defense budget proposal on Monday in Washington. This would leave two other major military installations in Greece _ a U.S. Air Force communications monitoring post and a refueling base for the Navy's 6th Fleet. Both are located on the island of Crete. The Hellenikon Air Base, which is used by reconnaisance aircraft to shadow Soviet fleet movements in the Mediterranean, is also a support unit for U.S. bases in Turkey. The Nea Makri station monitors telephone traffic in the Mediterranean. In addition to the four major installations, there are 20 small U.S. radar and communications stations spread throughout the country. The bases were established in Greece through a Defense and Cooperation Agreement initialed in the mid-1950s which also granted Greece $350 million annually through military assistance programs. A five-year agreement covering the bases expired in December 1988. It gave the U.S. 17 months to dismantle the bases if no new accord were reached. Parliament is to debate a conservative-socialist proposal next month calling for a six-month extension on the May 21 deadline to remove property, personnel and materiel in order to give Greek-U.S. negotiators more time. After 17 rounds of fruitless negotiations both parties suspended talks before national elections last June. A short-lived conservative-Communist coalition put the bases issue on hold. Officials in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the decision to close Hellenikon and Nea Makri is unrelated to the talks on renewing the lease for U.S. bases in Greece. The Greeks had demanded that any new defense accord include a guarantee of assistance in case of aggression by NATO ally Turkey, which the U.S. has been reluctant in providing.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Hijacker To Seek Seat On Chattanooga City Council
DOC.TEXT: A man who served 13 years in prison on a 1970 air hijacking conviction and helped challenge the city government as racially discriminatory says he plans to run for a seat on the new City Council. Lorenzo Ervin Jr. said Thursday he is trying to get his full citizenship restored so he can qualify as a candidate in the May 1 election to replace the current City Commission. In Tennessee, people convicted of felonies and sentenced to prison are barred from public office unless a state circuit court has granted full rights of citizenship, said Hamilton County election registrar Steve Conrad. Ervin was one of 10 people who filed a federal lawsuit in 1987 successfully challenging the City Commission system as discriminatory to black voters. U.S. District Judge R. Allan Edgar ruled in August that blacks did not have a fair chance to be elected under the at-large system, and last week he approved a new government consisting of a mayor and a nine-district council. Ervin announced his plans to run for a council seat in a letter to Gerald W. Jones of the Civil Rights Division of U.S. Department of Justice. Citing what he called a history of unfair elections in Chattanooga, Ervin asked the Justice Department to assign federal election monitors to the May 1 election. In a deposition filed with the voting rights lawsuit, Ervin testified he was convicted of two counts of air piracy and kidnapping in 1970 for boarding an Eastern Airlines jet in Atlanta and forcing the crew at gunpoint to fly to Cuba. Cuban authorities arrested him and sent him to Czechoslovakia, and eventually he was brought back to the United States, where he was convicted and sentenced to two life terms in prison. Ten years were added to that sentence for his participation in a prison riot, Ervin said, but he was paroled in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Police Bar Protests as English Cricket Team Begins Match
DOC.TEXT: Police set up roadblocks and arrested 31 black youths today to prevent protests at a stadium where an English cricket team defying a ban on sports contacts with South Africa played a match. Witnesses said activists ran through the mining city of Kimberley breaking car and shop windows after police barred them from demonstrating at the stadium. Hundreds of demonstrators attempted to protest outside the De Beers Club stadium where the match was being played, but police set up a roadblock about a half-mile from the stadium, witnesses said. Two busloads of protesters coming from the Johannesburg area were turned back by police. Protest leaders in Kimberley met with Ali Bacher, managing director of the South African Cricket Union, and demanded they be allowed to march on the stadium. Bacher, who organized the English tour, agreed to the demand. However, police still refused to allow the protesters near the stadium, where the English squad began a three-day match against players from two Cape Province teams. After the negotiations failed, witnesses said some protesters began running toward town carrying sticks and stones, and breaking windows along the way. Police dispersed the crowd at the roadblock and chased the demonstrators, witnesses said. Officers said 31 youths were arrested and that a 52-year-old man was injured by the protesters. Bacher, who has been seeking to minimize conflict related to the tour, later went to a local magistrate and obtained approval for a protest to be held outside the stadium Saturday. The English team is defying a ban on sports contacts with South Africa that was imposed to protest the country's policy of racial segregation. All the English players face expulsion from international cricket for five years for taking part in the tour. Activists have said they will stage protests throughout the six-week visit by the English team. There have been protests outside the hotels where the players have been staying in Johannesburg and Kimberley. Black hotel workers have refused to serve the British players and have demanded that other hotel guests produce identification showing they are not part of the team. The English players have not said how much they are being paid for the tour, but local newspapers have put the figure at $160,000 each.

DOC.HEAD: Burn Victim Advocate Seeks to Publish Letters by Man Who Burned Son
DOC.TEXT: Letters and an autobiography written by the man who set his 6-year-old son afire can provide insight into the minds of people who do such things, says a burn victims' advocate who wants to publish the writings. ``It's important to bring to the public's attention the problems that we're faced with here with child abuse, child abuse by burning,'' said Harry J. Gaynor, president of the National Burn Victim Foundation. Charles Rothenberg was paroled from a 13-year prison term in California on Wednesday. ``A world without fears has always been my dream. Son, I love you,'' Rothenberg wrote months after setting fire to his son. Gaynor said Thursday the book would consist of excerpts from 157 letters Rothenberg sent him, an autobiography Rothenberg wrote in prison and sections by a psychologist, pastor and Gaynor. All three interviewed Rothenberg for 10 hours in prison, Gaynor said. Rothenberg contacted the foundation in 1985 after seeing it mentioned on a television talk show and began his correspondence with Gaynor. Gaynor said a New York publisher he would not identify has expressed interest in the book. All proceeds from the book would go to the foundation's work, Gaynor said. The non-profit group, with a staff of six and $300,000 budget, coordinates transportation for burn victims and physicians, counsels victims, provides referrals, and trains health and social service professionals to detect child abuse by burning. Gaynor, a former electronics company executive, said he wants to publish the book to provide insight into what prompts adults to abuse children. ``If Charles had this book, or was knowledgeable about the problems he was having, perhaps, hopefully, he would have reached out for help,'' said Gaynor. ``God forbid'' the foundation should be considered an apologist for Rothenberg, Gaynor said. ``He is not the hero. It is David. We are not promoting Charles Rothenberg, we are telling his story and analyzing his story.'' Gaynor said the manuscript shows that Rothenberg wanted to hurt his wife, now Marie Hafdahl, more than his son. He said she has not answered his letters. ``I was ready, in some way, to commit suicide with David, to end it all, to get away from Marie's mouth and the years of verbal abuse that I could never understand,'' Rothenberg wrote. In letters Gaynor released Thursday, Rothenberg expresses remorse for his ``unforgivable act'' and said his ``mission is to help other parents' children who're abused and neglected.'' David, now 13 and still badly disfigured, said at a news conference Wednesday he wished his father could be jailed for life, and would never forgive him. California officials have kept Rothenberg's parole location a secret and have said he will be closely watched.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Encourages Residents to Buy Drugs
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff is encouraging residents to buy illegal drugs _ and promising them up to 25 percent of any money or assets seized from dealers they help arrest. ``I want people to realize they can make some really good money, depending on how much they cooperate,'' said Anderson County Sheriff Gene Taylor Taylor, who is putting some of his own money into a campaign to spread word about the program. Billboards scheduled to go up Feb. 2 will feature the slogan ``Need cash? Turn in a dope dealer.'' Participants may either work as buyers who testify in court or as confidential informants, although those who testify probably will be paid more, Taylor said. Security will be provided during drug transactions and informants won't face criminal charges for assisting in investigations. ``They'll be watched closely,'' he said. ``An officer would be within seconds of them.'' Taylor said his six narcotics agents are swamped and he needs more help with drug cases. The sheriff's program is modeled after one used by federal authorities that grant informants up to 25 percent of money or assets seized. The billboard program is a joint venture between the sheriff's office and Summey Outdoor Advertising Inc.. The company is donating space on 15 billboards and Taylor will spend $800 to $1,000 of his own money for the signs that go on the billboards. The sheriff said participants will be screened job and won't be paid until after the case has been cleared in court. ``I realize this program won't appeal to the majority of people in Anderson County,'' he said. ``This is for the person who really wants to get involved.'' The sheriff said he and Tim Ragen of the billboard company came up with the publicity idea after meeting Thursday. Ragen, who has been in Anderson several months, said he approached the sheriff about such a program after working with one on the Mississippi Gulf Coast. ``It was very successful,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Even China's Stern Police Drink in New Year
DOC.TEXT: Who says Chinese police don't like a good time? The eve of Lunar New Year, China's biggest festival, is the only day of the year that police are allowed to drink on the job. Those who patrol the streets around the Beijing Train Station joined the rest of the population Friday in saluting the Year of the Horse _ and commiserating on their hard lot. ``People say we have no feelings. That's an insult,'' said Zhao Guangheng, chief of the Train Station Police District. ``The requirements of our job are that we not show emotion, and we are always busy so we don't have much time with people. We are like thermoses _ the outside is cold and hard but inside is warm.'' Zhao, after giving a rare interview on crimefighting in one of Beijing's most heavily policed districts, invited foreign journalists to the station's Lunar New Year lunch and began passing around the ``white liquor'' _ 120-proof firewater. ``Ordinarily police can't drink on the job,'' he said after running from table to table to lift toasts. ``Even at home one can only drink a little _ it wouldn't do to get drunk.'' Most of the district's more than 200 police will be on duty throughout the four-day holiday weekend, Zhao said, including 40 who are undercover police. ``A policeman's life is a hard one, all over the world,'' he said with a sigh. ``We can't spend too much time with our families _ what if a crime was committed while you were resting at home?'' That's why the district decided to get its police together for a holiday lunch, he said, ``so everyone could display their warm feelings'' for a change during the lull between holiday crowds. Zhao said nearly 200,000 travelers passed through the station each of the days leading up to Friday, en route to family reunions. That's about double the normal passenger traffic. On Friday, by contrast, the station was so empty that uniformed and plainclothes police outnumbered travelers in the large lobby. The next rush will come on Monday and Tuesday, as holiday makers return home. Keeping illegal travelers out of Beijing is one of the main duties of Zhao's men, and patrols on Friday stopped passersby from time to time to check their identification. Chinese are required by law to carry a national ID card that shows where they are registered to live, and peasants seeking work in the city are quickly sent back home. Train station security was especially tight after June, when the government crushed massive pro-democracy protests in Beijing and other cities. But Zhang Shuquan, propaganda chief for the train district police station, said police have relaxed their checks of passengers more recently. A luggage X-ray machine that had been set up in the train station's entrance appeared to have been dismantled. Zhao's three-block district, which does not include inside the station, arrests an average of 500 people each year, he said. The crime rate dropped last year, and just four crimes have occurred so far this year, all thefts. One reason might be the citywide increase since June in patrols by plainclothes police. As the party progressed, a man in ordinary blue workman's clothes came in and sat down. ``Here is the head of our secret police,'' Zhao said. The man nodded and smiled. ``I've seen you around,'' he told the reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Innocent Pleas Entered for IRA Suspects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT Dundalk is in Ireland, sted Northern Ireland.
DOC.TEXT: A federal magistrate entered innocent pleas today for four suspected members of the Irish Republican Army accused of buying an anti-aircraft missile for a terrorist campaign in Northern Ireland. The four men refused to enter pleas and stood mute, prompting U.S. Magistrate Ann Vitunac to enter pleas in their behalf. A pretrial conference was scheduled for Feb. 28 in Fort Lauderdale. Kevin McKinley, 33, of Riviera Beach; Seamus Moley, 30, of Canada; Joseph McColgan, 39, of Dundalk, Ireland; and Sean McCann, 34, of Toronto, were arrested Jan. 12 by federal agents after the Stinger surface-to-air missile changed hands in an undercover sting. Prosecutors charge the defendants intended to use the missile against British military helicopters in Northern Ireland. Michael Dowd, a New York lawyer representing McKinley, was a co-counsel in a 1981 New York trial in which five suspected IRA terrorists were acquitted. He said attorneys for the four men are working for free. ``It's all about freedom,'' Dowd said. ``If you can't give your time for that, what can you give it for? This is very satisfying. It's better than money.'' The four defendants allegedly dealt with an undercover agent to buy the shoulder-fired missile for the militant Provisional IRA, a government affidavit said. They are charged with violating the Neutrality Act and the Arms Export Control Act. Each faces up to 38 years in prison if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Soused Sows? Neighbor Gives Booze to Pigs
DOC.TEXT: A man has been charged with trying to pickle his neighbor's porkers. Charles Myers, 19, of Canton, was in the Madison County Jail on Friday after giving whiskey and wine to a neighbor's hogs Saturday, said sheriff's investigator Carroll Phelps. Myers was arrested Sunday after Mattie Mae Randall accused him of giving the hogs the alcohol despite her pleas to stop, Phelps said. He threw whiskey on Randall and left only when she threatened to get her gun, she told authorities. Randall said Thursday her hogs apparently were unharmed and didn't appear drunk. ``I really don't know if it took effect on them or not,'' she said. Myers has been held in the jail since Sunday because of outstanding warrants on unrelated charges, authorities said. In the pig incident he was charged with trespassing, malicious mischief and three counts of simple assault, all misdemeanors.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Truck Stolen
DOC.TEXT: A thief stole a fire rescue truck from the scene of a fire, then apparently used the emergency radio to elude capture, authorities said. The vehicle was found, with a minor dent in the passenger door, in a parking lot more than four hours later, said Fire Department Capt. David Tolliver. No arrests have been made. ``Whoever had the truck listened to every move,'' Tolliver said. The truck was stolen Wednesday when two firefighters left it while investigating a small fire in a downtown apartment building. The truck, worth $10,000, contained $20,000 to $25,000 in equipment, Tolliver said. ``Who would have thought with two firemen and police in the building that someone would steal the vehicle?'' asked Tolliver. Firefighters are trained to leave the keys in the ignitions at fire scenes because they often need to move them in a hurry, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Durable Goods Orders Up for Second Straight Month
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for durable goods rose for the second consecutive month in December, the government said Friday in a report analysts said indicates the sluggish manufacturing economy is stabilizing. The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ increased 2.5 percent to a seasonally adjusted $133.5 billion in December after gaining 4.9 percent in November. But the manufacturing sluggishness through much of 1989 was reflected in the report's figures for the entire year: While orders were up 5.9 percent to $1.52 trillion, they advanced at their slowest pace since a 0.4 percent gain in 1986. Orders increased 10.9 percent in 1988. ``The durable goods report says there is a weak economy but hints at a slight firming in the industrial sector,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for The Boston Co. ``It (manufacturing) seems to be regaining its equilibrium,'' agreed Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for The Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``It doesn't seem to be spiraling down into a recession.'' Sinai also noted the volatility of the durable goods reports and said the two-month increase does not necessarily establish a trend. The pace of orders in 1989 ranged from November's 4.9 percent increase to a 4.5 percent decrease last May and often was affected by major one-time transportation and defense orders. Both Dederick and Sinai said the industrial economy remains weak and pointed out that if the transportation sector were excluded from the December report, total orders would have been unchanged from November. Indeed, the Commerce Department said the increase in orders last month was concentrated in the transportation sector, up 8.7 percent to $39.9 billion after a 10.6 percent gain in November. But this growth was in aircraft, shipbuilding and tanks, it explained, which more than offset a decline in motor vehicles. The automobile industry has been in a slump since sales incentives were removed when 1990-model cars were introduced in October, resulting in excessive inventories and widespread plant shutdowns. New orders for non-defense capital goods, often a barometer of business investment plants, jumped 18.6 percent to $46 billion after gaining 7.9 percent in November. The Commerce Department said the December increase was concentrated in the aircraft industry while the previous month's was shared by all of the categories. Orders for electrical machinery rose 1.6 percent to $22.1 billion after a 7.9 percent increase in November. But orders for non-electrical machinery, including computers and a wide variety of industrial equipment, slipped 4.3 percent to $21.7 billion after a 5.8 percent increase in November. Primary metals orders also were off, down 2.9 percent to $10.9 billion after a 2.2 percent gain the previous month. New orders for defense capital goods declined 29.2 percent to $8.1 billion after gaining 18.9 percent in November. Excluding defense, orders would have risen 5.5 percent. Shipments of durable goods in December slipped 0.2 percent to $122.9 billion after rising 1.1 percent in November.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Leader Says Azerbaijanis `Thirsty for Islam'
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Azerbaijan is ``a great market'' for Islam and Iran must exploit it before Western values can gain a foothold, an Iranian leader said Friday. Ayatollah Abdulkarim Musavi Ardebili, a former chief justice, said in a Friday prayer sermon it was urgent that Iran exert its influence with the predominantly Shiite Moslem population of the neighboring Soviet republic, Tehran radio reported. Strikes continued to paralyze transport in Baku, capital of Azerbaijan, on Friday but Soviet news media said many shops opened for the first time since the Red Army entered the city a week ago. More than 170 people have been killed since ethnic violence began Jan. 13 between Azerbaijanis and ethnic Armenians, most of whom are Christians. ``There is now a great market for the introduction of Islam,'' Ardebili said. ``Moslems are dutybound; I would like to say the issue is urgent. If we show complacency, the West will fill the vacuum: Western democracy, American morals, or even American economics.'' Ardebili said Soviet Azerbaijanis were ``thirsty for Islam. Therefore, it is a religious duty for us to respond to their requests through proper channels, before we even think of our own food, clothing, livelihood or medicine. Otherwise we will have to account to God.'' Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Ardebili also read a message addressed to Azerbaijani Moslems, in their own Turkic language, expressing condolences for the deaths of their loved ones. It quoted Ahmad Jannati, head of the Islamic Propagation Organization, as saying Soviet Moslems urgently needed religious books and a collection of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's sayings was being translated. Jannati's agency is in charge of exporting Khomeini's fundamentalist revolution. At the Tehran prayer meeting, Ardebili said the upheavals in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union were a ``miracle of history'' and described Communist governments as ``anti-God and anti-prophets.'' ``At present, communism has reached such a point that even seasoned and experienced Communists are ashamed to speak about it,'' he said, according to an IRNA dispatch. Ardebili, chief justice until August, is a member of the council appointed by Khomeini in 1988 to resolve differences between Parliament and the Council of Guardians, which reviews legislation. He also is on the five-man Supreme Judicial Council. The news agency said dozens of Azerbaijani Moslems crossed into Iran in the previous 24 hours despite frontier ``security measures,'' and hundreds who had been in Iran returned home.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ordered Washington Redskins owner Jack Kent Cooke to pay his ex-wife $29,000 a year to support the couple's 2-year-old daughter, far less than the $110,000 she had requested. a hotel and told they would be arrested, or even shot, if they stepped outside. In Muzaffarabad, Pakistan, Premier Sikander Hyat Khan of Pakistani Kashmir said he would launch a Moslem ``holy war'' unless the United Nations schedules a special session to address the Kashmir issue. Muzaffarabad is the capital of Pakistani Kashmir and near the cease-fire that has divided the region between India and Pakistan since 1947, when the subcontinent became independent of Britain and the two nations were created. India and Pakistan have fought four wars, three of them specifically over Kashmir. Most of the 5 million people in the Indian State of Jammu-Kashmir are Moslems. It is the only state with a Moslem majority in India, a predominantly Hindu nation. ``If the United Nations is not ready to play its role ... I will tell them to go and fight,'' Khan warned of the people in Pakistani Kashmir. He gave the world organization until Feb. 17 to schedule a special session. He said the deadline coincided with a scheduled meeting all Pakistani political and religious parties in Islamabad. Tariq Mahmood Butt, head of the student wing of the militant Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, said thousands of its members would cross the frontier Feb. 11 if the United Nations did not promise action. Indian state television described the situation in Jammu-Kashmir as ``by and large peaceful,'' but said at least nine people were killed Thursday when paramilitary troops fired on rioters in Handwara, 40 miles northwest of Srinagar. Troops in Srinagar tightened restrictions under the 24-hour curfew and prevented residents from opening windows, said witnesses reached by telephone. From various vantage points in Srinagar, a city of 1 million, only heavily armed troopers and an occasional government official could be seen on the streets. Several people reached by telephone from inside and outside Srinagar said they had not heard gunfire. Police sources in Jammu, winter capital of the state, said militants hurled a gasoline bomb at soldiers during house searches but no one was injured. The increased security coincided with the Moslem sabbath and Republic Day, which major towns and cities in India usually celebrate with military parades. Moslem separatists in Jammu-Kashmir, who want the state to be either independent or joined to Pakistan, declared the national holiday a ``black day.'' Television showed Jameel Qureshi, adviser to the Jammu-Kashmir state governor, taking the salute at a parade in Srinagar's Bakshi Stadium. No civilian spectators were shown and a policeman who was there said none attended. District magistrate Ghulam Abbas told about 20 journalists at the Hotel Broadway: ``If you go out of the hotel, you can be shot, and if we find out you have gone out, you can be imprisoned for six months.'' Soldiers with submachine guns were posted around the hotel, which is about a mile from downtown Srinagar. The door leading to the roof of the five-story building was locked and telephone service was halted after the warning by Abbas. Seven journalists returned to New Delhi on a commercial flight Friday afternoon. They said police took them to the Srinagar airport by a circuitous route one officer said was designed to skirt trouble. Police at the airport confiscated dozens of rolls of film, they said. The Moslem separatist campaign is as old as the two nations, but has escalated in recent weeks. Srinagar and surrounding towns were put under 24-hour curfew Saturday and soldiers and paramilitary troopers were deployed. Their number has not been released, but is known to be at least in the hundreds.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.BYLINE: Romanian Vice President Quits; Cites `Stalinist Methods' ^Eds: New thruout to ADD background on Mazilu's political career, activities in Ceausescu government and revolution; ADDS comments from ^By EDITH M. LEDERER
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dumitru Mazilu resigned today and cited ``Stalinist methods'' he said are being used by the governing National Salvation Front. ``Taking into account, with profound sorrow and deep distress, that the Stalinist methods and practices are maintained ... I resign from my position, which, as you may remember, I stated from the first day that I did not want,'' Mazilu said. Mazilu, who once was a colonel in Nicolae Ceausescu's dreaded secret police force, fell from favor in the government after writing a report for a U.N. commission that described ``nightmarish'' conditions in Romania. He became one of Ceausescu's most outspoken critics during the December revolution that led to the dictator's ouster. ``I am convinced that those who have carried out the revolution will never accept that it be taken over by people who haven't given anything of themselves to it,'' Mazilu said. ``Wholeheartedly I remain on the people's side. I shall forever remain devoted to democracy, freedom and ideals of dignity, which have inspired the youth of the country in its fight against tyranny,'' he said. ``I shall never forget their sacrifices.'' Critics have demanded that the entire National Salvation Front step down, in large part because of its decision to compete in national elections in May. Opponents say the Front cannot fairly take part in an election that it also administers, and some fear the Front wants a return to one-party rule in Romania. The Front has been governing Romania by decree since Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22. On Thursday night, the Front president, Ion lliescu, went on national television to defend the governing body against growing criticism. He denied it did anything wrong in deciding to compete in the elections May 20 and added: ``It would have been absurd ... for the Front, as the engine of national stabilization and recovery, not to participate in the elections.'' In an indication of the power struggle Romania faces in coming months, Iliescu accused three revived political parties of irresponsibility for demanding the Front stop governing if it enters the elections. Iliescu also countered complaints about Communist holdovers in the new leadership by charging that unidentified figures in some emerging political parties and some ``biting'' journalists had also been Communists. Virtually every professional in Romania had to be a party member to hold any rank in Ceausescu's time, thus many journalists and government figures who are prominent now were once Communists. ``For all its weakness and shortcomings, the National Salvation Front is the only structure, very frail still, that bears the brunt,'' Iliescu said. ``The collapse of this structure means pushing the country into chaos.'' Senior Communists who fell from Ceausescu's favor to become prominent in the Front include Iliescu, Mazilu and foreign affairs expert Silviu Brucan. The Front also includes non-Communists. Hundreds of people demonstrated against the Front outside its headquarters in Bucharest on Wednesday and Thursday before being dispersed by soldiers and police. No injuries were reported, but the Front responded by restating its Jan. 3 decree outlawing street protests unless authorized by police. On Jan. 12, an angry mob chanted ``Death to the Communists!'' outside the Front headquarters, prompting Iliescu to outlaw the Communist Party. But he retracted that decision. During the Jan. 12 protest, Mazilu joined in the anti-Communist chants and came under fire from some Front members because of it. Mazilu got in trouble with the Ceausescu regime when he was asked by the U.N. Commission on Human Rights in Geneva in 1986 to write a report on human rights and youth. He was never allowed back to Switzerland from Romania. His report, which almost exclusively focused on what he termed ``nightmarish'' conditions in Romania, was smuggled out and made public in Geneva last August. When his past as a secret police colonel was disclosed in a newspaper report after the revolution, Mazilu ignored calls for his resignation and was defended by other Front leaders. In another development today, Manea Manescu, a former Ceausescu associate facing trial, said in an interview that he was only a ``simple executioner of orders'' and regretted he had not tried to prevent the thousands of deaths in last month's revolution. Manescu was a member of the ruling Politburo under Ceausescu. He said the dictator would never have surrendered power peacefully and added that ``the revolution by the Romanian people, led by generous and courageous youth, was the only alternative to the tyranny of the two,'' in reference to the dictator and his wife, Elena. The two were executed by firing squad Dec. 25 after a military tribunal convicted them of genocide and ruining the nation's economy. Manescu's trial is scheduled to begin Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Major U.S. Crashes During Past 10 Years
With AM-Jetliner Crash
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of major U.S. plane crashes in the past decade: Oct. 28, 1989, Aloha IslandAir commuter plane crashes in Hawaii, killing 20, including 10 students and educators from one school. July 19, 1989, United Air Lines DC-10 crashes while attempting an emergency landing at Sioux City, Iowa, killing 112 of the 296 people aboard. Aug. 31, 1988, Delta Airlines Boeing 727 crashes and burns on takeoff at Dallas Fort-Worth Airport. Fourteen people died and 95 survived. Dec. 7, 1987, Pacific Southwest BAe 146 jet crashes near Paso Robles, 175 miles northwest of Los Angeles, 43 killed. Gunfire was heard on the ``black box'' cockpit recorder and authorities believe a vengeful ex-employee of PSA's parent company caused the crash. Nov. 15, 1987, Continental Airlines DC-9, crashes on takeoff at Stapleton International Airport, Denver, 28 killed. Aug. 16, 1987, Northwest Airlines MD-80, crashes on takeoff at Detroit Metropolitan Airport, 156 killed. A 4-year-old girl is the sole survivor. Aug. 31, 1986, Aeromexico DC-9, collides with small plane over Los Angeles suburb of Cerritos, 82 killed, including 15 on the ground. June 18, 1986, De Havilland Twin Otter plane and Bell 206 helicopter, both carrying sightseers, collide over Grand Canyon, 25 killed. Sept. 6, 1985, Midwest Express Airlines DC-9 crashes after takeoff from Milwaukee's Mitchell Field, 31 killed. Aug. 2, 1985, Delta Air Lines Lockheed L-1011 crashes at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, 137 killed. Jan. 21, 1985, chartered Galaxy prop-jet on gambling junket crashes after takeoff in Reno, Nev., 68 killed. July 9, 1982, Pan Am Boeing 727 crashes after takeoff in Kenner, La., 153 killed. Jan. 13, 1982, Air Florida Boeing 737 crashes after takeoff in Washington, D.C., 78 killed. June 2, 1983, Air Canada DC-9 catches fire in flight and lands at Greater Cincinnati International Airport, 23 killed. May 25, 1979, American Airlines DC-10 crashes after takeoff at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, 273 killed.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Common scents has convinced several students at Post Oak School in Houston that they need to recycle. Six students have been carrying around trash bags filled with their own garbage for a week as part of a science project designed to illustrate the growing solid waste crisis. Some were surprised at the load of trash they have accumulated. Seventh-grader Carlin Brady, 13, said Thursday that her cumbersome load ``is filled with everything not good for you or the environment. I'm surprised at how much trash one person can collect in one weekend.'' Students at the private school began the experiment last Saturday to kick off a symposium this weekend at the suburban Bellaire Civic Center called ``So You Want to Recycle?'' Miss Brady said she doesn't mind explaining why she's carrying the bag because ``it reminds people to recycle.'' But she admits that she didn't socialize much over the weekend. For those who did want to go out somewhere where a reeking bag of trash would be socially unacceptable, one could carry a small environmentally acceptable brown bag. When asked who had the stinkiest bag, the students quickly replied, ``Anthony!'' ``Yes, I will be glad to get rid of it,'' Anthony Tunis, 12, said shyly. ``There's a lot of stuff that can be recycled for money,'' he said. ``And we need to, so we can save the planet.''

A mock claim that French engineer Alexandre Gustave Eiffel stole the idea for his Paris tower from a structure in San Jose has been rejected by a judge. The just-for-fun legal debate City of San Jose vs. Paris probably failed to appease civic boosters in San Jose. In his decision Thursday, Justice Marcel Poche refused to rule if Eiffel, who was denounced as a crook, plagiarized the design of San Jose's 208-foot high electric light tower, which was passed off as resembling a clown's hat. Poche diplomatically ruled at the Court of Historical Inquiry that the case ``boils down to a situation where two creative individuals thousands of miles apart had similar ideas'' at about the same time. At issue was whether the 984-foot tall Eiffel Tower, erected for the International Exhibitin of 1889, imitated San Jose's ``Beacon of the West,'' built eight years before the symbol of Paris. San Jose's representative, Dean Gerald F. Uelmen of the Santa Clara University School of Law, alleged that the Eiffel Tower is a ``flimsy imitation'' of the San Jose tower built by J.J. Owen in 1881. Paris' representative, local attorney Jacques Dulin, retorted that he was shocked at the ``gall'' of San Jose and mocked its tower's ``poor clown's hat of a design.'' The ruling ended the fourth session of the court, which addresses controversies involving people and events of the past, producing often obscure and interesting historical detail. Of course, despite the mudslinging, all parties have fun along the way.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Outlines Energy Conservation Plans
DOC.TEXT: Dramatizing his point by helping install a high efficiency lighting fixture, a top Bush administration energy official Friday outlined energy conservation initiatives he said could save $32 billion by the year 2000. ``Americans are not wasteful by nature,'' W. Henson Moore, deputy secretary of energy, told a news conference. ``The record is good, but the record is not good enough.'' Moore said the initiatives being announced required an investment of $336 million in the next six years, including $30 million shifted from other Energy Department programs this year. The programs range from the use of more efficient lighting fixtures to exploring possible development of unused hydroelectric capacity at existing dam sites. Moore helped an electrician, Charles Jones, replace a part in a flourescent lighting fixture, one of 36 in the room where the news conference was held. He said it would increase the efficiency of the fixture by 25 percent, reducing its cost by $6.50 a year. The initiatives outlined at the news conference concentrate on increasing energy efficiency and using renewable energy resources. ``Using energy more efficiently under these initiatives will also avoid damage to the environment by an estimated 800 million tons of carbon dioxide, 2.3 million tons of sulphur oxides and 2.1 million tons of nitrogen oxides annually,'' Moore said. Moore said federal engineers and design specialists will identify federal buildings to refit with more advanced lighting technologies. He said the department would also explore ways to make it as profitable for electrical utilities to increase efficiency as to expand their capacity. The department will encourage states and localities to adopt the voluntary, interim standards the department has formulated for residential and commercial buildings, Moore said. He said the department will establish three new energy analysis and diagnostic centers per year at engineering schools until it has increased the current 13 centers to 40. The department also plans joint ventures with industry to demonstate advanced technologies for producing energy from waste, the deputy secretary said. ``A cooperative program with industry will be undertaken to reduce the time required to transfer technology from the research laboratory to the private sector from 10 to six years,'' he said. He said the department would work with the Department of Agrigculture and private companies in an effort to make ethanol fuels from non-food feedstocks a competitive alternative fuel by the year 2000. The department will speed up testing of a prototype for using concentrated solar energy to break down toxic chemicals into harmless byproducts in compliance with environmental standards, he said. Also part of the program is development of a laboratory for solar heat and other technologies in a government-owned building at the department's Solar Energy Research Institute in Golden, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Crashes of Boeing 707s in Recent Years
With AM-Jetliner Crash Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of some fatal crashes of Boeing 707s in recent years: _ Sept. 3, 1989, a Cubana de Aviacion charter crashed in a Havana suburb during a thunderstorm, killing 125 of 126 people aboard. _ March 21, 1989, a Transbrasil Airlines cargo flight crashed in a hillside slum of Guarulhos, Brazil, killing the 3 crew members and 15 on the ground and injuring 200. _ Feb. 8, 1989, charter owned by Independent Air Corp. of Smyrna, Tenn., crashed into Pico Alto mountain in the Azores, killing 144. _ Dec. 14, 1988, Nigerian cargo flight crashed near Luxor, Egypt, killing its eight crew members and one person on the ground. The plane, en route from Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania, to Brussels, Belgium, had been diverted to Luxor after being unable to land at Cairo for refueling due to bad weather. _ Oct. 17, 1988, Uganda Airlines flight crashed into houses and trees near Rome's main airport after three attempts to land in thick fog; 31 of 52 people aboard were killed. _ July 21, 1988, Angolan cargo flight crashed in bad weather while preparing to land in Lagos, Nigeria, killing its six crew members. _ Nov. 29, 1987, Korean Air flight crashed near the Thailand-Burma border, killing all 115 aboard; a bomb is suspected.

DOC.HEAD: Family Sues Navy Over Drowning of Recruit
DOC.TEXT: The Navy tried to cover up wrongdoing in the drowning of a recruit, the victim's family charged in one of two lawsuits seeking a total of $7 million from the government. The lawsuits, filed Thursday in U.S. District Court, stem from the 1988 death of Airman Recruit Lee Mirecki, 19, of Appleton, Wis., during a rescue drill at Pensacola Naval Air Station. Mirecki's mother, Elaine Kitowski, is seeking $5 million for wrongful death in one lawsuit. In the other, she is joined by Mirecki's two sisters and a brother in asking $2 million for severe emotional distress suffered allegedly because the Navy initially covered up wrongdoing by instructors. Kay Esty, a spokeswoman for the Naval Education and Training Command headquartered in Pensacola, said it would be inappropriate for the Navy to comment. In 1989 the family filed a $20 million administrative claim against the Navy, a required preliminary step before going to court. The Navy has neither accepted nor rejected the claim, so the family took the inaction as a denial, the lawsuits state. Mirecki suffered fear-induced heart failure before drowning in a swimming pool during training to become a rescue swimmer, according to court-martial testimony. Rescue swimmers jump from helicopters to aid downed fliers. One instructor, Petty Officer 2nd Class Michael Comb of Tucson, Ariz., was convicted of negligent homicide for forcing Mirecki's head under water. He was sentenced to 90 days in the brig. At a separate court-martial, Lt. Thomas Torchia of Princeton, Ill., the officer in charge of the Navy Rescue Swimmer School, was acquitted of dereliction of duty in the March 2, 1988, incident. Four other enlisted instructors received fines and reductions in rank for allegedly forcing Mirecki back into the pool after he had climbed out, shouting that he wanted to quit the voluntary training program. During the courts-martial, students testified they were ordered to face away and sing the national anthem while Comb dunked Mirecki. Relatives contend it was their persistence in questioning the circumstances of the death that led to investigations that confirmed it was not accidental. The Navy has denied any cover-up.

DOC.HEAD: Serious Business Shares Top Billing at Film Festival
DOC.TEXT: On its surface, the Sundance United States Film Festival is a laid-back celebration of creative cinema, but underneath the merriment lurks high-stakes dealing. Winning, and the momentum it generates, can spell the difference between obscurity and worldwide fame. ``The main intention of this festival isn't to get films sold but to showcase the best new independently made American films,'' said festival director Tony Safford. But it doesn't always work out that way. Selling is crucial. After taking the top prize last year for ``sex, lies and videotape,'' Steve Soderbergh returned to Park City this week to find that the landscape was changing: Independent movies were sparking the interest of accountants, not just film enthusiasts. ``I'm a little concerned by what `sex, lies' might have wrought here,'' Soderbergh said, ``that this can become more of a film market than a film festival.'' ``Sex, lies and videotape,'' costing $1.1 million, has made more than $24 million for Miramax Films. ``Roger & Me,'' a documentary costing $160,000, has collected $2.3 million so far for Warner Bros. With returns like that, it's not surprising that major studios are more interested than ever in snapping up distribution rights to independently made movies. ``It's a very complicated business right now because a lot of the independent distributors have gone out of business,'' said Caldecot Chubb, co-producer of ``To Sleep With Anger,'' debuting here. ``Warner Bros., Universal and 20th Century Fox all say they want to release 30 movies a year,'' Chubb said. ``Where are they going to get those films?'' Chubb is hopeful they'll come to him. ``To Sleep With Anger,'' starring Danny Glover, is looking for a distributor. The distribution problem is complicated by the success of a few booming independents like Miramax and New Line Cinema. ``Films those companies would have picked up two or three years ago are now too small for them,'' said Michael Spielberg, president of newcomer Monument Pictures.
