Some who come to the festival aren't interested in sales at all. Due to its pro-hunting tone, the only way writer-director George Butler could distribute his documentary ``In the Blood'' was by doing it himself. ``I had a tremendously difficult time making this movie,'' Butler said. ``The prejudice against hunting is so powerful in the film industry.'' Five years in the making, ``In the Blood'' was financed by and will be distributed through the contributions of 20 investors, including the hunting-wetland preservation group Ducks Unlimited.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Scheduling Fewer Cases for Arguments
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court is being choosier about what cases it reviews, and as a result the justices won't be on the bench as much this spring. An oral argument schedule for March, released Friday, shows 16 hours of sessions rather than the usual 24. The argument sessions, the public's only opportunity to see the court at work, usually are conducted six days each month for four hours a day. Each case is allotted one hour. The March argument schedule features four three-hour days, and two hours on each of two remaining days. In the past, some justices have complained about trying to squeeze too much work into the court's nine-month terms. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, in a recent speech, said a 1988 law that gave the court greater discretion over the cases it chooses to review ``is having a very beneficial impact on the court's selection of cases.'' Unless the court takes the unlikely step of giving expedited review to some cases in the interim, the April schedule also will be an abbreviated one _ with about the same number of cases argued as in March. Cases granted review from now through the end of the current term will be argued in the term that begins next October. The court in recent years granted review in about 150 of the some 5,000 cases reaching it annually. At its current pace, the court is likely to grant substantially fewer cases in its current term. Arguments in granted cases are conducted from October through April. The court generally announces decisions in each case argued during those months before taking its summer recess in late June or early July.

DOC.HEAD: Disciplinary Charges Brought Against 2 Lutheran Congregations
DOC.TEXT: Formal disciplinary charges have been lodged against two Lutheran congregations that violated church policy by ordaining three gay ministers who have refused to renounce sexual relations. St. Francis and First United congregations face punishment ranging from censure to expulsion from the Evangelical Lutheran Church in American for ``willfully disregarding'' membership requirements. The organization, the largest American Lutheran denomination, bans ordination of ``self-avowed, practicing homosexuals.'' The congregations have said they are prepared to accept expulsion. All three ministers, who were hired in November by their congregations, were removed from a list of ordainable clergy after they refused to agree to celibacy. The practice is often required of known homosexual pastors but not of heterosexual ones in the Lutheran tradition. Jeff Johnson, 27, was ordained Saturday as assistant pastor at First United, a working class congregation with no acknowledged homosexual members. Also Saturday, Ruth Frost, 42, and Phyllis Zillhart, 32, were ordained at St. Francis, near the predominantly gay Castro neighborhood. ``We find ourselves in a very unpleasant situation forced upon us by circumstance,'' said Synod Bishop Lyle Miller in a statement issued Friday. He had warned the congregations they faced possible expulsion. ``I very much support our church's ministry to and with gay and lesbian people. I have strived to maintain a pastoral relationship with these two congregations and continue to care for them,'' he added. A consultation team of three pastors and two lay people will be named to meet with the congregations. If the group cannot resolve the dispute, a 12-member disciplinary committee will review the charges. The Rev. John Frykman of First United said last week both congregations are prepared to accept expulsion if necessary. ``We see this as what God is asking us to do,'' he said. ``Our congregation felt this was a social justice issue, that gays are part of the rainbow coalition of God's creation.'' The dissident congregations have received support from some members and clergy in the 5.2 million-member Lutheran organization, formed by the merger of three smaller groups in 1988. Lutheran churches in some northern European countries have ordained so-called active homosexual ministers with approval from denomination leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet General Faints During Ship Tour
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet general fainted Friday while touring the USS Nassau with the Soviet Union's Independent Performing Band, Navy officials said. Maj. Gen. Nikolai M. Mikhaylov collapsed while the 91 band members were walking through the amphibious assault ship at the Norfolk Naval Base, said Atlantic Fleet spokeswoman Lt. Cmdr. Carrie Hartshorne. He was listed in stable condition at Portsmouth Naval Hospital. Ms. Hartshorne said Mikhaylov was conscious. ``Doctors are working on a diagnosis, and right now we are awaiting the arrival of officials from the Soviet Embassy in Washington,'' she said. The band has been on a tour of military bases, playing at a new base each night since Sunday. Ms. Hartshorne said Friday's night band performance at Hampton University would go on as scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Education Budget Will Lag Behind Inflation
With AM-Bush-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will propose a $24.6 billion education budget for 1991 on Monday that bolsters math and science initiatives while cutting the biggest loan program for college students, an official familiar with the plan said. The proposal, in an area Bush has called one of his priorities, represents a $500 million increase over this year's spending levels _ about half of what would be needed to keep abreast of inflation. The president will call for $1.8 billion in increases over 1990 levels in some programs and $1.3 billion in cuts in others for a net increase of $500 million, the official said on Thursday. The plan will be part of the $1.23 trillion budget for fiscal 1991 _ which begins Oct. 1 _ Bush unveils on Monday. The spending blueprint drew sour reviews Friday from several education lobbyists who complained that the increases did not go far enough and that the cuts should not be made. ``Overall it's an inadequate investment,'' said Gerald Morris, deputy director of legislation for the American Federation of Teachers, the nation's second-largest teachers' union. ``We think education in a lot of respects has been bled dry.'' Among the victims of Bush's cuts will be the Guaranteed Student Loan program, which will be pared by $500 million to a level of $3.3 billion. The program made 3.7 million loans to undergraduate and graduate students last year, making it the government's biggest student loan effort. Another $155 million will be slashed from the Perkins loan program for low-income college students, and $60 million more will be saved by eliminating federal grants that help states run their own student-aid efforts. The cuts angered Becky Timmons, director of congressional liaison for the American Council on Education, which represents colleges and universities. ``In my view, that's a step back to the time when only the sons and daughters of the privileged were encouraged to attend college,'' she said. Bush will also propose scaling back federal assistance to libraries from $140 million to $40 million. Two other programs for low-income students will be increased. Bush will ask lawmakers to increase the Pell Grants program, which provides money to low-income college students, by $473 million over the current $4.8 billion, enough to keep pace with inflation. Because the grants are financed in advance, the increase covers the school year that begins in the fall of 1991. But the budget will also say that because of across-the-board cuts included in this year's budget, the Pell Grants program will be cut next fall by $66.5 million, the official said. The document will state that as a result, about 14,000 students receiving awards averaging $200 will lose their grants, and 1.3 million other students will have their stipends cut by $50. The proposal will ask for $230 million _ $100 million more than this year _ for math and science programs. A $350 million increase will be sought for so-called Chapter One programs, which provide assistance to low-income public and private school students, raising that spending to $5.8 billion, the source said. Bush will renew his past proposals to spend $100 million for magnet schools, and another $225 million for schools that show improved student performance, no drug problems and lower dropout rates. Other increases will include a $50 million increase to $590 million for drug prevention and anti-abuse programs, and an $80 million increase, to $2.1 billion, for handicapped student aid. The president will also seek a $50 million increase, to $240 million, for adult education and literacy initiatives; near doubling, from $95 million to $175 million, of efforts to analyze the adequacy of education programs; and $70 million more for the Education Department's management budget, bringing it to $400 million. He will also ask for $25 million to train principals, and $20 million to assess the results of the meeting Bush held last September with the nation's governors to discuss education problems.

DOC.HEAD: Party's Break From Government Ripped by Rival Reformers
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's splintered pro-democracy groups agreed Friday to form a government with embattled Communist Premier Hans Modrow on the condition that all Cabinet members renounce their party loyalties. The surprise show of unity among the fractious political groups followed the announcement by Christian Democrats that they were pulling out of Modrow's 27-member Cabinet, presumably to distance themselves from the distrusted Communists and boost their election chances. East Germany's Christian Democratic Union is one of four small parties that stood by the Communists through their 40-year monopoly on power. One of the conditions set by the pro-democracy groups currently unrepresented in the government was that the officially recognized small parties join the coalition as well. Reform movements such as New Forum and Democratic Awakening do not want the official parties to escape responsibility for the disastrous state of the East German economy. In announcing the agreement to join Modrow's interim government, Wolfgang Ullmann of the Democracy Now movement said the various opposition forces would take part only if all Cabinet members agreed to give up their political affiliations until the May 6 elections. Ullmann said Modrow had been informed of their decision and was willing to meet with the groups on Sunday to discuss details of which ministries might be offered to the new groups. It was not immediately clear whether Modrow or the other ministers are willing to renounce their party affiliations, as demanded by the reform activists. Nor did the Christian Democrats indicate whether they would rejoin Modrow, although a show of solidarity would be likely if the other obstacles to a grand coalition can be overcome. West German politicians from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party had praised the Christian Democrat's decision to leave the East German leadership as a clear break with its Communist-aligned past. Until recent days, Modrow had enjoyed Bonn's endorsement as a caretaker leader pending the nation's first-ever free elections. But West Germans have become increasingly concerned about the hopeless outlook for East German recovery that is driving 2,000 East Germans to the West each day. Conservative politicians such as Kohl now appear eager to help an alternative force gain strength in East Germany. The many pro-democracy groups have proven themselves too unorganized to mount a serious campaign challenge, leaving many voters fearful the Communists could retain the leadership after the elections. The Christian Democrats resigned its three ministerial posts effective Feb. 9, pressuring Modrow to build a new government by then that would include the pro-democracy groups. The opposition politicians insisted their parties be given ministerial seats in order to gain experience in governing and to influence decisions that will affect the nation's future. Some groups opposed entering the government on the grounds that their participation could open them to blame for the nation's daunting problems. But after more than eight hours of negotiations Friday, Ullmann announced the parties had forged a united strategy. Modrow, a relatively respected Communist reformer, was chosen to lead after massive protests ousted the hard-line regime last year. But a worsening economy and the continued exodus of his people has brought a resurgence in dissent. The decision by Deputy Premier Lothar de Maiziere and two fellow Christian Democrats to pull out of Modrow's government was portrayed by the party as a way to allow the newer opposition groups to join the government. But the pullout also allowed the Christian Democrats to flee a sinking Communist ship. Steffen Reiche, whose Social Democratic Party has no representation in the government, called the Christian Democrats' departure ``the crowning irresponsibility of its 40-year service.'' Reiche was quoted by the official ADN news agency as saying his party would not accept Cabinet posts unless the Christian Democrats did likewise. In Vienna Friday for meetings with Austrian officials, Modrow told reporters he was making a ``fair offer'' of a coalition to East Germany's opposition groups. Modrow, also seeming to distance himself from the party, criticized the Communist Party for being too slow in moving away from its Stalinist past and the abuses of Erich Honecker's corrupt rule. Communists now hold 16 ministerial posts, the Liberal Democrats four, the Christian Democrats three, and the National Democrats and farmers' party two each.

DOC.HEAD: Father of Astronaut-Teacher Christa McAuliffe Dies at Age 67
DOC.TEXT: Edward C. Corrigan, father of Christa McAuliffe, the teacher-astronaut who along with six other crew members was killed in the Challenger space shuttle explosion four years ago, has died. He was 67. Corrigan died Thursday after a struggle against cancer. He also had fought to make sense of his daughter's death seconds after the space shuttle's lift-off ended in a fiery explosion. ``He missed Christa every day of his life,'' said Corrigan's wife of 42 years, Grace. ``We incorporated her in everything, because she was part of us. He spent the last four years doing what she had left undone.'' In recent years, Corrigan had traveled from Alaska to Jordan to deliver lectures on his daughter's behalf at school and scholarship dedications, fund-raisers and the annual Governor's Ski Invitational in New Hampshire. ``We all knew he was sick,'' said Harold Masterman, a founder of the Christa McAuliffe annual fund-raising scholarship dinner. ``I thought he was a very strong and courageous person. He had a great sense of humor, and he handled the tragedy very courageously,'' Masterman said. Corrigan, who was a retired accountant, is survived by his wife, two sons and two daughters. A funeral was scheduled Sunday, the fourth anniversary of his daughter's death.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Quits, Citing `Stalinism' in Interim Government
DOC.TEXT: BUCHAREST, Romaniasident Dumitru Mazilu resigned Friday because, he said, ``Stalinist methods'' are being used by the government that took over when the dictator Nicolae Ceause (AP) _ Vice Prescu was deposed and executed. Mazilu, who had been under pressure to quit because of ties he once had to to Ceausescu, made the announcement on Radio Free Europe. Also Thursday, Manea Manescu, one of the four Ceausescu henchmen facing trial Saturday, said in an interview he was only a ``simple executioner of orders.'' Manescu expressed regrets that he did not try to prevent the thousands of deaths in the uprising that ousted Ceausescu on Dec. 22. Ion Iliescu, president of the provisional government, has castigated critics of the decision by his governing National Salvation Front to run candidates in elections. Iliescu denied in a national television address that the Front ever said it would no' he said. On Saturday, the Front is to discuss financing, access to the media and a proposed electoral law with representatives of the 15 new and revived parties planning to contest the elections. Gheorghe Copil, an adviser to the head of the Peasants Party, accused the Front of being a ``destabilizing force'' and said his party had not decided whether to attend. The Peasants Party, Liberal Party and Social Democratic Party have demanded the Front resign and appoint an administration of all parties to govern until the elections. More than 300 students defied a ban on protests for a second night Friday and demonstrated outside Front headquarters demanding the resignation of its leadership. A double line of tanks and soldiers blocked their path to the the building, the former Foreign Ministry on Victory Square. Mazilu telephoned Radio Free Europe and read this statement of resignation: ``Taking account with profound sorrow and deep distress that the Stalinist methods and practices are maintained, that label are being still used based on security files and accusations imposed under threat, that the press is still directed to destroy some people and promote others, I resign from my position, which, as you may remember, I stated from the first day that I did not want. ``I am convinced that those who have carried out the revolution will never accept that it be taken over by people who haven't given anything of themselves to it. ``Wholeheartedly, I remain on the people's side. I shall forever remain devoted to democracy, freedom and ideals of dignity, which have inspired the youth of the country in its fight against tyranny. I shall never forget their sacrifices.'' In 1986, Mazilu was asked by the U.N. Commission on Human Rights in Geneva, of which he was a member, to write a report on human rights and youth in Romania. He was never allowed to return to Switzerland. His report, focusing on what he termed ``nightmarish'' conditions in Romania, was smuggled out and made public in Geneva last August. When his past as a colonel in Ceausescu's Securitate secret police was disclosed in a newspaper report after the revolution, Mazilu ignored calls for his resignation and was defended by other Front leaders. Silviu Brucan, the Front spokesman on foreign affairs, noted at a news conference Jan. 18 few other people in Ceausescu's Romania had the courage to speak out against the dictator's policies. Manescu, the former Ceausescu associate, was vice president of the State Council and a member of the ruling Communist Party Politburo. In an interview published Saturday by the daily Romania Libera, he was quoted as saying the dictator would never have surrendered power peacefully and ``the revolution by the Romanian people ... was the only alternative.'' Manescu's co-defendants are Emil Bobu, No. 3 in the regime behind Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, who were executed Dec. 25; former Interior Minister Tudor Polstelnicu, who was responsible for the Securitate, and Ion Dinca, another Politburo member.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Noriega Claims Status as POW under Geneva Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with judge denying bond, add details of letter to Bush, and to tighten. Picks up 12th graf, `A Noriega...'
DOC.TEXT: Deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega claimed status as a prisoner of war under the Geneva Convention and asked today to be moved to a neutral third country to avoid trial on U.S. drug charges. The claim was mailed to President Bush in a letter signed by Noriega, who listed his title as commander-in-chief of the Panamanian Defense Force. A copy was contained in a motion filed in federal court by defense attorney Frank Rubino. Rejecting the court's jurisdiction, Rubino said he would ``respectfully decline'' to participate in a scheduled pretrial detention hearing. But U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler ordered the hearing to continue. As expected, he denied bond, ruling that the defense had not rebutted the prosecution's contention that Noriega might flee the country if freed on bail. The hearing opened with Noriega appearing in uniform and Rubino reading his motion into the court record. The defense contended Noreiga, who was whisked out of Panama on Jan. 3 to face a 1988 drug indictment in Miami, was a political prisoner captured as the result of an illegal military invasion in violation of international conventions, treaties and accords. The motion recounted events leading up to Noriega's arrest outside the papal nunciature in Panama City, including American troops' use of high-intensity lights and loudspeakers playing rock 'n' roll music. The judge acknowledged receipt of the motion but called it untimely and said he would give the prosecution time to respond. The government, not the defense, demanded the bond hearing, concerned that failure to guarantee Noriega the opportunity could jeopardize their case in both the legal and political arenas. Rubino refused to ask for bond because Noriega does not recognize U.S. jurisdiction and, he said earlier, because ``I don't file motions I don't expect to win.'' A Noriega co-defendant won a small victory Thursday when a federal judge refused to order an immediate trial in a parallel indictment. Brian Alden Davidow was one of 15 people accused of cocaine trafficking in February 1988 along with Noriega. He also was indicted in a second case the same day. After two years of delays in the second indictment, Assistant U.S. Attorney Barbara Schwartz on Thursday asked for an immediate trial for Davidow, over the objections of his attorney, Richard Sharpstein. ``I think they're using this tool for leverage to make us more amenable to plea bargaining,'' Sharpstein told Chief U.S. District Judge James L. King. The judge said he was surprised by the U.S. attorney's decision to go ahead with the trial, and Ms. Schwartz's contention it would take only a few days. The judge said the original prosecutor told him the case would be complex. ``I was told it would be a preview of the Noriega case with the same witnesses and the same evidence,'' King said. The judge delayed Davidow's trial for several weeks until it was clear whether Noriega's trial would take place as scheduled March 5, and whether Davidow's case would be separated from the larger trial. Meanwhile, defense attorneys continued a barrage of motions aimed at forcing the government to turn over documents to be used against the Noriega defendants. An attorney for Noriega co-defendant Daniel Miranda, a pilot accused of flying laundered drug profits, has filed a separate motion asking that Hoeveler appoint an independent caretaker for evidence seized during last month's invasion of Panama. ``There have been reports of almost 50 tons of documents seized by the United States,'' wrote attorney Michael O'Kane. ``The government has shown that it cannot act responsibly to preserve these documents.'' And an attorney for another co-defendant, former Noriega aide and accused money-launderer Luis del Cid, has filed papers demanding immediate access to the evidence the government used in the original February 1988 drug-trafficking indictment. Prosecutors have sought to delay handing over evidence, arguing investigators must sift through thousands of documents seized during the invasion of Panama, but del Cid's lawyer Samuel Burstyn rejected that explanation. ``The fact that the government may develop further evidence which it would have a duty to tender in no way suspends its duty to furnish to the defense evidence that it already has in its possession,'' Burstyn wrote. The U.S. attorney's office refuses to comment on the motions until court hearings, said spokeswoman Diane Cossin.

DOC.HEAD: Citizen Protest Cuts Lucrative Shipments Of Foreign Waste
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Citizens angry about decades of environmental abuse forced authorities to curb imports of West German waste Friday and reassess East Germany's policy of accepting foreign garbage in return for hard currency. Since taking office two weeks ago, Environment Minister Peter Diederich had promised to cut the waste trade that he said has netted the nation nearly $590 million in badly needed foreign exchange in the past 15 years. But the government's hand was forced after area residents Thursday blocked sites at Schoeneiche and Vorketzin, south of Berlin in East Germany, where West Berlin and West Germany dump more than 1 million tons of garbage annually. West German environmentalists say about 100,000 tons of dangerous waste discarded each year for a decade have polluted groundwater at both landfills, where practically no ecological precautions have been taken. Diederich has called for Vorketzin to be closed but denied there is any danger for humans. East Germany, which previously knew virtually no environmental protest, was a discreet dumping ground for ever-rising mountains of garbage from highly industrialized West Germany. But since last fall's peaceful democratic revolution, East Germans have started railing against evidence of widespread pollution damage wrought under 40 years of Communist rule. That makes state-sponsored ``garbage tourism'' a rising problem for both Germanys at a time when they are working on ever-closer ties. ``East Germany cannot continue to offer garbage disposal for other countries as it has in the past,'' said Berthold Goeke, a West German Environment Ministry spokesman. ``That will increase the pressure on us,'' he said by telephone from Bonn. Friday's East German measures included an indefinite ban on West Berlin shipments of toxic waste, which includes paints, solvents, oils and asbestos-laced cement that the city is gradually scrapping. Also barred were West German exports of industrial and sewage sludge, the state-run news agency ADN said. Diederich urged the Foreign Trade Ministry to renegotiate the agreement governing that trade. West Berlin, an urban island in the midst of East Germany, trucks most of its waste to the surrounding countryside. The business is regulated by a 20-year contract running through 1994. Since East Germany opened the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9, officials from both sides of the city have launched talks on a costly dump cleanup and new ways to distribute West Berlin's garbage. West Germany and West Berlin account for more than 80 percent of East German garbage imports totaling 5.5 million tons a year, according to Diederich. East Germany also solicited dangerous waste from Switzerland, Austria, the Netherlands and Italy. For example, Switzerland, which has tough environmental laws, has trucked hundreds of tons of spent household batteries to East Germany annually. The batteries usually contain dangerous heavy metals such as mercury and zinc. But the money East Germany made seems likely to be dwarfed by the cost of any comprehensive cleanup and damage awards that citizens have begun demanding. Diederich's predecessor in the Communist-led Cabinet, Hans Reichelt, quit Jan. 9, citing his age of 65. Reichelt had been widely accused of failing to resist policies that have turned East Germany into one of Eastern Europe's most polluted countries. On Friday, Diederich announced the international environmental group Greenpeace has been given official approval to begin work in East Germany. A government commission called for five heavily polluting enterprises in the Leipzig area to be shut down by December 1991, three years ahead of schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Secluded Community Jolted by Plane Crash
With AM-Jetliner Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Paramedic Jeff Race didn't have enough time to be startled when a jet plane crashed a half mile from his home. Too many people needed help. ``There were bodies on top of bodies on top of bodies,'' said Race, 26, the first rescuer to reach the secluded wooded area where Avianca Flight 52 crashed Thursday night. ``People were screaming, `Help me, help me, help me.' Limbs were bent every way you can imagine. I just started pulling people from the wreckage,'' said Race. The wreckage was located off Tennis Court Road, the only road into and out of the affluent section of Long Island. Race borrowed a flashlight from a neighbor and pulled out six children while ambulances were called to the scene. Through several hours in the dark and drizzle, Race freed 12 more people. ``One guy pinned in the wreckage had a little boy next to him. He said, `Get the kid out first.' I'll never forget that,'' said the paramedic. ``I had to hold the flashlight strap in my teeth to carry another kid out. There were bodies all over the place _ outside the plane, and buried in the wreckage. It was all mangled metal, aluminum, steel, and wires,'' he said. Race, a New York City paramedic and volunteer member of the Oyster Bay Fire Company, spooned soup from a foam cup and munched cookies after his exhausting night. He stood in the rain in his Docksiders because he didn't have time to put on his fireman's boots. ``We're trained to prepare for the worst, but my first reaction was that this was a dream,'' Race said. ``I think it was a miracle for anybody on the plane to be alive,'' said Race. ``Hero? Everybody who was there was a hero.'' The plane crashed in a secluded hamlet of 400 residents that covers three square miles on Oyster Bay Harbor, which is part of Long Island Sound. Any new home requires four acres for a building permit. The parents of tennis pro John McEnroe have an estate here and a temporary morgue was set up on their lawn across from a private outdoor tennis court. Pop singer Billy Joel once owned a home here, and Race's parents live on a cottage that was once part of Theodore Roosevelt's estate. The ex-president is buried in nearby Sagamore Hill. The community's normal calm was pierced by a procession of wailing police cars and ambulances. Helicopters roared overhead and landed in the flare-lit zones to whisk away the injured. ``If anything looks like a war, this has got to be it,'' said Race. ``We couldn't get the live people out because they were buried under the dead people.'' The plane clipped a path through the tree line before it plowed into an embankment. Most of the passengers were still buckled in their seats. But Race said one woman's seat was thrown from the plane and perched on top the orange and white fuselage, while another woman had to pulled down from a tree. The airplane lay in three pieces. The cockpit section had broken off the deck on Sam Tissenbaum's home, and the tail section lay across the road just 100 yards from Rick Robinson's two story green cottage. Robinson, 53, was watching ``The Dave Thomas Comedy Show'' on television with his 79-year-old mother when he heard a disturbance and went out to investigate. ``It was a scraping noise, like a tree falling or a snowplow dragging along the road. I didn't hear any engine noise,'' said Robinson, a sports writer for the Oyster Bay Guardian. He returned to the house for a flashlight without realizing what had happened. ``A wire burst into flame and I could see the outline of the plane. I could just hear them feebly crying for help,'' said Robinson. ``It's amazing it didn't explode. It just crumpled. It's shocking how close it came to my house.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls on Mayors to Support His Anti-Drug Strategy
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked the nation's mayors to support his new anti-drug strategy Friday, but urban leaders voiced ``strong disagreement'' with his answers for drugs and other urban problems. Bush appealed to the U.S. Conference of Mayors one day after presenting his revised plan for fighting drugs, which adds $1.1 billion in federal spending but was criticized by mayors as too little. ``I ask you to support our strategy to take back the streets from crime and drugs,'' Bush said. Bush offered the mayors no specifics and no new initiatives on urban problems beyond the second phase of his drug program outlined a day earlier. He repeated his call for more private efforts, saying Americans are willing to help, and pledged to use his ``bully pulpit'' to ask for volunteers. ``Let's join hands to inspire the millions of Americans who want to help America get clean and stay clean,'' he said. ``Together, let's defeat public enemy No. 1.'' Bush's appearance at the conclusion of the big-city mayors' annual winter meeting was the first time an incumbent president has spoken to the overwhelmingly Democratic group since Jimmy Carter in 1980. Mayors interviewed after the speech said they appreciated the symbolic support his appearance provided but that he had offered the cities little. ``We certainly appreciate the fact the president showed up here today,'' said Boston Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, a Democrat. ``I think there is strong disagreement as to how to proceed to address some of the issues of urban America that have been ignored for such a long period of time.'' Mayor Kathyrn Whitmire of Houston, president of the conference and the elected leader of Bush's adopted hometown, said the size of Bush's drug proposal _ $10.6 billion _ was too small. ``We have not yet seen a level of commitment in line with the size of the problem,'' she said. Whitmire was invited by Bush to spend Friday night at the White House, and she said she hoped to use the opportunity to discuss her objections to the drug plan. Whitmire, a Democrat, said she was ``pleased'' Bush addressed urban problems in his speech and said it suggested his administration would be more receptive to the mayors than President Reagan was. ``I think his presence here indicates a little more willinginess to discuss those disagreements and see if something can be worked out,'' she said. Besides the size of the drug program, she said mayors object to the administration's insistence on routing aid to local governments through state governments, which mayors say don't pass along the full amount. She also said mayors want a commitment from Bush to provide enough money so that any drug abuser needing treatment can receive it. Bush told the mayors his drug proposal for education, treatment, interdiction and enforcement amounted to ``a 41 percent increase in outlays over the current year, and means a 69 percent increase in drug-related spending overall since our administration took office.'' Whitmire, however, said, ``the increase is there, but it is much smaller, generally below 10 percent.'' ``I like what he said about education,'' said Mayor Karen Vialle of Tacoma, Wash. ``But we need the bucks to do it.'' The mayors' meeting ended with some of the first indirect criticism of Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp that's been heard in public meetings of urban officials. Kemp, the former professional football player and congressman, was invited but did not attend the three-day meeting because he was attending Super Bowl-related events, said J. Thomas Cochrane, executive director of the conference of mayors. Several of Kemp's assistants engaged in a sometimes contentious debate with members of the mayors' housing and community development committee. Mayor Jessie M. Rattley of Newport News, Va., chairman of that panel, said later that the mayors were told by the HUD officials that mayors are ``really the cause of the problem'' in some of the scandal-plagued agency's programs, and that new accounting procedures in one program were to make the mayors ``accountable.'' ``As one mayor, I'm unwilling to accept that accusation,'' Rattley said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party, in Death Throes, Seeks Reincarnation at Congress
DOC.TEXT: Poland's beleaguered Communists begin a party congress Saturday at which they are expected to change their name, shed the old ideology and declare themselves champions of parliamentary democracy. They also intend to choose new leaders they hope can mold the new incarnation into the main left-wing party of Poland's new political spectrum. About 1,600 delegates will attend the 11th congress of the party, which ruled Poland from its founding in 1948 until the government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, led by Solidarity, took over last year. The congress will continue at least until Monday, and insiders say the party is in such disarray it is difficult to predict what will happen. Politburo member Janusz Reykowski said no one in the party advocates a split, but it is possible either orthodox Communists or extreme liberals may bolt and form their own group. Reykowski said in an interrview Thursday the party now claims 2 million members, but the new party will be much smaller. ``It is a necessity to lose a great majority of the members,'' he said. ``It is inevitable. ... The problem is rather what kind of people remain, whether those who remain are based on the old guard or are those oriented toward a completely new way of political activity.'' Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and Communist members of Parliament have expressed support for Tadeusz Fiszbach as leader of the new party. He is a former party chief in Gdansk, Walesa's hometown, who was dismissed because he opposed the imposition of martial law in December 1981. Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski, the current leader, said early in January he would be a candidate, but he appeared to be reconsidering this week because of arguments that only new leadership will give the party a chance. When asked at a news conference Friday whether he would seek the job, he replied: ``I don't have the answer to this question today.'' Reykowski, the Politburo member, said neither Rakowski nor Fiszbach would be chosen if delegates felt the time had come for a ``clear generational change.'' Possible candidates from the new generation are Slawomir Wiatr, founder of a liberal party faction called the 8th of July Movement, and Leszek Miller, a Rakowski loyalist and party secretary. The Communist Party, formally named the Polish United Workers Party, was created by a forced merger in Stalin's days of the Polish Workers Party and the Polish Socialist Party, a left-wing group founded in the 19th century that enjoyed broad support between the world wars. Now, the party says, it wants to shed its Communist identity and become a party of social democrats in the old Socialist tradition. A draft policy declaration to be presented to the congress harshly criticizes the past. It finds the party guilty of ``crimes committed during Stalinism, departing from democratic principles, conflicts with the working class, the impoverishment of the intelligentsia and the present economic and social crisis.'' On the other hand, it defends the ``patriotism'' and ``honest commitment'' of millions of party members and says Stalinism was imposed at a time of ``limited state sovereignty'' _ shorthand for Soviet domination in the 1940s and 1950s. The Communists' ``sources of strength and ability to regain popular trust have dwindled to the point of exhaustion,'' the resolution says. ``The time has come to build a new party of the left.'' Names being considered are: Socialist Party of Poland, Socialist Party of Working People, Social Democratic Party of Poland, Polish Party of Working People, Polish Party of the Socialist Left and Polish Labor Party. Parliamentary elections in June were an overwhelming victory for Solidarity, demonstrating the party's lack of popularity. Not one of the 100 freely contested Senate seats went to a party candidate. Senior party leaders running unopposed for Parliament seats on a ``national list'' were rejected by more than half the voters. Government funding ended when Mazowiecki's government took over in August, forcing the party to lay off many employees and seek new ways of raising money. Those included renting out office space and operating garages and driving schools. Fully democratic local elections scheduled for April probably will end party power in town and city halls, its last bastions. Grass roots pressure has grown for confiscation of the party's extensive property, which many Poles believe was acquired illegally during four decades of absolute power. Bureaucrats who enjoyed comfortable positions in state enterprises or institutions based on party affiliation fear the prospect of dismissal and see the property as their hedge against poverty.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Mayor Says Bush Pleased With Police Handling of Stuart Case
DOC.TEXT: Boston Mayor Ray Flynn got some praise for his police force's handling of the Stuart murder case in Boston from President Bush, the mayor said Friday. Flynn, a Democrat who has been a critic of the president, shared the platform with Bush when the president spoke to the U.S. Conference of Mayors meeting. Afterward, Flynn said Bush had spoken to him about the case and passed along praise for Boston Police Commissioner Francis ``Mickey'' Roache. ``He came up to me and said, `You tell Mickey Roache,' our police commissioner, `he's doing a wonderful job in that Stuart case and we're with him all the way,''' Flynn said. Boston's police force and Flynn have come under criticism for the initial reaction to the shooting death of a pregnant white woman, Carol Stuart, after leaving a childbirth class last October. Charles Stuart, her husband, suffered a gunshot wound in the stomach and said they were attacked by a black mugger. Authorities now say Stuart probably shot his wife and himself. He killed himself Jan. 4 as the purported scheme was coming to light. Flynn recalled the president's comments as he helped deliver the mayors' response to Bush's speech, saying he found Bush ``a very warm fellow'' although they disagreed on how to solve urban problems. ``I appreciate that,'' he said of Bush's comments. ``That's a nice thing to hear. That's the kind of person the president is. We respect him for it. But on the issues, substantively, there's a long way to go.'' Bush has been pleased by Boston's police before. During his 1988 campaign for president against Democrat Michael Dukakis, the governor of Massachusetts, Bush flew to the city to receive the endorsement of the Boston Police Patrolmen's Union. Flynn said the president told him he had tried to call the mayor at his home recently and spoke with Flynn's 9-year-old daughter. Flynn said he told Bush he never got the message, and joked that maybe his daughter didn't know who Bush was.

DOC.HEAD: President Will Ask More Money for Fish, Wildlife, Recreation
With AM-Bush-Budget,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's new budget proposals will include more money for fish, wildlife and recreation plus a cutback in timber sales, Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson told The Associated Press on Friday. ``When the president unveils his budget to the Congress on Monday, you're going to see a bigger shift in our programs than ever before in one year,'' Robertson said in an interview. ``And you're going to see increases in these programs that the forest supervisors ... are concerned about.'' Forest supervisors and others in the Agriculture Department agency have questioned the conduct of their basic mission, particularly as it relates to wildlife, ecology and the public's use of 156 national forests in 43 states, a total area equal to California, Oregon and Washington combined. Robertson did not provide details of the plan, but he added that ``you will see a lower timber target and expanded programs in fish, wildlife and recreation, and soil and water'' in fiscal 1991, which will begin Oct. 1. ``We're moving and we're changing the balance of our program,'' he said. ``But _ you know how Washington works _ you just can't do that overnight.'' Robertson commented just after a week-long quarterly meeting with regional foresters and research station directors, where he outlined some of the president's proposals, which need congressional approval, for the coming year. Complaints have smoldered for months about what forest supervisors perceive as a decline in the agency's multiple-use function, notably a concentration on timber production and sales at the expense of other programs. A November letter to Robertson supervisors in the Forest Service's Region 1 said there was ``growing concern that we have become an organization out of control.'' Region 1 includes Montana, northern Idaho, North Dakota and western South Dakota. Robertson said he did not consider the complaints as indicative of rebellion in the ranks of the agency and that debate has always been encouraged. ``I see that as a strength,'' he said. ``It may come across to the press or outside people as a big rebellion, but I see it as strength when we're able to talk about some of these things.'' One of the complaints has been that the Forest Service timber program has taken 35 percent of the agency's total budget for the last 20 years, compared with 2 percent to 3 percent each for recreation, fish and wildlife, and soil and water programs. ``That is true,'' Robertson said. ``It has been heavily oriented toward timber.'' But for some time, he added, the public has had a voice in Forest Service operations and has urged more attention to recreation and ecological programs. ``We now have forest plans out there that say we're going to do that'' Robertson said. ``The forest supervisors are experiencing some frustration. They've worked with the public in a forest plan, and we've said we're going to do that.'' But the federal budget for such changes tends to lag behind the plans. The task now, he said, is to ``rearrange our budget more in line with what the forest plans say we ought to do.'' Robertson said the changes and rearrangements come slowly, however, under the tight federal spending constraints now in place. ``You just don't turn that thing around overnight,'' he said. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, told the foresters Tuesday that the agency ``has not done enough to protect the environment'' and that, ``too often, it has given achieving timber harvest levels a higher priority than preserving the rest of the forest ecosystem.'' Robertson said Leahy's recommendation that the Forest Service work with a broader segment of Congress instead of pursuing parochial interests was well taken. Many issues, such as the endangered spotted owl and old-growth timber, ``are being nationalized'' by being of interest to a wide section of America, including Congress, he said. Asked to predict what may happen to Forest Service timber sales by the year 2000, Robertson said sales have ``kind of stabilized'' since rising in the 1960s and early 1970s. Now, he said, they are edging down and probably will continue to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Decries Hardships That Forced Emigration
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Friday decried the hardships that have forced hundreds of thousands of citizens of this African archipelago to emigrate to the United States and Europe. In a speech to tens of thousands of people gathered on a dirt soccer field, the pope said the former Portuguese colony had been ``greatly tried by suffering'' as a result of its harsh climate, scare natural resources and problems of hunger and malnutrition. ``In this situation, the lack of real prospects for the future lead many of your brothers and sisters to a forced emigration toward other nations and continents, with all the problems involved,'' he said on the second day of his eight-day, five-nation African tour. As a light rain fell in Cape Verde's cultural and economic capital on Sao Vicente Island, the pope said he understood the problems of trying to adjust to a new society without losing one's cultural identity. ``Who knows how many of those of you here haven't already had the difficult experience of having to leave your own land?'' he said, speaking in Portuguese. John Paul urged all institutions dealing with emigration to ``safeguard personal dignity (of emigrants) and favor their free and responsible participation in community and social life.'' While expressing understanding and solidarity with Cape Verdians living abroad, the pope urged them not to forget the country and the families they left behind. ``In finding bread and better living conditions in far away lands, never forget your native soil and the people who live there,'' he said. Up to 700,000 Cape Verdians _ nearly double the current population of 360,000 _ live and work abroad, mainly in the United States, Portugal, France, The Netherlands and Italy. There are an estimated 350,000 to 400,000 Cape Verdians in the United States mostly in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The biggest community is found in New Bedford, Mass. The Rev. Paulino Andrade, a Franciscan priest, attending the Mindelo service, said his sister moved to Massachusetts eight years ago and his two brothes were planning to join her soon. ``Life is better there,'' he said. ``There is more work and better salaries. There is no comparison to life here.'' Cape Verde's economy depends heavily on remittances from its emigrants, accounting for about 15 percent of the gross national product. The United States provides $6 million a year to Cape Verde, making it the second-highest recipient per capita of U.S. foreign aid in Africa after Egypt, diplomats said. The money finances projects to stop soil erosion, promote reforestation and encourage more foreign, private investment. The steady drizzle that lasted most of the day delighted Cape Verdians, who last year measured their total rainfall in minutes. Located in the sub-Saharan Sahel region 300 miles west of Senegal, the barren wind-swept islands are often prone to drought. After the Mindelo service the pope flew back to the capital Cidade da Praia to celebrate Mass on the Quebra Canela beach. As tens of thousands of faithful kneeled on the black volcanic sand and small fishing boats bobbed in the choppy bay he recalled the country's past as a slave-trading center and condemned ``every kind of discrimination.'' John Paul leaves Saturday for Guinea Bissau. His sixth trip to Africa will also take him to Mali, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Fighter Jet Crashes; Search For Pilot
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Marine Corps Harrier support fighter jet crashed Friday off Okinawa and a search has begun for its pilot, the U.S. military announced. The one-seat AV-8B Harrier aircraft was flying from Kadena Air Base on Okinawa Island to Osan Air Base in South Korea when it went down, according to the United States Forces, Japan. A search is under way for the pilot, whose name was withheld pending notification of relatives, the military said. Three Japanese coast guard patrol ships and a helicopter were sent to the scene near Iheijima Island, about 88 miles northeast of Naha, Okinawa, said a night duty officer of the Japan Maritime Safety Agency. The Japanese coast guard officer said the aircraft, which was flying in formation with another Harrier, crashed 23 miles northeast of Iheijima. The U.S. military said the USS St. Louis was diverted to the area to help in the search. Herbert Nakayoshi, a spokesman for the Marine Corps on Okinawa, said the Marines' Harriers in Japan are based in Iwakuni, in southwestern Japan, but regularly operate out of Kadena Air Base. The plane that crashed was assigned to Marine Attack Squadron 542 and based at Iwakuni on a six-month deployment program. The squadron's home base is at Cherry Point, N.C. The cause of the accident is under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Criticize Senate Bill
DOC.TEXT: Emission control and fuel efficiency standards in a Senate clean air bill would drive some dealers out of business and give consumers a drastically narrower selection of cars, automakers said Friday. In an unusual move, representatives of fiercely competitive domestic and foreign manufacturers held a joint news conference to criticize portions of the Senate bill that would set tougher anti-pollution requirements than President Bush recommended. The Senate standards also exceed what a pending House bill would require. The disputed provisions ``would have a devastating impact on the auto industry, its dealers, suppliers and employees, and perhaps most importantly on the customers we serve,'' said Helen O. Petrauskas, a Ford Motor Co. vice president and chairman of the Engineering Policy Committee of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. Represented at the news conference were the Big Three domestic automakers plus Honda, Volkswagen, and the Automobile Importers of America, which includes European and Asian manufacturers. A spokesman for the National Automobile Dealers Association also participated. Automakers have two primary objections to the Senate bill, on which floor debate began this week: _The Bush, House and Senate bills envision a roughly 3wed to U.S. banks. ``Brazil cannot be relegated to the confinement and the backwardness in which it is living today,'' Fernando Collor de Mello told a news conference in Washington. He said the Brazilian people can not pay a high price for solving the debt problem. ``We have to pursue economic growth as the sole way for Brazilians to solve their internal problems, ending the social injustice amd misery of millions of Brazilians who are hungry, that live in poverty, totally without hope,'' he said. ``We cannnot relinquish our economic growth.'' He said he would use the strategy proposed for debt reduction by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady or any other method of negotiation. Brady's ideas have brought agreement between Mexico, the Third World's second biggest debtor, and its creditor banks. Though the amount of reduction for Mexico is expected to be small, there will be a significant drop in the billions Mexico has been paying out every year as interest. Collor de Mello said he had discussed the debt situation with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III, along with environment and trade problems. He invited the heads of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the Interamerican Development Bank to dinner Friday night before continuing a round-the-world trip. Brazil, the biggest and most populous country in Latin America, has been struggling because of the debt problem. Inflation exceeds 1,700 percent a year, meaning that a given basket of goods will cost 17 times as much next January. Illiteracy is following the same pattern, up to 27 percent in 1988 from 25 percent in 1986. Collor de Mello, a conservative, last month won Brazil's first presidential election in 29 years, defeating leftist Luis Inacio Lula da Silva by a narrow margin.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Reject Illuminating the Matterhorn
DOC.TEXT: A project to illuminate the Matterhorn seems headed for official rejection after citizens came out strongly against it, officials said Friday. Engineer Herbert Schoettl had submitted to municipal authorities a proposal to instal laser projectors on two glaciers that, he said, would turn the famous mountain into a ``grandiose light sculpture.'' The project, according to Schoettl, would be an ``essential contribution to the festivities planned next year to mark the 700th anniversary'' of the Swiss Confederation. But it stirred little enthusiasm among Zermatters who argued that sun, moon and stars suffice as sources of light for the 14,700-foot ``horu,'' or ``horn'' as the peak is called locally. Ninety-nine percent of those present at a meeting Wednesday opposed the idea, according to one resident. Mayor Daniel Lauber was described as confident the final word from the communal council also would turn down the project. ``This would mean us inviting sensation tourism,'' a newspaper quoted him as saying. ``We have no need for that.''

DOC.HEAD: `Kung Hei Fat Choy' _ Asia Celebrates Lunar New Year
DOC.TEXT: With a deafening burst of fireworks and the gongs of an antique bell, Asians welcomed the Year of the Horse on Saturday after jamming airports, ferry terminals and train stations for the four-day getaway. Hong Kong's noisy street markets filled Friday with last-minute shoppers purchasing food, flowers, nuts and candy from merchants happily charging up to three times normal prices before the city shut down for the holiday. Family feasts on the eve of the Lunar New Year traditionally kick off the holiday, which for Chinese and Vietnamese is the most important festival of the year. In China, the Lunar New Year is known as the Spring Festival. The eve is the one day of the year Chinese police can drink alcohol on the job, and officers in the Beijing Train Station, long emptied of departing holiday travelers, toasted the holiday with 120-proof firewater during lunch. Fruits from temperate climates, such as oranges, bananas, and even kiwi, were brought into the capital to ensure bountiful feasts. Each lunar year is represented by one of 12 animals of the Chinese zodiacal calendar. The Year of the Snake gave way to the Year of the Horse at midnight Friday. As the clock struck 12, Beijing Mayor Chen Xitong revived an imperial tradition by striking the capital's 500-year-old bronze bell _ China's largest and heaviest _ 12 times. Nearby, a worker and a soldier beat two large, red drums atop Beijing's Drum Tower, but both the drums and the bell were drowned out by a cacophony of firecrackers that continued unbroken for about 15 minutes. In Taiwan, the new year was greeted with a barrage of firecrackers. Hong Kong forbids firecrackers but put on a spectacular fireworks display over its famed harbor. Buildings in the British colony were adorned with colorful New Year's greetings, and tangerine trees, narcissus and other plants considered auspicious adorned doorways. Hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people jammed the airport, ferry terminals and the Chinese border crossing as they left to visit relatives or take vacations. Most businesses closed Friday and will not reopen until Tuesday. The most popular New Year's greeting _ ``Kung Hei Fat Choy,'' which means congratulations and be prosperous _ will be repeated countless times, and children will receive ``lai see'' _ red packets stuffed with money. Hong Kong astrologer Andrew Yau predicted the coming year will bring more rainfall, some instability, and rising gold prices. After fluctuating for the first half of the year ``the gold price definitely will rise very much, perhaps more than 50 percent,'' Yau said. Both Yau and President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan predicted political instability, but for different reasons. Yau cited a complicated formula involving the Chinese calendar, while Lee looked to the upheaval in Eastern Europe. ``Several Communist authoritarian regimes were overthrown in the past year. We believe Chinese communists will face the same fate soon,'' Lee said. He said that as ``long as Chinese Communists exist and Chinese reunification problems remain unresolved, we will not enjoy real stability and security.'' Chinese Premier Li Peng and Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin were shown on television bringing holiday greetings to their nation at midnight Friday. The unusual appearance was part of an annual pre-recorded, four-hour New Year's Eve variety show, one of China's most-watched television shows. The leaders traveled to the provinces during the week to bring holiday greetings to workers and to thank soldiers for putting down last spring's pro-democracy movement. During a six-day tour of Shanxi province, in northern China, Jiang said socialism will triumph in China if ``we learn from (their) spirit of fearing no hardship and quietly contributing to the country and the people.'' Such exhortations have been common in the wake of last year's pro-democracy movement, which was violently crushed by the military. This year's Spring Festival celebrations in Beijing seemed more subdued than past years, when the sound of firecrackers could be heard all night long. Traditionally, Chinese set off firecrackers for almost any special occasion but especially at the Lunar New Year because it is supposed to ward off evil spirits. The official Xinhua news agency said Beijing's huge bell and drums will be sounded on the eve of every Spring Festival from now on. The Bell and Drum Towers were the timekeepers for imperial Beijing, but until now, neither had been used for 66 years, since the last emperor left the Imperial Palace. ``In the old society, that's how we knew the time,'' said a 60-year-old woman who lives near the towers. She said it was the first time she had heard the bell or the drum since 1949, when the Communists took power.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Set for Suspect in 1985 Tokyo Airport Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A man facing charges in a 1985 Tokyo airport bombing that killed two baggage handlers will stand trial in September, a judge ruled Friday. Inderjit Singh Reyat, 37, a former resident of Duncan on Vancouver Island, was extradited from England in December. He faces two manslaughter charges and five explosives charges. British Columbia Supreme Court Justice Howard Callaghan scheduled the trial for Sept. 17 and said he will rule Feb. 9 on a government motion to change the venue of the trial to surburban New Westminster from Vancouver. Reyat's attorney, David Gibbons, has opposed the move, saying it would make it difficult for his Vancouver office to support him. Gibbons said outside the court he has not applied for bail for his client because he is still gathering evidence to support such an application. The prosecution alleges Reyat bought materials similar to those used in a bomb that was placed on a CP Air flight in Vancouver and killed the baggage handlers when they unloaded luggage from the plane at Narita airport.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Coal Field Rally, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0639,0583
DOC.HEAD: 500 Union Miners March at Site of Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 7-8, bgn `Cars and...' with 3 grafs to CORRECT southeast to south, and UPDATE with comment from Rum Creek parent company.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CN4
DOC.TEXT: More than 500 United Mine Workers members from three states marched two miles up an Appalachian hollow Friday to demand the removal of non-union workers from a coal preparation plant. Union coal miners chanting ``UMW all the way'' marched up Rum Creek to a private bridge leading to the Rum Creek Coal Sales Inc. plant, site of confrontations and arrests earlier this week. ``We're here to show solidarity in a peaceful manner and show the community of Dehue that it needs a rabies vaccination to rid of some bad dogs,'' said Roger Nelson, a UMW strike organizer. Miners struck Rum Creek in mid-August after the company re-opened the coal preparation plant with non-union contractors. UMW members men had run it before. It was the largest gathering of UMW miners since June, when a rally in Charleston in support of miners on strike against the Pittston Coal Group, attracted more than 1,000 people, the union said. That march triggered wildcat strikes the next day, which eventually idled 43,000 miners in 10 states. ``Our focus is to bring public attention and bring justice to people in the coal fields,'' said Bob Phalen, president of UMW District 17. Cars and pickups lined a state highway about 70 miles south of Charleston, and state police escorted the miners, from West Virginia, Virginia and Kentucky, two miles from a parking lot to the coal company bridge. No violence was reported. Rum Creek officials told U.S. marshals at the site that no coal trucks would make runs Friday. Marshals were present because the UMW is under court order not to block access to the coal company property. ``The continued presence of federal marshals and state police has helped contain UMWA violence at Rum Creek,'' said Deborah Herndon, a spokesman for A.T. Massey Coal Co., Rum Creek's parent company. Many miners said they were prepared to be arrested. ``If that's what they want us to do, we'll do it. It's one for all and all for one in the United Mine Workers,'' said Bill Humphrey of Whitesville, who carried a framed copy of the Declaration of Independence. Humphrey works at New Beckley Coal Co., where the UMW has been on strike for nearly a year. About 100 of his co-workers also attended the rally. ``I get emotional over stuff like this,'' said Bill Ingram, a 40-year veteran of the Rum Creek plant. Pickets have blocked the coal company road with cars and trucks. On Monday and Tuesday, coal trucks plowed the vehicles out of the way. On Wednesday, federal marshals had them towed away. Two UMW members were arraigned Thursday in Charleston on charges of assaulting federal marshals Wednesday and freed on $25,000 secured bonds. A third UMW member was freed on $10,000 unsecured bond after being charged with violating the court order. On Thursday about 60 pickets gathered at the site but allowed trucks to pass without incident. The Rum Creek strike is not related to the 9-month-old strike against the Pittston Coal Group, which was tentatively settled Jan. 1. The proposed pact has not yet been submitted for ratification by the rank and file.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 8 p.m. EST _ Time Set by Source
DOC.HEAD: Justice Brennan Says Dissent is a Duty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf pvs, ``I do, to CORRECT ``use'' to ``us.''
DOC.TEXT: Justice William J. Brennan, the leading liberal member of an increasingly conservative Supreme Court, said Friday that dissenting from court rulings is not ``an egoistic act'' but a duty. In a speech to the New York State Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, Brennan said, ``Where significant and deeply held disagreement exists, members of the court have a responsibility to articulate it.'' A copy of the speech was made available here. ``I do not mean to suggest that one has a duty or right simply to make noise,'' Brennan said. ``What I am saying is that all of us _ judges, lawyers, students, teachers, factory workers, bankers _ must recognize values which are so important to us that we cannot remain silent if and when we feel those values threatened.'' The justice added, ``The right to dissent is one of the great and cherished freedoms that we enjoy by virtue of the excellent accident of our birth as Americans. For a dissenting judge, Brennan said, ``Writing is not an egoistic act _ it is duty. Saying, `Listen to me, see it my way, change your mind,' is not self-indulgence _ it is hard work that we are not permitted to shirk,'' he said. He noted that dissents can strain collegiality and sometimes bruise feelings. Brennan, 83, is the high court's senior member. He was appointed by President Eisenhower in 1956 and soon thereafter became a key architect of a liberal court under Chief Justice Earl Warren. ``I'm sure it has not escaped your attention that these days I am often a dissenter,'' Brennan said. ``How different that is from 20 or 25 years ago. In some terms during the 1960s I was in the majority in all but one or two cases.'' He discussed the various roles of dissents: _To offer a corrective, ``in the hope that the court will mend the error of its ways in a later case.'' ``This function reflects the conviction that the best way to find the truth is to go looking for it in the marketplace of ideas,'' Brennan said. ``It is as if the opinions of the court _ both for the majority and the dissent _ were the product of a judicial town meeting.'' _To emphasize the limits of the majority decision, ``a sort of damage-control mechanism.'' _To express the conscience of the individual justice, a category Brennan called ``the most enduring dissents.'' ``These are the dissents that ... seek to sow seeds for future harvest. These are the dissents that soar with passion and ring with rhetoric. These are the dissents that, at their best, straddle the worlds of literature and law,'' he said. The justice said the tradition of issuing dissenting opinions began early in the Supreme Court's history, in 1805.

DOC.HEAD: Four-Month Hunger Strike Called Off
DOC.TEXT: A man serving life in prison for the attempted assassination of an Iranian exile leader decided Friday to call off his 19-week hunger strike, the Justice Ministry said. Anis Naccache told officials at Fresnes Prison of his decision to end his fast without giving any explanation, the ministry said. Naccache, a native of Beirut, contends that France promised to free him in the deal that won the release in May 1988 of all French hostages then held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. On Sept. 8, he began refusing food to try to force the government to let him go. He continued to drink liquids, and doctors in the prison hospital fed him intravenously on occasion, which they said could keep him alive indefinitely despite the hunger strike. Naccache, 38, and four other men were sentenced to life in prison for a July 1980 attack on Shahpour Bakhtiar, Iran's last prime minister before the 1979 Islamic revolution. Bakhtiar escaped injury but a policeman and a bystander were killed. Both defense lawyers and the prosecution said Naccache was the leader of a team ordered by top Iranian leaders to kill Bakhtiar. Iran's current leaders, while not confirming they ordered the assassination, have supported Naccache's claim that France promised to free him during the 1988 hos5 pounds. There were fears that if he died, French targets would again be hit by terrorist bombs. Naccache was one of three prisoners whose freedom was demanded by a group calling itself the Committee for Solidarity with Arab and Middle East Political Prisoners, which claimed responsibility for bombings in 1985 and 1986 that killed 13 people and injured more than 250 in Paris. The criminal trial is scheduled to open Monday for 10 people charged in those bombings.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Privately With Brazilian President
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Brazilian President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello on Friday he wants to work with Brazil on environmental problems and revitalizing its economy, the White House said. Collar de Mello refused to comment on Bush's invasion of Panama when asked during a photo session, but at a press conference later, he reiterated Brazil's opposiion to the Dec. 20 military action. ``The only intervention we approve is the intervention of reason,'' he told reporters. Environmentalists' concerns about Brazil center on the destruction of the rain forests there, with increasing development encroaching on thousands of acres of the ecologically important forests. The topic is a sensitive one, however, because Brazilians say their ailing economy benefits from the development. Destruction of the trees is believed to worsen the global warming trend. Suggestions have been raised that debt relief for Brazil be tied to resolution of the rain-forest situation. ``The president reviewed our own efforts to address environmental problems in the United States and expressed a desire to work with Brazil and other countries so that a proper balance can be worked out between development and environmental concerns, with full respect for every nation's sovereignty and with the need to base deliberations on the best scientific data available,'' the White House said. At his news conference, Collor de Mello said his government is aware of the environmental concerns, but added that any actions Brasilia decides to take will be because the government feels it is in the best interest of Brazil, not because of outside pressure. Brazil's Amazon jungle contains 30 percent of the world's rain forests. Satellite photos have shown cattle ranchers and miners each year destroy an area the size of Belgium. Collor de Mello is on a get-acquainted trip to the United States, Japan, Europe an the Soviet Union to talk with world leaders before his March 11 inauguration. The White House said he and Bush discussed a range of issues including trade, investment, debt, and the environment. ``The president expressed strong support for president-elect Collor's plans to reform and revitalize Brazil's economy and stated that the Uited States would work closely with Brazil toward this goal.'' Brazil has a $115 billion foreign debt, the largest in the developing world. Collor de Mello, a conservative, free-market advocate, was elected last Dec. 18, defeating a socialist opponent. It was the first direct presidential election in Brazil in 29 years. Collor de Mello also met with Vice President Dan Quayle, who was leaving later in the day for a trip to Honduras, Panama and Jamaica. Quayle was to talk to several Latin leaders about the U.S. invasion of Panama and explain Bush's rationale in the face of Latin resentment about that action.

DOC.HEAD: 100 Feet in 10 Seconds Equal How Many Slices of Bread?
DOC.TEXT: The problem, as posed to 150,000 school children on Friday, was this: A student, running 100 feet every 10 seconds, 24 hours a day, requires 1,467 days to reach the moon. He or she burns 864 calories an hour. A slice of bread contains 60 calories. How high would the loaf of bread have to be to supply the student with enough energy to reach the moon? Okay, okay. Something is left out of the problem. A sandwich slice is about one-half inch thick. The answer is, 30,419,712 calories are represented in 506,995 slices of bread which stacked would be 253,498 inches high, creating a loaf of bread four miles high. Oh, yes. The moon averages about 240,000 miles away, though you didn't have to know that to solve the problem. This problem was one of five presented on a satellite network connecting 900 schools around the country to spark youngsters' interest in learning and to spur appreciation science, math, and teaching. It was the first of such classroom lessons sponsored by the Challenger Center, an educational project founded by the families of the seven astronauts who perished aboard the space shuttle Challenger four years ago. ``Today, we took you on an imaginary trip to the moon,'' said Dr. R. Lynn Bondurant Jr., chief of educational services at NASA's Lewis Research Center who conducted the program. ``Some day you may be on a real trip to the moon ... Remember to reach for the stars.'' Teachers in the participating classes received matterials in advance. The preparation showed as pupils afterward asked questions of Michael Collins, who flew the mother ship while astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin made the walk on the moon in 1969. What impresses you most from that far away from home? ``The size of the Earth,'' said Collins. ``First you have to find it. It is as small as your thumbnail.'' What supplies should you take? ``Hydrogen,'' said Collins. Human beings need water, which is two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen. ``You can get a lot of oxygen out of the rocks on the moon, but you have to take hydrogen from Earth.'' How long will the footprints left on the moon last? ``I don't know,'' said Collins. Eventually, he said, they would be obliterated by micrometeorites hitting the moon. Friday's lessons included calculations to find the distance to the moon, evaluating the differences in gravity, mapping the moon, and the Collins interview. In the next few weeks the student will work on designing a lunar mining base and one plan from each school will be submitted to the Challenger center. For the gravity calculations, the students were shown a clip in which astronaut David Scott, on Apollo 15, dropped a hammer and feather simultaneously to the moon and they hit the surface at exactly the same time. What they weren't asked to calculate was one of the space age's most enduring mysteries. How far did the golf ball that Alan Shepard hit on the moon during the Apollo 14 mission travel in the one-sixth gravity and no atmosphere to slow it down?

DOC.HEAD: Services Monday for Actress Ava Gardner
DOC.TEXT: Graveside services will be held Monday for actress Ava Gardner. She died in her sleep Thursday at her home in London at the age of 67. Services will be held Monday morning at Sunset Memorial Park for Miss Gardner, said Kenneth Baker, owner of Underwood Funeral Home in Smithfield. Miss Gardner, who grew up in Johnston County, will be buried next to her brother, Jack Gardner, a state legislator who died in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Delays IRS Auction Of Comedian's Property
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Friday delayed an Internal Revenue Service auction of property belonging to comedian Redd Foxx, just 24 hours before the sale was to begin. U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Clive Jones issued a 30-day stay despite protests by IRS attorneys and the auctioneer involved. Foxx's attorney, Paul Whitford, told the court that the sale would conflict with the interests of the bankruptcy court. Whitford said the issue was ``whether provisions of the bankruptcy code override provisions of the IRS code.'' Foxx, who filed for Chapter 11 protection from bankruptcy in 1983, owes the IRS $900,000 in back taxes, penalties and interest. He was not at the hearing. Foxx gained his widest audience as a junk dealer on the 1972-77 TV series ``Sanford and Son.'' The IRS seized more than 400 items of personal property Nov. 28. The property ranged from his Las Vegas home to antique cars, furniture, dozens of pieces of flashy jewelry, posters and photographs. Auctioneer Robert Deiro pleaded with the court to let the action proceed, saying ``hundreds of people are descending on the city'' from as far away as Asia to attend the sale. Jones said another hearing would be scheduled next month to review the issue of whether the court or the IRS has jurisdiction over the property. Deiro said Foxx would suffer if the auction is delayed because many of those who planned to attend Saturday's sale would lose interest and not return later. ``I feel Mr. Foxx has shot himself in the foot,'' Deiro said. Deiro predicted the sale would ``go a long ways toward retiring the debt Mr. Foxx owes the taxpayers of the United States.'' Deiro said a public showing of the sale items was already under way while the hearing was being conducted, and estimated his company had spent $20,000 promoting the sale. Jones also ordered Foxx to turn over a watch which the IRS believes the comic still has in his possession. The watch was given to him by the late Elvis Presley and was represented as being worth ``the high six figures,'' according to IRS attorney Rollin Thorley. Jones said if Foxx didn't turn over the watch by Tuesday, he would consider lifting the 30-day stay.

DOC.HEAD: Two Americans Found Dead on Paris Houseboat
DOC.TEXT: Police discovered a vacationing American doctor and his wife dead Friday on a houseboat in central Paris, the apparent victims of gas suffocation, U.S. Embassy officials said. An autopsy was planned on the bodies of John and Barbara Hartman of San Luis Obispo, Calif., to determine the precise cause of death, an Embassy spokesman said. Foul play was not suspected. The couple appeared to have been dead for some time before their bodies were discovered on the houseboat in a sheltered inlet off the River Seine near the Place de la Bastille, the spokesman said. The Hartmans arrived in France on Jan. 9, the spokesman said. Other details were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Orders Support Staff Cut
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered that about 250 jobs be cut over the next three fiscal years from the staff that supports the Pentagon's civilian leadership, the Defense Department announced on Friday. The reduction in the staff, formally known as the Office of the Secretary of Defense, will be taken in three separate reductions in fiscal years 1991, 1992 and 1993, the department said in a statement. Simliar cuts have been ordered in the money allocated for outside contract services, the statement said.
