The reductions are designed to comply with the secretary's efforts to streamline the Pentagon bureaucracy as called for under his defense management review. ``With tight budgets, every element of the department's work force must pass the same test of necessity and efficiency. My staff has to make the grade, just like everybody else,'' Cheney said in the statement. The statement did not say exactly how the cuts would be achieved, but Pentagon spokesman Army Maj. David Super said officials expect normal attrition to help in the reductions.

DOC.HEAD: Lobbying Group Calls for Expanded Health Care
DOC.TEXT: The public interest group Citizen Action on Friday announced a nationwide campaign to push for passage of a comprehensive national health care program. The current system is too expensive, inefficient, wasteful and does not provide routine access to medical care for everyone, Citizen Action leaders said at a news conference. ``We reallly can't wait any longer to push for a solution to our health care crisis,'' said Robert M. Brandon, vice president and political director of Citizen Action. ``The current system is bankrupting American families, hurting American businesses and threatening the very health of our whole economy,'' he said. Last year, Americans spent an estimated $600 billion on health care, about 11 percent of the nation's gross national product, the group said. Yet, an estimated 37 million people have no health insurance. One of the consequences of this statistic, the group said, is that the nation's infant mortality rate ranks 22nd in the world. The group wants to see a system along the lines of the one in Canada, which is funded by taxpayers but still allows patients to choose their own doctors and hospitals. Brandon said the group's 2 million members in 27 states will organize a grassroots effort that, among other things, will work for state-level passage of universal health care plans. Proposals are being discussed in nearly 20 state legislatures, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Investigate `Baffling' Killing
DOC.TEXT: Police sought clues from overseas Friday in the execution-style slaying of an Israeli businessman allegedly tied to mercenaries who trained Colombian drug cartel gunmen. Arik Afek, 39, was shot to death and stuffed into the trunk of a car, the Dade County medical examiner's office said. The body was found in a Miami International Airport parking garage after a passer-by reported a foul smell. ``Homicide is keeping mum about the whole thing,'' said police spokesman George Reyes. ``Apparently this is kind of baffling for them. ``They're still collecting information,'' Reyes said. ``They're getting calls from overseas, from folks in Israel.'' Afek was wanted by Colombian authorities who accused him of helping an Israeli who allegedly trained the guards of drug lords. He was interviewed recently by U.S. Secret Service Agents, said a U.S. official in Washington who spoke on condition of anonymity. The agents, preparing for President Bush's visit to Colombia for a drug summit next month, have been inquiring into whether Colombia's Medellin drug cartel has access to anti-aircraft missiles or other weapons. Miami police investigators Friday were interviewing Afek's friends and relatives, but hadn't taken anyone into custody, said police spokeswoman Lucy Fitts. She didn't have any information on who owned the beige Buick Regal that contained Afek's body. The medical examiner's office released a statement saying Afek died of ``multiple gunshot wounds,'' but didn't reveal where he was shot or when. Police said Afek had been dead several days when his body was discovered Wednesday morning. His wallet was missing, and he wasn't wearing jewelry. He was lying on his back, wearing shorts and a casual shirt. Afek had been working in Miami as an officer in a business that imports flowers from Colombia. In September, Colombian authorities issued warrants for Afek and reserve Israeli army Lt. Col. Yair Klein. Afek was accused of helping Klein escape from Colombia amid reports he was training gunmen for the Medellin and Cali drug cartels. Klein later said he thought he was training farmers to fight guerrillas. At the time, Diva Rojas, a spokeswoman for Colombia's Department of Security, identified Afek as a civilian who had an arms business in Israel and flower shops in the United States. Israeli television said Thursday that Afek was being investigated by the CIA, which had given him a U.S. passport in return for information on Israeli activity in Colombia. CIA spokesman Mark Mansfield said Friday he could neither confirm nor deny the report. The Miami Herald, quoting unidentified federal sources, said U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service investigators discovered Afek made nearly daily calls to the Israeli National Police office at the Israeli consulate in New York and well as frequent calls to a woman at the Colombian Embassy in Washington. He had been under investigation since December because he was admitted to the U.S. under a ``special agricultural worker'' program open only to foreign-born farm hands and fruit pickers, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Polyps Removed from Governor's Colon
DOC.TEXT: Gov. William A. O'Neill disclosed Friday that he had had two benign polyps removed from his colon this week. The governor said his doctors have told him he's fine. O'Neill, 59, has been plagued by colon polyps for more than a year. Of two removed previously, one was cancerous. O'Neill made the disclosure during a taping of the ``On The Record'' program on Connecticut Public Television. ``I went to the hospital Monday, I had a check and two minor polyps were removed,'' O'Neill said. ``They were benign, non-cancerous, quite normal, quite natural, according to my own doctors. ``I feel fine, I really do, physically fine and mentally alert,'' O'Neill said. O'Neill has repeatedly said he will run for a third full term this year unless a health problem develops. He indicated during the interview that this latest development wouldn't change his plans. ``I just don't see anything at the present time that's going to curtail me running,'' O'Neill said.

DOC.HEAD: TV Crew, Transients Assist Homeless Woman Giving Birth in Park
DOC.TEXT: A television crew and several transients helped a homeless mother give birth in MacArthur Park, an inner-city park where drug deals are commonplace, authorities said. Eugenia Marin, who had been living in the park since September, delivered a 5-pound, 4{-ounce girl Thursday morning, said fire Inspector Ed Reed. Mother and baby were later listed in good condition at a hospital. ``There were homeless people around her and one was holding the child, still attached by the umbilical cord,'' Reed said. ``The baby was cold and dirty.'' Employees of Newsreel Video Service, a free-lance television news crew, arrived shortly before paramedics after hearing a call for medical aid on a police scanner. Crew members trained their camera lights on the 21-year-old mother as she gave birth about 3:45 a.m. They also took pictures. Gary Arnote, Newsreel Video owner, said his crew's lights have helped police out during accidents, but it's the first time they've been used during a child's birth. ``It really makes you feel good when you get a story like that,'' he said. ``We tape anything that is unusual, and a birth at the park, well, that's unusual.''

DOC.HEAD: More Snow And Rain In Northwest
DOC.TEXT: A windy storm blew snow and rain across parts of the Northwest on Friday, and rain and snow also were scattered over the Northeast. At midday, snow showers extended over south-central and western Montana, Western Wyoming, northern Nevada, the mountains of northern California and southern Oregon, and west-central Washington state. To the south, rain showers reached across northwestern Oregon and along the northern coast of California. Up to 3 inches of snow fell overnight and during the morning at Jackson Hole, Wyo., and as much as 8 inches of snow fell in the Tetons and Absaroka mountains of northwestern Wyoming. Winter storm warnings were posted into Saturday over the Washington Cascades and Olympics. A high wind warning was in effect through Saturday over the eastern foothills of Colorado, where gusts reached 90 mph Friday morning at Rollinsville. Rain fell over much of New England, southeastern New York state and New Jersey. Snow extended from west-central New England across southern New York state, northern and western Pennsylvania and northeastern Ohio. Rain over southern Maine changed to snow by early afternoon. Three inches of snow fell at Binghamton, N.Y., during the 6 hours up to noon. Heavy rain overnight across northeastern New York state caused rapid melting of snow cover and flood warnings were in effect over the Hudson Valley in northeastern New York state and southern Vermont. Elsewhere, snow showers were scattered across southeastern Lower Michigan, eastern Upper Michigan and northeastern Minnesota. In the wake of Thursday's storm that socked Michigan, foul weather and hazardous driving conditions Friday forced schools across the northern Lower Peninsula to close, giving students plenty of time to help their families dig out from under up to 15 inches of snow. At least 120 school districts in northern Lower Michigan and the eastern Upper Peninsula closed Friday. Classes had ended early in some districts Thursday to give buses extra time to negotiate snow-covered back roads. ``It was a particularly wet and heavy snow. It made the roads pretty slippery. Out in the patrol car, the wheels kept spinning when I didn't want them to. A lot of people ended up in the ditches,'' said Sgt. Mike Gillette of the Ogemaw County Sheriff's Office. Toppled trees and branches tore down power lines, knocking out power to about 44,000 Detroit Edison Co. customers. By midday Friday, electricity was restored to all but 12,500 customers, most of them in Wayne, Oakland and Macomb counties, spokesman Bob Dobkin said. Consumers Power Co. reported 40,379 customers lost power in the storm, most in the Kalamazoo and Lansing areas. By midday Friday, 7,640 were without power, spokesman Bob Goodwin said. Jamestown, N.D., had a record high Friday of 51 degrees. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 9 degrees below zero at Hibbing and International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 22 degrees at Warroad, Minn., to 73 at San Diego and Wink, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Former Secret Service Agent to Justice Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he will nominate Richard J. Hankinson, one of his former Secret Service agents, to be inspector general at the Justice Department. Hankinson worked at the Secret Service from 1966 through 1985. He was assistant special agent and later special agent in charge for Bush as vice president and then joined the General Services Administration as an assistant commissioner for physical security and law enforcement.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Unveils Head Start Funds Proposal
DOC.TEXT: President Bush proposed a $500-million spending increase Friday for the Head Start program for low-income children, saying every youngster ``deserves the opportunity for a full and happy life.'' The proposal, which will be included in the 1991 budget he unveils Monday, is a step toward Bush's campaign pledge to expand Head Start to reach all eligible four-year-olds. Bush said the new funds would permit Head Start's enrollment to grow to 667,000 children, or 70 percent of those eligible. It now enrolls 39 percent. ``I urge the Congress to fund our Head Start proposal in full, because every American child with special needs _ whether physical, emotional or material _ deserves the opportunity for a full and happy life,'' Bush said. Head Start programs emphasize social and learning skills necessary to succeed in school. It serves pre-school, low-income children, usually in the year before the enter school. The 1,300 local Head Start programs also provide breakfast and lunch and screen children for medical or dental problems. Analysts of both parties and widely diverging political views consider Head Start the most successful of all the government's educational aid programs. Bush's proposal would increase Head Start spending to $1.9 billion. ``I think a $500-million increase is quite remarkable,'' said Louis Sullivan, secretary of health and human services. Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, and The Committee for Education Funding, an advocacy group, have called for Head Start appropriations of $5 billion a year. Bush announced his proposal at a ``celebration of children ceremony'' in the East Room where he also underscored his support for adoptions, which he has promoted as an alternative to abortion. Bush, who has two grandchildren who are adopted, said, ``Adoption is good for America, for the children who need a loving home, for the birth parents who want the best for their children, and for the adoptive parents by giving them the joy of raising and loving a child.'' About 100 ``special needs'' children _ those hard to adopt because of handicaps or because of their age _ attended the ceremony, playing and moving around as Bush spoke. ``This has got to be the most unique event ever held in the White House, I think _ like a fishpond moving around,'' he said. Bush interrupted his speech when a child standing in front of him wailed for a bathroom. ``This guy's got to go real bad, doesn't he? '' Bush said. A man who appeared to be the boy's father rushed over to collect him, and Bush said, ``That's okay, we're used to that around here.'' Consoling the child, Bush said, ``That's okay, big guy.''

DOC.HEAD: Bangladesh President Ershad Visiting United States
DOC.TEXT: President Hussain Muhammad Ershad of Bangladesh will visit the United States and France on a foreign journey starting next week, the Bangladesh Embassy said Friday. No formal meeting was scheduled with President Bush, but it was possible they would meet at the National Congressional Prayer Breakfast that both presidents planned to attend here next Thursday, the White House said. Ershad, a Moslem, is among 3,500 people invited to the breakfast, said John Bishop, spokesman for the organizers of the annual non-sectarian event. En route to Washington, Ershad plans to speak at U.N. headquarters in New York to a meeting of the Group of 77 Developing Countries, the embassy said. With a population of 110 million and annual income under $160 a person, Bangladesh is one of the largest and poorest of the group. Ershad's Washington schedule includes meetings with Secretary of State James Baker III, World Bank President Barber Conable and members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and House Foreign Affairs Committee. The Bangladesh Embassy said Ershad would call on meet President Francois Mitterand in France after his departure from the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Sperry Executive Sentenced to 60 Days in Halfway House
DOC.TEXT: A former Sperry Corp. marketing executive who admitted initiating a scheme to bribe a Navy procurement official was sentenced Friday to 60 days in a halfway house. Frank J. Lavelle, 69, of Dunedin, Fla., was sentenced in U.S. District Court in Alexandria, Va., on his guilty plea to conspiracy to defraud the government and commit bribery of a public official. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton gave Lavelle a two-year sentence, then suspended all but 60 days of the term and ordered the defendant to serve that period in a halfway house. Lavelle, former marketing director of Sperry Corp.'s Clearwater, Fla., facility, could have received a 20-year prison term for initiating the scheme to bribe Navy procurement officer Garland L. Tomlin Jr. Lavelle, who pleaded guilty Oct. 20, has agreed to cooperate with the Justice Department's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud codenamed ``Operation Ill Wind.'' Lavelle admitted that he introduced Tomlin to Sperry Corp. vice president Charles F. Gardner, telling Gardner that Tomlin wanted a ``nest egg'' for his retirement. Tomlin has pleaded guilty to accepting $400,000 in bribes from Sperry, which later merged with Burroughs Corp. to become Unisys Corp., and $75,000 from Honeywell Inc. in exchange for confidential bid information. Gardner, 59, once vice president of Sperry's surveillance and fire-control systems unit, received a 32-month prison term for his involvement in a separate bribery scheme. Both Tomlin and Gardner are cooperating with the Ill Wind probe.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says U.S. Can't Evict Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday barred the State Department from evicting Lebanon's deposed ambassasdor from the Lebanese Embassy. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene issued a temporary restraining order pending his final ruling, expected within 10 days. Greene was acting on a motion filed by Lebanese Christian Gen. Michel Aoun and his ambassador to Washington, Abdallah Bouhabib. The State Department argued that Bouhabib should be removed from the embassy because the United States does not recognize Aoun as Lebanon's legitimate ruler. The United States has extended recognition to Aoun's rival, President Elias Hrawi, who was elected in November by Lebanon's parliament. Greene said the State Department failed to consider that Aoun provides protection for the U.S. Embassy in Lebanon, located in an area controlled by his forces. U.S. diplomats have left Lebanon, but Lebanese employees continue to work there. Greene indicated that his final ruling might favor the State Department, but he criticized the United States for not giving Bouhabib sufficient notice of the intention to evict him. The State Department received a request Wednesday from the pro-Syrian Hrawi government to evict Bouhabib so that a new Lebanese ambassador could occupy the embassy and adjacent residence. The Hrawi government representative, appointed earlier this month, is working out of temporary offices. Greene said that while he could not interfere with the U.S. decision to recognize Hrawi, he rejected the State Department's argument that Bouhabib had committed an ``intrusion or forcible entry'' into the embassy. Bouhabib has been Lebanon's ambassador since 1983. The Hrawi government removed Bouhabib from his job in December. Assistant U.S. Attorney Daniel Standish argued that his removal from office served as Bouhabib's notice of eviction from the embassy. Greene disputed that, saying that ``those in possession'' of premises ``are entitled to reasonable notice and process under U.S. law.'' A 30-day notice was appropriate, he said. Bouhabib, who has lived in Washington for 20 years, has refused to leave the embassy and the residence, locking out most employees. He controls the embassy's bank accounts, its files and diplomatic cyphers. Greene said the court ``has the duty to prevent the forcible turning over of archives to a rival regime'' at least until sensitive material can be removed.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Looking at Alleged Ambulance-Chasing
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys who were ``callous'' toward grieving families are the subject of a grand jury investigation into alleged illegal lawsuit promotion following the deaths of 21 students in a school bus wreck. Seven lawyers and several ``runners'' soliciting business for them are the focus of the investigation, said Hidalgo County District Attorney Rene Guerra. ``Some of these people were being solicited at the wakes, which is pretty callous,'' Guerra said. It is illegal in Texas for lawyers or their representatives to solicit business from victims or their families. The crime, commonly known as ``ambulance chasing,'' is called barratry. The grand jury finished its first full day of inquiry Thursday, and will meet again Wednesday, Guerra said. It could take three weeks for the grand jury to decide about indictments, he said. In November, Guerra said he was investigating 18 attorneys in connection with the Sept. 21, 1989, accident. But he said Thursday there was not enough evidence to present some of those cases to the grand jury. The junior and senior high students died when a soft drink truck ran a stop sign and hit their bus, knocking it into a water-filled pit in the southern Texas town of Alton. Guerra was not specific about where the lawyers under investigation were from, saying only that some came from outside the Lower Rio Grande Valley. Barratry in Texas is a misdemeanor on the first offense, punishable by up to a year in jail and a fine of up to $2,000; and a third-degree felony on the second offense, under certain circumstances, punishable by up to 10 years in prison and a $5,000 fine. Those convicted also could face sanctions from the State Bar of Texas, including possible disbarment. Lawsuits that potentially could run into tens of millions of dollars have been filed in the case, principally against McAllen-based Valley Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Inc., owner of the truck. The truck driver is set for trial in March on 21 counts of involuntary manslaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Yazov Says Military Task Was to Prevent Seizure of Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to include report of Azerbaijan-Armenian meeting; picks up 7th `The defense'
DOC.TEXT: The Red Army went into Baku a week ago to stop the Azerbaijani People's Front and other groups from seizing power, Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov said in remarks published Friday. He told Soviet journalists in Baku, capital of the Azerbaijan republic, that on Jan. 20 _ the day after soldiers took over the city _ ``a meeting was planned at which it was proposed to declare the transfer of power into the hands of the People's Front.'' Baltic activists said Friday that Azerbaijani representatives had agreed to visit Riga, capital of Latvia, next week for possible talks with an Armenian delegation on resolving ethnic strife that caused the military intervention. Opposition members of the Soviet parliament and an official newspaper questioned the Kremlin's use of force in the Caucasus to quell the ethnic violence that began Jan. 13. Yazov said the People's Front declared its own state of emergency in Baku a full day before the soldiers moved in, and ``in many regions of the city ... Soviet and party organs had ceased to control the situation.'' In the remarks published by the government newspaper Izvestia, Yazov appeared to stress the need to control the political situation over stopping ethnic warfare in which dozens of people were killed. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other top officials have cited public safety as the reason for the military assault and ensuing battle with nationalists in which at least 80 people died. The defense minister said the military's task now was to destroy the power structure the People's Front and other informal political organizations had established in state-run institutions. Critics of the military move against well-armed Azerbaijani nationalists have said attacks on the Armenian minority had ended well before the army moved. Azerbaijani nationalists have accused Moscow of seeking to crush their movement against the Communist Party and government apparatus. Yazov said 80 ``extremists'' from the People's Front and other informal organizations had been arrested. Baku journalist Tuuzala Kasumova said by telephone that, after meeting with Azerbaijani deputies, Yazov had pulled some tanks and other military equipment off the streets of Baku and the city was less tense. Yazov said: ``The army's actions are directed at breathing new life into Baku's fading economy, confiscating weapons from the population and destroying the organizational structure of the People's Front leaders who are keen on seizing power. ``According to our estimates, about 40,000 militants armed with submachine guns, rifles of various systems, machine guns and shotguns are loose in Azerbaijan.'' Yuri N. Afanasyev, a member of the Congress of People's Deputies was one of the opposition figures who requested an emergency parliament session to settle the Caucasus dispute. ``From our point of view, we should have a Supreme Soviet session to hear all groups, to regulate the conflict,'' he said at a Moscow news conference. ``We need to call a session so that the threat of the south does not touch all of society,'' he said. The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet has the power to call the Supreme Soviet into session. A regular session of the Supreme Soviet is scheduled for mid-February. Although Gorbachev's reforms have opened up Soviet society, Afanasyev likened the decision to send soldiers into Baku to the secret decisions to crush democracy movements in Hungary and Czechoslovakia and send troops to Afghanistan. He and 12 other legislators signed a document urging a special session of the Supreme Soviet to discuss redrawing the border between Armenia and Azerbaijan, which have been locked in a territorial dispute for two years, and a deadline for withdrawning the soldiers in Baku. They said they were ``categorically against the use of force.'' Afanasyev is a leader of the Inter-regional Deputies Group, the formal parliamentary opposition that claims about 400 members and was created largely through the inspiration of Andrei Sakharov, the late human rights activist. The newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said two veterans of the Afghanistan war, Cols. A. Savelyev and A. Rusakov, sent a telegram to Gorbachev Jan. 19 that said bringing in troops would lead ``to a total break in relations and put their families in danger,'' as well as ``creating a rise in the anti-Russian mood.'' Since then, thousands of relatives of Soviet soldiers have been evacuated from Baku and there have been reports of threats and attacks against Russians in the Azerbaijani capital. Bringing Russian families into the conflict could spread unrest far across the Soviet Union. Despite having their own republics, Armenians and Azerbaijanis live together with Russians in many parts of the country. Military commandant Lt. Gen. Vladimir Dubinyak said Baku was ``relatively calm,'' early Friday, Tass reported. In the previous 24 hours, 147 people had been detained in Baku either for breaking curfew or other violations, Tass said. Two newspapers were banned by the military authorities. The agency said troops had not used weapons Thursday, but Komsomolskaya Pravda reported two people were killed when an armored personnel carrier ran over a car. In Moscow, Azerbaijani activists said commandos in bullet-proof vests and helmets raided the republic's mission and arrested a nationalist leader. A Moscow police official confirmed the raid and said it was being investigated. Azerbaijan journalist Shain Hadjiev said commandos charged into the government mission at 3 a.m., searched it and herded about 40 men into buses. But he said all were released except Ekhtibar Mamedov, who has gained attention recently by pushing Azerbaijani claims that there were far more people killed in the troop assault on Baku than the official death toll.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes in Restive Kosovo; Shooting Reported
DOC.TEXT: Scattered strikes were reported in restive Kosovo province Friday in response to a call for a general walkout, and police intervened to stop crowds of ethnic Albanians from demonstrating. State television said protesters ``shot with guns in the direction'' of police in Pec, 30 miles west of Pristina, the provincial capital. The report could not be confirmed and did not say whether anyone was injured. Tanjug, the official news agency, said strikes occurred at 20 companies, including at the Stari Trg mine near Titova Mitrovica, 25 miles north of Pristina, and at the Trepca mine near the capital. It did not say how many workers were involved. ``Swift police actions'' prevented hundreds of ethnic Albanians from protesting in Titova Mitrovica, Podujevo and several other Kosovo towns, Tanjug said. Turmoil began in Kosovo, an impoverished southern province adjacent to Albania, after constitutional changes last year limited its autonomy and gave more control to Serbia, of which it is a part. At least 28 people were killed. Hundreds of ethnic Albanians, who make up about 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people, were jailed in a police crackdown that followed. A partial state of emergency remains in force. Strikes and protests at the Stari Trg and Trepca mines in January led to the arrest of Azem Vlasi, former Communist Party chief in Kosovo, on charges of ``anti-revolutionary activity.'' He is being tried and could face death if convicted. Protesters in Kosovo demand an end to alleged discrimination and free elections in the province. An independent Kosovo human rights group issued a statement Friday protesting what it termed ``brutal police action against innocent citizens'' who demonstrated peacefully in Pristina on Wednesday. The Committee for the Protection of Human Rights also demanded free elections, an end to the state of emergency and the release of hundreds of political prisoners. Up to 100 riot police guarded the Communist Party headquarters in Pristina on Friday and 500 Pristina University students gathered outside their dormitories, under the eyes of other security personnel. ``We want our legal rights, like all other people in Yugoslavia,'' said a student, who refused to give his name. ``We want a change of leadership, the release of all political prisoners and free elections.'' On Wednesday, police used a water cannon to disperse 40,000 ethnic Albanians demonstrating in front of party headquarters. The student who spoke to journalists said the Democratic Alliance of Kosovo, a new political movement, represented the interests of all people in Kosovo, both the majority Albanians and minority Serbs. Democratic Alliance leader Ibrahim Rugova claimed Friday that more than 100,000 people had joined in the past month. He said the group, which authorities have called hostile and separatist, had applied for official registration and expected a reply by next week. Rugova said the alliance was cooperating with other movements promoting human rights in the region. International human rights groups and media in Yugoslavia's liberal northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia have claimed human rights violations are common in Kosovo.

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces `String Confetti' Recall
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday announced the recall of three million cans of an aerosol string confetti because the propellant used in the product may be highly flammable. The product, ``Extra Thick Super String,'' often used at children's birthday parties and other celebrations, is hazardous if sprayed near an open flame, said the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The commission received consumer hotline reports of six children who were burned when fires started after the string was sprayed in the area of birthday cakes with candles, said CPSC spokesman Ken Giles. Approximately three million cans of the string were sold nationwide from December 1988 until October 1989, when the New Jersey-based manufacturer, E. Davis, Inc., developed a new inflammable propellant formula, the agency said in a written statement. Consumers should discard any pre-October cans of the product and mail the each orange, blue, pink or green plastic can cap to the company for two replacements with the reformulated items. Send to: E. Davis, Inc., P.O. Box 8060, Piscataway, N.J. 08854-8060.

A grandson and namesake of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said Friday he is dismayed by a proposal to rename Washington Dulles International Airport for Dwight D. Eisenhower. Backers of the name change, however, said they still think it is a good idea, especially since ``Dulles'' often can sound like ``Dallas,'' leading to confusion for international travelers. Under a plan favored by Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas, the airport would be named for Eisenhower, but its central building, designed by famed Finnish architect Eero Saarinen, would bear Dulles' name. Dole is chairman of the Eisenhower Centennial Commission, named to plan ceremonies to mark the 100th anniversary of Eisenhower's birth, Oct. 14. Supporters would like to see the name change take effect by that date. Dulles, 46, an analyst for the U.S. Civil Rights Commission in Los Angeles, said Eisenhower ``was most determined in his belief that the new airport should be named for his close friend and secretary of state.'' ``It is most appropriate that we honor President Eisenhower, on this the centennial of his birth,'' Dulles said. ``However, it would certainly not be in keeping with his desires that the tribute which he accorded my grandfather be taken away in this manner.'' In a letter to The Associated Press, he said: ``I was dismayed to learn that Senator Robert Dole has proposed changing the name of Dulles International Airport. President Eisenhower decreed that the airport should be named for Secretary Dulles, who flew more than half a million miles and who was recognized (before the jet era) as the most traveled Secretary of State in our history.'' Michael D. Barnes, a member of the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority who is lobbying for the change, said, ``My feeling is that we can honor both of these gentlemen in the manner that has been proposed in the Dole resolution.'' The airport authority will decide whether to accept Dole's recommendation. Jane Kratovil, executive director of the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute, said, ``We think it is an appropriate mechanism in the Eisenhower centennial year to pay tribute to two individuals and to try to elevate, if you will, Secretary Dulles' role. As an outsider, I would say that probably 90 per cent of the people that land at Dulles today may not even understand that Dulles was indeed John Foster Dulles, a very important secretary of state.'' The airport in the Virginia suburbs was built during Eisenhower's administration and opened in 1962. Dulles, a Wall Street lawyer long prominent in Republican foreign affairs causes, served as secretary of state from Eisenhower's inauguration in 1953 until shortly before his death in 1959. The secretary's grandson said he also was writing to Dole. The senator's office said the letter had not been received.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Criticizes Theory of `Curing' Homosexuality
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of gay activists, human rights and medical groups Friday harshly criticized a conservative lobbying organization for promoting long-term psychotherapy as a way to ``cure'' homosexuality. ``Research findings suggest that efforts to `repair' homosexuals are nothing more than social prejudice garbed in psychological accouterments,'' said Bryant L. Welch, executive director for professional practice of the American Psychological Association. Welch spoke at a news conference organized by the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. Also participating in the news conference were the Rev. William Sloan-Coffin, president of the SANE-Freeze Campaign for Global Security, and representatives of the Human Rights Campaign Fund, Union of American Hebrew Congregations and Federation of Parents and Friends of Lesbians and Gays Inc. The groups hoped to disrupt a weekend meeting of the National Task Force for the Preservation of the Heterosexual Ethic. ``People can be treated, like they can be treated for alcoholism,'' said the Rev. Louis P. Sheldon, who heads the conservative Traditional Values Coalition that convened the meeting. Sheldon argued that reparative therapy has a 50-year history in behavioral psychology but was removed from the APA's list of recognized mental disorders in 1973 after presssure from gay rights activists. ``The fact is I have not been able to cure one homosexual,'' said Joseph Nicolosi, a psychologist-consultant to the TVC. But Nicolosi said curative efforts must be seen as long-term, sometimes lifetime processes. Sheldon, a Presbyterian minister and his coalition of 6,500 California churches, gained prominence when they helped defeat a domestic-partnership law in San Francisco. Last year, the group tried to include creationism as part of the science curriculum in state schools. Sheldon said his group will publish a report on the meeting, which is closed to the public, next week. A keynote speaker was Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., an outspoken critic of homosexuality.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Make Three-Hour Space Walk
DOC.TEXT: Two Soviet cosmonauts stationed on the Mir orbiting complex installed a docking device for a ``space motorcycle'' and other scientific gear Friday during a three-hour space walk, Tass said. The space walk by Alexander Viktorenko and Alexander Serebrov was their third in recent weeks. They plan two more before they return to Earth in mid-February, ending a six-month mission. The official Soviet news agency said the cosmonauts assembled a docking mechanism that will be used later when they install the ``space motorcycle,'' a device to help cosmonauts get around in open space near the orbiting complex. Tass said they also installed a television camera that will be used for geophysical research and made an inspection of the outside of their spacecraft and checked their radio communications. The two cosmonauts spent three hours and two minutes in space, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Modrow Says East Germany Wants Relations With Israel
DOC.TEXT: Hans Modrow, the Communist premier of East Germany, said Friday his country wants diplomatic relations with Israel and is willing to consider reparations for victims of Nazism. East Germany has never had full relations with Israel because it refused to accept responsibility for Adolf Hitler's extermination of 6 million Jews. Modrow told reporters after meeting with Austrian leaders that East Germany had proposed talks with Israel ``and the problem of reparations will be aired.'' Interest in establishing relations with Israel has grown in Eastern Europe since Communist parties have lost or renounced their power monopolies. West Germany has paid reparations, but Communist East Germany always claimed its people were the anti-Nazi resistance and bore no responsibility for Hitler's actions. Romania was the only East European nation not to follow the Soviet Union in breaking relations with Israel after the Arab-Israeli war of 1967. In September, Hungary became the first to resume diplomatic ties. When asked about his problems at home, Modrow refused to say he would quit the Communist Party, as some opposition groups demand. He said he would be ready to discuss his future relationship with the party when he had built a coalition government, including the opposition, that could run East Germany until free elections scheduled for May 6. Modrow criticized the party for slowness in moving away from its Stalinist past and for abuses under Erich Honecker, who was Communist Party chief for 18 years until his downfall in October. On Friday, Modrow's government faced a new crisis of confidence Friday when one of the four small parties involved said it would pull its three ministers out of the 27-member Cabinet. Modrow told the news conference he was making a ``fair offer'' of a coalition to East Germany opposition groups, which are divided over whether to join any government he leads. He is to visit Moscow Tuesday for talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Company Gets Research Rights
DOC.TEXT: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration on Friday granted a small Virginia company the right to do research and development for using spent space shuttle fuel tanks as a platform for military, civilian and commercial experiments. The agreement, signed with Global Outpost of Alexandria, is the first for using the 154-foot-long tanks which now are destroyed in their plunge through the atmosphere. The tanks carry the 528,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen that carry the shuttle into orbit. Under the agreement, NASA will be reimbursed for any work it does for Global Outpost, a firm formed in 1988 in response to President Reagan's commercial space initiative.

DOC.HEAD: Schroeder Says Partisanship in Base Closings Would Lead to Hill Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2 grafs for 3rd graf pvs, The Pentagon, to insert material on defense budget. Subs 5th graf pvs, Other bases, to CORRECT reference to San Francisco Bay area. Deletes 22nd graf pvs, Cheney is, now redundant.
DOC.TEXT: A senior member of the House Armed Services Committee said Friday that if the Bush administration adopts a partisan approach to closing military bases, a rancorous fight with Congress is certain. Preliminary reports indicate that a large chunk of the bases slated for closing in Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's new list are in the districts of congressional Democrats. The Pentagon is expected to release the list of bases Monday, the same day President Bush presents his proposed defense budget to Congress. Congressional sources and Pentagon documents obtained Friday said Bush would ask for a $7 billion increase, from this year's $301.6 billion to $306.9 billion. Officials said last-minute changes in the closings list are possible. Congressional and Pentagon sources said that among the bases targeted are Fort Ord, Calif., in the district of Democratic Rep. Leon Panetta; Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, represented by Democrat Thomas Foglietta, and Fort Hood, Texas, located in the district of Rep. Marvin Leath, also a Democrat. Other bases mentioned in Texas are all in the districts of Democrats while the installations cited in the San Francisco Bay area are represented by liberal Democrats Barbara Boxer, Nancy Pelosi and Ronald Dellums. Early reports indicated that the Army's Fort Monroe, a training center in Hampton, Va., was on the base closing list, but a spokesman for Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the senator had been assured the site will not be closed. ``There are no significant base closures in Virginia, although there are several minor realignments,'' said spokesman Phil Smith. Fort Monroe is represented in the House by Rep. Herbert Bateman, a Republican. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., chairman of the House Armed Services subcomittee on military installations and facilities, fired a warning shot at the Pentagon on the issue of partisanship in base closings. ``If the Defense Department is going to start playing politics with the defense budget then, heavan help us, that is an invitation for the Congress to start playing with it, and who knows where we can go,'' Schroeder told reporters. Among the red flags that Schroeder said she will look for are base closings that largely target the Air Force and Army, but not the Navy, and disproportionately few closings in the South and overseas. Pentagon sources said the Air Force and Army were expected to suffer the brunt of the closures, far in excess of what the Navy anticipated. ``The Navy's not coughing up much,'' said one official who requested anonymity. Despite the reports, Schroeder said she believed that Cheney, who served as a representative from Wyoming for 10 years, would not be ``silly enough'' to target Democratic districts for base closings. ``Cheney knows this place better than any other secretary of defense,'' she said. The Pentagon plans to brief lawmakers early Monday on the bases it intends to close, said one official. But several members of Congress have already confirmed rumors of closings in their districts and complained loudly. ``I simply do not understand the logic behind trying to close down the most productive and efficient yard, while keeping those yards losing money open,'' Rep. Glenn M. Anderson, D-Calif., said of plans to shut down the Long Beach Naval Shipyard. Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif., issued a statement announcing that the base list does not include any San Diego installations, but does include Naval Air Facility El Centro, home of the Navy's Blue Angels, which is in his district. Rep. Glen Browder, D-Ala., a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said that Fort McClellan, located in his district at Anniston, is among the proposed base closings. ``I am not complaining simply because they're aiming at my district, nor am I criticizing the armed services,'' Browder said. ``They were ordered to cut and being good professional soldiers, they followed orders and cut to the bottom line. ``My complaint is that a numbers crunching machine is determining national policy without proper direction,'' he said. Fort McClellan has 2,700 military and 1,500 civilian personnel. Just one year ago, Congress agreed to follow a congressionally-created commission's recommendation for 86 base closings and five realignments. Last year's closings were part of an all-or-nothing package that could not be changed. This year's base closings proposals will be dealt with on an individual basis as the defense budget is reviewed by the House and Senate armed services committees. ``I could have a hearing every hour on the hour,'' Schroeder said.

DOC.HEAD: Longest-Serving Black in Congress to Retire
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, veteran chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee and the longest-serving black in Congress, said Friday that he will retire at the end of the year. Hawkins, one of the last New Deal Democratic liberals still in office, said he made the decision Thursday night with his wife after concluding that ``maybe I can do a better job calling attention to my concerns on the outside than on the inside.'' The 82-year-old Hawkins has represented the primarily black and Hispanic Watts area of Los Angeles and surrounding Hispanic suburbs since 1963, when he became the first black elected to Congress from a Western state. In 1984, he replaced the late Rep. Carl D. Perkins, D-Ky., as chairman of the education and labor committee. His most likely successor as the panel's chairman is Rep. William D. Ford, D-Mich. Hawkins, in an interview Friday, expressed frustration at the low priority the government has put on education under the Reagan and Bush administrations despite passage two years ago of an $8.3 billion school improvement bill named in his honor. ``If we only implemented that law as it should be, education would be at the top of the agenda,'' he said. ``Instead, we're moving in just the opposite direction, fooling around with fads.'' While an adamant liberal with a 100 percent favorable voting record from the AFL-CIO six of the past eight years, Hawkins took a pragmatic approach in forging alliances with conservatives to advance his agenda. In 1982, for example, he worked with Vice President Dan Quayle, then a conservativee Republican senator from Indiana, and Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, to assure unions and community activist groups a voice in allocating wage subsidies to businesses under the Job Training Partnership Act. ``I never tried to play the role of superstar, that's just not my nature,'' Hawkins said. ``My approach has always been to get some tangible results. You can't let your ego stand in the way.'' Last year, he and Hatch formed an alliance to emphasize early, school-based childhood education for 3- and 4-year-olds as part of a multibillion-dollar child-care bill that remains stymied because of opposition from President Bush and conservative Democrats. With child care high on the agenda of both the administration and Democratic leaders again this year, Hawkins said he fears a compromise now may produce a bad result. ``We may end up with two systems,'' he said, ``one in which the poor will go to inferior care facilities and the wealthy will be able to take care of their own children.'' Narrowing the disparity between rich and poor has always been the focal point of Hawkins' agenda. Just a year after entering Congress, he co-authored the 1964 Civil Rights Act Title VII, which created the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and mandated fair employment practices. In 1978, he was the co-author with the late Sen. Hubert Humphrey of the Humphrey-Hawkins full employment bill, which officially targets an unemployment rate of 4 percent as the nation's goal. For most of the past decade, Hawkins was forced into a role of tilting at windmills as a leading opponent of the so-called Reagan revolution. An increase in the $3.35 an hour minimum wage was shelved for nearly a decade. A raise to $4.25 over the next two years was enacted in November only after House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., bypassed Hawkins to cut a compromise with Bush's staff chief, John Sununu.

DOC.HEAD: Innocent Pleas Entered in IRA Missile Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal magistrate entered innocent pleas Friday for four men accused of plotting to buy a Stinger missile for the Irish Republican Army. The men, who are being represented for free by a legal team experienced with IRA cases, refused to answer the charges before U.S. Magistrate Ann Vitunac. The magistrate entered the innocent pleas and scheduled a Feb. 28 pre-trial hearing in Fort Lauderdale. Michael Dowd, a New York attorney for defendant Kevin McKinley, said the men were advised to stand mute at the arraignment because defense lawyers may challenge the court's jurisdiction in the case. He declined to elaborate on a possible basis for the challenge. ``At this point I'm not ashamed to say I just don't know how we are going to proceed,'' said Dowd, who represented one of five alleged IRA arms suppliers acquitted in a 1982 federal trial in New York. The five-count indictment announced Wednesday charges McKinley, 33; Joseph Martin McColgan, 39; Sean McCann, 34, and Seamus Anthony Moley, 30, of violating the Neutrality Act and the Arms Export Control Act, and conspiring to destroy a British aircraft. The men were arrested Jan. 12 following a two-month operation by undercover federal agents posing as arms dealers, according to a government affidavit. A $47,500 cash payment was made for the 5-foot-long, surface-to-air heat-seeking Stinger missile, which McColgan put in a car at a West Palm Beach warehouse just before his arrest, the affidavit said. The other three men were arrested at a store in North Palm Beach, about 65 miles north of Miami. The men were seeking the shoulder-fired missile for the militant Provisional IRA for use against British military helicopters in Northern Ireland, the affidavit alleged. A U.S. Customs service agent testified in an earlier hearing that the defendants also expressed interest in .50-caliber rifles, detonators and plastic explosives. If convicted, the men each face 38 years in prison. They were being held without bond at the Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami. Dowd and McColgan's lawyer, Frank Durkan of New York, say they have defended dozens of suspected IRA members. Both participated in the so-called ``Brooklyn Five'' case in 1982 in which Irish Northern Aid Committee founder Michael Flannery and four others were acquitted of running sub-machine guns to the IRA. The defense in that case argued the defendants had shipped arms to Northern Ireland for 25 years with the tacit approval of the CIA. Dowd said all four main defense attorneys have taken the case for free. Other defense attorneys are Bruce Zimet of Fort Lauderdale for Moley, and Jo Ann Harris of New York for McCann.

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Bases to be Closed
DOC.TEXT: The United States will close two of its four major military installations in Greece, leaders of political parties said Friday. They made the announcement after leaders of the three parties that support the coalition government met with Premier Xenophon Zolotas. Constantine Mitsotakis, who leads the conservative New Democracy alliance, confirmed a report by the Athens newspaper Ethnos that U.S. Ambassador Michael Sotirhos advised the government Thursday of the U.S. decision. Socialist Party chief Andreas Papandreou told reporters Zolotas brought up the U.S. advisory at their meeting. Harilaos Florakis, head of the Communist Party, said closing the bases would be a ``significant development.'' Ethnos said Sotirhos delivered a letter from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to his Greek counterpart, Tzannis Tzannetakis. It said Hellenikon Air Base, adjacent to Athens International Airport, and the U.S. Navy communications station at Nea Makri, 22 miles southeast of the capital, would close. The Pentagon plans to shut dozens of military installations in the United States and abroad. The two other major U.S. military installations in Greece, both on the island of Crete, are an Air Force communications monitoring post and a refueling base for the Navy's 6th Fleet. Hellenikon, used by reconnaisance aircraft to shadow Soviet fleet movements in the Mediterranean, also is a support station for U.S. bases in Turkey. Nea Makri monitors telephone and telex traffic in the Mediterranean. In addition to the four major bases, the United States has 20 small radar and communications stations in Greece. All were established under the Defense and Cooperation Agreement of the mid-1950s, which also provided $350 million a year in U.S. military aid. A five-year agreement, which expired in December 1988, gave the United States 17 months to dismantle the bases if no new accord was reached. Parliament is to debate a proposal next month to grant a six-month extension beyond the May 21 deadline in order to give negotiators more time. After 17 rounds with no result, talks were suspended before the Greek elections in June. A short-lived conservative-Communist coalition put the issue on hold. Officials in Washington said privately the decision to close Hellenikon and Nea Makri was not related to negotiations on lease renewal.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Associate Who Was Sought by U.S. Army Surrenders
DOC.TEXT: Fugitive Lt. Col. Luis ``Papo'' Cordova, a close associate of Manuel Antonio Noriega and No. 1 man on the U.S. most-wanted list here, gave up after five weeks of hiding and was in U.S. Army custody Friday. Cordova, who surrendered late Thursday, had been the most important member of Noriega's inner group still on the loose. Panamanian authorities want him in connection with the execution of officers involved in the failed coup against Noriega on Oct. 3. He had been in hiding since U.S. forces invaded Panama on Dec. 20 and overthrew dictator Noriega. At one time Cordova sought refuge in the Peruvian Embassy but was turned down. U.S. Army officials said Romulo Escobar Bethancour, a leader of the Revolutionary Democratic Party that backed the previous government, also surrendered to the U.S. military. Escobar Bethancour was a major negotiator of the 1977 treaties that transfer the Panama Canal to Panamanian control on Dec. 31, 1999. U.S. officials would not say what charges were pending against him. Since the invasion the U.S. Army has arrested and held many former government officials or pro-Noriega politicians while the new government prepares charges against them. Sources said Cordova called U.S. officials to arrange for his surrender. He was in an apartment in a residential building downtown. A source at the attorney general's office said Cordova is charged in connection with the execution of Maj. Moises Giroldi, who led the Oct. 3 coup attempt against Noriega. At the time, Giroldi was said to have died in action, but later reports said he and other rebels were executed. Cordova also is wanted for questioning in connection with the beheading of Hugo Spadafora, who tried to organize a guerrilla war against Noriega. Both Cordova and Escobar Bethancour were taken to Fort Clayton. At least 50 other former high-ranking officers of the Defense Forces also are being held there since their arrest or capture after the U.S. invasion. The Inter-American Press Association said Friday that press freedoms have improved considerably since the Dec. 20 invasion. An IAPA mission led by its prresident, Edward Seaton, visited Panama for three days ``to study the situation of the communications media after the U.S. military action and change of government in this country.'' Seaton told reporters his group informed the government of its concern that at least 10 radio stations and two TV stations remained in government hands. ``The IAPA has asked the government that these media, after an adequate investigation, determine what belongs to the state and put them in private hands through equitable means,'' said an IAPA statement. The statement said that despite the improvements the IAPA was recommending, Panama has ``improved very much'' the conditions for freedom of expression. The IAPA commission also asked that the government quickly resolve the cases of three journalists arrested during the invasion. Previously, the government controlled all major broadcast and print media in Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Anarchists Protest Acquittal Of Policeman Who Killed Demonstrator
DOC.TEXT: About 250 anarchists built flaming roadblocks and battled police Friday after an appeals court acquitted a policeman who killed a young protester in 1985. Police fired tear gas at rioters who burned a police bus, said an officer at the scene who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the protestors attacked police with gasoline bombs, sticks and stones. An officer at police headquarters said four policemen were ``slightly injured in stone-throwing incidents.'' He said the anarchists broke into Athens Polytechnic, which they were using as a staging point, and riot squads had pulled back out of sight. All traffic on Patission Street, one of the capital's main streets, was halted Friday night because of the disturbance, the officer at the scene reported. He said no arrests have been made. Earlier Friday, an Athens appeals court voted 6-1 to acquit Athanassios Melistas, 30, originally sentenced to 2{ years in prison for manslaughter and illegal use of a weapon. Melistas was accused of shooting 15-year-old Mihalis Kaltezas on Nov. 17, 1985, when anarchists attacked a police bus after a march commemorating a 1973 student uprising against the military government then in power.

DOC.HEAD: Judge OKs Drug Testing for 19 White House Workers
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday lifted a ban on drug testing for 19 employees in the Executive Office of the President who have ``top secret'' security clearances, but continued to bar the tests for 10 others authorized to see information only up to the level of ``secret.'' In a lawsuit, the employees are challenging random, mandatory urinalysis called for by Bush administration officials, who declare that the employees hold sensitive positions and should be tested. The employees are in the Office of Management and Budget, the Office of Administration and the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative. U.S. District Court Judge Louis Oberdorfer said it is ``unlikely'' that those with top secret clearances will prevail in the case, although he allowed that portion of the lawsuit to proceed. The judge said ``the permissibility of subjecting'' the 10 others to drug tests ``is less clear'' and he kept the ban in place. The government contends, in effect, that information classified as secret is by definition as truly sensitive as top secret information, noted the judge. On the record to date in the lawsuit, ``the government is not likely to prevail on what is apparently the essence of its rationale: that a government agency may, in its discretion, test the urine of any employee who possesses a secret security clearance,'' said Oberdorfer. The judge issued the preliminary injunction May 19 covering a group of federal employees who do not hold White House passes. A 1982 executive order draws the distinction between top secret and secret information by saying that disclosure of the former could reasonably be expected to cause ``exceptionally grave damage'' to the national security. Disclosure of secret information could reasonably be expected to cause ``serious'' damage, says the executive order. Some 2 million federal workers have secret clearances, including State Department personnel with access to routine cables to custodial workers at nuclear weapons plants.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Search House-to-House for Separatist Moslems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to include new details; picks up 5th `In Muzaffarabad,' SUBBING 11th `Indian state' to UPDATE casualties
DOC.TEXT: Troops searched from house to house Friday for pro-Pakistan Moslems waging a violent separatist campaign in Kashmir, and the government imposed a virtual news blackout. At least 70 people, most of them Moslem militants, have been killed since the government began a crackdown Saturday to try to halt separatist violence. Witnesses in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, said soldiers and paramilitary commandos of the elite National Security Guard were searching the city. Similar searches were reported in the nearby towns of Anantnag and Baramulla. Many residents of Srinagar refused to switch on lights after dusk in protest of the crackdown. Journalists were confined to a hotel and told they would be arrested, or even shot, if they stepped outside. They were denied access to telex and telephone lines after the warning. In Muzaffarabad, Pakistan, Premier Sikander Hyat Khan of Pakistani Kashmir said he would launch a Moslem ``holy war'' unless the United Nations schedules a special session to address the Kashmir issue. Muzaffarabad is the capital of Pakistani Kashmir and near the cease-fire that has divided the region between India and Pakistan since 1947, when the subcontinent became independent of Britain and the two nations were created. India and Pakistan have fought four wars, three of them specifically over Kashmir. Most of the 5 million people in the Indian State of Jammu-Kashmir are Moslems. It is the only state with a Moslem majority in India, a predominantly Hindu nation. ``If the United Nations is not ready to play its role ... I will tell them to go and fight,'' Khan warned of the people in Pakistani Kashmir. He gave the world organization until Feb. 17 to schedule a special session. He said the deadline coincided with a scheduled meeting all Pakistani political and religious parties in Islamabad. Tariq Mahmood Butt, head of the student wing of the militant Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, said thousands of its members would cross the frontier Feb. 11 if the United Nations did not promise action. Indian state television described the situation in Jammu-Kashmir as ``by and large peaceful,'' but said paramilitary troops fired on rioters Thursday in Handwara, 40 miles northwest of Srinagar. A government spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 11 people were killed and 14 wounded. Troops in Srinagar tightened restrictions under the 24-hour curfew and prevented residents from opening windows, said witnesses reached by telephone. From various vantage points in Srinagar, a city of 1 million, only heavily armed troopers and an occasional government official could be seen on the streets. Several people reached by telephone from inside and outside Srinagar said they had not heard gunfire. Police sources in Jammu, winter capital of the state, said militants hurled a gasoline bomb at soldiers during house searches but no one was injured. The increased security coincided with the Moslem sabbath and Republic Day, which major towns and cities in India usually celebrate with military parades. Moslem separatists in Jammu-Kashmir, who want the state to be either independent or joined to Pakistan, declared the national holiday a ``black day.'' Television showed Jameel Qureshi, adviser to the Jammu-Kashmir state governor, taking the salute at a parade in Srinagar's Bakshi Stadium. No civilian spectators were shown and a policeman who was there said none attended. District magistrate Ghulam Abbas told about 20 journalists at the Hotel Broadway: ``If you go out of the hotel, you can be shot, and if we find out you have gone out, you can be imprisoned for six months.'' Soldiers with submachine guns were posted around the hotel, which is about a mile from downtown Srinagar. The door leading to the roof of the five-story building was locked and telephone service was halted after the warning by Abbas. Seven journalists returned to New Delhi on a commercial flight Friday afternoon. They said police took them to the Srinagar airport by a circuitous route one officer said was designed to skirt trouble. Police at the airport confiscated dozens of rolls of film, they said. The Moslem separatist campaign is as old as the two nations, but has escalated in recent weeks. Srinagar and surrounding towns were put under 24-hour curfew Saturday and soldiers and paramilitary troopers were deployed. Their number has not been released, but is known to be at least in the hundreds.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Ask that Noriega be Declared POW
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to RECAST lead, UPDATE with prosecutors suggesting judge, U.S. attorney general may have been subject of Noriega curse. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Malman promised...'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ordered Manuel Noriega held without bond Friday after his attorneys repudiated the court's jurisdiction, insisting the deposed dictator be declared a prisoner of war and transferred to a neutral country. The prosecution gave several reasons why Noriega should not be released on bail, and suggested he may have placed a voodoo-type curse on four Americans, including the U.S. District Court judge himself, William Hoeveler, and U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. The government said the names were found at a Noriega office where a black magic altar was discovered during the U.S. invasion of Panama. Prosecutors listed homes, bank deposits, sports cars and other assets worth up to $30 million, including $5.8 million in cash found in Noriega's Panama ranch, to bolster their argument that Noriega would flee the country if necessary. They also said Noriega is an expert in counterterrorism and covert actions and still has a loyal band of armed followers. ``Mr. Noriega is an extraordinary danger to the community,'' prosecutor Myles Malman told Hoeveler, noting that Noriega faces 145 years in prison. Hoeveler, noting the defense's refusal to participate in the bond hearing, said he had no choice but to order Noriega, 51, held without bond. Defense attorney Frank Rubino, opened the hearing by telling the judge the defense would not participate because it challenges the jurisdiction of the U.S. court system and his client is covered by the Geneva Convention. Noriega sat quietly nearby in military uniform listening with interpreters' headphones. The motion said Noriega in a letter delivered Friday morning to President Bush and the secretary of state ``claimed the status of prisoner of war pursuant to the Geneva Convention.'' ``There can be absolutely no question, whatsoever, that the invasion of Panama by the United States military totally and completely fulfills the definition of armed conflict,'' Rubino said, reading from the motion. Hoeveler did not consider the motion immediately and Malman began his arguments against bond in the hearing stemming from the February 1988 drug indictment. As part of his presentation, Malman implied that a curse may have been placed on Hoeveler, Thornburgh and two other men whose names were found on a white sheet of paper confiscated by U.S. troops at Noriega's Fort Amador office _ referred to as the ``Witch House'' because of black magic paraphernalia discovered there. The other two named on the list were Charles Saphos, head of the Justice Department's drug section, and Mark Schnapp, a former Miami federal prosecutor who helped bring about the Noriega indictment. ``Maybe I better not enter it into evidence,'' the judge joked as Malman handed him the list. Malman promised the government would show that Noriega has a $400,000 condominum in Paris, and that $5,800,000 in cash was found in envelopes marked ``confidential'' in his three-story home in Panama. The prosecution also introduced photos of deposit slips showing that Noriega's 17-year-old daughter deposited $1.3 million in Panamanian banks in September 1989. ``The U.S. govenment has frozen $20 million in Noriega assets _ $4.8 million in Luxembourg; $2.3 million in France, $8 million in Switzerland, $1.6 million in Austria and $3.5 million in other accounts that we do not wish to disclose at this time,'' Malman said. The prosecution maintained that Noriega also transferred about $19 million from his account at Bank of Credit and Commerce International's London branch to its Luxembourg branch a week after the indictment was unsealed. It was not clear whether the deposits and seizures were duplicated in the prosecution's listings. In addition to the vast sums Noriega was said to have deposited overseas, Malman said Noriega also had friends in countries at odds with the United States, including Cuba and Libya. He noted that Moammar Gadhafi had presented Noriega with his and hers Gadhafi watches which the Libyan leader gives to personal acquaintances. Asked by Hoeveler at the end of the session if he wished to rebut prosecution arguments, Rubino replied by reciting Noriega's name, rank and serial number _ 0001. The defense motion had noted that ``Noriega, in his capacity as chief of state and commander in chief of the Panamanian Defense Forces was recognized as the leader of the Republic of Panama by the United Nations, the Organization of American States and independent governments in this hemisphere and throughout the world.'' The defense contends that an international tribunal, perhaps the World Court at The Hague or Geneva, must automatically be invoked by Noriega's alleged POW status. Noriega has been held without bail since he was flown to the United States Jan. 4 and jailed in the federal courthouse basement here to face 12 drug-trafficking counts from the 1988 indictment. The defense had refused to ask for bail because of the denial of U.S. jurisdiction in his case. Prosecutors, however, feared that failure to guard Noriega's rights could later undermine their case. Under a federal magistrate's orders, defense attorneys Rubino and Steven Kollin have given prosecutors a list of two homes and three offices Noriega used in Panama. In return, the government was to supply an inventory of what was taken from the residences before Friday's bond hearing began. The hearing was the first time attorneys for Noriega or his five co-defendants, in custody or out on bond, have seen any of the government's case. Ten others named in the indictment are still at large. Richard Sharpstein, an attorney for co-defendant Brian Alden Davidow, attended the hearing and talked briefly with Noriega before the judge arrived. ``He has a good sense of humor,'' Sharpstein said. ``I asked him if he was going to watch the Super Bowl with George Bush, and he laughed and gave me the thumbs up.''

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Suggests New East European Union
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia suggested Friday that Eastern Europen countries emerging from Communist domination form an informal, market-oriented union. ``It is clear that our countries, which only recently were Soviet satellites, are now seeking the path to democracy and to rejoining Europe,'' Havel told reporters at the end of a one-day visit to Hungary. ``It only stands to reason we should see about coordinating our moves.'' Havel said he planned to organize a meeting in April of government and opposition leaders from Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. He said the foreign ministers of Austria, Italy and Yugoslavia also would be invited to the conference in Bratislava, capital of Slovakia. ``The purpose would be to discuss not only the possibilities of our return to Europe, but also the sort of Europe we want to return to,'' said the Czechoslovak president, a playwright who was his country's leading dissident before Communist rule crumbled last month. Havel did not mentioned precise areas of possible cooperation and said policy coordination would not interfere with individual projects involving outside countries. He said Czechoslovakia had accepted an invitation by President Matyas Szueroes of Hungary to link policies with Austria, Hungary, Italy and Yugoslavia. Poland and Czechoslovakia also are initiating ``northern Baltic cooperation, with Czechoslovakia acting as a link'' with Austria, Hungary, Italy and Yugoslavia,'' Havel added, without giving details. It was not clear whether that project would extend to the three Soviet Baltic republics, which seek autonomy or independence. On a visit Thursday to Warsaw, Havel proposed that Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary work together to rejoin Europe as politically independent states. In a brief address to Poland's parliament, he expressed hope that ``the Prague parliament, too, will soon be a real parliament, with a strong and intelligent opposition sitting across from me in the chamber.'' Czechoslovakia plans free elections in June. Hungary's elections are scheduled for March.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget to Call for VA Loan Down Payments, Sources Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs, `And Rep...,' to UPDATE with Cranston comment; SUBS 11th graf pvs `Sen. Alan ...' to DELETE now redundant 1st reference to Cranston; SUBS 22nd graf pvs, `As for ...' to DELETE incorrect reference to Senate VA Committee
DOC.TEXT: For the first time, veterans would be required to make down payments on VA home loans to buy even the most modestly priced houses under a proposal in President Bush's new budget, sources say. Officials of veterans groups were quick to denounce the idea, with one of them saying such a plan ``dashes the dreams of countless veterans of participating in the American dream of home ownership.'' And Rep. Sonny Montgomery, D-Miss., chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, said simply on Friday, ``I'm not going to buy that,'' though he added he was pleased with other aspects of the budget request. ``I will strongly oppose all changes in the fundamental nature of this important veterans benefit,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., chairman of the Senate Veteran Affairs Committee. According to sources familiar with the proposal, Bush's $31 billion budget request for veterans programs will include a request that military vets be required to make a 4 percent down payment for loans over $25,000. The VA has already imposed a 5 percent down payment requirement for its mobile home loan program. And an unofficial down payment system already is permitted to exist for relatively expensive houses. For example, a borrower who wants to buy an $80,000 home but whose income would permit the purchase of only a $75,000 home under the VA program can pay a $5,000 ``down payment'' to make up the difference. But such a broad down-payment requirement is unprecedented for the 45-year-old VA program instituted as American men returned home after World War II. Under the Bush proposal, due to be released Monday, VA-insured loans under $25,000 would still be exempt from any down payment. The exemption is designed to cover home improvements such as additions to a house. In another area, the budget for veterans will call for federal spending of $12.3 billion for health care, $1 billion more than appropriated for the current fiscal year, according to the sources, who commented on condition they not be named. That total would cover actual health care services provided by the Veterans Affairs Department, not entitlement payments such as disability compensation. Cranston said that if the medical-care figure proves accurate, Veterans Secretary ``Ed Derwinski has done a tremendous job in convincing the president that the downward spiral in VA health care must be haulted.'' Federal Housing Administration loans, also government-insured, already require a 5 percent down payment, while conventional home loans outside government programs can require down payments as high as 20 percent. The GI home loan program was begun to ease the housing crunch for returning soldiers and to stimulate the construction industry after World War II. The lack of a down payment requirement has been a key advantage. The program has undergone heavy losses in the past, due to heavy foreclosures, especially as a result of the oil depression in Texas and Oklahoma. According to the VA Department, 178,000 guaranteed loans will be closed in this fiscal year, with the average loan amounting to $70,000. The administration also proposes to increase the ``mortgage indemnity fee'' from 1.25 percent to 1.75 percent. That fee, which began this month as a result of a law passed late last year, is used to back up the home loans and to protect veterans from liability in case of foreclosure. Before that, borrowers paid only a 1 percent origination fee. ``If the 4 percent proposed down payment to the VA home loan above $25,000 is part of the budget, it represents a drastic change in the very concept and intent of the 45-year-old VA home loan program,'' said Larry W. Rivers, executive director of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. ``It is an unreasonable, an unfair proposal, which dashes the dreams of countless veterans of participating in the American dream of home ownership,'' he said. Said spokesman John Hanson of the American Legion: ``If that's going to be a plan then it seems like the VA again is trying to make veterans bail out the home loan program, a program whose problems veterans have not created. ``And it seems very odd that raising the indemnity fee before it's had time to work is going to be part of the solution.'' Veterans groups say veterans are being unfairly blamed for defaults. They say losses are due to poor administration of the program, especially in determining eligibility, and to the VA selling off its good loan portfolios in order to lower the deficit. As for health-care funding, the proposed increase would still leave spending short of the amounts requested by veterans organizations. Although Congress appropriated $11.5 billion for fiscal 1990 for health care, but $160 million was cut from that under the Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law. The total proposed increase would go largely for personnel costs. Included is $70 million in pay increases for VA doctors, nurses and other health care professionals in order to slow departures to higher-paying private jobs. The veterans service groups say $13.4 billion is needed for health care funding for 1991. In a letter last December to the White House, Cranston urged Bush to restore the $160 million and request a $252.4 million supplemental appropriation for 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Trying to Sell Stalin Statue
DOC.TEXT: Local officials are looking for someone who will pay $50,000 for their statue of Josef Stalin. Vladimir Till, deputy chairman of the Zabreh Municipal National Committee, told the daily Mlada Fronta at least two West Germans had expressed interest in the 12-foot statue since a For Sale ad was placed in Wednesday's Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. The official Czechoslovak news agency CTK said Alois Frank, another official of this town about 100 miles northeast of Prague, reported that ``many other media want to print the advertisement'' and he felt it was only a question of time before buyers appeared. The statue of the Soviet dictator was removed from public display Dec. 8. It had stood since 1950, three years before Stalin's death, and was paid for with funds originally earmarked for a likeness of Tomas G. Masaryk, founder of the Czechoslovak republic.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Propose $7 Billion Military Budget Increase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``Following the,'' to note inflation factor and recent spending trends; SUBS 3rd graf: ``Planned budget,'' similarly; SUBS 16th graf: ``Among the,'' to note V-22 and F-14D kept alive last year by Congress; SUBS lede to recast
