DOC.TEXT: President Bush will propose a $7 billion increase in military spending in the new budget, including money for five B-2 stealth bombers and two land-based nuclear missiles, according to congressional sources and Pentagon documents. The budget, to be released formally on Monday, includes a reduction of 38,000 in military personnel, the mothballing of two battleships and cancellation of several weapons programs, including the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft and the Army's M-1 tank. Planned budget outlays for the year beginning Oct. 1 total $303.3 billion _ up 2.4 percent, less than inflation, from this year's $296.3 billion _ according to military spending documents made available to The Associated Press Friday by congressional sources. The figure includes $292.1 billion for Pentagon spending, up from $286.8 billion, with the rest representing Energy Department spending for nuclear programs. Total budget authority for the military would be $306.9 billion, up from $301.6 billion, also including Energy Department money. Pentagon officials, confirming the figures, stressed that the spending would represent a 2 percent decline in defense purchasing power after inflation. Following the buildup of the early Reagan years, so-called ``real'' defense spending _ that is, spending after inflation has been factored out _ has been declining slightly since 1986, even though the Reagan and Bush administrations have been calling for modest real increases. The new budget will represent the first proposal by an administration since the 1970s for a real decrease. The budget figures come on the heels of dramatic changes in Eastern Europe that have raised speculation that a diminishing Soviet threat could lead to reduced military budgets in the United States. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, in comments included in the documents, said the budget ``represents the first steps in responding to changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, as well as tighter budget constraints.'' Cheney said that while defense cuts were in order, this is ``the worst possible time to contemplate changes in defense strategy.'' Defense Department officials have been talking for weeks about military reductions that would save $180 billion over five years. But those savings are measured against Bush administration plans made last spring to boost Pentagon spending to levels now seen as unrealistically high. Among the proposals in the budget is $5.5 billion in Pentagon spending for five B-2 stealth bombers. Congress last year approved funds for components for the five bombers in fiscal 1991, but that total is still expected to come under attack on Capitol Hill where lawmakers have expressed sticker shock over the cost of the radar-evading bombers _ about $530 million apiece. The budget also includes $2.8 billion for 12 multiple-warhead, MX rail-garrison missiles and $202 million for the single-warhead, Midgetman missile. The fiscal 1990 budget that emerged from Congress included slightly more than $1 billion for the two land-based nuclear missiles. Money for the Strategic Defense Initiative _ popularly known as Star Wars _ totals about $4.5 billion in Pentagon spending, which when added to about $300 million in Department of Energy and military construction money amounts to $4.8 billion, a $1 billion increase over the amount Congress approved last year. The budget also includes plans to mothball two battleships, the USS New Jersey and the USS Iowa, and various cancellations of weapons programs, some of which had been placed on the chopping block last year. Among the programs terminated are the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft, the Navy's F-14D jet fighter, the Phoenix and Maverick missiles, the Apache helicopter, the Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP), the F-15E fighter and the M-1 tank. Congress kept the V-22 and the F-14D alive last year over administration objections. The budget calls for a reduction in active troop strength by 38,000 from the nearly 2.1 million and cuts in civilian forces of 5,000 and reserves by 3,000. At the Pentagon, a senior administration official focused on the idea that the spending would represent a decline in purchasing power after inflation is taken into account. ``It means that we will be able to buy fewer planes, tanks, and ships, and support fewer troops,'' said the official, who spoke only on condition he not be named.

DOC.HEAD: Four Shot to Death by Security Guards as Hijacking Foiled
DOC.TEXT: Four men brandishing pistols and grenades were shot to death by security guards that foiled their attempt to hijack a domestic Iran Air flight, Tehran radio reported Friday. The broadcast quoted an official of the Internal Security Force, whose agents overcame the hijackers, as saying hijackers with hand grenades and Colt pistols had taken a crew member hostage in an attempt to force the pilot to fly the Boeing 727 to Israel or Iraq. The radio said the hijackers of Thursday's flight were ``American agents whose attempts to hijack an Iranian airliner were foiled.'' Iran Air Flight 133 was on a flight from Shiraz to the port city of Bandar Abbas, the radio reported. It said the hijackers attempted to take control of the plane about 90 miles from Shiraz, in southern Iran. The Internal Security Force, whose agents fly on every Iran Air flight, said all four hijackers were killed in a shootout with agents on board the plane. None of the passengers were wounded and the plane returned to Shiraz after the attempt, the radio said in a report monitored in Nicosia. It said a team was trying to determine the identity of the gunmen.

DOC.HEAD: Rail Strike Ending in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: A mediator said Friday that black workers and management have agreed tentatively to end a 12-week-old railway strike that killed more than 30 people and caused millions of dollars in property damage. The far-right Conservative Party denounced the settlement involving the state-owned South African Transport Services, saying the government had ``capitulated to radical groups.'' ``It is shocking that after one of the most violent strikes .. . the strikers have again been installed in their posts,'' party transport spokesman Jurg Prinsloo said. Charles Nupen, who began mediation efforts last week, said management of Transport Services and officials of the South African Railways and Harbor Workers Union planned to sign the accord Saturday. Neither the union nor management would comment on the tentative agreement. Nupen said the company agreed to recognize the union, as demanded by the 25,000 strikers. But the statement said nothing of a requested pay increase. The company fired almost all the strikers, but agreed to rehire them, Nupen said. The walkout was illegal under legislation that bars industrial action against essential services. The transport company employs about 170,000 people and runs rail and harbor operations nationwide. The workers struck Nov. 2, demanding that the minimum monthly wage be increased from $240 to $600. Numerous battles between strikers and non-strikers followed. Railway coaches and track were sabotaged in dozens of incidents. The company says it suffered property damage of $16 million.

DOC.HEAD: Storm That Battered Western Europe Sinks Ship in Baltic Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs to UPDATE with meteorological forecast having warned since Sunday of severe conditions, Thatcher government accused. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON5
DOC.TEXT: A powerful storm that killed at least 94 people in northwest Europe swept into the Baltic Sea on Friday, sinking a Danish ship and leaving behind hundreds of injured and damage estimated at more than $1 billion. The storm, with winds recorded Thursday at 110 mph, knocked out communications and power and paralyzed transportation in large areas of Britain and the Continent. Shipping was badly disrupted and $29 million worth of greenhouses were shattered in Holland's flower-growing region. With winds diminished but still at gale force, the storm moved across the Baltic on Friday, hitting Scandinavia, northern Poland and the Soviet republics of Latvia and Lithuania, Britain's meteorological center said. Britain was hardest hit, with 46 people reported killed by collapsing roofs, falling trees, and in traffic accidents. Official reports said 19 people died in Holland, 10 in Belgium, eight in France, seven in West Germany and four in Denmark. Crews scrambled on Friday to restore power to a million homes and clear toppled cars from cluttered highways. On Thursday wind tore a hole in the roof of Parliament in London and toppled a nuclear plant chimney in France. The European Community said it would aid victims of the storm after it completes an assessment of the damage. In the Baltic Sea, the Danish boat Jotun sank Friday off East Germany in heavy seas. A Danish helicopter rescued three crew members, but one later died. Three others were missing and presumed dead after their lifeboat was found empty. Dutch authorities said hundreds of Dutch were injured in the storm, the worst in a decade. Four main rail lines remained closed Friday. The death toll in Britain far exceeded that of Oct. 16, 1987, when the country's worst storm in centuries left 17 people dead. That storm struck late at night, when most people were indoors. The storm Thursday caught motorists on country roads where falling trees caused many deaths. Trucks flipped over on major highways, making them impassable. Children were at school, and two died and 16 were hurt when roofs collapsed. Roof tiles, scaffolding and heaps of brick from collapsed chimneys littered sidewalks around London. The government said at one point 1 million people, mostly in western England, were without electric power. Subway, rail, bus and air services halted in the London area Thursday but transport workers were out through the night clearing debris from the tracks and were able to restore much of the rail service by Friday. The London newspaper The Independent said insurers put early estimates of damage to property in Britain at more than $1.3 billion, compared with $1.8 billion for the 1987 storm. In Sweden, winds uprooted trees and damaged houses, but no injuries were reported. In Belgium, winds reached 105 mph, bending or knocking down power, radio and television towers and destroying countless buildings in towns and rural areas. At least three people were crushed by trees, cyclists were swept under trucks and people were blown from roofs while trying to make repairs. The storm struck a large area of West Germany, from Hamburg, in the north, where streets were flooded; to Bavaria in the south, where damaged cars and fallen trees littered roads. A West German Navy helicopter rescued 29 people from the Soviet fish factory ship Briz, which ran into rough seas off the Dutch island of Terschelling. A Belgian helicopter picked up another 19 crew members. A helicopter and rescue boat searched the English Channel for three French sailors missing since their catamaran capsized while being towed Thursday. The storm disrupted ferry services across the channel on Thursday. On Friday morning, ferries were back on the channel, and service was restored between Scotland and Northern Ireland, where heavy snow added to road problems. ``These are the worst weather conditions I have ever seen in well over 20 years of service,'' said Capt. James Martin, skipper and P and O's Pride of Kent ferry. A chimney was blown down at the Paluel nuclear power plant in France. State-owned Electricite de France said the plant was shut down immediately. France's Central Service for Protection against Ion Radiation issued a statement Friday saying there was no danger of a radiation leak, but said it would increase surveillance at the site until the stack is rebuilt. The government's Meteorological Office, which is responsible for weather forecasting in Britain, said severe conditions had been widely forecast since Sunday and that warnings had been broadcast. But David Blunkett, environment spokesman for the opposition Labor Party, accused Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government of failing to take precautions. ``Adequate (government) warnings would have helped, so would appropriate civil defense preparation,'' Blunkett said. The failure of the Meteorological Office to forecast the 1987 hurricane in Britain led to severe criticism and an official inquiry. This found that the weathermen had followed computer projections too rigidly and failed to take into account factors that might have shown the computer forecast in error.

DOC.HEAD: Bush `Certifies' Panama as Quayle Leaves on Fence-Mending Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs `Quayle was ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with vice president leaving U.S.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Congress Friday that Panama is now cooperating in international anti-drug efforts as Vice President Dan Quayle headed for meetings with Latin leaders to soothe anger at the U.S. invasion. Bush sent the certificnt of President Guillermo Endara has made the war against drugs a centerpiece of its program.'' Bush said Panama's government and people ``recognize that it is in their direct national interest to end their association with the scourge of drugs,'' citing the return of Noriega to the United States to face drug-trafficking charges. Quayle left Friday evening for Honduras, where he was to attend the presidential inauguration on Saturday, and meet with six attending heads of state later in the day. The presidents of Costa Rica, Venezuela, Belize, Guatemala, El Salvador as well as Honduras scheduled meetings with Quayle. In addition to their bilateral concerns, a topic of discussion was expected to be the continued presence of U.S. troops in Panama, which has particularly rankled the South Americans. The Central American nations were generally less strident in their criticisms of the invasion. ``I hope the reception is a good one,'' Quayle told reporters before leaving on the trip Friday evening. ``My message will be one of friendship, consultation, where do we go from here. How do we build democracy in Panama. How do we build how do we build democracy in our Western Hemisphere.'' Asked if he expected to encounter opposition from the leaders he sees, he replied, ``I'll find out when I get there.'' Quayle has stressed that he hopes to consult with the Latin leaders on future cooperation, and urge them to recognize the Endara government rather than focusing on the past or ``fence-mending'' efforts. However, Bush has said he recognizes the hurt feelings that remain over the Panama invasion, widely viewed in the region as an invasion of Panama's sovereignty. In addition, the Latin countries did not look kindly on U.S troops surrounding the Vatican Embassy where Noriega initially took refuge or the intrusion into the home of the Nicaraguan ambassador. Bush said he wants Quayle to explain that the invasion, aimed at toppling Noriega, was not taken just to show wanton use of military might. Quayle travels Sunday to Panama, where he will discuss details of Bush's $1 billiion aid package, much of which will need congressional approval for the spending. On Monday, Quayle will stop in Jamaica, where he is expected to face complaints about a $25 million cut in U.S. economic assistance to that Caribbean nation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Confirms Peace Proposal from Mandela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `The country's' to CORRECT spelling of Treurnicht on first reference. Picks up 3rd, `Mandela, South ...'
DOC.TEXT: The government confirmed for the first time Friday that it had received a written peace proposal from jailed black leader Nelson Mandela, but said its contents were secret. The country's most powerful right-wing politician, Andries Treurnicht of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, demanded the government halt its consultations with Mandela. The prisoner's goal was ``white surrender,'' Treurnicht said. Mandela, South Africa's best-known black leader, is expected to be freed within weeks after more than 27 years in prison. He is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of an anti-government sabotage campaign by the outlawed African National Congress. Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee said Friday that he received from Mandela on Dec. 12 a proposal titled ``A Document to Create a Climate of Understanding.'' ``The document is confidential and enjoys the status of a useful background document,'' said Coetsee. The same document reportedly has been forwarded to the ANC's exiled leaders. It is believed to suggest steps to bring about negotiations between the government and the ANC, which has the largest following among South Africa's black majority. Mandela has met regularly in recent months with government and anti-apartheid leaders. Coetsee, one of the officials involved in these meetings, said last week the government might accept Mandela's offer to serve as mediator in negotiations with the ANC. On Thursday, South newspaper, an anti-apartheid weekly in Cape Town, published a policy document written by Mandela urging such negotiations. Both Mandela and Coetsee said Friday this was not the peace proposal submitted in December. Mandela said he wrote the policy document early last year, handed it to a team of government officials, and informed the ANC of it. He denied news reports that he had presented the document to then-President P.W. Botha when they met in July or to President F.W. de Klerk when they met in December. De Klerk, who took office in August, says he wants to ease restrictions on political activity to the extent that the ANC will agree to talks. Mandela wrote that the negotiators' crucial task will be to reconcile blacks' demands for majority rule with whites' desire for protection from black domination. ``Most Africans, black and white, hope to see the ANC and the government working closely together for a new era in our country in which racial discrimination and prejudice, coercion and confrontation, death and destruction, will be forgotten,'' he wrote. ``The move I have taken (to serve as mediator) provides you with the opportunity to overcome the current deadlock,'' he wrote. ``I hope you will seize it without delay.'' Treurnicht, whose party won 31 percent of the white vote in general elections last year, said the government was ``making a myth of a man who had been found guilty of a crime similar to high treason.'' ``What Mandela and the ANC demand is the transfer of power to the so-called majority,'' Treurnicht said. ``It must be clearly understood that the white people will under no circumstances negotiate its own demise.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Jamaicans Found Slain Execution-Style
DOC.TEXT: Police searched Friday for the killers of five people who were found shot to death execution-style in what authorities say were drug-related murders. Police, citing testimony from neighbors and the victims' four children, who were not hurt, said four men burst into a home early Thursday in rural White Hall, on the island's mountainous east end, and killed each of the victims with a single shot to the head. National Security Minister K.D. Knight flew by helicopter to the scene and described it as a ``horror story.'' Those killed were taxi driver Samuel Reid, 34, his common-law wife Sharon Morris, 26; Ernest Moyston, 31, unemployed; his common-law wife Carlene Munroe, 26; and her twin sister Arlene Ashley. All were White Hall residents. The intruders demanded money and marijuana from the group, shot Moyston, Ms. Munroe and Ms. Ashley in Moyston's house, then took Reid and Ms. Morris outside and shot them across the road under a banana tree, police said. Police said they believed the shooting had something to do with a dispute over marijuana smuggling. The adjacent homes of Reid and Moyston were ransacked, and an undetermined amount of money was stolen from Moyston's house. Police said the two families were neighbors and known to be close friends. Moyston's 11-year-old daughter Janice and 6-year-old son Andre, and Reid's two children, both under 13, were awakened by the shooting but were not taken hostage or hurt, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Announcing Budget Increases, but Economy May Not Cooperate
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS $8.5 million to $8.5 billion in 9th graf, which is 2nd bullet graf: ``_Increased spending,''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday announced another big increase in proposed spending _ this time for Head Start _ in a $1.2 trillion 1991 budget he said was designed to provide ``opportunity for all.'' At the same time, however, economists were saying the optimistic deficit projections underpinning Bush's spending plan were threatened by signs of a weakening economy. The anemic 0.5 percent growth in the gross national product reported Friday for the final three months of 1989 could make meeting the new budget's deficit-reduction goals all but impossible, some analysts contended. From proposed increases in spending for wildlife and recreation to tougher terms for home-buying military veterans, details of Bush's budget were sprouting all over official Washington in advance of Monday's official release of the spending plan for the year beginning Oct. 1. Bush himself was anything but tight-lipped, announcing some of the increases himself and telling the U.S. Conference of Mayors that his budget would ``build on prosperity'' and ``together we can create opportunity for all.'' One day after unveiling the anti-drug portion of his budget, calling for a spending increase of $1.1 billion, he proposed what he hailed as ``the largest increase ever'' for Head Start, a $500 million gain for the preschool program for disadvantaged youths. Administration officials say the budget will re-propose much of Bush's ``unfinished agenda'' from 1989. According to administration and congressional officials, the budget will include these highlights: _No new general tax hikes and a renewal of Bush's call for a lower capital gains tax rate, a tax credit for adoptions and for child care. _Increased spending for environmental, education and drug programs but a $8.5 billion slash in Medicare funds, and a requirement that veterans for the first time be required to make down payments of 4 percent on VA home loans as small as $25,000. _The most austere Pentagon budget in more than a decade. Bush will propose $292 billion in new outlays, up only slightly from current spending. However, the budget will include a request for increased spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative to $4.8 billion, up from $3.8 billion this year. _A massive tree-planting program to help combat global warming and an appeal to developers not to clear-cut new tracts but to leave as many original trees standing as possible. Bush also has promised support for elevating the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet status. _Sharp cuts in a variety of energy-conservation programs, including $350 million from a program that helps poor people pay their heating bills and $161 million from one that helps them weatherize their homes. _An increase in federal spending for education by $500 million over this year's level of $24.1 billion _ but coupled with cuts in the Pell Grant program that would knock 14,000 college students off the rolls and cut stipends for another 1.3 million. _A new ``family savings account'' that would allow people to earn tax-free interest and dividends on money that is squirreled away for at least seven years _ with contributions of up to $5,000 per year per family. The 1,592-page budget document was in its final press run on Friday, said Donna Alexander, a spokeswoman for the Government Printing Office. Some 24,000 of the blue-jacketed documents are being printed, and they will go on sale Monday at government bookshops for $38 apiece. But even as the ink was drying on the final budgets to come off the presses, a new government economic report raised fresh doubts about the administration's assertions that the Bush budget would lower the federal deficit to $64 billion, as required by the Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law. The budget deficit was $152 billion last year and administration economists estimate it will decline to around $100 billion this year. The Commerce Department reported Friday that economic growth in the last three months of 1989 had fallen to 0.5 percent when adjusted for inflation, considerably worse than had been projected by the Office of Management and Budget as it put together the economic assumptions for the new budget. The budget to be released on Monday will project economic growth for this year of 2.6 percent, even though the Congressional Budget Office had issued a more pessimistic prediction of 1.8 percent. Slower growth has a direct impact on the budget deficit, increasing it as revenues to the government fall. The Bush budget also assumes declining interest rates, while interest rates in the past few weeks have been inching up _ also potentially adding to the deficit. The recent economic figures will make ``total hash'' of the administration's claims that its spending outline _ which does not contain any new taxes _ can significantly reduce the budget deficit, said Michael Evans, president of a Washington-based economic forecasting service. ``We're in the worst of all possible worlds. Interest rates are going up, growth is going down,'' Evans said. Every 1 percent decline in growth, as measured by the gross national product, raises the budget deficit by $15 billion. Every 1 percent rise in interest rates increases it by about $10 billion. Even before the GNP report, the bipartisan Congressional Budget Office predicted the deficit this year would be $138 billion _ far above the Bush forecast. Chief White House economist Michael Boskin argued that the poorer-than-expected GNP showing would have only a modest impact on the Bush budget. He said the administration would not revise its forecasts at this time, in expectation that the economy would rebound later this year. Still, he predicted a ``period of slower growth.''

DOC.HEAD: Palmer Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Mark Palmer, U.S. ambassador to Hungary, has resigned, the State Department said Friday. The department released a copy of Palmer's statement in Budapest that he was resigning to ``avoid any possible conflict of interest.'' The New York Times said in a dispatch from Budapest Friday that Palmer would manage a consortium of financiers from the United States and Canada that had bought a half-interest in a Hungarian bank. Palmer will leave Budapest next Wednesday. A career Foreign Service officer, he took over in Budapest in 1986. The Times said he had planned to leave in July. The department's announcement said Secretary of State James A. Baker III had recommended a successor to President Bush, but did not say who that person is.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Sues Over Illness, Blaming Diet Supplement
DOC.TEXT: A couple has sued a maker and retailer of the diet supplement L-tryptophan, saying it gave the wife a rare and painful blood disorder that required hospitalization and left her unable to work. Federal officials suspect that contaminants in some batches of the over-the-counter supplement caused the disorder in 1,000 Americans last year and have blamed the ailment for at least one death. L-tryptophan, an enzyme, is sold as a natural sleeping aid. The lawsuit, filed Thursday by Louise and Donald Pangle, alleges that she suffered rashes starting in September and later developed muscle aches, nausea, weakness and other pain. Mrs. Pangle, 39, was hospitalized twice in November and has yet to return to her job, said the Pangles' attorney, Joe Leman. The lawsuit Catoosa County Superior Court names Price Ringgold Drugs of Ringgold and Nature's Bounty Inc. and Hudson Corp., both of Bohemia, N.Y., as defendants, he said. It says the companies were negligent in the making, testing and sale of the product and failed to warn the public about possible dangers of taking the supplement, he said. The attorney said papers had yet to be served on the defendants, and no hearing date has been set. Telephone calls Friday to Nature's Bounty went unanswered. Outbreaks of the disorder, eosinophillia-myalgia syndrome, first appeared last year in New Mexico, afflicting more than 1,000 Americans. The Atlanta-based federal Centers for Disease Control says the syndrome has caused at least one death and may be responsible for as many as six. The disorder causes excessive levels of white blood cells. Researchers say people have used the substance for years without reported problems. It was commonly sold in health food stores under a variety of brand names until the outbreak, when most retailers honored a recall request from the federal Food and Drug Administration and removed it from the shelves. Scientists at the CDC and the FDA are trying to determine if the disorder is caused by the product itself or by contaminants that may have gotten into certain batches of it.

DOC.HEAD: Madge Bellamy, Silent Screen Actress, Dead At 89
DOC.TEXT: Madge Bellamy, a silent screen star who starred in such films as ``Lorna Doone'' and ``The Iron Horse,'' has died of chronic cardiac problems. She was 89. Miss Bellamy, whose last film appearance was in 1935, died Wednesday at San Antonio Community Hospital, where she had been admitted Jan. 10. She was born Margaret Philpott on June 30, 1900, in Hillsboro, Texas, the daughter of Ann and William Philpott. Her father was a professor of English at Texas A&M University. She studied dance as a child, but a fractured ankle changed her career and she began making stage appearances. Thousands knew her for her role in the play ``Pollyanna.'' In Hollywood, she starred in silent movies, including ``Alimony,'' ``Sandy,'' ``Lightnin','' ``The Golden Strain,'' ``Bertha, the Sewing Machine Girl'' and ``Ankles Preferred.'' In John Ford's ``The Iron Horse,'' she played the daughter of the transcontinental railroad's chief contractor, who fell in love with the lead actor, George O'Brien. In ``Lorna Doone,'' she was the innocent aristocratic girl kidnapped and raised by bandits before she was rescued by John Bowers. The Hollywood Foreign Correspondents Association named her ``American Beauty'' in 1928, the year she bought a 20-room mansion for the then-astounding price of $200,000, and filled it with another $100,000 worth of furnishings. Also that year, Miss Bellamy married Los Angeles broker Logan F. Metcalf in Tijuana, Mexico. Three months later, he obtained a divorce on a charge of cruelty, testifying they parted just four days after the wedding. Her career began to falter with the advent of talking films, but she appeared in ``White Zombie,'' a 1932 horror film starring Bela Lugosi. She lived a solitary life in the Los Angeles suburb of Ontario in her later years. She leaves no known relatives.

DOC.HEAD: 44 Die in Flooding in Indonesia
DOC.TEXT: Floods triggered by two days of heavy rains devastated the central Java capital of Semarang on Friday, leaving 44 people dead and four missing, an official said. Rescuers said the Banjir Kanal Barat River poured over its banks in the worst floods in the city in 20 years, breaking an embankment and crippling traffic in much of the city. The official said in a telephone interview that thousands of houses along the river were inundated by floodwaters that reached a height of up to 10 feet, and that the ``bodies of dead domestic animals are scattered along the riverbanks.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Miners Seek Help from AFL-CIO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs `The U.S. ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT that mine is near Abingdon, Va., sted in Beckley, W.Va.
DOC.TEXT: AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland on Friday put the power of his organization behind the free trade union movement in the Soviet Union, and six visiting Soviet miners said they wanted to follow the American lead. ``The Soviet miners have asked for our help. We intend to honor that,'' Kirkland told a news conference that marked the end of a monthlong visit and AFL-CIO training session for nine Soviets who led the strike of 400,000 miners last summer. Three of the miners were not at the news conference. Kirkland said his giant union, which supported Poland's independent Solidarity union in its darkest days, would send the fledgling Soviet movement medical supplies, communications equipment and ``other materials that are essential to a trade union organization.'' The Soviet miners repeatedly thanked Kirkland and the union, saying they would keep the American example in mind as they struggled to build a federation of free unions from the scattered groups they are trying to organize across the Soviet Union. ``In this work, the AFL is instructive,'' said Sergei A. Naidyonov, a miner from the Donetsk Coal Basin in the Soviet Ukraine, the largest Soviet coal producer and a center of the strike last summer. The strike sparked a movement to create unions free of control by the Communist Party and government. Official Soviet unions have been sharply criticized by the AFL-CIO. ``We no longer want to feed the bureaucrats,'' Naidyonov said. ``We feel we have gained victory'' by starting independent unions. The coal strike and ensuing miners' demands for free trade unions caught Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev by surprise and he has sought unsuccessfully to persuade the legislature to ban strikes. The Soviet miners invited the AFL-CIO to send a mission to the Soviet Union, but Kirkland said Moscow authorities balked. ``We regret Moscow's refusal to allow an AFL-CIO delegation to meet with independent trade unionists in the Soviet Union, and we shall continue to hope that this barrier is a temporary one,'' Kirkland said. ``We expect the Soviet government's restrictions will not make this endeavor an easy one, and we foresee considerable difficulty ensuring that any material assistance we provide actually gets into the hands of those for whom it is intended. But we will do our best.'' AFL-CIO aid to Solidarity, which continued even during the 1981-83 martial law crackdown against the movement, in many cases involved smuggling material across borders, according to Polish sources. The U.S. labor federation wants to repeat that success with the Soviets, and took them to New York, Chicago, Denver, Pittsburgh, and the picket lines of miners striking the McClure No. 1 Mine near Abingdon, Va. Naidyonov said free trade unions were needed in the Soviet Union because ``it was clear that the official trade unions were not living up to expectations.'' Naidyonov is a member of the Association of Socialist Trade Unions, or Sotsprof, which he said was attempting to coordinate among free labor groups organizing in the Soviet Union. ``Sotsprov is a horizontal structure,'' he said. ``It consists of local committees'' and seeks to coordinate efforts nationwide. Local groups include unions of miners, white collar workers, journalists and others, he said
All financial institutions in Hong Kong were closed Saturday for the Lunar New Year holiday. They will reopen Jan. 30. The AP

DOC.HEAD: Mine Blasts Hit Israeli Tank, Truck, Wound Three Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Two mine explosions on Friday hit a tank and a military truck and wounded three Israeli soldiers in Israel's self-designated security zone in south Lebanon, security sources said. Israel radio said an officer was slightly wounded when the first blast went off near the tank, which was headed toward an Israeli post in the southern village of Baraachit. Five hours later, mine went off under an Israeli military truck near Baraachit, wounding two Israeli soldiers, said the security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. No immediate claim of responsibility was made. Baraachit, five miles north of the Israeli border, is near Tibnin, where the headquarters of an Irish battalion serving with the U.N. peacekeeping force in south Lebanon is based. Also Friday, a Palestinian guerrilla group issued communiques saying it ambushed an Israeli army patrol in a narrow valley near Taibeh inside the security zone in south Lebanon. The first communique from the Moscow-oriented Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine reported that an undisclosed number of ``enemy soldiers'' were killed or injured. The second said nine Israeli soldiers were killed or wounded in fighting that raged until around noon. The Israeli army called the battle ``not a major incident,'' said its soldiers came under light arms fire and returned fire, and denied any Israeli casualties. The Democratic Front said it was retaliating for an Israeli air raid on Palestinian targets in south Lebanon Thursday. Police had said one guerilla was killed and three were wounded in that air strike. Israel has controlled the 6-to-10-mile-deep zone since 1985, when it withdrew the bulk of its occupation army three years after invading Lebanon. The zone runs from the Mediterranean coast to the foothills of Mount Hermon and is used as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla forays.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescus Buried in Secret Bucharest Location
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife Elena were secretly buried in Bucharest after their execution by firing squad last month, Romania's vice premier said Friday on French television. The site of the graves of the former dictator and his wife have ``been kept secret to keep the population from losing self-control,'' Gelu Voican said in an interview with the television station La Cinq. The National Salvation Committee, which led the bloody revolt against Ceausescu and now governs Romania, ordered Voican to organize the secret tribunal that sentenced the couple to death, he said. The Ceausescus were found guilty of murdering tens of thousands of Romanian dissidents during their 24 years of harsh rule over the Eastern European country. ``We were in a state of war, it was necessary to act quickly,'' said Voican, adding that had it been up to him he would have killed the Ceausescus without a trial. The couple, tried in secret at the military base at Tergoviste, attempted to flee from the courtyard as a military firing squad took position to shoot them, Voican said. ``We were taking out the camera and the soldiers began firing without any order being given,'' Voican said. ``There was a general fusillade and the cameraman didn't have time to take the shot.'' The only images released of the execution show the Ceausescus' bullet-riddled bodies crumpled against a wall, covered with dust Voican said was knocked from the stone by the hail of bullets. The bodies were taken to Bucharest and buried, Voican said. Voican said three soldiers were originally chosen to take part in the firing squad but that ``the whole regiment'' ended up shooting. In an interview published Monday in the French newspaper Le Figaro, National Salvation Committee member Silviu Brucan was quoted as saying 80 soldiers fired about 120 bullets into the Ceausescus.

DOC.HEAD: COVE NECK: his intestines. ^Eds: Edits to tighten. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: There was no warning of the crash, said one passenger, Colombian businessman Jorge Lozano. Suddenly, ``it was bumpy. The ladies and kids were screaming.'' ``I had time to say a prayer,'' said Lozano, who suffered a cracked spine in the crash. ``I put my attache case over my knees because I didn't have a pillow. I bent over in the crash position. In about five seconds we were crashing into the trees.'' The crash occurred 15 miles northeast of the airport. Scores of emergency workers raced down narrow roads to the scene, where they laid ladders up the steep wooded hillside and passed survivors down. ``What a way to come to America,'' one passenger told rescue worker Jay Krul. The plane had been scheduled to land at 8 p.m. Diane Spitaliere, an FAA spokeswoman, said the plane missed an approach at Kennedy at 9:24 p.m. She said she didn't know why the plane pulled away from the airport. At 9:32 p.m., she said, the plane reported that its No. 2 engine was out. At 9:34 p.m., the tower lost contact with the plane, moments before the crash, Spitaliere said. A veteran Avianca pilot told The Associated Press in Colombia that when the 707 gains altitude quickly after an aborted landing while low on fuel, engines can shut down because the forces generated push fuel to the back of the tanks. The pilot spoke on condition of anonymity. The AP's investigation source said investigators told him the pilot notified the Kennedy tower that he was low on fuel before he tried to land the first time. But he aborted the landing, telling the tower he was having trouble with his No. 2 engine and that the cloud ceiling was too low _ 200 feet. Other aviation sources who visited the scene and spoke on condition that they not be identified said the Boeing 707 should have been able to make its landing even if just one engine retained fuel. The plane's voice and flight data recorders were recovered and sent to Washington. No homes were hit in the crash, and there were no casualties on the ground, though one part of the plane came to rest on a home's patio. On board, there was pandemonium. ``There was a lot of screaming and groaning around me,'' said Lozano, the Colombian businessman. ``There were bodies on top of bodies on top of bodies,'' said Jeff Race, 26, a New York City Emergency Medical Services officer who lives a half-mile away and said he was the first rescuer at the scene. ``Some were alive, some were dead. Limbs were bent every way you can imagine.'' Among the injured were an undetermined number of children who were bound for adoption in the United States. Cheryl Simon, co-chairman of the Latin American Parents Association, which aids people who want to adopt, said a new Colombian law made it more difficult to bring children into the United States, and there was a rush to beat the deadline. ``A lot of the kids we got out alive,'' said rescuer Charles Harris. ``When you have a live kid in your hands, you just pray to God that they will be OK. The most terrible thing is when you have an injured mother crying, `My baby, my baby.''' The crash occurred a quarter mile from the home where the parents of tennis pro John McEnroe live; their lawn was used as a morgue, with at least 47 bodies wrapped in plastic and lined up in rows. Flight 52 had made one stopover in Medellin, home of an international cocaine cartel, and some speculated that drug-related terrorism was involved in the crash. However, Matt Murphy, an agent at the federal Drug Enforcement Administration office in New York, said that was doubtful. Last Nov. 27, an Avianca Boeing 727 was bombed out of the sky minutes after takeoff from Bogota on a domestic flight, killing all 107 people on board. Drug traffickers fearing extradition to the United States claimed responsibility for the bombing.

DOC.HEAD: Crash Survivor: `I Had Time To Say a Prayer'
With AM-Jetliner Crash, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `At least 66 ... swollen tongue', to UPDATE with new death count.
DOC.TEXT: Jorge Lozano felt the flight turn bumpy. ``The ladies and kids started screaming,'' the 59-year-old Bogota businessman recalled Friday, hours after he was rescued from the wreckage of Avianca Flight 52. ``I thought we were going to crash. ``I had time to say a prayer. I put my attache case over my knees because I didn't have a pillow. I bent over in the crash position. In about five seconds we were crashing into the trees.'' The Boeing 707 plunged into a hillside Thursday night on the north shore of Long Island, killing 72 people and injuring 89. Lozano, a gray-haired man who works for the American Cargill grain company in Bogota, escaped with a cracked vertebra, a gash on his head and a swollen tongue. Whispering in English from his bed at North Shore University Hospital, Lozano spoke about curious aspects of the disaster _ a low pass over Kennedy Airport, a lack of communication from the cockpit and the possibility that the jet ran out of gas. ``I'm so lucky,'' he said. ``My wife is flying in today to see me from Bogota. When the whole thing ended, I saw a big hole. I took my seat belt off. I slid down the hole. It was an opening in the plane, right where I was. It was a miracle.'' Lozano said Flight 52 was already running late when it reached the fog-shrouded metropolitan area. ``We were told 20 minutes from landing that because of congestion or airport conditions we were going to have an additional 20 minutes before landing,'' said Lozano, who sat in seat 4-F in the first class section. About 9:15 p.m. or 9:20, he said, ``we tried to land. We flew low. I recognized the highways. I thought we were going to land. We flew by _ apparently the runway was not visible. We went up, circling very high. Then, 10 minutes later, it was bumpy.'' And then, the screaming started. ``The pilot or stewardess didn't say a thing. I think the guy ran out of gas,'' Lozano said. ``Inside, the lights went off. Outside, the lights were off. But there was a little light inside the plane. I guess it was run by battery.'' Then came the impact. Residents heard no jet engines roaring and there was no explosion. Authorities on the scene speculated the plane had no fuel left. When the crashing stopped, the hole in the fuselage appeared. But Lozano was stuck. ``I couldn't move,'' he said. The plane had crashed onto a steep wooded slope, a few feet from a home. ``It took a long time, maybe 30 minutes. Then the firemen came,'' he said. ``There were big lights. They were trying to remove things. ``There was a lot of screaming and groaning around me. It took them half an hour _ it seemed like an eternity. I was hoping people would help this little girl, she was 18 years old. She was screaming for her other, `Please help my mother, she's stuck under the seat!''' Looking up, ``I saw people were being rescued on top of me. They took me out and put me on the ground.'' ``One of the men said, `This guy is much better than the others.' I said, `That's correct. As long as you don't forget me, you go and help the others.' I laid there, counting my blessings. It was a miracle.''

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Caucus Calls for Disbanding Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Parliament deputies from Solidarity on Friday called on the government to disband the secret police and preserve its records following reports that police files were being destroyed. ``The Security Service (secret police) was a basis of the Stalinist system and its activity threatens the socio-political stability of our state,'' a resolution passed by the Solidarity caucus said. ``We appeal to the government for an immediate securing of its operating materials and archives and for taking up action to dissolve'' the service. A special parliament commission investigating the activities of the Interior Ministry earlier complained that the records of a secret police department investigating priests were destroyed. The Interior Ministry was one of the few departments that remained under communist leadership after a Solidarity-led coalition took control of the government in September. The resolution came the same day Solidarity's newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported that men in an unidentified car had burned files of the secret police Jan. 20 along a lake near Starachowice in southern Poland. Among the ashes were partly burned documents bearing stamps of the Security Service, which is part of the Interior Ministry, the paper said. There have been dozens of other reports of similar activity around the country, the paper said. Meanwhile, television news reported that in Krakow communist party records have been burned the past several days in meadows along the Vistula River and that the party files in Bialystok in northeastern Poland were also burned.

DOC.HEAD: Windows Smashed in South African Black Protest against English Team
DOC.TEXT: Black activists ran through this mining city smashing car and shop windows to protest an English cricket team that began its first match Friday despite a ban on sports contacts with South Africa. The ban stems from South Africa's apartheid policies of racial segregation. Police said 31 youths were arrested Friday and reported that a 52-year-old man was injured by the protesters. Hundreds of demonstrators tried to protest outside the De Beers Club stadium where the match was being played, but police set up a roadblock about a half-mile from the stadium, witnesses said. Crowd estimates ranged from 300 to 4,000. Two busloads of protesters coming from the Johannesburg area were turned back en route by police. Protest leaders in Kimberly met with Ali Bacher, managing director of the South African Cricket Union, and demanded they be allowed to march on the stadium. Bacher, who organized the English tour, agreed. However, police still refused to allow the protesters near the stadium, where the English squad began a three-day match against players from two Cape Province teams. After negotiations failed, some protesters began running toward town carrying sticks and stones, breaking car windows along the way, witnesses said. Police dispersed the crowd at the roadblock, pursued the demonstrators running through town and arrested several youths, witnesses added. Bacher, who has been seeking to minimize conflict related to the tour, later went to a local magistrate and obtained his approval for a protest to be held outside the cricket stadium on Saturday. All the English players face expulsion from international cricket for five years for taking part in the tour. Activists have said they will stage protests throughout the six-week visit by the English team. Protests have been held outside the hotels where the players have been staying in Johannesburg and Kimberley. Black hotel workers refused to serve the British players and demanded that other hotel guests produce identification showing they are not part of the team. The English players have not said how much they are being paid for the tour, but local newspapers have put the figure at $160,000 each.

DOC.HEAD: 58 Countries Sign U.N. Document on Children's Rights
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-eight countries signed a U.N. protocol on children's rights at a ceremony Friday as part of efforts to establish an international treaty to protect youth worldwide. Signing indicates a government's intent to consider ratifying the Convention on the Rights of the Child adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in November. Twenty countries must ratify the convention to give it the force of an international treaty. James P. Grant, executive director of the U.N. Children's Fund, said, ``In creating this convention, the international community has provided a firm foundation for a new ethic for children, an ethic that defines children as individuals with inalienable rights of no less value than those of adults.'' The convention stresses the importance of primary health care and education, and recommends measures to guard against child labor, sexual exploitation and drug abuse. It sets up steps to protect children in cases of adoption, foster care and juvenile justice proceedings. A UNICEF report issued last month said spending by Third World countries on armaments and debt service rather than health and nutrition could doom 100 million children to death by disease and starvation in the 1990s. The report said that almost 8,000 children die each day because they are not immunized. Nearly 7,000 die daily from dehydration caused by diarrhea, and about 6,000 are killed each day by pneumonia. The cost of immunizing all these children and providing medicines for dehydration and pneumonia would be about $2.5 billion a year, it adds.

DOC.HEAD: Airliner Crash That Killed 72 May Have Been Caused by Fuel Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 20 grafs to UPDATE details of problems on first approach, edit to tighten. Picks up 20th graf pvs, `Dickinson also...'
With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: The crew of a Colombian jetliner warned controllers repeatedly they wer running out of fuel before the Boeing 707 crashed on its second approach to Kennedy Airport, killing 72 people, investigators said Friday. Avianca Airlines Flight 52 from Bogota had been delayed by air traffic and appeared to have barely enough fuel to land before it slashed into a suburban hillside Thursday night, officials said. The jet may have lost power in three of its four engines before it went down. The plane's crew, however, never declared an emergency or requested an emergency landing priority, Lee Dickinson, spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board, said at a Friday evening news conference. Eighty-nine people survived the crash and 72 died, including the entire nine-member crew except for the chief steward, Dickinson said. Only nine victims had been positively identified, he said. The Boeing 707 carried 152 passengers. Hospital officials said at least 25 of the injured were in serious or critical condition, and more than two dozen children were among the injured. Some of the children were being adopted by American parents and were making their first trips to their new homes. Investigators picking through the wreckage of the jet in the woods of this isolated, wealthy suburb found gauges indicating it had 10,000 pounds of fuel left, Dickinson said. That corresponds to about 6 percent of the plane's capacity. Investigators had not checked the actual tanks, he said. After aborting their first attempt at landing, the cockpit crew told the control tower repeatedly that ``they were running out of fuel or that they were low on fuel,'' Dickinson said. In Seattle, Boeing Commercial Airplanes spokesman Jack Gamble said the 10,000 pounds would have been roughly the amount the jet needed to get to the airport, ``but not much more.'' Gamble said 10,000 pounds equals about 1,500 gallons, ``enough to land an airplane when it's three to five minutes out'' from the field and the plane is in a normal landing configuration. A 707 can carry up to 23,855 gallons. Three to five minutes flight time equals about 17 miles in a landing configuration, Gamble said. The Avianca jetliner, nearing the end of a 2,400-mile flight, crashed about 15 miles northeast of the airport. Dickinson said investigators flew over the site early Friday and determined the wreckage was on course for another Kennedy approach. In addition, the landing gear was up and the flaps were ``somewhere between fully extended and retracted ... indicating that the airplane was in some phase of approach,'' he said. Before the crash, the plane was put in a holding pattern over Norfolk, Va., and New Jersey for 75 minutes, NBC News reported. Dickinson and an FAA spokeswoman said they could not confirm that. When it finally reached Kennedy International Airport, the jetliner was forced to abort an initial landing in fog and rain because of warnings that it was ``sinking too fast'' _ descending too quickly and at the wrong angle, Dickinson said. It was making a second approach shortly after 9:30 p.m. when the crew reported to the airport tower that it was having trouble with its number two engine. The crew then reported two engines out, and shortly thereafter the jet disappeared from the radar screens, Dickinson said. Prior to the first landing attempt, the pilot, Laureano Caviedes, told passengers that because of heavy air traffic at JFK, the plane would have to circle for 20 minutes, according to statements by one witness. ``But the plane spent more than an hour circling in high winds, heavy rain and incredible air pockets,'' said Marisol Velasco, a Colombian residing in New York City, in an telephone interview with Caracol, a Colombian radio network. ``The plane rose and fell, and nobody had told us anything when suddenly the lights went out. The plane descended and we felt the biggest impact in the world,'' he said. Earlier in the day, a source close to the investigation who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press that authorities had compiled evidence indicating the plane may have run out of fuel. There was no fire on impact, and the landing was a low-impact, low-speed crash, suggesting that the plane glided to the ground. Also, there was no fuel smell, and the nose, wings and body came down level instead of thrusting forward, as they would have if the engines were running. In addition, witnesses said there was no explosion when the jetliner crumpled into several pieces in the woods. Dickinson also said there were indications that three engines were not working when the plane crashed. The fourth engine, buried in mud at the crash site, has not yet been inspected. The Colombian radio network RCN reported that the 23-year-old plane had been plagued by mechanical problems recently, having been sent to the maintenance shop 37 times in the past four months. The radio didn't say what the maintenance was for. An Avianca spokeswoman in Colombia identified the cockpit crew: pilot Laureano Caviedes, 52, who had flown for the airline since 1962; copilot Mauricio Klotz, 27, with the company 3{ years, and flight engineer Matias Moyano Rojas, 44, a 24-year Avianca veteran. One of those injured, a 30-year-old man, was found by doctors to have four condoms packed with a white powder they speculated was cocaine in his intestines.
DOC.HEAD: Picks up 1st graf of 4th Ld-Writethru, 1st take, a0811
Two Sentenced for Stealing Jet Engines from Air Force
DOC.TEXT: Two former Air Force base security policemen who pleaded guilty to stealing three fighter jet engines worth nearly $10 million were sentenced Friday to federal prison terms. The case grew from ``Operation Punchout,'' a two-year Pentagon investigation of thefts from bases in the West and Southwest that resulted in charges against nearly three dozen military personnel and civilians. Undercover agents running a phony military surplus business in the town of Roy, outside Hill Air Force Base, bought millions of dollars worth of stolen military hardware over the two-year period, including the three engines for F-16 fighter jets. U.S. District Judge David Sam sentenced Airman 1st Class Brian David Roth, 23, to 10 years on each of five counts of theft of government property. The terms are to be served concurrently. In addition, the judge ordered Roth, of Chesterfield, Ohio, to pay $24,749.50 in restitution, and placed him on three years' probation following completion of his prison sentence. Senior Airman Danny Joe Stroud, 24, Newton, Kan., was sentenced to 37 months in prison, ordered to pay $14,711 in restitution and given three years probation. Stroud pleaded guilty to a single count of theft. Under a plea bargain last October, government prosecutors agreed to drop 17 of the 22 original charges against Roth. Roth's lawyer, Jerold McPhee, argued that while his client had committed a serious crime, ``it is only a theft of government property, albeit a lot of government property. ... This is not a case of treason.'' Roth apologized for the crimes, saying his involvement in the thefts began when he accidentally was issued two sets of basic equipment at Hill, and decided to sell his extra helmet. As time went on, his thievery escalated, he said. ``I am not sorry I got caught. I only wish it had ended sooner,'' Roth said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Bruce Lubeck argued for a stiff sentence for Roth, noting that the theft of the F-16 engines _ valued at $9.9 million _ caused a ``monumental disruption'' of operations at the northern Utah base. He said Roth was guilty of an ``aggravated abuse of trust.'' Stroud's attorney, Stephen Madsen, said his client was a follower, recruited into crime by Roth. He said he had been involved in thefts less than a month at the time of his arrest July 10, 1988, and cooperated extensively with government lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Fan Blade Crack Blamed for Northwest Airlines Mishap
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board said Friday that a fan blade crack one-third of an inch-long introduced during a repair process was to blame for forcing a Northwest Airlines DC-10 to make an emergency landing in Denver in August. The blade broke away and fragments punctured the left fan cowl in three places and partially penetrated the plane's vertical stabilizer, the NTSB said. The crew shut down the engine. The plane, en route from Los Angeles to Minneapolis, landed safely. ``Metallurgical examination revealed that the blade separation had stemmed from a 0.34-inch-long fatigue crack that began in a weld adjacent to a patch at the trailing edge of the fan blade,'' the report said. ``The examination indicated that the fatigue crack had originated from a small, about 0.03-inch deep, discolored crack region introduced during the repair process.'' The discoloration was so obvious, the report said, that the crack should have been detected during the repair process. The blade had been ``patch-repaired'' by Union Carbide Corp. in Kansas City, the board said. ``The safety board is concerned that other (Pratt & Whitney) fan blades patch-repaired by Union Carbide may have similar or even smaller cracks that were introduced during patch repair and that these cracks could grow by fatigue in service, producing blade separation and resulting in personal injury, loss of life and substantial damage to the airplane and engine components,'' the board said. It recommended that the Federal Aviation Administration require a one-time eddy current inspection of all such patch-repaired blades and, if needed, recurring inspections ``capable of detecting a propagating fatigue crack before it reaches a critical length.'' Robert Berzok, Union Carbide's chief spokesman, said the Danbury, Conn.-based company had been working with federal authorities, Pratt & Whitney and its airline customers since August to inspect the more than 1,000 fan blades repaired at the Kansas City facility. He said more than 90 percent of the blades had been inspected and the remainder fell in a ``very low-risk category.''

DOC.HEAD: Final Leg of Avianca Flight: Delays, Bad Weather, Fuel Worries
With AM-Jetliner Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The last leg of Avianca Flight 52 disintegrated into a series of delays, ominous weather reports and increasing fuel worries, followed by abrupt silence, according to investigators and news reports. Cockpit voice recordings analyzed Friday show the flight crew reported several times that the plane was running out of fuel before it crashed Thursday night on Long Island, 15 miles short of Kennedy International Airport. Also Friday, NBC News reported the flight was delayed three times as it flew up the East Coast, being placed in holding patterns once above Norfolk, Va., and twice over New Jersey. The delays totaled 75 minutes _ so long that when the pilot was asked if he could be diverted to Logan Airport in Boston to avoid the bad weather, he said he didn't have enough fuel to make it there, NBC said. At that point, controllers ordered the plane directly to Kennedy, NBC said. Officials of the National Transportation Board, which is investigating the crash, refused to comment on the NBC report. Lee Dickinson, an NTSB member, released information obtained from a preliminary analysis of the cockpit voice recording. The recorder continually monitors conversations, preserving the last 30 minutes. Early in the tape, ``there is some conversation among the crew about the fuel'' in the plane, Dickinson said. A short while after the first reference to the fuel shortage, the crew was told as the plane approached Kennedy that there were reports of wind shear _ powerful downward bursts of wind _ at altitudes of 1,600 feet to 500 feet. On the final approach to the airport, an alarm warned the crew the plane was losing altitude too quickly and was at an improper angle for a safe landing, Dickinson said. The alarm repeatedly warned, ``Pull Up! Pull Up!,'' followed by another warning that the plane was sinking too fast, he said. The crew aborted its landing approach and asked the air traffic controller for permission to try again. ``They said they would try again but they were running out of fuel or they were low on fuel,'' Dickinson said. The tower gave directions for a second approach and the crew repeated that the plane was running low on fuel. Traffic controllers again gave them directions ``and asked them if that was OK and the crew responded OK,'' Dickinson said. Shortly after that exchange the crew reported two engines had shut down. The tape ended abruptly after that, but before the crash. Several NTSB officials said the recorder would have stopped recording if power in the airplane had been shut off. Several survivors have said all lights were shut off before the crash at 9:34 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Accuses Defendant of Lying
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor said Thursday that a woman accused of killing her 6-week-old infant in April has lied under oath by changing her story about a masked gunman who allegedly attacked and stole her baby. Paula Marie Sims, 30, testified Wednesday that the same gunman who stole her first-born daughter, Loralei Marie, from her home in 1986, also attacked her and abducted her 6-week-old daughter Heather Lee last year. Assistant state attorney Donald Weber Thursday accused Mrs. Sims of changing her original account of the April abduction and slaying of the infant to neutralize what could be damaging testimony by a medical expert. Weber said Mrs. Sims lied about the time the attack occurred because the expert, a medical examiner, said it would have been impossible for her to remember much about the incident if she had been knocked unconscious for 45 minutes, as she told police. ``She's changing her story as she goes,'' Weber said during rebuttal arguments. ``She has specifically added facts to her testimony and the defense is trying to prevent me from proving her to be a liar.'' In Wednesday's testimony, Mrs. Sims said she was knocked unconscious for at least 15 minutes less than she said in her original account. That meant her ability to recall events most likely would be clearer, according to the medical examiner's testimony. Mrs. Sims is charged with first-degree murder of Heather Lee, and has been charged in a separate indictment with obstructing justice and concealing the homicide of her other daughter. No murder charges have been filed in that case.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Gun Permits Suspended to Disarm Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: All gun permits will be suspended next week in an effort to disarm old-guard remnants of the secret force who still hold weapons, the state news agency CTK reported Thursday. It also reported a gun amnesty, quoting an official report as saying that ``all citizens holding guns illegally are asked to hand their weapons over voluntarily. Such cases will not be considered as misdemeanors or criminal acts.'' CTK said, ``To avoid possible cases of abuse of firearms for criminal activity and to strengthen the safety of citizens, Interior Minister Richard Sacher ... suspended the validity of gun permits as of Feb. 2, 199O. ``This measure applies also to members of the ... departments of internal political service of the State Security, who will hand their weapons to their designated superiors.'' Sacher suspended all officers of the Security Service's internal political service last week, and said new superiors would be appointed from the ranks of non-discredited police force members. The service was a dread instrument of the state under the Communist regime that ruled Czechoslovakia for more than four decades until last month. Interior Ministry spokesman Jan Valsa told The Associated Press that besides citizens with private gun permits, the new measure will also apply to regular police and even soldiers, should they have firearms at home. ``In the next few days the Interior Ministry will submit to the Parliament a draft law on firearms and ammunition, which will envisage a much stricter procedure in issuing gun permits,'' CTK said. The penalty for illegal posession of a firearm is three years, and that for posessing more than one gun five years.

DOC.HEAD: Defectors Report Protest Demonstrations in Albania
DOC.TEXT: Four Albanian defectors said Thursday that anti-Communist protests were held this month in their hometown of Shkoder and police broke up one rally with clubs and tear gas, Tanjug news agency said. The defectors said thousands of people tried to tear down a downtown statue of Josef Stalin during the protests on Jan. 11 and 14 in Shkoder, Albania's second largest city near the Yugoslav border. ``The destruction of the statue would symbolize the destruction of the current regime in Albania,'' one of the men told Tanjug. The four, two workers and two high school students, escaped to Yugoslavia from their isolated country on Wednesday over the heavily guarded border. They were not identified by name. They told Tanjug that police did not make arrests or use force to disperse about 2,000 demonstrators during the Jan. 11 protest, but on Jan. 14, police fired tear gas and swung clubs to disperse up to 7,000 people who had gathered around Stalin's statue. About 60 demonstrators were detained and arrests continued for the next couple of days ``since the police filmed the Jan. 14 protest,'' they said. The defectors said ``the Albanian people expect radical changes to take place in their country this spring,'' but did not elaborate. They said they fled to Yugoslavia because they could not stand the ``regime, poverty and hopelessness of life in Albania,'' according to Tanjug. Yugoslav, Greek and other Western media have published reports of recent unrest in Albania, the last Stalinist stronghold in Eastern Europe. The reports could not be independently confirmed as few foreigners are allowed to enter the Balkan country. Albanian officials have denied the allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Carol Stuart Announces Memorial Fund in Her Memory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `More than...,' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with black legislators calling for special commission to investigate police work and media reports on case; DELETES first reference to Charles Stuart in 7th graf pvs to conform. Pick up 8th graf pvs: `The case drew...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX9
DOC.TEXT: The family of Carol Stuart on Thursday announced a scholarship fund in her memory to aid residents in the inner-city neighborhood who were put under an unfair cloud of suspicion when she was killed. The DiMaiti family said they want their daughter to be remembered as more than just the victim of a sensational murder. They also said they hope to begin a healing process in Mission Hill, where she was fatally shot Oct. 23 in a hoax that shocked the country. The announcement was welcomed by some black leaders who have complained that police and the media were too willing to believe the claim of Mrs. Stuart's husband, Charles, that the couple was shot by a black mugger. Charles Stuart committed suicide after he was implicated in the crime. In a less conciliatory development, black state legislators announced a bill Thursday that would establish a special commission to investigate police work in the case. The commission, which would have limited subpoena power, would examine how police built a case against William Bennett, a black man included in a lineup who has since been exonerated. The panel also would try to determine where the media got information about Bennett. The commission wouldn't interfere with the criminal investigation, but would examine why police focused on a black suspect and failed to investigate the husband earlier in the case, said state Rep. Byron Rushing, a Boston Democrat who sponsored the measure. ``How did that idea last as the only valid proposition for about two and a half months?'' Rushing said. Immediately following the televised announcement of the scholarship fund, more than 40 people telephoned the DiMaiti family's lawyer and offered to donate money to the Carol DiMaiti Stuart Foundation. Giusto DiMaiti, 64, read a brief statement to reporters, choking up during the end of his remarks. It was his first public comment on his daughter's death since the disclosure of the hoax Jan. 4. ``She was truly the brightest of lights in our lives,'' said DiMaiti. ``She will always and forever be with us. ... Mere words cannot express the emptiness we feel or how much we miss her.'' His wife, Evelyn, 62, and son Carl, 37, attended the news conference but did not speak. DiMaiti clutched his wife's hand and Mrs. DiMaiti dabbed at her eyes as their lawyers took questions from reporters. The fund was established for residents of Mission Hill, where a massive manhunt was launched after Stuart claimed a black mugger had shot him and his 30-year-old, pregnant wife. The case drew wide attention and the badly wounded Stuart's dramatic call for help on his car telephone was broadcast nationally. His wife died hours later after their son lived just 17 days after being delivered by Caesarean section. Ten weeks after the shootings, Stuart apparently committed suicide after one of his brothers implicated him in the shootings. In announcing the scholarship, attorney Marvin Geller recalled the ``old scars of racial tension'' opened by the hoax. ``The DiMaiti family believes that Carol would not have wanted her death to be remembered as the cause of such divisiveness,'' he said. ``(Carol) would not have wanted to be remembered as a victim of a sensational murder.'' Black leaders in Boston applauded the announcement but tempered their remarks with lingering concerns about the damage done Mission Hill's residents. ``I think it's a magnanimous gesture on their part ...,'' said Louis Elisa, president of the Boston chapter of the NAACP. ``Maybe they can prevail on the mayor to make an apology so the real healing can start.'' Another attorney, John Wortmann Jr., said Carol's parents never suspected their son-in-law prior to his death. He said their concerns were no more than ``the doubts that any parent would have about whether anybody is good enough for their daughter.'' He said the family had no desire that anyone else be prosecuted in the case, ``only that justice and the truth come out.'' Wortmann wouldn't elaborate. One of Stuart's brothers, Matthew, has acknowledged getting rid of the gun, but says he didn't know at the time that Mrs. Stuart had been shot with it. It was Matthew who finally went to police Jan. 3. Another Stuart brother, Michael, has said he learned of Charles Stuart's involvement in the crime within days but said nothing. Wortmann said there had been informal contact between the DiMaiti and Stuart families in recent weeks, but declined to elaborate. He also said the DiMaiti family has made no arrangements to cooperate on book or movie projects. He said the family knows books and movies will be made about the case, and hope they ``will not denigrate the memory of Carol Stuart.''
EDITORS: The foundation address is Shawmut Bank N.A., P.O. Box 11029, Boston, Mass. 02211.

DOC.HEAD: Broadway's `M. Butterfly' To Close
DOC.TEXT: ``M. Butterfly,'' the drama by David Henry Hwang at the Eugene O'Neill Theater on Broadway, will close on Saturday after its 777th performance, it was announced Thursday. ``Business has not improved and the advance sale for the next four weeks is not sufficient to keep us in the manner to which we have been accustomed. In like a lamb, out like a lion,'' producer Stuart Ostrow said in a statement. The show's spokesman, John Springer, said that ``M. Butterfly,'' in which the part played by Tony Randall is based on a real French diplomat, made more than $1.5 million profit and is the longest-running Broadway drama since ``Amadeus,'' which won a Tony Award as best play in 1981. ``M. Butterfly'' also won a Tony as best play, in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Blizzard Belts Midwest with Snow, Wind, Lightning
DOC.TEXT: A blizzard belted the upper Midwest with up to 10 inches of snow Thursday, packing high winds that ripped roofs off buildings in Michigan and lightning that injured 12 people in Illinois. In severe weather elsewhere, a tornado tore through a trailer park in Centenary, Ala., injuring 24 people. The snowstorm brought traffic to a standstill in parts of Michigan, Illinois, Wisconsin, Iowa and Indiana. Storm warnings for snow and high wind remained in effect into the night in some areas. Airline flights were delayed up to two hours at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport and Midway Airport because of blowing snow and high wind, said Lisa Howard, a spokeswoman for the city Department of Aviation. ``This is a red alert storm,'' Ms. Howard said. ``Things are at a standstill.'' The weather also caused scattered power outages and temporarily closed airports in Milwaukee, St. Louis, and Detroit. In Crystal Lake, Ill., 35 miles northwest of Chicago, a lightning bolt struck a telephone pole and was conducted through snow across a parking lot, injuring 11 people. Two were in serious condition. Workers at Precision Twist Drill Co. were trying to help each other free their cars from six inches of snow that fell overnight when the bolt struck at 8:30 a.m., said Art Beck, company president. ``There were sparks coming through their fingers,'' Beck said of the injured. Lightning also struck a woman's umbrella in the Chicago suburb of Palatine, slightly injuring her as she was on her way to work at William Rainey Harper College, said school spokeswoman Elaine Stoermer. Wind up to 60 mph peeled roofs off buildings and uprooted trees in southeast Michigan. In Auburn Hills, just north of Detroit, wind tore the roof off one of three Headquarters Motel buildings. No one was injured. ``Several other buildings in the area lost parts of their roofs, but the motel lost the whole thing. It's open air,'' said Auburn Hills police Sgt. Jerry Knapp. In Ohio, two U.S. marshals were injured when a tree fell on their car as they were returning from a firing range near Toledo. One, David Hartzel, was in serious condition at Flower Memorial Hospital in suburban Sylvania with head injuries. Winds gusting to 50 mph in downtown Indianapolis blew out windows from the 21st and 36th floors of the INB National Bank Tower, injuring a 54-year-old woman who received a cut on her right thigh from falling glass. Farther south in Centenary, Ala., a tornado flipped or split open a dozen mobile homes at about 5:30 a.m., strewing furniture, clothes, toys and pink insulation about the area 40 miles south of Montgomery. Among the injured was a boy rescued by a man who lifted the corner of a shattered mobile home that pinned him, witnesses said. Of the 24 people hospitalized, three were children with serious head injuries, said Nancy Williams, spokeswoman for the county hospital. The Midwest blizzard was blamed for many minor accidents as cars slid off snow-covered roads, and many people simply stayed home. Illinois state police closed 35- to 40-mile stretches of Interstate 90 near Elgin and I-88 outside Aurora for two hours beginning at 11:30 a.m., said Sgt. Tami Haukedahl. In Michigan's northern Lower Peninsula schools and businesses closed early, cars and buses slid off the roads and even snow plows got stuck. ``We're losing ground at this point,'' said Wexford County road engineer Pat McCormick in Cadillac. ``We're making the way clear for school buses where we can. They're stuck all over the place.'' The storm lashed southeast Iowa with 45 mph winds that whipped 5 inches of snow into a treacherous near-whiteout on roads slick with ice. ``Not only is there zero visibility, but you can turn left and not go left,'' said Bob Wilson, district manager for the American Automobile Association's Motor Club of Iowa. ``People could die out there.''
