DOC.HEAD: Former CBS News President Decries Travelling Anchors
DOC.TEXT: Former CBS News president Richard S. Salant on Thursday criticized the relatively new trend of sending network anchormen overseas to make their newscasts where big news is breaking. ABC ``Nightline'' anchor Ted Koppel said he agreed with Salant's complaints, but that such actions were necessary because ``the anchors are the ones who in very large measure are perceived as bringing in the audience.'' The two appeared at a duPont-Columbia University forum on network news, along with former NBC News president Les Crystal, now executive producer of PBS ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' and NBC News vice president Tim Russert. Salant, referring to network anchormens' trips last year to Eastern Europe and West Germany when the Berlin Wall was being demolished, said he's against such trips, known in network news circles as ``bigfooting'' a story. Network news divisions may consider it important, ``but I don't like this business of it not being an important story unless you get the anchor there,'' said Salant, who retired from CBS in 1978. It's better to use correspondents who know the territory and have long experience covering the story, he said, drawing chuckles by joking that ``the (Berlin) Wall doesn't go down unless the anchors are there.'' Salant, who didn't single out any anchorman for criticism, cited what he said was a large staff CBS sent to West Berlin for Dan Rather's newscasts there. ``It costs more to do that, but I think it's money ill spent,'' he said. Koppel wrly noted that he's going to South Africa this year to anchor his program from there and that he hoped ``it will be money well spent.'' In an age of cable news and satellite, when network newscasts are fighting far stronger competition than ever before, it's important to have someone to whom viewers are loyal, Koppel said. In this new era, Koppel said, ``having that familiar face _ Peter Jennings, Dan Rather, Tom Brokaw _ is the only thing that now distinguishes the networks in the eyes of many people, many viewers. ... ``It is the familiarity with an anchor that you've known for ten, 15, 20 years.''

President Bush, savoring a major triumph over Congress, is claiming a mandate to deal with China ``the way I feel is correct'' despite widespread opposition to his policies from Democrats and Republicans alike. ``Surprised you, didn't it?'' Bush exclaimed Thursday after the Senate, by a four-vote margin, upheld his veto of a politically popular bill protecting Chinese students from deportation. Bush said the victory would ``be helpful in reaching accommodation'' with the Senate and House on other matters. Senators voted 62-37 against Bush but the vote failed to meet the two-thirds margin needed for an override. The House had voted 390-25 a day earlier against the president.

A storm with winds of up to 110 mph tore across southern England and Western Europe, killing at least 64 people in five countries as it ripped off roofs, caused buildings to cave in and brought trees crashing down on cars and pedestrians. Britain, with 41 dead, was the worst hit Thursday. ``London is virtually at a standstill,'' Scotland Yard said as air, bus, subway and train services halted and rain came through the wind-damaged roof of Parliament. Police reports said 11 people died in Holland, six in France, five in Belgium and one in West Germany. The storm swep in from the Atlantic Thursday morning, cutting a trail of destruction across the continent before turning northeast and heading out into the North Sea at night.

Some lawmakers are reacting cautiously to President Bush's proposed $1 billion aid plan for Panama, with one senator saying Congress wants to help the country but predicting a ``tough battle'' on how much to give. ``That's a substantial amount of money for a tiny country,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., echoing questions that others also raised about the amount Bush is proposing for the country he ordered the U.S. military to invade on Dec. 20. ``Where's it going to come from?'' asked Rep. Peter Kostmayer, D-Pa., a member of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Western Hemispheric affairs. ``It's too much.'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger planned to provide additional details of the plan to senators today, the day after Bush unveiled it. To spend the money, the administration must submit a supplemental appropriation requiring congressional approval.

President Bush's nominee to become the Justice Department's civil rights chief acknowledges he lacks broad experience on the issue but says he has an ``understanding and a sensitivity'' about civil rights. Former New York state Sen. John R. Dunne was nominated Thursday by Bush to be assistant attorney general for civil rights, a post that has been vacant since December 1988. Bush's first choice, William Lucas, failed to win Senate confirmation last August. Dunne, 59, of Garden City, N.Y., spent 24 years in the New York state Senate, where he was chairman of the Judiciary Committee. He resigned in September after losing a battle for Republican majority leader and is currently a partner in a Long Island law firm. On the eve of his nomination, Dunne acknowledged: ``I haven't had as much experience as I'm sure many civil rights activists perhaps would like to see.''

DOC.HEAD: Valerie Harper's New CBS Sitcom a No-Ho.
DOC.TEXT: Fans of ``The Famous Teddy Z'' may demand a recount. CBS temporarily took it off the air to make room for Valerie Harper's new sitcom, ``City,'' which makes its premiere tonight. The move does not seem wise. ``City,'' where Harper plays Liz Gianni, the harried city manager presiding over a colorful staff in one of television's many towns with no names, is somewhat to the left of whoopee. It's not just because the show has an off-screen announcer intone: ``In every city, there is a handful of unsung heroes that make the city run. Underappreciated, overworked, underpaid, they are ... The Bureaucrats.'' Nor is it because our single heroine has one of the old reliables of sitcoms, a 19-year-old daughter (some shows co-star kid sisters to vary things) who has dropped out of college and come to live with her. Or even because the staff worries about Liz's sex life (it's not clear if Liz is widowed, divorced, or what have you). One of her crew, noting Liz has a date with a councilman coming up, cheerfully says, ``Hey, Miss Gianni _ hope you score tonight.'' It's just that the whole show kind of falls down and goes boom. This usually indicates that succeeding episodes may do likewise. With LuAnne Ponce as Harper's mischievous daughter, tonight's debut, foaled by executive producer Paul Hagguis, offers Harper two crises. One is the daughter's announcement she is thinking of having sex with a married man whose name she doesn't know. The other is a bunch of coffins that have slid down a hill into the city. It seems they accidentally were exhumed by a bulldozer rooting around in what is described as ``an abandoned cemetery.'' The coffin caper touches off an emergency meeting at Harper's rundown city hall office. This, of course, lets viewers meet her mildly zany staff and the city's dim, obnoxious, easily bribed deputy mayor. Raising a point of disorder at the meeting, a Cuban-born bureaucrat (Liz Torres) says Americans don't appreciate freedom and that her husband ``rots in a Cuban jail'' just because he fought for freedom. The assistant city manager (Todd Sussman) scoffs: ``Your husband was caught smuggling in 40 crates of Teddy Ruxpin dolls from Florida.'' ``When the CIA asks for a favor, you don't ask why,'' says she. With snappy patter like this, all one can do is pray for the players, and note that two of them provide the only good moments, salvaging dead lines with fine timing and sly performances. Those two are James Lorinz, excellent in a small part as the young security chief of city hall, and Sussman. The performance of Harper, who last starred on CBS in ``Rhoda,'' a spin-off of ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' is up to her usual standards. But she doesn't seem at ease in ``City.'' That is understandable, given the quality of tonight's script. The whole thing is best summed up in a line by the daughter, who says, ``I sort of need to flounder around a while to try to find out what I want.'' With CBS trying to avoid a third season in the Nielsen cellar, ``City'' had best find out what it wants, and swiftly. CBS can't afford to let it flounder _ you know what happens when any dead fish is left around too long.

Elsewhere in television: GOOD GRIEF, CHARLIE BROWN, YOU`RE OLDER THAN JACK BENNY: CBS on Friday night is airing ``You Don't Look 40, Charlie Brown,'' a one-hour look at Charles M. Schulz and his funny, long-lasting ``Peanuts'' cartoon. Schulz also is a jazz fan who championed the use of pianist Vince Guaraldi on many of the ``Peanuts'' TV specials. Not surprisingly, the music of Guaraldi and two better-known jazzmen, Dave Brubeck and Dave Grusin, will be part of Friday's special.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Riot Turned Inmates Against Other Inmates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: note contents of 29th graf, ``A blowtorch ...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The plea came crackling over two-way radios in the predawn hours of Feb. 2, 1980: ``You all stop killing each other. There's blood all over. ... No more killing. No more hurting.'' It was merely a hint of the horror going on inside New Mexico's only maximum security prison after inmates seized control. Some prisoners were systematically and brutally murdering others; officials later said they were settling personal grudges against informers. When it was over, 33 inmates were dead _ the worst prison riot in the United States since the 1971 Attica rebellion in New York that left 43 dead. The rebellion exposed an inadequate and mismanaged prison system run by an insufficient number of poorly trained, underpaid and sometimes abusive guards in a facility overflowing with frustrated criminals. In the decade since, the state has spent $127.5 million building prisons, and training for guards has been improved. Since 1980, the prison system has been operated under a federal court decree covering 13 broad areas of prison life. The uprising began at 2 a.m. that Saturday 10 years ago when inmates beat and overpowered three unarmed guards. Within seconds, the convicts had smashed the newly installed and supposedly unbreakable tempered glass around the prison control room, gaining control of internal locks and communications. Fifteen minutes later, Gov. Bruce King's security men notified him that the lights were off at the penitentiary and that there was no response from 15 corrections officers inside. King ordered the state police to take up positions outside the prison, where they were joined a few hours later by the National Guard. For 36 hours, the inmates controlled the prison, which was built to house 850 prisoners but held more than 1,130. They burned most of the penitentiary buildings, destroyed records, terrorized their hostages, and beat and raped other prisoners. State medical examiner Dr. James Weston, whose office autopsied the dead, later said most of the bodies had been mutilated and some had ``injuries suggesting torture.'' One prisoner had been beheaded. Reporters and others listening to the two-way radio conversations between inmates early in the siege heard prisoners talking about the carnage under way. One inmate radioed: ``There's a whole lot of dead in A-1, about 15.'' That prompted another to plead for no more violence in a general broadcast to the prison. Clouds of thick black smoke billowed from several areas of the penitentiary as helpless officials outside identified the burning buildings: the administration offices, the gymnasium, the psychiatric ward. ``Get a fire truck in here,'' a riot leader called Chopper One radioed just before dawn. ``There are men suffocating to death. There's fire, a lot of places on fire, in the chapel, in the gym.'' Early in the rebellion, the prisoners had released two injured guards, but Chopper One later told officials, ``If you don't start negotiating pretty soon, these (remaining) guards are going to get wasted.'' Corrections Secretary Felix Rodriguez and Deputy Warden Robert Montoya went inside to talk with inmates, but King said they had problems determining who was leading the rebellion. ``They will start talking to one inmate and another will run up and say he is in charge,'' the governor said. At first, he said, there were no specific demands. ``They said they were treated like kids and not like men,'' King said. The inmates did demand that there be no prosecution for any crimes committed during the riot, but state officials refused. Later, the prisoners drew up a list of 11 demands, including better food, recreation, visiting conditions and educational opportunities, an end to overcrowding and assurances there would be no retaliation for the uprising. About 80 inmates who had announced they wanted no part of the rebellion moved to the prison ball field about 8 a.m. Saturday. Throughout the day, more inmates surrendered. By Saturday night, Warden Jerry Griffin estimated about 450 had turned themselves in. And although the prisoners were still in control, Griffin said the situation was stable. The inmates continued releasing hostages one by one; by early Sunday morning, nine still were held. By midday Sunday, most of the fires had died down, about half the prisoners had surrendered and two more guards were freed. Seven inmates had been confirmed dead and dozens were hospitalized, some for drug overdoses after rioters broke into the penitentiary's pharmacy. At 1:45 p.m. Sunday, about 100 guardsmen carrying M-16s and police officers carrying shotguns marched in, retaking control within minutes without firing a shot. Within hours, the full horror began to be known. Lt. Richard Montoya, who headed the state police Special Weapons and Tactics team that led the move to retake the prison, said, ``There was blood all over, against the wall, smeared around.'' A blowtorch had been turned on one prisoner and a rod was rammed through another's head, a mutilation the medical examiner later determined occurred after death. ``Some of these guys' faces are totally gone,'' corrections officer Fred Herrera said. ``There's nothing to identify.'' ``National guardsmen are throwing up all over,'' said Corrections Commission Chairman Steven Richards. The U.S. Supreme Court earlier this month declined to consider New Mexico Attorney General Hal Stratton's challenge to the consent decree governing New Mexico's prisons, which Stratton contended the federal courts lack the jurisdiction to enforce. The former inmate whose 1977 lawsuit led to the decree, Dwight Duran, blames efforts to overturn it on conservative, ``saber-rattling'' legislators. He called the decree the inmates' only way to prevent the prison system from backsliding. ``I'll still be around,'' Duran said, ``and so will a lot of other people who believe as I do and who are knowledgeable enough to do battle with the saber-rattlers.''

DOC.HEAD: Recession Fears Develop Tardily
DOC.TEXT: The realization that a recession is possible seems to come as a shock to a good part of the investment and economic fraternity, almost as if they had been caught from behind by a mugger. But the signals have been flashing all year long. The rate of corporate earnings increases has been shrinking for a year, but it wasn't until September that it seemed to grab attention. The index of leading economic indicators has also been flashing yellow since last January. Industrial production has been showing weakness for several months, and the level of corporate dividend cuts or omissions has been moving higher. Banks are in trouble, inventories have been growing, factories have cut work weeks. Nobody knows better than brokers that the seven-year era of growth has encountered problems: some have had their commissions cut, their companies have run into financial problems, their analysts have been issuing warnings. It was there in the numbers too, in the various ratios of stock prices to values, such as the price-earnings and price-equity ratios, which were running higher, albeit not by much, than their long-term averages. But all the warnings might not have mattered, however, judging from the sense of shock being expressed around Wall Street, among economists and in the laboratories of academe. They may not have heeded their own advice. That the economy was likely to slow was evident in still another obvious way _ the determination of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, to resist any substantial economic growth until he had conquered inflation. While some people, perhaps even including a few in the White House, might think that any inflation rate below 5 percent is tolerable, Greenspan more than once has indicated that nothing above zero is acceptable. The very attempt to achieve anything approaching zero inflation was in itself a warning, because no person or institution can tinker with an inflation level that low without running the danger of recession. The warnings, therefore, were there _ and seemingly ignored. Seven long years of expansion, unprecedented in any peacetime period this century, probably had dulled the sense of fear that had prevailed throughout the 1970s. That dulling was evident in the annual forecasts issued during December, when one forecast after another came out with the same view of 1990, a year of slow growth, low inflation and _ underlined _ no recession. Now that recession fears have been roused, it seems there exists a danger that those fears will cloud the outlook as badly as their earlier absence hid the true nature of things. It wouldn't be the first time. In fact, while everyone is talking about a recession to come, the factors of recovery might be taking shape. The Fed, for example, could be thinking about easing money restraints. The Japanese could be looking at U.S. stocks. The past demonstrates clearly that economic forecasters are at their best when little change is expected, and at their worst in attempting to spot economic turnabouts. It could happen again. They are not alone in their failure to discover either the present or the future. When Gerald Ford was president he had just begun a campaign to cool the economy and whip inflation when his economists spotted a cloud. It was recession instead.
