DOC.TEXT: Sellers sold more stock in a market rattled by fears of higher worldwide interest rates, knocking the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 40 points to a six-month low. The average of 30 industrial stocks, Wall Street's best-known barometer, dropped 43.46 to 2,561.04 on Thursday. The Dow average, which has fallen 249.11 points over the past 17 trading days, reached its lowest close since it stood at 2,544.76 last July 18. Brokers said the market performance reflected the increasing reluctance of many investors to hold stocks because of the economic uncertainty posed by rising interest rates in Europe and Japan.

Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan has cautioned Congress against placing any new impediments on foreign investment, saying it would force interest rates higher and ``probably curb economic activity.'' ``These investments sometimes disrupt established patterns of doing business,'' Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee on Thursday, ``but on the whole such concerns are overblown.''

Existing home sales, dragged down by high interest rates, slumped 4.6 percent last year, to the lowest level since 1985, but were rebounding as the year ended, a real estate trade group said. Sales of existing homes totaled 3.43 million units, compared with 3.59 million in 1988, the strongest year of the decade, the National Association of Realtors said Thursday.

After months of promising its creditors 100 cents on the dollar, struggling Eastern Airlines has proposed paying off only part of its debts to unsecured creditors, and giving them a 40 percent stake in the slimmed down carrier. Officials of Miami-based Eastern presented the revised reorganization plan Thursday in a meeting with major creditors at a New York hotel. Eastern proposed that unsecured creditors be paid only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest. In return, Eastern's parent, Texas Air Corp., would give the creditors 40 percent of the airline's equity, reducing its holding to 60 percent.

Americans' wages, salaries and other benefits rose 5 percent last year, the government said. Economists called the rise a sign that high labor costs may worsen the nation's inflation problems. The Labor Department said Thursday its Employment Cost Index, considered one of the best gauges of inflationary wage pressures, showed an increase equal to the 5 percent rise in 1988 in employment costs. Rising health care costs, in part, pushed the index forward both years, the agency said.

Federal regulators have imposed a 10-day trading suspension in the securities of Bolar Pharmaceutical Co., the blood pressure medication maker under fire over allegedly falsifying safety claims. The Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday it ordered the suspension due to ``the lack of adequate current information'' about a disclosure that false documents were given to the Food and Drug Administration. A House subcommittee on Tuesday disclosed a letter from Bolar's attorneys indicating the generic drug maker apparently falsified documents about safety tests for its version of a popular blood pressure-controlling drug.

The nation's top life insurer plans to allow terminally ill policyholders and those permanently confined to nursing homes to tap into death benefits while they are still alive, providing them cash to cover the enormous cost of dying. The move by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, to be announced Friday, will be available initially to current policyholders in 10 states where regulators have already approved the program: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Idaho, Kentucky, Montana, New Jersey and West Virginia.

A federal bankruptcy judge promises swift action to help ensure that Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. keep their shelves stocked and registers ringing during Chapter 11 reoganization. ``It will be full speed ahead in this case,'' U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said Thursday. Aug gave the two retailers approval to continue funding benefits for their 100,000 employees. He also granted interim approval to draw on loans that Federated and Allied said they need to buy spring merchandise and hold their market shares against competitors.

Crooks and con artists are updating their scams for the 1990s and ``if you own a telephone, then you are a potential victim,'' a group dedicated to fighting telemarketing fraud has warned. The decade's new con jobs include bogus offers that ``guarantee'' _ for a hefty fee _ to help sell that vacation timeshare unit you got stuck with in the 1980s, the Alliance Against Fraud in Telemarketing said Thursday in releasing its predictions for the decade's 10 most prevalent telemarketing scams.

A late burst of selling drove stock prices down to a six-month low Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 43.46 to 2,561.04, closing for the first time below the 2,569.26 level it hit in a severe but short-lived selloff last Oct. 13. The dollar closed mostly lower amid fears of falling foreign investment. Treasury bond priced slumped again. Wheat futures prices sank to four-month lows and soybean futures reached their lowest levels since mid-October; corn and oat futures retreated; oil futures rose; sugar futures were up sharply; pork bellies soared while livestock futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Proposes Cutting Payments to Creditors, Restructuring Ownership
DOC.TEXT: After months of promising its creditors 100 cents on the dollar, struggling Eastern Airlines has proposed paying off only part of its debts to unsecured creditors, and giving them a 40 percent stake in the slimmed down carrier. Officials of Miami-based Eastern presented the revised reorganization plan Thursday in a meeting with major creditors at a New York hotel. Eastern proposed that unsecured creditors be paid only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest. In return for accepting partial repayment, Eastern's parent, Texas Air Corp., would give the creditors 40 percent of the airline's equity, reducing its holding to 60 percent. Under Eastern's two previous plans, unsecured creditors were to be repaid in full with interest at the completion of Chapter 11. Eastern owes the unsecured creditors, primarily trade suppliers such as aircraft manufacturers, around $1.1 billion. Eastern's plan also calls for paying preferred stockholders, to whom it owes another $1.175 billion, no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new stock. On the other hand, consumers holding $45 million in Eastern tickets made unusable by the strike that began last March 4 still would receive full cash payment if the reorganization plan is approved by the court. They also would have the option of exchanging tickets for other Eastern tickets of higher value. Attorneys for the unsecured creditors' committee said they were reserving judgment on the new plan. ``The committee will evaluate this plan as well as consider other options and will measure this plan against various alternatives,'' said Adam Harris, a lawyer for the group. He declined to elaborate. Eastern also told the creditors it expects to post a net loss of $280 million for the fourth quarter, bringing losses for all of 1989 to an estimated $850 million. The airline also projected a $125 million net loss for the first quarter of 1990. Thursday's meeting followed news that a major shareholder in Texas Air had sold its stake in the nation's largest airline holding company. Loomis Sayles & Co., an investment firm based in Boston, said Wednesday it had sold its stake in Texas Air, also the parent of Houston-based Continental Airlines. Last summer, Loomis Sayles controlled 12.3 percent of the company. ``I sold every share I owned,'' said Ken Heebner, Loomis Sayles' portfolio manager. ``If I had other airlines, I would have sold them.'' He said airline stocks are no longer attractive. Stock of Houston-based Texas Air continued to drop Thursday, falling 37{ cents to close at $7 after plunging $1.37{ on Wednesday. Before the meeting, rumors swirled that Texas Air itself could seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors, as did Eastern last March and Continental in 1983. The Fort Worth (Texas) Star Telegram published an article Wednesday headlined, ``Texas Air Fighting Rumors of its Demise.'' Texas Air spokesman Art Kent rejected the article on Thursday. ``Continental is not going into bankruptcy. Texas Air is not going into bankruptcy. Eastern is not going to be liquidated,'' he said in a telephone interview from Houston. ``We are in very good financial condition.'' Kent said the three companies together have around $1 billion in cash, including funds held in escrow that Eastern raised by selling a number of assets, including its Northeast shuttle service. Texas Air reported a net loss of $158 million in the third quarter of 1989, as Eastern's losses offset profits at Continental. In a statement issued late Thursday, Eastern said it plans to emerge from bankruptcy as soon as mid-year as a ``strong competitor'' with $500 million in cash, access to new aircraft and a more conservative balance sheet. The new reorganization plan ``helps position Eastern as a significant competitor and provides definite advantages to the consumer,'' Eastern President Phil Bakes said in the statement. ``That has always been our primary goal.'' In the plan, Eastern also proposed to continue to pay employees' retirement and pension benefits in full. Holders of Eastern preferred stock would receive new preferred shares equal to 5 percent to 10 percent of the current stock value, depending on the issue. Some of the new preferred shares would pay 10 percent annual dividends after a two-year period. Creditors are expected to review the proposal next. Eastern and its creditors must agree to the plan, then obtain the approval of the bankruptcy court before the proposal can be implemented and Eastern can emerge from bankruptcy. Eastern also said it plans to ask the court for $100 million in cash from escrow funds to cover operating expenses. Similar requests totaling $210 million have been granted previously. In addition to the Air Line Pilots Association, the Machinists and the Transport Workers Union, other members of the creditors' committee include Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium; General Electric Co.; Boeing Co.; United Technologies Credit Corp.; Rolls-Royce Credit Corp.; Marriott Corp.; and AT&T Communications.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Suspends Stock Trading of Generic Drug Maker
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended trading for 10 days in the securities of Bolar Pharmaceutical Co., the generic drug maker accused of falsifying safety claims. The SEC said it suspended trading Thursday because of ``the lack of adequate current information concerning the recent public disclosure that certain false documents were submitted to the Food and Drug Administration.'' On Tuesday, a House subcommittee disclosed a letter from Bolar's attorneys that indicated the Copaigue, N.Y.-based generic drug maker apparently falsified documents about safety tests for its version of a popular blood pressure-controlling drug. The SEC said suspension of trading for Bolar securities began at 9:30 a.m. Thursday and would continue until 11:59 p.m. Feb. 3. ``The SEC made their decision to suspend trading because the company did not disclose enough information and when we can, we will,'' a Bolar spokeswoman, Patricia Shukri, said from the company's Long Island headquarters. ``This whole matter is under investigation and the company cannot make further comment at this time,'' she said. Bolar's anti-hypertension drug is the only generic version of Dyazide on the market after another company took its version off the market after it admitted cheating on tests required for FDA approval. Dyazide is a widely prescribed high blood pressure medication made by SmithKline Beecham. Two generic versions of the drug were approved by the FDA. In August the FDA said it would seek to remove Bolar's version of the drug, claiming the drug maker may have misrepresented documentation and safety data. An allegation Bolar denied. However, the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on oversight and investigations disclosed a letter from attorneys for Bolar which said the company appeared to have used false documents to fight government action against its generic form of of Dyazide. Leaders of the subcommittee said Tuesday that it appears the company was involved in a ''criminal cover-up'' and called for Bolar to remove its generic drug Dyazide from the market.

DOC.HEAD: Telemarketing Scams: Forecasting Phone Fraud for the '90s
DOC.TEXT: A group dedicated to fighting telemarketing fraud is urging victims of con artists to speak out and report them to the authorities. ``Please don't suffer in silence,'' said Mike McCarey, of the Federal Trade Commission's consumer protection bureau. ``Don't be ashamed if you become a victim,'' said Linda F. Golodner, executive director of the National Consumers League. ``Report it to the authorities so something can be done to help the next person.'' They were among the speakers at a news conference in Washington Thursday sponsored by the Alliance Against Telemarketing Fraud. The alliance, in announcing its predictions for the 10 most prevalent telemarketing scams this decade, warned that crooks and con artists are updating their scams for the 1990s. The decade's new con jobs include bogus offers that ``guarantee'' _ for a hefty fee _ to help sell that vacation timeshare unit you got stuck with in the 1980s. In another, mortgage acceleration scalpers promise to ``help'' homeowners save money by paying off their loan obligations early but actually wind up costing them much more. ``With each change in technology, there's a new twist,'' said Ms. Golodner of the National Consumers League, one of the 60 consumer groups, trade associations, government agencies, businesses and labor unions that form the alliance. The Federal Trade Commission estimates that telemarketing fraud has cost consumers $1 billion a year for the last five years. Kansas Securities Commissioner Doug Mays went even further. ``These people are crooks. Their weapons are telephones _ not guns,'' he warned, adding ``If you own a telephone, then you are a potential victim for these people.'' The alliance's watch list of schemes aimed at relieving U.S. consumers of their money includes ``abusive'' 1-900 long distance telephone numbers that charge the unwary several dollars per minute _ often while they are kept on hold for information they could get for free. ``The industry is trying very hard to police our end of it, but we're only one part of the equation,'' said Ken Griffin, a spokesman for American Telephone and Telegraph Co. He said AT&T screens potential 900-service customers for credit background and other routine information but not for how the phone link will be used. Although there are numerous legitimate telemarketers, ``we want to warn consumers that con artists are making these types of offers through high-pressure sales pitches providing little concrete information,'' said Ms. Golodner. Richard Barton of the Direct Marketing Association, a trade group of about 3,000 telemarketing companies, said, ``We believe very strongly as an industry that telefraud is very harmful to our businesses.'' Barton, who also attended the news conference, noted that his association maintains a code of ethics but ``an outright fraudulent organization is not going to pay attention to us anyway.'' All of the speakers urged consumers to avoid becoming victims by checking out offers that sound too good to be true, asking for explanations in writing, hanging up on high-pressure salespeople and taking their time before agreeing to buy.

DOC.HEAD: High Taxes Drive Canadian Beer Buyers Across The Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollar figures are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Visitors to this border town shouldn't be surprised if the cold Canadian beer their host offers them has an ``imported'' stamp on it these days. An increasing number of Canadians who live near the U.S. border have taken to buying their favorite brews in the United States, where popular Canadian beers sell for as little as half the price charged back home. The trend is seriously worrying the managers of beer outlets in border towns such as Fort Erie, just across the Niagara River from Buffalo, N.Y. They say they're hamstrung because of government controls on price and marketing. ``We're not on a level playing field,'' said Gordon Reichett, manager of the Fort Erie Beer Store. ``There's no way for us to do anything about the marketing because we're limited by the (Ontario) Liquor Control Board.'' In Ontario, for example, beer may be sold only through Beer Store outlets and provincial liquor stores, and prices, by law, must be the same everywhere. That leaves border-area beer sellers unable to meet the competition from New York supermarkets, which use beer as a loss leader to lure customers. ``We use some beers ... as draws to get people into the stores,'' said Mark Zee, manager of a Tops supermarket in Buffalo. ``We don't lose money on it but we don't make a lot either.'' In Buffalo, Canadian brands such as Molson Golden or Labatt's Blue cost about $12 a case, including tax, deposit and the round-trip toll on the international Peace Bridge. The same beer costs $19.65 a case at Beer Store outlets, which control 94 percent of Ontario's beer trade. The price difference has existed for years, but merchants on both sides of the border said Canadians only began shopping for beer in the United States in large numbers about a year ago, when the Canadian dollar strengthened against U.S. dollar and American stores began advertising heavily in Canada. Reichett said business at his store is off 11 percent from last year's pace. Sales would be even slower if it weren't for U.S. shoppers seeking premium high-alcohol Canadian beers that are unavailable in the United States. Those buyers now make up almost 25 percent of his business, he says. ``The Fort Erie people are not buying the Molson Dry and the Brador and the Extra Stock ales,'' Reichett said. ``It's the American clientele, and thank God for them.'' Canada Customs does not keep statistics on beer imports, but inspectors at the Peace Bridge estimate that Canadian brands account for about 30 percent of the beer that Canadians bring back from the United States. Jan Westcott, executive director of the trade group Brewers of Ontario, said the problem exists throughout the province's borders with New York, Michigan and Minnesota. He said high alcohol taxes are the culprit. ``If you take $10 worth of tax off and account a little for the exchange rate, there's not that much difference in the price,'' he said. ``We have a very aggressive tax policy with respect to alcohol.'' Even when you add in $6.80 a case in tax and duty collected by Canada Customs at the border, it's cheaper to buy beer in New York. And that's only if shoppers declare their beer. Some don't, and many who do say they often are waved through without paying duty. ``They're pretty slack on the bridges these days, letting people go back and forth with whatever they want,'' said Larry Shale, manager of the Beer Store in Niagara Falls, He said business at his store is off almost 20 percent in the past year. ``If they were stricter in controlling what goes over the bridges, that would help us.'' Customs officials say that's an exaggeration, but admit many shoppers do get by without paying duty, especially on busy days. ``We get some days where the traffic's backed up across the bridge,'' Stuart McLeod, a Canada Customs supervisor in Fort Erie. ``There's no way of collecting duty on every single case.''

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Profit Down; Blumenthal Retiring
DOC.TEXT: W. Michael Blumenthal, the former treasury secretary who engineered the creation of Unisys Corp., has announced his long-expected retirement after a year of losses and layoffs that ended on a profitable note. Blumenthal, 64, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, will retire in April to join the investment banking firm Lazard Freres & Co. as a limited partner, Unisys said in a statement from Detroit, where the board of directors met Thursday. The board gave the CEO position to president James A. Unruh, 48, who also will retain the title of president. Blumenthal will remain chairman of the board. Unisys also reported its fourth-quarter profit fell 84 percent as a weak U.S. market offset strong international growth and previously announced layoffs took a toll. Blumenthal was chairman of Bendix Corp. for five years before President Jimmy Carter named him treasury secretary in 1977. He resigned in 1979 to join Burroughs Corp. and was chief executive when the Detroit-based computer maker took over Sperry Corp. to form Unisys in 1986, the biggest acquisition ever in the industry. ``After almost two decades of managing major industrial companies and 10 years at Burroughs and Unisys, the time has come for my long-planned retirement,'' Blumenthal said in a statement. For the three months ended Dec. 31, the company reported net income of $34 million, or 5 cents a share on a fully diluted basis, compared with $218 million, or $1.05 a share, in the same quarter of 1988. Revenue for the fourth quarter totaled $2.97 billion, up 2 percent from $2.91 billion a year earlier. Decreases in defense business and U.S. commercial computer orders offset double-digit growth in international orders, Unisys said from its Blue Bell headquarters. The U.S. business was hurt temporarily by a $230 million restructuring charge against third-quarter earnings that included the layoff of about 8,000 employees and consolidation of factories, the company said. But the restructuring helped the company return to profitability and a positive cash flow from operations after a $648.2 million loss in the third quarter, Unisys said. For all of 1989, Unisys reported a loss of $639.3 million, or $4.71 a share. In 1988, the company reported a profit of $680.6 million, or $3.27 a share. Revenue for the year rose 2 percent to $10.10 billion from $9.94 billion. Unisys said inventories were cut $216 million during the quarter to $1.8 billion, bringing the year's reduction to $723 million. The company had set a goal of reducing inventories by $500 million after they rose $628 million in 1988 to $2.5 billion. ``We are encouraged by the very early results from our fundamental cost structure initiatives,'' Blumenthal said. ``Our program is on schedule. Benefits are expected to accelerate gradually with the full impact to be realized in the latter part of this year.'' Unisys will seek to reduce debt by $600 million to $800 million in 1990, in part through the sale of non-strategic and idle assets, Blumenthal said. ``Overall, 1989 was a difficult and disappointing year,'' he said. ``We believe we have made progress against problems unique to Unisys, such as the high inventory position entering 1989. And we moved decisively to adapt to the rapidly emerging new economic model for the industry in the 1990s. These actions will facilitate additional progress in the implementation of our strategic plans.''

DOC.HEAD: UAL Noncommital On Union Offer, Opens Door To Davis
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. is encouraging United Airlines employees to work up a formal buyout proposal for the parent company, but still is keeping other options open. The board, for example, opened the door Thursday to a new bid from Los Angeles billionaire Marvin Davis. It also said it will continue to explore a possible recapitalization, rather than a buyout, as a means of boosting its stock price. Separately, UAL underscored the financial cost of the 6-month-old ownership contest when it reported a 67 percent plunge in its fourth-quarter earnings, due largely to $60 million in buyout expenses. After meeting at UAL's Chicago-area headquarters on Thursday, UAL's directors issued a statement saying a plan outlined by United's three labor unions on Wednesday to acquire 75 percent of the carrier did not constitute an acquisition proposal. The board instructed its legal and financial advisers to work with the unions in developing a formal bid. The board also said it would ``consider any acquisition proposal made by the employee group or any third party when any such proposal is made.'' The statement also said the board was releasing Davis and British Airways PLC from agreements they signed last summer prohibiting them from making takeover offers of less than $300 a share. Davis first put UAL in play last August with an unsolicited offer of $200 a share or $4.32 billion. UAL's board later accepted a $300-a-share, $6.75-billion offer from United's management and pilots, with British Airways as an equity partner. That offer collapsed in October when banks refused to finance it, precipitating a 190-point plunge in the stock market. Analysts said UAL may have released the parties from the restrictions both to avoid future lawsuits should the company be sold to its workers for less than $300 a share, and to open up the field to all comers. ``I think they genuinely want to get this thing over with and I think it's fair to open the door to any and all who want to bid on the company,'' said analyst Stephen Dexter of Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. Davis sources last week denied a report in Business Week magazine that Davis was preparing a $250-a-share offer for UAL. The California investor did not immediately return calls seeking comment on Thursday's development, nor did spokesmen for United's unions. British Airways spokesman Sandy Gardiner said his company had no plans to participate in a new bid for UAL. UAL's stock fell $3 to $158.50 Thursday in New York Stock Exchange trading. The buyout proposal revealed Wednesday by United's unionized pilots, flight attendants and Machinists would put 75 percent of UAL's stock in employees' hands, creating the country's largest employee-controlled company. The unions have said they will take pay cuts and sign five-year contracts in return for majority ownership of the nation's second-largest airline. But the proposal left many key issues open, including the structure, financing and price of a buyout and the role of Chairman Stephen Wolf in an employee-controlled UAL. Meanwhile, UAL on Thursday reported net income fell to $6.8 million, or 31 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with $20.9 million, or 97 cents a share, for the same period of 1988. Revenues rose to $2.4 billion from $2.2 billion. Fourth-quarter expenses of $60 million related to the failed buyout bid were offset partially by a $40.7 million gain from stock appreciation rights also linked to the buyout attempt, the company said. Those pre-tax items combined to depress fourth quarter earnings by $11.6 million. A 34 percent increase in jet fuel costs also depressed earnings, UAL said. For all of 1989, UAL reported net income of $324.2 million, or $14.96 per share, down 71 percent from $1.1 billion, or $37.87 per share, in 1988. Revenues last year totaled $9.8 billion compared with $9 billion in 1988. UAL said 1988 earnings were boosted by a $393 million pre-tax gain from the partial sale of its Covia automated reservations system and a $523.9 million gain from the January 1988 sale of Westin Hotel Co.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Some Interim Financing
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge promises swift action to help ensure that Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. keep their shelves stocked and registers ringing during Chapter 11 reoganization. ``It will be full speed ahead in this case,'' U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said Thursday. Aug gave the two retailers approval to continue funding benefits for their 100,000 employees. He also granted interim approval to draw on loans that Federated and Allied said they need to buy spring merchandise and hold their market shares against competitors. James Zimmerman, president of Federated Stores Inc., parent company of Allied and Federated, said the interim funding would allow the company's nine department store chains to continue business. Aug said he sympathized with U.S. Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern and creditors' lawyers, who argued for delays to give them time to go through the bulky financial agreements the retailers propose. Morgenstern, who is helping steer the companies through the reorganization proceedings, said his office has been so swamped that his staff will not be able to start assembling a creditors' committee until next week. ``I realize it's going to put a tremendous burden on everybody in this room, ... but let's face it, there are no babes in the woods here,'' Aug told a courtroom packed with lawyers for major banks and other creditors. ``We're going to come to a decision in this case on the financing sooner, rather than later.'' Aug approved Federated and Allied payments for health and disability insurance, drug and alcohol abuse counseling, employee educational programs and a company savings plan. David Heiman, a lawyer for Federated and Allied, said the payments would total more than $5 million, but he said the companies don't know how much all of the programs will cost. Warren N. Rothman, a Federated and Allied vice president for benefits, said paying the benefits that employees earned before the retailers sought bankruptcy court protection would help boost employee confidence. Thursday's hearings were the first for the retailing divisions of Toronto-based Campeau Corp. since they filed for protection from creditors on Jan. 15, listing debts of $7.5 billion. It is the biggest Chapter 11 filing in American retailing history, brought on by debts amassed when Campeau bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. Under Chapter 11, the companies must get court approval to pay operating expenses and other bills. Aug granted Federated and Allied permission to draw immediately on bank financing to ensure shipments of imported spring merchandise. Federated received interim approval to use up to $50 million for letters of credit. Allied got interim approval to use up to $50 million in working capital and $80 million in merchandise financing. Aug scheduled final hearings on the financing arrangements in Cincinnati on Feb. 8 for Federated and Feb. 9 for Allied. John Zeiger, a Federated-Allied lawyer, persuaded Aug not to delay final hearings on the bank financing agreements. Zeiger said provisions of the agreements permit the banks to withdraw from their commitments if the financing doesn't receive court approval by Feb. 14. ``Another week will be a killer on the business of Allied and Federated,'' Zeiger said. ``That's why we've pushed as hard as we have.'' Harvey Miller, a lawyer for the Citibank-led bank consortium that has agreed to provide Federated with $400 million in financing, said the group includes more than 100 banks, 60 percent of them foreign. He said it would be difficult to recruit new supporting banks if the Feb. 14 expiration date passed. Allied negotiated a $300 million financing agreement with Chemical Bank. The judge also ruled that Federated and Allied may maintain credit lines they had before the Chapter 11 reorganization petitions were filed. Federated has a $1 billion credit facility and Allied $700 million, both through New York's Citibank. He also approved Federated's request to be allowed to continue to sell Allied computerized credit services. And Aug permitted the resumption of 20 percent store discounts to Federated and Allied retirees, and $600,000 in bonuses promised to some employees of Federated's Bloomingdale's chain.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Lobbies FCC in Bid to Become Fourth TV Network
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Fox Broadcasting Co. will ask the Federal Communications Commission to allow it to develop into a true ``fourth network'' to compete with NBC, ABC and CBS free of rules that restrict network programs and sales. Fox Inc. Chairman Barry Diller, in Washington Thursday to press his case on Capitol Hill and at the FCC, said his company on Tuesday will ask the commission to relax so-called financial interest and syndication rules on networks. The FCC defines a network, among other things, as a company that broadcasts at least 15 hours of television programs a week. Fox Broadcasting, the scrappy three-year-old company that has won a loyal following with such shows as ``21 Jump Street,'' ``Married ... With Children'' and gritty ``reality'' programs, expects to achieve network status in September. Besides asking the FCC to change the rules _ called fin-syn rules in the industry _ Fox also wants a waiver from the 15-hour programming limit so it can ``continue to grow,'' Diller said. Fox also wants the FCC to revise its definition of a network, said Diller. The fin-syn rules prohibit a TV network from selling to independent stations programs that have been presented on the network. They also prohibit a network from having a financial interest in programs it does not solely produce. Fox has been airing its shows on its seven owned stations and is selling them to an affiliate ``network'' and to non-Fox-affiliated stations. The selling to non-affiliated stations would stop if Fox qualified as a network. Fox officials claim the rules are antiquated in an era of multinational media conglomerates and that they stifle competition. ``I think there is sympathy for our position,'' Diller said after his meetings. ``We are providing the first competition to the three television networks in 40 years. And it has been the stated policy of the FCC going back 40 years to do everything they could to encourage the development of a fourth network.'' The FCC in 1983 suspended its investigation into the network rules after then-President Ronald Reagan intervened on behalf of his former colleagues in Hollywood production circles. FCC Commissioner James Quello, after meeting with Diller and other top Fox officials, predicted it would be a ``very close call'' whether the commission takes up the company's request. ``There's a lot of merit on both sides,'' Quello said in a telephone interview. Congress and the FCC have said they would prefer that Hollywood and the TV networks work out a new agreement on fin-syn rules. The rules are under attack by the three major TV networks, which have been foreclosed from the multibillion-dollar market for network reruns on local stations. Hollywood TV producers, following a network run of their shows, can reap huge sums in the syndication market. The networks have been conducting lengthy and so far fruitless negotiations with Hollywood television producers on new regulations. NBC President Robert Wright has complained to House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman John Dingell, D-Mich., the rules make it more difficult for American networks to compete with overseas companies that can produce, own and syndicate their programs.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Offer Plans to Scrap Gramm-Rudman Balanced-Budget Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The chairmen of Congress' two budget committees want the government to change the way it tries to cut the federal deficit, adding their voices to the growing chorus that says the current system doesn't work. The two Democrats _ Rep. Leon Panetta of California and James Sasser of Tennessee _ proposed separate plans on Thursday to scrap the oft-derided Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law and replace it with other mechanisms. ``Gramm-Rudman is no longer part of the solution,'' Panetta told reporters. ``It has become part of the problem.'' The proposals come amid increasing dissatisfaction in Congress with the credibility of the budget process. Sasser's plan would dangle the possibility of $17 billion in cuts in the Social Security payroll tax as a reward for each year lawmakers enact $30 billion in budget savings. ``With this shift, every working man and woman in America will become part of a constituency for fiscal responsibility, because they have something to gain from deficit reduction,'' Sasser told reporters. Panetta's idea would lower the amount of deficit reduction required each year, but stiffen the rules by which the cuts are calculated and achieve a balanced budget by 1998, he said. Interest in budget honesty has been galvanized by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. He has sought to justify his plan to slash the Social Security tax by contending that the retirement system's huge surpluses make the overall federal deficit seem smaller than it really is. Bipartisan criticism also has been leveled at Gramm-Rudman, which requires a series of declining deficit targets culminating in a balanced budget in 1993. Legislation enacted last year that claimed a savings of nearly $2 billion simply by shifting the money-losing Postal Service ``off budget'' was merely the latest device budget writers have devised to evade the law's intent. The actual deficit has exceeded Gramm-Rudman's targets every year since the legislation was passed in 1985. ``Gramm-Rudman simply rewards, on a year-to-year basis, the big lie,'' Sasser told reporters. Both Panetta's and Sasser's plans would abandon the automatic spending cuts that Gramm-Rudman requires in most federal programs should the law's deficit targets not be technically met. Sassers proposal would require Congress and the president to agree to $30 billion in deficit reduction each year. It does not address how those savings would be found, the key question that bedevils lawmakers and the administration every year. If the savings target were achieved, separate legislation would be considered paring the Social Security tax by $17 billion for that year. Sasser said his plan would result in a budget surplus by 1997. He said it also would save workers and employers _ who pay the Social Security levy _ $475 billion over seven years, or an average of $600 a year per worker. Panetta's plan would require about $30 billion per year in deficit reduction through 1993, and about $20 billion annually after that until the budget is balanced. Any spending increases or tax cuts would have to be offset by equal savings. Gimmicks such as moving payments out of a fiscal year to make the deficit appear smaller would be forbidden. Panetta would not permit the Social Security trust fund surpluses to be used to make the deficit appear smaller.

DOC.HEAD: Auditors See Danger of Federal Sales Depressing Real Estate Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration should do a better job coordinating the sale of federally owned properties or face the ``real danger'' of depressing fragile real estate markets, congressional auditors warn. The Resolution Trust Corp., a new agency created this summer to dispose of as much as $300 billion in assets from failed S&Ls, is prohibited from dumping the property _ selling real estate too fast for too little money. But other agencies with vast residential real estate holdings, such as the Veterans' and Housing departments, are not restricted and may try to beat the RTC to the market, the General Accounting Office said Thursday. ``A real danger is that the enormous amount of real estate assets in federal inventories could tempt some federal agencies to quickly reduce holdings in anticipation of a growing surplus in real estate markets that may occur once the RTC begins to actively market its assets,'' GAO assistant comptroller Richard L. Fogel told the House Banking Committee. ``Such a development could ... depress real estate markets generally,'' he warned. A plan for the S&L bailout prepared by an administration oversight board ``sheds little light on how asset management and disposition efforts will be coordinated and harmonized across the federal government,'' Fogel said. However, Diane Casey, a spokeswoman for the oversight board, said the RTC has been instructed to consult with other agencies and has already begun meeting with them. The GAO, the auditing and investigative arm of Congress, also criticized the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. for failing to properly monitor billions of dollars of government assistance going to S&Ls that were rescued in 1988 by the now-defunct Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. The cost of the assistance approaches $40 billion, yet the FDIC ``has not given ... sufficient priority'' to managing it, Fogel said. Audits assessing the condition of bailed-out thrifts and the government's likely liabilities were supposed to be finished, for the most part, by the middle of last year. But only nine of 152 required audits are complete, Fogel said. Meanwhile, the Congressional Budget Office, confirming an earlier warning from FDIC and RTC Chairman L. William Seidman, said the cost of the S&L bailout is ``quite likely'' to exceed the $50 billion allotted. The RTC is supposed to handle any thrifts failing before August 1992, but probably won't have enough money to do that, said James L. Blum, assistant director of the budget office. That means the new Savings Association Insurance Fund, which will have $16 billion to spend from 1992 through 1999, ``will have insufficient funds,'' he said. The government would be left in the position of having to keep insolvent S&Ls open because it lacked the money to close them, just as it was before the bailout bill passed. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the banking panel, urged the administration to ``face this reality and come to Congress with a realistic appraisal of RTC's funding needs, as soon as possible, rather than slowing down the RTC's activities and increasing the costs to taxpayers.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Finds Food Makers Practice Abroad What They Oppose at Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: American consumers who want to know exactly what's in their food may have to go shopping overseas to find out, says a consumer advocacy group. The Center for Science in the Public Interest said Thursday that U.S. food companies are providing some foreign consumers with food labeling details the firms have opposed in the United States as too costly and intrusive. ``The labels of almost all processed foods sold in Thailand, including well-known American products ... disclose the percentage of each major ingredient contained in the product,'' said CSPI in a written statement. Such labeling would reveal, for example, the percentage of oil in peanut butter, sugar in a candy bar or flour in a cake. Among the products cited by the center as containing more detailed labeling abroad was Kellogg's Frosted Flakes breakfast cereal. Joseph M. Stewart, spokesman for the Michigan-based Kellogg Co., said percentage labeling could mislead consumers who are trying to reduce their intake of certain dietary substances. ``We don't eat on a percentage basis,'' he said. For instance, Stewart said, a 12-ounce can of cola contains 39 grams, or 11 percent, sugar. By comparison, the 11 grams of sugar in a one-ounce serving of Frosted Flakes would equal 39 percent of its content. The difference is explained by the lighter weight of the flakes when compared to the weight of the water in the cola, Stewart said. ``At the moment you decide to eat the one with 11 percent sugar over the one with 39 percent you will have committed the sin of percentage labeling,'' said Stewart. Stewart said Kellogg was complying with Thai government regulations but opposed such requirements by the U.S. government. ``I never expected to find American products with that kind of labeling,'' said Bruce Silverglade, CSPI legal director, in a telephone interview. Silverglade said he discovered the detailed labeling in a Thai grocery store last summer when he went in to purchase bottled water. Alan Goldberg, a spokesman for the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said the food trade group opposes percentage-ingredient labeling on U.S. food products. ``And we will continue to based on propriety information and trade secrets,'' said Goldberg. ``It's not in the consumer interest to put that kind of clutter and detail on labels,'' said Roger Coleman, a spokesman for the National Food Processors Association. ``To do this kind of labeling does nothing but add to the cost and confusion for consumers,'' said Coleman. ``It is ironic that as U.S. food companies work to keep this information secret at home, they have been providing the very same information to consumers overseas,'' said Robert Parrish, a CSPI staff attorney. Consumer, food industry and governmental groups already are wrangling over legislation that would strengthen and make mandatory nutrition labeling _ the amount of calories, proteins, fats and other micro-ingredients _ for all foods.

DOC.HEAD: Prudential Offers to Pay Death Benefits to Terminally Ill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The terminally ill and those facing permanent confinement to nursing homes have a new source of help to pay their skyrocketing bills _ benefits from life insurance policies that usually are paid after they die. The Prudential Insurance Co. of America intended to announce today its ``living needs benefit program,'' the first mass-market plan that lets policyholders tap into their death benefits while they are still living. Prudential will pay close to the face value of a policy if a doctor certifies the policyholder has less than six months to live or has been in a nursing home for six months with little hope of leaving. ``The world is changing in many ways,'' Prudential President Joseph Melone said. ``People are living longer and the medical treatment that is keeping them alive is getting expensive. These are real market needs that should be met.'' Prudential said the new program will be available to current policyholders with death benefits of $25,000. New customers with policies of $50,000 also can qualify. There will be no additional cost for the service other than a small processing charge if a claim is made. Regulators in 10 states have already given the company permission to offer the program. The company plans to expand the program to cover some 3 million policyholders throughout the country. The 10 states: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Idaho, Kentucky, Montana, New Jersey and West Virginia. Once the company receives medical certification, it will assess the policy, figuring in the amount of interest the company will lose for making the early payment and deducting it from the policy's face value. For example, the company is looking into the case of a 57-year-old electrician with a terminal bone marrow disease. The man has three life insurance policies that would pay $186,795 on his death. Under the new program, the man could collect $184,184, or a lesser figure with the balance to be paid to a beneficiary after his death. Robert Hill, Prudential's senior vice president and actuary, said prior to the program the man would only be able to get $73,965 before his death by cashing in the policy for whatever interest had accrued. Similarly, a hypothetical policyholder confined to a nursing home carries a policy that would pay $229,340 at the time of his death. Under the Prudential program, the man could collect the money in 60 monthly payments of $3,810, for a total of $228,600. If he cashed in the policy, he would receive $163,989. Although Melone stressed the Prudential program is no solution to the catastrophic care issue facing the nation, he said it would provide an added safety net to policyholders. ``The main purpose of life insurance was the unexpected death,'' he said. ``What we are talking about here is another very meaningful use of a life insurance benefit.'' Prudential's move comes after a yearlong experiment at its Canadian subsidiary, which provided advanced payment of death benefits to 14 policyholders, many of them suffering from AIDS. Other companies have taken cautious steps toward accelerated benefit payments. For the past year, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. has offered a life insurance rider that pays 30 percent of a policy's face value if the policyholder is the victim of cancer, a severe heart attack, Alzheimer's disease or a variety of other serious illnesses. The rider costs an additional 10 percent of the premium. ``Much to my surprise, it has not produced a significant amount of sales,'' said Gerry Goldsholle, chief brokerage executive for Metropolitan Life's life insurance subsidiary. Goldsholle said his company was studying a program similar to Prudential's. John Booth, vice president and chief actuary for the American Council of Life Insurance, said living benefits has been a long-discussed issue in the industry, ``but no one has acted.'' There are many reasons. To introduce such a program, an insurance company like Prudential must negotiate a maze of different state regulations. In some states, like New York, insurance laws must be rewritten to allow the plan. There is also a question of taxes. While there are no taxes on death benefits, it is uncertain whether early payment of benefits would be taxable. Booth said other companies may overcome their hesitation after watching Prudential's program. ``If this gives Prudential new sales and hurts their competitors, the competitors are sure to run out and do the same thing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Legal Friction In Japan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers usually do the bickering in society, but they may become the subject of the next round of trade bickering between the United States and Japan. Almost two years after Japan opened its doors to foreign lawyers, U.S. attorneys say barriers impede their business here. Japanese lawyers charge Americans want to make Japan over in its own legal image. On Thursday, members of the Japanese Bar Association and representatives of four U.S. bar associations, including those of New York City and California, met to discuss the restrictions. ``Japan will continue to try to resolve these difficult issues but right now we can't say yes or no,'' said Go Kajitani, deputy secretary-general of the Japanese Bar Association. But U.S. lawyers and government officials who attended the private talks said the Japanese lawyers' group, which supervises both Japanese and foreign lawyers in Japan, resisted any changes to the 1987 law that authorized foreign lawyers to work here. Foreign lawyers have a list of grievances: They cannot hire or forge partnerships with Japanese lawyers to facilitate advising their foreign clients about Japanese law. They are also generally barred from arbitration proceedings _ where most legal wrangles in Japan are resolved _ thus missing out on considerable business. And, they say, a requirement that foreign lawyers have at least five years of experience in their home countries means they can send only their experienced _ and most expensive _ lawyers to Tokyo. These barriers prevent American lawyers from providing first-rate legal services to help foreign enterprises fight it out in the relatively closed and difficult Japanese market, U.S. lawyers and officials say. ``These restrictions constitute an important non-tariff trade barrier because, right now, foreign companies cannot go out into the market and get the kind of legal services they need,'' said Ned Perry, chairman of a legal services committee of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan. Foreign companies can seek the advice of Japanese lawyers, called bengoshi, but many U.S. lawyers here say bengoshi are not trained to be advocates for their clients like American or European lawyers are. A U.S. official said access of U.S. lawyers to the Japanese system is a trade priority for the United States. The U.S. government has requested Cabinet-level talks on the issue in late February. The issue is a familiar one to top U.S. trade officials. Trade Representative Carla Hills was a private lawyer in Washington before being tapped for the Cabinet post and S. Linn Williams, Hills' deputy in charge of Japan, opened his California law firm's office in Tokyo in 1987. Of the 57 foreign lawyers who have registered to practice in Japan since April, 1987, almost two-thirds are American. Japanese Bar Association members opposed the opening from the beginning, saying they feared an increase of lawsuits in Japan and an unwelcome tinkering with the way justice is administered here _ which depends more on mediation of disputes than the U.S. adversarial system. But no flood of foreign lawyers has materialized, and lawyers say they are not asking to represent clients in Japanese courts. Japanese lawyers are merely ``drumming up this kind of fear to protect their own positions,'' said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. With just under 14,000 lawyers in Japan _ compared to 100,000 in the state of California alone _ there is little competition among Japanese lawyers, who are generally affluent and revered as professionals. Other U.S. attorneys say the Japanese fear bi-cultural law firms headed by Americans will dominate international law in Japan, as they did for a decade immediately after World War II. Beginning in 1955, foreign lawyers were forbidden from working here except as trainees at Japanese law firms. But some Japanese lawyers see the issue as a further U.S. encroachment on the Japanese system. ``America will not be satisfied until Japan overhauls its laws and regulations to guarantee American companies the same freedoms in Japan that they enjoy at home,'' wrote lawyer Takeshi Suzuki in the journal Japan Echo.. Another rule foreign lawyers complain about is that they are not allowed to call themselves by their real names. They must use the names of their resident partners, followed by a Japanese phrase meaning foreign business lawyer, followed by the name the firm is known by at home. This not only takes up a lot of space on office stationery but robs a law firm of the powerful advertising value of its name. A U.S. official says the problem will likely be resolved soon.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador, Cosmetics Heir Form Central European Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. envoy to Hungary and a cosmetics heir have teamed with other North Americans to form a Central European investment fund, which already has bought half interest in a Hungarian bank in a move to take advantage of recent changes in the region. The U.S. ambassador to Hungary, Mark Palmer, is resigning to become president and chief executive officer of the Central European Development Corporation, said a statement released Thursday. It said Ronald S. Lauder, the son of Estee Lauder and a Republican maverick who lost in last year's primary elections for New York mayor, is the chairman of the new venture. Lauder is a former U.S. ambassador to Vienna. ``The lifting of the Iron Curtain offers an unprecedented opportunity for capital Western investors to promote and encourage economic prosperity in Central Europe,'' Lauder was quoted as saying in the release. ``CEDC (the company's acronym) is putting that opportunity to work.'' Lauder described the corporation as ``investors in _ and believers in _ Central European growth.'' The group announced it had bought 50 percent interest in the Hungarian General Banking and Trust Company Ltd. for $10 million. Palmer plans to resign from the State Department and end his diplomatic career following the Hungarian general elections, which are set for March 25, the release said. It said the company would initially concentrate on business opportunities in Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Company headquarters, now at Lauder's New York City office, will be moved to Budapest, the statement said without giving a specific date. Canadian businessman Andrew Sarlos, a Hungarian expatriate, has been named vice-chairman. Political reforms across the East bloc since last summer have opened up markets for investors, but until Thursday's announcement, few companies outside of General Electric, which bought controlling interest in a Hungarian light bulb company, have stepped forward with large-scale investments. The reforms have opened what used to be closed markets to potential Western investors in other countries such as Poland, Bulgaria, Romania and East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Record Export of Swiss Watches in '89
DOC.TEXT: Swiss watch exports jumped 20 percent in 1989 to a record high of more than $4 billion, the Association of Swiss Watchmakers said Friday. The association said Swiss watch output now accounts for about 50 percent of world production, dominating the more expensive end of the world market. Exports to Japan, one of Switzerland's major watchmaking rivals, surged 70 percent to $295 million. As a result, the Japanese overtook the French as the fifth largest customer, the association said. Hong Kong remains the most important market for Swiss watches. Exports to the British crown colony topped $660 million in 1989. The United States followed with purchases worth $560 million, Italy with $423 million and West Germany with $327 million, the association said. The watchmakers' association said while the number of watches sold last year rose only 6 percent, the value soared because of the increase in demand for more exclusive models. The average price for Swiss watch and watch parts leaving the factory was $53, compared with $8.70 in Japan and only $3 in Hong Kong, the association said. A total 42.5 million watches and watch parts were exported last year.

DOC.HEAD: USAir Union Accepts Pilots Contract
DOC.TEXT: Union representatives for USAir's 6,000 pilots have accepted a proposed contract, ending 17 months of negotiations with the carrier. Elected members of the Air Line Pilots Association met for 10 hours at a hotel here Thursday before ratifying the contract, the first for the combined pilot staffs of USAir and Piedmont Airlines. ALPA spokesman Chris Beebe said the contract provides slightly better pay for junior pilots, improved retirement benefits for pilots who were with USAir before the merger with Piedmont, and strengthened language to prevent USAir from hiring pilots at lower pay to fly some classes of airplanes. But Beebe said USAir gave little ground on many of the contract issues. ``I'd say we are not overjoyed, but we are comfortable with the contract,'' he said. The contract comes a day after USAir reported a $63 million loss for 1989, including a surprising $102 million loss in the fourth quarter. USAir Chairman Edwin Colodny told industry analysts last week that concluding negotiations with several labor groups is a top priority for USAir in 1990. The carrier is still negotiating with two unions representing its flight attendants and mechanics. Baggage handlers conclude a vote Jan. 31 on whether to continue representation by the Teamsters union. Analysts agree the airline needs to get on to other business. ``The hope of the (union leaders) is to now work with the company to help make this the profitable, dependable and customer airline we all hope it will be,'' said Beebe. The union representatives voted 15-12 to accept the contract, but Beebe said the group decided against sending the contract to a vote of its at-large membership. The union had the option of ratifying the contract itself. Pilots who had been with USAir had been without a contract since August 1988. Former Piedmont pilots' contract ran out in October 1989.

The stock market turned in a mixed showing today in an equivocal response to the latest data on the state of the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 9.46 to 2,570.50 in the first half hour of trading. But losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 372 up, 558 down and 505 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 25.37 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The Commerce Department reported this morning that the gross national product grew at a 0.5 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the fourth quarter of last year. The figure was a bit stronger than some analysts had projected. But observers noted that it was magnified to a great extent by increases in inventories, which is not usually interpreted as evidence of robust business activity. A separate report showed a 2.5 percent rise in new factory orders for durable goods in December. In the bond market, where traders are especially sensitive to even slight changes in the perceived pace of the economy, interest rates rose slightly after the figures crossed financial news wires. Teledyne gained 5{ to 339{. The company declared a 5-for-1 stock split and cleared a previously announced plan for a spinoff of its insurance and finance subsidiaries. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .23 to 180.84. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .44 at 353.20. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 43.46 to a six-motnh low of 2,561.04, extending its slide since Jan. 2 to 249.11 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 5 on the NYSE, with 520 up, 933 down and 490 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 172.27 million shares, against 207.83 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Grew by Just 0.5 Percent in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy, hurt by slumping consumer demand, grew just 0.5 percent in the final three months of 1989 for the poorest showing in more than three years, the government said today. The meager performance of the gross national product, the total output of goods and services, was certain to fan the debate over whether the country is in danger of toppling into a recession. The GNP for all of 1989 rose a moderate 2.9 percent. This followed growth of 4.4 percent in 1988 and was the slowest annual increase since a 2.7 percent rise in 1986. While most private economists say the United States will be able to avoid an outright downturn, a more pessimistic minority noted that the government statistics are subject to wide revisions and that today's growth rate could be lowered in coming months, possibly to a negative number. A recession usually is defined as two consecutive quarterly declines in the GNP. ``The GNP report shows the economy ground to a virtual halt in the fourth quarter with signs of weakness everywhere,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``The economy is flirting with a recession.'' But the administration, which is counting on a rebound in growth to provide badly needed government revenues, was more upbeat in its assessment of the GNP report. Michael Boskin, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, blamed part of the fourth-quarter slowdown on one-time factors, such as the unusually cold December weather, the Boeing aircraft strike and the effects of Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco Bay area earthquake. Boskin predicted ``a period of slower growth'' in the months ahead, but he said the economy would rebound later in the year. And, while not ruling out a recession, the president's chief economist said, ``I believe it's unlikely.'' He said the low growth figures could have a ``modest'' impact on the fiscal 1991 budget that Bush unveils on Monday, making it harder to meet the goal of reducing the federal deficit to the $64 billion required under the Gramkm-Rudman budget balancing law. But Boskin suggested that rebounding growth later in the year would cancel any negative impact on the budget. The 0.5 percent growth in the fourth quarter marked the economy's weakest showing since a decline of 1.8 percent in the second quarter of 1986. However, after that one downturn, economic activity rebounded, helped in large part by a boom in U.S. export sales that lifted the fortunes of American manufacturers. But with the improvement in trade deficit slowing dramatically this year, manufacturing unemployment has begun to rise again. In a separate report showing further weakness, the government said that orders to U.S. factories for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ rose just 5.9 percent for all of 1989, half of the 1988 increase. On the inflation front, prices, as measured by an index tied to the GNP, rose 4.5 percent in 1989. That was the fastest increase since a 6.2 percent jump in 1982. The biggest drag on economic activity in the fourth quarter was a huge swing in consumer spending, which posted a rare decline of 0.1 percent, reflecting a big drop in demand for new autos. It was the first decline in consumer spending in two years and came after a giant 5.6 percent jump in the July-September quarter, when consumers had rushed to buy cars to take advantage of discount pricing. Since consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity, the big swing in this category had a major dampening effect on economic activity. Other areas of weakness included the second consecutive quarter in which the trade deficit worsened, reflecting stronger growth in imports than exports. Business investment for expansion and modernization, which had been a key source of strength, dropped by 3 percent in the fourth quarter for the first decline in a year. Military spending fell by $5.4 billion, the biggest setback since the first quarter of 1989. In one of the few signs of strength, the GNP report showed that housing construction, which had fallen for three consecutive quarters, rose a modest 2.6 percent in the September-December period. It was a sign that the credit easing engineered by the Federal Reserve Board are beginning to bolster the fortunes of the housing industry. Economists who believe the nation's seven-year economic expansion will continue are counting on the Fed to ride to the rescue with further moves to lower interest rates and bolster economic growth. But even optimistic forecasters believe growth this year will be quite sluggish, with the GNP expected to rise by only 1.8 percent. This is significantly lower than the projection of the Bush administration, which is counting on stronger growth to help the president keep his pledge of reducing the budget deficit without raising taxes. The Congressional Budget Office, siding with the more pessimistic private forecasters, projected a 1991 deficit of $138 billion, far above the $64 billion deficit limit set by the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law.

DOC.HEAD: P&G Agrees to Buy Del Monte Division
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. has agreed to acquire Del Monte's Hawaiian Punch business for $150 million, the companies announced Friday. P&G expects to complete the purchase by March, after required notification to the Federal Trade Commission, said P&G spokeswoman Wendy Jacques. The Hawaiian Punch purchase will complement P&G's fruit juice lines, which include Citrus Hill orange juice and Sunny Delight punch, she said. Del Monte spokesman Al Vela said the company decided to sell Hawaiian Punch to raise money for Del Monte's primary businesses in canned fruits and vegetables. ``It's a strategic investment, and it's going to let Del Monte concentrate on strengthening the Del Monte brands,'' Vela said. The Hawaiian Punch business employs about 280 people, most at Del Monte's processing plants in New Brunswick, N.J., and Atlanta, Vela said. He said that without Hawaiian Punch, Del Monte expects revenues of $1.2 billion this year in the United States, Mexico and the Caribbean. Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble had worldwide sales in fiscal the last fiscal year of $21.4 billion.

For Release Monday Jan. 29
DOC.HEAD: Payout Elusive From Peace Dividend
DOC.TEXT: The stock market's January tailspin has been especially dizzying for investors who had been caught up in the high-flying hopes engendered last fall by the political upheaval in eastern Europe. Now the letdown has many market participants wondering whether they erred in trying to cash in the ``peace dividend'' too long before it ever had a chance to be declared. In the waning days of 1989, many Wall Streeters began a crash course of study into the prospective economic benefits that might arise from the spread of democracy behind the Iron Curtain. The headlines stirred visions of vast new markets in eastern Europe for many types of goods and services, and of relief at home for the strained federal budget, in the form of reduced federal spending. All these hopes may prove to have a substantial basis in reality, many analysts still say. But they caution that it is easy for investors to get carried away any time they are confronted with ``historic'' changes. In addition, they note, market history shows that even concrete signs of peace in the making don't automatically translate into a rapid increase in stock prices. Some veterans recall that a market top in early 1973, on the eve of a two-year bear market, came just as signs were emerging of an end to the long war in Vietnam. ``While the spread of capitalism bodes for bullish developments in the decades ahead, the transition will be painfully slow and expensive,'' says James Stack, editor of the InvesTech Market Analyst advisory letter. ``We think investor expectations have already surpassed the realistic benefits for the next few years.'' Suresh Bhirud, chief portfolio strategist at Oppenheimer & Co., doesn't seek to minimize the importance of what has happened. ``It's a wonderful surprise that the threat of a major world conflict has diminished significantly for the foreseeable future,'' he observes. ``If these countries achieve some stability, we would expect a resurgence in demand for consumer products, capital goods, and goods and services related to infrastructure construction. This would be icing on the cake for the world economy, which is already much stronger than it was in the 1970s. ``There are some caveats, however. If the move towards economic reform continues in most of eastern Europe, extraordinary demand for consumer goods and food commodities will be created, which could lead to strong inflationary pressures. ``In addition, if political turmoil spreads to the more volatile areas of the world near-term, shortages of key raw materials could develop. ``Thus, it is quite possible that the euphoria surrounding the outlook for the 1990s, while probably justified from a longer-term standpoint, could be premature in terms of 1990 or even 1991.'' Even in the midst of a broad market setback, some fast-moving speculators have reaped handsome payoffs from the search for ``plays'' on eastern Europe. Last Thursday, for example, while the Dow Jones industrial average was tumbling to a six-month low, the New Germany Fund made a dazzling debut in the market, soaring to $22 in its first day of trading, from an offering price of $15. Some other closed-end ``country funds'' have continued to climb in price even as their ranks grow more and more crowded. Most analysts agree that patient investors may find rewarding opportunities in the future if they keep close tabs on the situation. Concluded Greg Smith, investment strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities, ``I believe a realization is now settling in that although there will be a major economic opportunity in eastern Europe, it will be further out than people were assuming.''

DOC.HEAD: Nissan to Make Engines for Minivan
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corp. USA will produce V-6 engines for the new Nissan-Ford mini-van in late 1992, officials said Friday. Nissan's plant, 30 miles southeast of Nashville, will produce 150,000 engines annually and will require an additional investment of $25 million, said Nissan President Jerry L. Benefield. The operation, which will create 250 jobs, will require a 40,000-square-foot expansion and new assembly lines. This comes in addition to a $490 million expansion currently under way to add a production line for a third vehicle in 1992. Nissan is now adding 1.2 million square feet to its existing 3.4 million-square-foot plant. With the engine production, the plant will employ more than 5,400. It already makes Sentra cars and Nissan small pickup trucks. Nissan and Ford Motor Co. announced in 1988 a $900 million joint venture to produce the Nissan-Ford upscale multipurpose vehicle. It will be produced at Ford's Avon Lake truck plant west of Cleveland, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Business Outlook Steadies for First Quarter, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: The outlook for sales and profits, which slumped during the second half of 1989, leveled off for the first quarter of this year, according to a survey of business executives released Friday. The survey, conducted by Dun & Bradstreet Corp., indicated ``business optimism has reached a turning point and businesses are regathering strength for the second half of 1990, said Joseph Duncan, a Dun & Bradstreet economist. ``Prices have moderated, inventories are in line and new orders are respectable,'' Duncan said. In the survey, conducted in November, Dun & Bradstreet asked 1,500 manufacturing, retailing and wholesaling executives what changes, if any, they expected in sales, profits, prices, inventories, employment and new orders during the first quarter. The survey found expectations for sales and profits edged lower for the first quarter after steeper declines in the previous two quarters. The outlook for selling prices also dipped after a sharper drop the previous quarter, while inventories were expected to shrink and employment expectations also fell. The outlook for new orders was unchanged. Duncan said the results were consistent with the ``soft landing'' outlook for the economy that many analysts have predicted.

DOC.HEAD: President's Son Refuses to Negotiate With Thrift Regulators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with federal thrift officials saying they are seeking cease and desist order against president's son, editing to conform. Picks up 10th graf, `Hoyle said....; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: Federal thrift officials said today they are seeking a cease and desist order against Neil Bush, one day after the president's son rejected a settlement over his role as a director of a collapsed savings and loan. Neil Bush's actions as a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver amounted to conflicts of interest, said the Enforcement Review Committee of the Office of Thrift Supervision in Washington, D.C. The case will be heard by an administrative law judge. If the order is granted, the younger Bush would be barred from practices that could constitute a conflict of interest if he ever serves again with a federally insured financial institution. Bush said Thursday the Office of Thrift and Supervision had proposed the cease and desist order, but he had rejected it because it would imply that he had acted improperly. ``In my view, a settlement agreement would leave an implication that I misbehaved as a director of Silverado,'' Bush said in a statement. ``As I have said in the past, I have nothing to hide and I have done nothing wrong,'' he said. ``Therefore, I have refused to consent to any agreement with the Office of Thrift Supervision and if they choose to bring action against me, I will fight the matter in court.'' Bush, 34, served as a director of Silverado from 1985 to August 1988, resigning two weeks after his father got the GOP presidential nomination. The collapse of Silverado, now operating as part of Columbia Savings, the largest thrift in Colorado, is expected to cost taxpayers up to $1 billion. Karl Hoyle, senior deputy director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said in Washington late Thursday that Bush's lawyers had told the agency Bush intends to contest the allegations of conflict of interest made by thrift regulators. Hoyle said the agency wouldn't seek a more severe penalty, which would ban Bush from ever working for a federally insured financial institution, because the office didn't believe it had grounds to seek it. That penalty has been imposed on five former Silverado officers. In a related matter, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is considering whether to sue Silverado officers and directors, including Bush, for damages for losses to the taxpayers in the bailout. The Office of Thrift Supervision said examiners had expressed ``grave concern'' about Silverado's operations, particularly its heavy investment in Colorado's ailing commercial real estate market. They also have focused their investigation on what they said was ``an exceptionally large number of problem transactions'' between Silverado insiders and borrowers. Bush, who was a partner in an oil exploration firm, JNB Exploration, had business deals with two of Silverado's major borrowers, developers Bill L. Walters and Ken Good. ``Bill Walters had a passive 6.25 percent limited partnership interest in JNB Exploration,'' Bush said. ``Because I did not benefit directly or indirectly from any loan or transaction between Silverado and businesses controlled by Bill Walters, as an outside director I voted in 1986 with the other directors in unanimously approving the Walters loans and transactions brought to us by management. ``I voted because there was no conflict of interest under the federal banking laws and regulations or under the laws of Colorado,'' Bush said. Good, according to Bush, had a more active interest in the financing and management of JNB Exploration, and ``as a result, I abstained on all votes concerning Good. The other board members unanimously approved the transactions with Good,'' Bush said. He said both Walters' and Good's relationships with Silverado, as borrowers and preferred shareholders, were established before he became a director. ``Their relationships with my company, which began in 1983, also preceded my Silverado board appointment,'' Bush said. A former federal S&L examiner, James Moroney, has alleged that regulators dragged their feet on Silverado because of Bush's presence on the institution's board and other political connections. But regulators in Washington have said they investigated Moroney's allegations and found them invalid. Bush has said he never sought to use his political connections and wouldn't have if asked.
