DOC.HEAD: Worries About Japanese Appetite for Treasury Issues Weighs On Bond Prices
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese have gotten slammed by some Americans for their highly visible investments in U.S. business properties ranging from Columbia Pictures to Rockefeller Center. But this past week's slump in bond prices suggests that the U.S. government and those holding its debt should put out the welcome mat for Japanese investors in Treasury securities. Over the past few years, the Japanese have been steady and substantial customers at the quarterly securities sales where the government has borrowed heavily to finance its expanding debt. Market watchers estimate the Japanese typically buy 25 percent to 35 percent of new Treasury issues maturing in 10 to 30 years. As a result, some analysts argue, the government has been able to peddle its securities at lower rates of interest than it would have to pay otherwise. But worries about whether Japanese investors will be big buyers of the Treasury's expected $30 billion auction of new securities next month have weighed heavily on bond prices. Those concerns have stemmed from a recent rise in Japanese interest rates that has narrowed the difference in yields available on Japanese securities relative to U.S. notes and bonds. William Griggs, a partner with the investment firm Griggs & Santow Inc., said 10-year Japanese notes, for example, were yielding about 1.35 percentage points below the yields on 10-year Treasury notes earlier this month, compared with a 2 percentage point difference at the start of the year. While the difference in yields has since widened toward 2 percentage points once again in more recent days, William V. Sullivan Jr. of Dean Witter Reynolds said the more typical yield spread has been 2.5 to 3 percentage points. The fear among U.S. bondholders is that some Japanese investors will find the current yields in Japan rewarding enough that they will decide against taking the extra risks involved in converting yen to dollars and buying Treasury issues. That could drive U.S. rates higher, depressing the value of bonds already trading in the market. The realities of what can happen when foreign investors sit out a bond auction were illustrated this past Tuesday when the Resolution Funding Corp. had to pay higher rates than many market professionals had anticipated to find buyers for its $5 billion issue of 40-year thrift bailout bonds. The Japanese had not been expected to bid on the bonds, which carry maturities of 10 years later than the Treasury's longest security and are expected to be far less readily salable than Treasury issues. ``We didn't expect the Japanese to be there, and they weren't,'' said Robert Brusca, economist for Nikko Securities International in New York. He said no conclusions should be drawn from the absence of the Japanese from the 40-year auction relative to what may happen at the Treasury auctions expected to be conducted in early February. But some traders said the auction illustrated nonetheless that interest rates must often go higher than expected when the pool of bidders is smaller. Prices of long bonds tumbled in the wake of the 40-year auction, and got another jolt on Thursday that reflected traders' sensitivity to the importance of foreign investment in the U.S. bond market. Bond prices careened lower after some press reports suggested Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan had indicated he might consider the idea of reinstating a withholding tax on investment income earned here by foreigners. The Federal Reserve later said Greenspan did not favor such action. But the market failed to revive anyway, and prices lost more ground Friday in the wake of a stronger-than-expected report on durable goods orders in December. By midafternoon Friday, prices of 30-year Treasury bonds were down more than $25 for every $1,000 in face value for the week. Their yield had risen to 8.54 percent from 8.26 percent at trhe end of the previous Friday. Griggs suspected yields were getting high enough that Japanese interest in the upcoming auctions will be strong. But Sullivan said it is still too early to tell. ``We have a a long way to go until we bid these secutiries,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Slows to a Crawl, Bringing New Talk of a Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy slowed almost to a standstill in the last three months of 1989, registering a barely perceptible 0.5 percent annual growth rate that was the poorest since the spring of 1986, the government said Friday. The weak growth in the gross national product, the country's total output of goods and services, raised fears among private economists that the record seven-year-long peacetime expansion was in danger of ending, especially if jittery financial markets drive interest rates higher. The Bush administration was more upbeat, however, predicting that the sluggishness will be followed by an economic rebound, although Vice President Dan Quayle called the GNP report disappointing, adding, ``These numbers this morning were not what we had hoped for.'' The Commerce Department blamed the big drop-off in growth from October through December on a rare decline in consumer spending, a deteriorating trade deficit and a slump in business investment spending. For the year as a whole, the GNP grew by 2.9 percent, following a much more rapid 4.4 percent increase in 1988. It was the slowest annual growth rate since a 2.7 percent rise in 1986. Even with the slower growth, inflation was slightly worse during the year with a price index tied to the GNP rising by 4.5 percent, up from 4.2 percent in 1988 and the worst showing since 1982, when it was 6.2 percent. While the fourth quarter GNP advance was in line with expectations, many economists questioned where the economy will get strength for a rebound. ``The economy ground to a virtual halt in the fourth quarter with signs of weakness everywhere,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co. ``My own view is that we are near and possibly headed into some sort of a recession.'' Other economists were not as pessimistic, believing that the Federal Reserve would provide another dose of lower interest rates if necessary to spur growth. ``We are on the bottom edge of the famous soft landing, although it is somewhat softer than one might have wanted for comfort,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Co. ``Nevertheless, the odds are against a full-fledged recession.'' Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, told reporters at the White House that the credit easing engineered by the Federal Reserve since last June was one of the reasons he was optimistic that growth will rebound and the fourth quarter weakness will turn out to have only a ``modest'' impact on the budget deficit. The administration is basing its $1.23 trillion budget for 1991, due to be unveiled Monday, on a forecast that the GNP will grow 2.6 percent this year, when measured from the fourth quarter of 1989 to the fourth quarter of 1990. But private analysts, even the majority, who are not forecasting a recession, are decidedly less optimistic, projecting a lackluster GNP increase this year of around 1.8 percent, which would be the slowest growth rate since the recession year of 1982. Economists were split on how quickly the economy will regain strength. Michael Darby, Commerce undersecretary for economic affairs, predicted that GNP growth would rise above 1 percent in the current quarter. He said that a variety of one-time events, including the Boeing strike, the San Francisco earthquake and Hurricane Hugo, had all dampened growth during the last three months of 1989. But private analysts said recent uneasiness in the stock and bond markets could take a toll on economic growth by pushing interest rates up to continue to attract foreign investors. Such a development would harm housing and other interest-sensitive sectors of the economy. In addition, analysts noted that what little strength there was in the fourth quarter GNP report came from a substantial $10.7 billion rise in unsold business inventories, a potential drag on future production. Dederick said he expected that GNP growth would remain stuck at a weak 0.5 percent rate in the current quarter as well but that the two very weak quarters would be followed by better prospects for the rest of the year. He noted that a separate report Friday on orders to factories for big-ticket durable goods climbed 2.5 percent in December, following a 4.9 percent November gain. The 0.5 percent GNP increase was the weakest quarterly showing since a decline of 1.8 percent in the second quarter of 1986, another period of sluggish activity and one that raised fears at the same time the recovery from the 1981-82 recession was in danger of stalling out. The biggest drag on activity last quarter was a huge swing in consumer spending, which went from a robust growth rate of 5.6 percent in the third quarter to a rare decline of 0.1 percent in the fourth. The swing was attributed to car sales, which surged in the third quarter as consumers responded to sales incentives only to slump when the incentives ended. The trade deficit worsened for the second quarter in a row, rising by $4.7 billion as export sales failed to keep up with a surge in imports. Business investment spending fell by 3 percent. The various changes put the GNP at an annual rate of $4.168 trillion in the fourth quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Say UAL Employee Buyout Plan Promising
DOC.TEXT: A new employee buyout proposal for UAL Corp. holds more promise than a previous employee offer that collapsed in October and helped cause a sudden selloff on the stock market, securities analysts said Friday. ``If the price is in the $190 (a share) to $200 range, it should be a doable deal,'' said Louis Marckesano, an industry analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ``If they have a unified proposal among the employees, I wouldn't really think it would be that difficult,'' he said. Machinists, who represent 25,000 employees in the parent of United Airlines, opposed the original employee bid on grounds it would saddle the company with too much debt. But this week they said they would join with pilots, flight attendants and other workers in the new buyout effort. Labor unity and a realistic offer _ much lower than the $300-a-share, $6.75 billion bid last fall _ would go a long way in reassuring the banks needed to finance the deal, another analyst said. The collapse of the previous buyout offer on Oct. 13 scared many investors thought it signaled the end of the corporate takeover activity buoying the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 190 points that day. ``If you go back and look at what the concerns were before, the major concern most of the banks floated was the fact that the machinists union was not part of the buyout proposal,'' said the airline analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Moreover, he said, ``At $300, the price was much too high. If they can make a bid at $200 or less, that will go a long way at satisfying that concern.'' Employees still have not agreed on a price for an offer and have not yet offered a concrete plan for its financing. UAL has been mired in efforts to define its future since last August, when Los Angeles billionaire Marvin Davis made an unsolicited offer of $200 a share or $4.32 billion for one of the nation's largest airlines. This week, UAL encouraged employees to work up a formal buyout proposal but still kept other options open, releasing Davis from prior agreements prohibiting him from making an offer for less than $300 a share. Some analysts doubted, however, that other bidders would resurface. Marckesano said one key issue yet to be resolved is the role current chairman Stephen Wolf would play in an employee-controlled UAL. ``The big question is Mr. Wolf,'' he said. ``I'm a Wolf fan _ I think whatever course UAL takes in the future they'd be better off with him steering the ship.'' But the analyst who asked not to be named said machinists had long resented Wolf. The analyst speculated they joined the buyout bid only after receiving reassurances Wolf would not be part of the deal. A UAL spokesman refused to comment on Wolf, and a spokesman for the machinists' union did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment. The takeover wrangling that's afflicted UAL has come against a background of uncertainty in the airline industry caused by higher fuel prices and signs of a broader economic downturn. On Thursday, UAL reported earnings of $6.8 million, or 31 cents a share for the three months ended Dec. 31, drastically lower than the $20.9 million, or 97 cents a share, for the same period of 1988. Quarterly revenues totaled $2.4 billion, up from $2.2 billion in 1988. UAL said fourth-quarter expenses of $60 million related to the failed buyout bid were partly offset by a $40.7 million gain from stock appreciation rights that were also linked to the buyout attempt. Those items combined depressed fourth quarter earnings by $11.6 million. A 34 percent increase in jet fuel expenses also depressed earnings, UAL said.

DOC.HEAD: Recent Round of Layoffs Points Out Weakness In Economy
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: News Friday that economic growth slowed to a crawl in the last quarter capped two weeks in which major U.S. companies announced more than 15,000 layoffs. The upshot, according to many economists, is that employment is sluggish, particularly in manufacturing, and more layoffs may be in the offing. The gross national product figures released Friday ``suggest the economy needs to cut production somewhat,'' said Susan Lakatos, an economist for Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``In general, the economy is slowing.'' The government report showed the economy grew by just 0.5 percent in the final three months of 1989, the poorest performance since the spring of 1986. ``I think you'll end up with a broad pattern of increasing layoffs,'' added Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. In the past two weeks: _General Electric Co. said it would eliminate about 5,700 aerospace jobs as it prepares for reduced Pentagon spending. _Boeing Co. said it would pare up to 5,000 jobs, also due in part to anticipated defense cutbacks. _Grumman Corp., another defense contractor, said it would lay off 300 workers and eliminate 700 more jobs by year's end for the same reason. _Caterpillar Inc., the heavy-equipment maker, said it would lay off 1,200 workers. _Merrill Lynch & Co. said it would lay off more than 3,000 workers as the investment house continues to reel from Wall Street's two-year slump. Going back to the beginning of the year, more than 45,000 autoworkers have been notified of indefinite or temporary layoffs at plants around the country. ``What we're seeing right now is looking dramatic because it's big companies and big numbers,'' Ms. Lakatos said. What's harder to see _ but even more important _ is that companies of all sizes are not hiring as many new workers due to a slowdown in expansion, she said. The economy's manufacturing sector showed steady growth in employment until last summer, when it stopped in its tracks, Ms. Lakatos said. About 20 percent of all U.S. workers are employed in manufacturing. On Friday, the government also reported that orders to factories for durable goods increased 2.5 percent in December, but that almost all the gain came in orders for aircraft, ships and tanks. Excluding these categories, factory orders would have been flat. Hoey said the companies making cutbacks in their defense businesses are taking prudent action because they realize the defense buildup of the 1980s is ending. He believes layoffs will spread from the defense and auto industries to other areas of the economy this year. ``What you're seeing is the early signs of what ultimately will prove to be a recession,'' he said, giving a minority opinion among Wall Street economists. John Hagens, an economist at the forecasting firm WEFA Group, is not as pessimistic. ``Our view is there will be more layoffs coming and the unemployment rate will rise, but not like in a recession,'' he said. But, he added, job growth overall this year ``will be substantially less than we've had in the last seven, eight years.'' During the 1982 recession, for example, unemployment jumped to about 11 percent from 5.7 percent in 1979. In contrast, Hagens' firm forecasts the jobless rate will rise by one-half to one percentage point this year. ``You really can become overly pessimistic about job prospects and employment growth by focusing on big-company layoffs,'' he said. Job growth continues in many service industries, such as health and education, he said. However, he added, ``When we have very sluggish growth in the economy and profits extremely weak in 1989, and unlikely to rebound in 1990, there will be a shedding of (other) jobs.''

DOC.HEAD: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Rates Up
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages surged back over the 10 percent threshhold this week and are currently averaging 10.05 percent, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. That rate was up from a rate of 9.90 percent last week. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.41 percent this week, up from 8.39 percent the week before.

Stock prices showed some spotty declines in an erratic session today, adding a bit more to their early-1990 losses. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 1.36 at 2,559.68.

The stock market remained on the defensive today as traders studied the latest data on the state of the economy. The Commerce Department reported that the gross national product grew at a 0.5 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the fourth quarter of last year. The figure was a bit stronger than some analysts had projected. But observers noted that it was magnified to a great extent by increases in inventories, which is usually interpreted as evidence of weakness in business activity. A separate report showed a 2.5 percent rise in new factory orders for durable goods in December. In the bond market, where traders are especially sensitive to even slight changes in the perceived pace of the economy, interest rates rose after the figures crossed financial news wires.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Drug Chain to Divest More Than 700 Stores
DOC.TEXT: Revco D.S., Inc., the first big company to seek bankruptcy-court refuge from debts incurred in a leveraged buyout, announced plans Friday to sell 712 of its 1,873 stores in a costly restructuring. The company, one of the country's largest drugstore chains with a work force of 26,800 people, said it would refocus on operations in Eastern states where sales are strongest. ``The strategic advantages of restructuring operations have become increasingly clear over time,'' said Gregory K. Raven, chief financial officer for the company based in Twinsburg, Ohio, a Cleveland suburb. ``Internal and external analyses agree _ this is what's best for Revco.'' Its announcement to shrink by more than a third came against a background of growing alarm about the consequences of the 1980s debt-financed takeover tactic known as the leveraged buyout or LBO. Earlier this month, Toronto-based Campeau Corp., owner of many famous U.S. department stores, sought Chapter 11 protection because it couldn't make payments on the multibillion-dollar debts incurred to buy the stores over the last three years. Revco's drugstores will now join many of Campeau's department stores on the auction block. Revco filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors back in July 1988, about a month after it failed to make an interest payment on about $700 million in outstanding high-risk junk bonds used to finance its $1.5 billion management-led LBO in 1986. It was the first major LBO to seek the sanctuary of bankruptcy court to untangle its finances. To cover the cost of the restructuring announced Friday, Revco said it would take a record $230 million charge against earnings in its third fiscal quarter, which will end Feb. 10. The company intends to open discussions with potential buyers for 712 of its drugstores. Any sales are subject to bankruptcy court approval. Boake A. Sells, chairman and chief executive officer of Revco, said he believed the majority of company's employees will keep their jobs. The company hopes that those working in stores now targeted for sale would be hired by eventual buyers, he said. Harrison Jones, manager of the Revco store in downtown Magnolia, Ark., said he was concerned but not surprised at the news. Arkansas is one of the states where stores are targeted for divestiture. ``Actually, I feel good about it, like maybe someone in this general area will purchase this thing and it will be solid financially and they'll take it and run with it,'' Jones said. ``Generally (employees at the store) aren't surprised. They're a little disappointed because on the surface it generally means bad news,'' he said. In October, it was reported that Revco was considering a $925 million buyout bid from a Texas-based group of investors that included billionaire Robert Bass, well known for his takeover forays. It was unclear Friday whether these investors played any role in Revco's divestment plans. Revco spokeswoman Kathleen Obert declined to identify any possible store buyers. Sells said it was too early to estimate how long it would take to complete the restructuring. Sales from the stores to be divested represent about 36 percent of the chain's total sales, the company said. Revco plans to concentrate and build on markets in Georgia, Maryland, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, eastern Tennessee, Virginia, and West Virginia. Locations targeted for divestiture include 712 Revco drugstores currently operating: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, Colorado, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, New Mexico, Oklahoma, western Tennessee, and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Mixed; Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed Friday, weakening against the British pound and Japanese yen but rising against other currencies in heavy trading. Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of gold gained $4.10 a troy ounce to close at $420.10. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $420 a troy ounce, up $3 from Thursday. Most of the day's activity centered on the yen, which investors continued to buy aggressively. Analysts noted that optimism about the future of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party ahead of next month's elections spurred interest in the currency. But the dollar suffered as investors sold the U.S. currency to buy yen. ``There are fears that foreigners are withdrawing from U.S. markets,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago. He said traders are edgy ahead of the upcoming quarterly refunding. The Treasury Department is expected to announce next week its schedule for the sale of an estimated $30 billion in bonds, the proceeds of which are used to keep the government running. Foreigners, who have been attracted by relatively high interest rates here, need dollars to buy U.S. debt securities. But Chandler noted that rising interest rates abroad _ especially in Japan _ have incited fears that foreigners will shun the bonds. The dollar got somewhat of a boost from a government report that showed the gross national product posted a 0.5 percent annual growth rate in the final quarter of 1989. Although the figure, which represents the country's total output of goods and services, was the poorest showing since the spring of 1986, it was better than the market had expected and therefore bolstered the dollar initially. ``The market had already priced in the number,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Shortly after the figure was released, trading turned again to the yen. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.97 yen, down from 145.30 yen on Thursday. Later in London, the dollar traded at 143.30 yen. In New York, the dollar closed lower still, at 142.80 yen, compared with Thursday's 143.93 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6571 from $1.6570 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.6635 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.6600. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.6865 West German marks, up from 1.6850; 1.4900 Swiss francs, up from 1.4850; 5.7290 French francs, up from 5.7255; 1,254.50 Italian lire, up from 1,253.75, and 1.1966 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1876. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6935 West German marks, up from 1.6870; 1.4975 Swiss francs, up from 1.4870; 5.7510 French francs, up from 5.7305; 1.9060 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8975; 1,260.00 Italian lire, up from 1,254.75; and 1.1937 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1903. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $418.75 a troy ounce from $416.25 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $418.50 from $413.50 bid late Thursday. Hong Kong precious metals markets were closed for the lunar New Year holiday. Trading is to resume Tuesday. Silver prices moved higher. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $5.222 a troy ounce, up from $5.212 on Thursday. In London, the metal rose to a late bid price of $5.25 a troy ounce from Thursday's $5.22.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Earnings Drop 69 percent
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc., a leading producer of computer chips, reported a 69 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings Friday, blaming the performance on a tighter U.S. defense budget and lower demand for its products. Texas Instruments said earnings less dividends on preferred stock for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was $35.9 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with $86.3 million, or $1.04 per share, in the comparable year-earlier period. Revenues fell slightly from $1.73 billion to $1.72 billion. For the year, earnings totaled $291.7 million, or $3.04 per share, compared with 1988's $335.8 million, or $4.05 per share. Revenue last year was $6.52 billion, up from $6.45 billion in 1988. ``The growth rate of the world semiconductor market slowed significantly during the second half of the year,'' especially in the second half, Chairman Jerry R. Junkins said, blaming the weakness for most of TI's earnings decline. ``In addition, the U.S. defense market is undergoing a period of tighter constraints on spending,'' he said. Junkins said TI expects the weakness in semiconductor sales to continue for several months and historically low first-quarter defense spending will continue to drive down profits, although he predicted the company will benefit during the second half from capital investments and a recovering memory market.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures End Mostly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil and gasoline futures closed higher while heating oil had a mixed day on the New York Mercantile Exchange Friday. The March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, closed at $22.56 a barrel, up 32 cents. Contracts for later delivery ended with gains of between 25 cents and 29 cents. Among refined products traded on the New York Merc, February wholesale unleaded regular gasoline ended 1.52 cents higher at 62.12 cents a gallon. Later contracts advanced but posted lower gains. Meanwhile, wholesale heating oil for February delivery slipped 0.17 cent to 59.60 cents a gallon, while other contracts ended higher. Analysts said crude oil and gasoline rallied after a slow start as some big refiners made commitments ahead of the weekend. Meanwhile, heating oil lagged as demand slackened. ``Heating oil was just laying there as warm weather continued,'' said Mary L. Haskins, an assistant vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Trading in gasoline was particularly buoyant as investors bought contracts in anticipation of an increase in demand this spring. In addition, recent statistics showed that gasoline inventories are lower than last year's, energy traders said.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street West? Hawaii Looks to Diversify
DOC.TEXT: Hawaii is making a major push toward becoming a world financial center, attempting to remold itself as something more than an exotic Pacific vacation spot. Efforts are underway by the state's political and business community to lure large brokerage houses and create one or more exchanges that would trade stocks, commodities, currencies, options and other products. At stake for Hawaii is the chance to position itself as a leader of the Pacific Rim and an opportunity to diversify its tourist-driven economy. ``We have to convince the business community both here and elsewhere that Hawaii is more than a place to vacation,'' said Bill Cook of the state Department of Economic Development. Since the effort to create a Honolulu stock exchange began in 1987, talks have taken place with several exchanges, including the New York Mercantile Exchange, Pacific Stock Exchange and exchanges in Chicago and Asia. No deals have been reached, and negotiations are continuing. The talks are centered on how much assistance and incentives the state will provide the exchanges, largely in the form of tax breaks. Important to Hawaii's exchange bid is that it would fill in the four-hour time gap between the closing of the New York Stock Exchange and the opening of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, allowing for trading on almost a 24-hour-a-day basis. ``What we make it easier for American exchanges to do is trade with Asia on Asian time,'' said Galen Fox, executive assistant for Honolulu Mayor Frank Fasi. ``If you want to expand business with Asia, which is in some ways the financial center of the world already, then you should be catering to their markets and interests, rather than asking them to get up early in the morning or at midnight to trade with your markets. ``It's a breakthrough in thinking in terms of how important it is to reach Asia,'' Fox said. ``The breakthrough occurs in part because you can do it in Honolulu.'' Another asset is Hawaii's population base, which includes a sizable mainland and Asian population. It's this diverse cultural foundation that may convince brokerage firms on both sides of the Pacific to set up shop here. ``You have a number of people here that are very knowledgeable about both (U.S. and Japanese) markets,'' said David Bess, dean of the University of Hawaii school of business administration. ``I think a knowledge base exists here that few other cities would have.'' A Honolulu exchange would allow Asian brokers to trade in products not offered in their markets, and would add to the volume of their new-born options trading, which started in 1989. Also, all trades would be regulated by U.S. securities laws, a sales point being used to placate wary mainland firms. Fred Sexton, president of the Economic Development Corp. of Honolulu and the man leading the exchange effort, said his biggest challenge is alleviating the skittishness of American brokerage houses. ``The number one obstacle is fear among American companies,'' he said. ``It's not been done here and they don't know whether they can generate enough volume to make it successful. The only way they're going to find out is to do it.'' Diversification of Hawaii's economy is a major goal of the 1990s, as state and business leaders realize the need to generate more professional jobs to keep the state's young people from leaving. Tourism accounted for 39 percent of the state's $20 billion in revenues in 1988, the most recent figures available from the state. Officials feel a Honolulu financial center would create hundreds of high-paying professional jobs, as well as bring a number of high-technology firms and related financial service companies to Hawaii. ``The whole range of industries that will come in connection with the emergence of a Honolulu financial center will be helpful,'' Fox said. ``Related industries like backroom financing and information-related industries ... these are kind of secondary benefits from having a financial center grow here.'' Because of the high costs of setting up an equities trading floor, it's likely other products like currencies and options would set up trading floors first, with stock trading beginning after the foundation is laid. ``What I see as a possibility is the trading of currencies, futures and options,'' said Randy Havre, a broker with J.D. Havre and Associates. ``It's less costly and more practical than trading equities, so if and when trading equities would be feasible, it would have a base to build on.'' Gov. John Waihee said while Hawaii stands to benefit from a financial center, it won't come about unless the brokerage houses have something to gain. ``There's no use coming out to Hawaii and essentially processing the same number of trades as you would in New York,'' the governor said. ``From Hawaii, you can get into an entirely new market and an exchange can stand on its own. ``The bottom line is going to be whether or not coming to Hawaii results in the creation of new markets,'' Waihee said. ``If it does, than the advantage of coming here increases. You can almost do this anywhere, why not do it in paradise?''

DOC.HEAD: Resilient Gasoline Futures Surge, Leading Energy Market Up
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline futures prices rose sharply Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, showing surprising resilience to bearish fundamentals and leading the entire group of energy commodities to a higher close. On other commodity markets, pork belly futures fella while livestock futures were mixed; precious metals advanced; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower. The contract for February delivery of wholesale unleaded gasoline surged 1.52 cents to 62.12 cents a gallon. Other contracts settled .55 cent to .97 cents higher. West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished 25 cents to 32 cents higher with March at $22.56 a barrel; heating oil was .17 cent lower to .28 cent higher with February at 59.60 cents a gallon. Much of gasoline's strength apparently stemmed from fears of tight supplies for delivery against the February gasoline contract, which expires Wednesday. Concerns about such a supply squeeze surface frequently in the energy market but usually prove unfounded. The rally defied a bevy of negative signals, including Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute report of a large increase in U.S. gasoline supplies, and the resolution Wednesday of an eight-day strike by Brazilian oilworkers. In addition, a savage storm that ripped through Britain on Thursday had little effect on the North Sea petroleum industry. Fears of storm-related disruptions to pumping and refining operations had contributed to a runup in crude oil values on Thursday. ``The market is remarkably strong despite having a couple of things thrown at it over past couple days,'' said analyst Peter Beutel of Elders Futures Inc. in New York. Pork-belly futures fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, ending a week of roller-coaster moves in the thinly traded market. The contracts for February, March and May deliveries fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound after rising more than 1 cent on Thursday and falling nearly the limit on both Monday and Wednesday. The losses early in the week reflected expectations that Wednesday's monthly Agriculture Department cold-storage report would show an increase in supplies of frozen pork bellies. But the report indicated supplies were much smaller than expected, prompting Thursday's strong advance. Friday's tumble reflected weaker cash markets for both bellies and hogs, said Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. Frozen pork bellies were .98 cent to 2 cents lower with February at 54.10 cents a pound; live cattle settled .23 cent lower to .12 cent higher with February at 79.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .13 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 83.42 cents a pound; live hogs were .48 cent lower to .13 cent higher with February at 49.25 cents a pound. Gold futures climbed strongly on New York's Commodity Exchange amid stock-market jitters. The Dow Jones industrials average ended nearly unchanged after seesawing widely during the session. Gold futures ended $4.10 to $4.30 higher with February at $420.30 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent to 1.3 cents higher with March at $5.26 a troy ounce. Most grain and soybean futures fell on the Chicago Board of Trade on concerns about slack export sales of U.S. grain. Wheat futures also were pressured by improved growing conditions in the U.S. winter wheat belt, where recent rains and snowfall have helped to relieve extreme dryness. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 4\ cents lower with March at $3.81\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to { cent higher with March at $2.38\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $1.37\ a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents lower to \ cent higher with March at $5.58{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices slipped Friday as the market reacted to government figures that showed the economy was not slowing as much as some had assumed. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond, which has lost about 1{ points over the past three sessions, dropped 19-32 point, or about $5.94 for every $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, edged up to 8.51 percent from 8.46 percent late Thursday. The government released a pair of economic reports Friday saying the economy grew at a 0.5 percent pace in the final three months of 1989 and that orders to factories for durable goods rose 2.5 percent in December. Analysts said the gross national product figures matched expectations, but many of them had been looking for a decline in durable goods orders. Luke Haney, a bond trader with the Philadelphia brokerage Butcher & Singer Inc., said the economic news ``kind of puts your investors on the sidelines wondering exactly what is going on.'' ``We've just been in a tremendous downflow and there don't seem to be any buyers out there,'' he added. William Griggs, a partner in the investment firm Griggs & Santow Inc., said the reports disappointed traders who were looking for signs of economic deterioration clear enough that the Federal Reserve would be compelled to encourage lower interest rates, a move that would boost bond prices. ``There was nothing in these numbers that will suggest the Fed will ease policy right away,'' Griggs said. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were down by 1-16 point to 3-16 point, intermediate maturities were off [ point to 5-16 point, and long-term issues lost as much as 11-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was down 3.31 at 1,159.63. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 11-32 point to 91 11-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.44 from 7.41 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.91 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 7.67 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.02 percent as the discount rose 1 basis point to 7.62 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell marginally to 8.03 percent as the discount remained unchanged at 7.49 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 13-16 percent, up from 8 3-16 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Airlines Fires Ayer As Ad Agency
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines said Friday it had dismissed N.W. Ayer as its advertising agency, ending an association that began in 1986. The Houston-based carrier, a unit of Texas Air Corp., notified the agency late Thursday that it was placing its advertising assignment up for review, the agency said. ``Ayer is no longer Continental's agency as of today,'' Continental spokesman Art Kent confirmed by telephone from Houston. ``We just felt it was time for a change.'' He said he could not elaborate and did not know what steps were being taken to get another agency. Ayer had been using the theme ``Working to be your choice'' in Continental's advertising. Recent ads touting service to warm-weather destinations used the line, ``We've got your place in the sun.'' Continental planned to spend an estimated $35 million to $40 million on its advertising this year, executives familiar with the account said. Kent said he did not know the actual figure. Ayer, a privately-held agency based in New York, handles $1.3 billion in advertising billings worldwide and counts among its clients American Telephone & Telegraph Co., Procter & Gamble Co. and General Motors Corp. The decision came as a surprise to Ayer executives, said Vice Chairman Thomas F. Maxey. ``We had no indication this was coming,'' he said. Ayer opened an office in Houston after it was awarded the account in 1986, and the office currently employs about 30 people. Ten to 15 more employees work on the Continental account in New York. Maxey said it was likely that the Houston office would be closed after an orderly transition. Ayer expects to continue servicing the account for up to 90 days. In addition to the Continental account, the Houston office handles only a few small public service assignments at no charge. John Walsh, an executive vice president who oversees the Continental account, said he understood that Continental's business was improving although the industry has been troubled by declining traffic and rising fuel costs. ``They said they felt they needed a change. In our estimation of the situation, the situation was good and our work was good,'' he said. Kent confirmed Continental's business was improving. He said the airline earned $59.1 million for the first nine months of 1989, in contrast to a loss of $215.9 million a year earlier. Texas Air also owns Eastern Airlines, which has been operating since March under protection of federal bankruptcy laws and has been losing millions of dollars. Airline accounts are particularly labor-intensive, industry executives say, because of frequent price changes within the industry and the need to develop different print ads for each market. But Maxey said Ayer would be interested in going after another airline account anyway. He said the agency handles advertising assignments for Iberia Airlines, Air France and Scandanavian Airline System. He said the agency is one of the finalists for four different advertising assignments, which he declined to identify. In 1989, Ayer was fired by Burger King Corp. after working as its ad agency for 18 months and producing the campaign, ``We do it like you'd do it.'' The fast-food chain was spending $150 million a year on its advertising then. Among Ayer's recent notable ads have been its commercials for AT&T long-distance service that featured people near the Berlin Wall and a commercial for Phillip's Milk of Magnesia that used a roll of toilet paper to illustrate the powers of the laxative.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Largest Defense Contractor Reports More Bad News
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. on Friday reported a 58 percent decline in fourth-quarter profits as major write-offs in several divisions plagued the nation's largest defense contractor. For the three-month period ending Dec. 31, the company had profits of $60 million, or $1.56 a share, compared with $145 million, or $3.79 a share, for the same period a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter totaled $4.29 billion, up slightly from $4.14 billion for 1988's final quarter. ``This is obviously a major disappointment,'' said Phil Friedman, a stock analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York. ``You never expect write-offs like these.'' McDonnell Douglas stock closed at $57.62{ Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, down 62{ cents. The company, based in St. Louis, took $127 million in after-tax write-offs in the quarter _ $91 million for its AH-64 Apache helicopter, $22 million for its T-45 aircraft training system, and $14 million in its missiles, space and electronic systems segment. Companies take write-offs when they have to reduce the value of an asset. McDonnell Douglas attributed its reductions to higher cost estimates that lowered earnings rates. The company already had reductions of $162 million in the first three quarters of the year that contributed to a 37 percent decline in annual profits. For the year, the company reported profits of $219 million, down from $350 million for the same period a year ago. Revenue increased to $14.6 billion from $14.4 billion in 1988. ``They're having a lot of trouble figuring out where their problem is and that doesn't give the investor a lot of confidence,'' said Paul Nisbet, an analyst with Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Along with the write-offs, the company's transport aircraft division, based in Long Beach, Calif., continued to struggle through cost overruns and increased interest expenses. The division, called Douglas Aircraft Co., has said all of its programs including the development of the Air Force's C-17 cargo plane and the new commercial, wide-body jet, MD-11, are behind schedule. In the fourth quarter, the division had a profit of $5 million in the quarter, compared to $76 million for the same period a year earlier. For the year, the division lost $222 million, compared to profits of $127 million in 1988. McDonnell Douglas is the nation's second largest maker of commerical aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Son Says Dad Told Him to `Do What's Right' in Thrift Probe
DOC.TEXT: Neil Bush said Friday that his father, the president, told him to ``do what's right'' when the younger Bush said he intends to fight conflict-of-interest charges leveled by federal thrift regulators. The decision may put the president in the awkward position of appointing the official likely to decide the case, but Neil Bush said after talking to his father earlier in the day that he did not believe the matter would pose a problem. ``He's giving me the same advice he has given me for 35 years: Do what's right. And I'm doing what's right,'' the president's son told a news conference in Denver. ``I will fight and ... although I know that taking on the feds is tough ... I intend to win.'' The Office of Thrift Supervision said Friday it will issue a ``notice of charges'' alleging that actions by the younger Bush as a director of a Colorado savings and loan ``amounted to conflicts of interest.'' The announcement came after the president's son refused to voluntarily accept an order from regulators directing him to refrain from actions amounting to a conflict of interest if, in the future, he becomes an officer of a savings and loan, a bank or a credit union. ``I believe in the principle that if you haven't done anything wrong, don't do anything that might be an admission of wrongdoing,'' Neil Bush said. He was a director of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver from 1985 until August 1988, resigning two weeks before his father accepted the GOP presidential nomination. According to Karl Hoyle, senior deputy director of the thrift office, the younger Bush's stance triggers an administrative process that typically lasts a year and could stretch to as long as two years if initial rulings are appealed. Hoyle said the thrift office will ask an administrative law judge to hold a hearing on the notice of charges and recommend to thrift office director M. Danny Wall that a cease-and-desist order be issued against the president's son. But Wall, a Reagan administration appointee who announced his resignation last month, almost certainly will have left the agency by then, passing on the case to a new thrift office director, who must be nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said, ``The president's decision on a nominee for the thrift office will be made completely independently of this or any other case.'' The December 1988 collapse of Silverado, now operating as part of Columbia Savings, the largest thrift in Colorado, is expected to cost taxpayers up to $1 billion. Hoyle said the agency expected to make public the specific charges against Neil Bush after they are filed. The agency has focused its investigation of Silverado on what it said was ``an exceptionally large number of problem transactions'' between Silverado insiders and borrowers. The younger Bush was a partner in an oil exploration firm, JNB Exploration, with two of Silverado's major borrowers, developers Bill L. Walters and Ken Good. In a statement Thursday, however, Bush said there was nothing improper with the connection. ``Bill Walters had a passive 6.25 percent limited partnership interest in JNB Exploration,'' the president's son said. ``Because I did not benefit directly or indirectly from any loan or transaction between Silverado and businesses controlled by Bill Walters, as an outside director I voted in 1986 with the other directors in unanimously approving the Walters loans and transactions brought to us by management.'' Good, according to Neil Bush, had a more active interest in the financing and management of JNB Exploration and ``as a result, I abstained on all votes concerning Good.'' Earlier this month, the thrift office announced that five officers of Silverado had accepted orders banning them for life from working for a federally insured financial institution without permission from regulators. Hoyle said the agency does not believe it has the grounds to seek that more severe penalty against the president's son. He noted that any thrift office action does not preclude a civil suit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. seeking damages from Silverado's officers and directors in compensation for taxpayer losses incurred in the bailout. Nor does it preclude any criminal charges if evidence indicates they are warranted. The administrative cease-and-desist order being pursued against Neil Bush would enable the thrift office to seek fines up to $1 million a day for future violations, according to Rosemary Stewart, thrift office enforcement director. ``Out of the whole arsenal, this is the mildest form of enforcement,'' said Warren L. Dennis, a Washington attorney specializing in S&L law. ``It's not even a stun gun or a rubber bullet.'' Dennis said both Neil Bush and the government are in a difficult position. ``The government is pursuing these types of orders even for passive directors and they feel they cannot make an exception for the president's son, who is in the position of many of these directors of not wanting to accept even a pro forma slap on the wrist because they feel they've done nothing wrong,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Bell Labs To Unveil Prototype of Photon Computer
DOC.TEXT: AT&T Bell Laboratories plans to announce the development of a computer that runs on photons instead of electrons, creating the potential for vastly more powerful computers, an official said Friday. The company has set a news conference for Monday, but refused to comment on its subject matter. But an industry official familiar with the research, who spoke on condition of anonymity, confirmed the conference would be about the creation of a ``photonic'' computer. Such a computer would transmit information with photons, the fundamental particles of light, rather than electronic impulses. The prototype to be unveiled Monday is a fairly rudimentary device that runs at a low level of power, but is believed to be the first to run on photons, the official said. Scientists believe such computers some day may run at speeds thousands of times faster than today's versions.

DOC.HEAD: Former Grabill Corp. Chairman Acquitted of Bankruptcy Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Former Grabill Corp. Chairman William Stoecker was acquitted Friday on six counts of bankruptcy fraud in connection with the collapse of his financial empire. A U.S. District Court jury deliberated for six hours before returning the not-guilty verdicts for Stoecker, 32, who was charged with failing to disclose $255,000 to the bankruptcy trustee appointed to oversee his estate. Until his troubles surfaced last year, Stoecker had a reputation as a financial genius who had built a multimillion-dollar conglomerate of 22 manufacturing and retail companies, all acquired in leveraged buyouts. But his financial empire began to crumble in December 1988 when he was unable to make full payment on a $150 million loan. A nine-bank consortium that loaned Stoecker the money forced the conglomerate into bankruptcy in early 1989 after finding that $100 million in assets had disappeared. Stoecker also went into personal bankruptcy. He was charged last April with bankruptcy fraud. Prosecutors said he concealed assets to maintain a lavish lifestyle that include mansions, airplanes and expensive art. The government alleged Stoecker contributed $140,000 to a bank account he created in his maid's name. They also said he hid another $115,000 in a safe in his suburban home. But during the week-long trial, Durkin contended that government witnesses lied and that attorneys who testified against Stoecker were trying to protect legal fees exceeding $1 million from the bankruptcy proceedings. Some of Stoecker's friends and relatives in the courtroom burst into tears when the verdicts were read. Afterward, Stoecker said he felt ``oustanding.''

DOC.HEAD: RJR Nabisco Junk Bonds Tumble After Ratings Downgrade
DOC.TEXT: RJR Nabisco Inc.'s junk bonds, previously a stalwart in the volatile high-yield debt market, fell sharply Friday after Moody's Investors Service Inc. lowered its rating of the company's debt. Analysts said some of RJR Nabisco's junk bonds fell 10 percent in value. The rest of the high-yield market also declined, but not as severely. Moody's lowered its ratings on RJR Nabisco's outstanding debt and assigned a lower-than-expected rating to an upcoming $1.25 billion bond issue the company plans. Jim Lewis, a corporate bond trader with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said RJR Nabisco's bonds _ which helped finance the record $24.53 billion leveraged buyout of food and tobacco company _ were hurt by the downgrade, but also have fallen this week in response to volatility in the stock market. Friday's decline reversed a trend in high-yield trading. RJR Nabisco's bonds fared better than other issues recently when the junk bond market plunged in response to the failure of Campeau Corp.'s buyout of Federated Department Stores Inc. ``The (RJR Nabisco bonds) don't look as good as they used to,'' Lewis said. The bonds declined although RJR Nabisco securities received somewhat more favorable ratings from two other companies, Standard & Poor's Corp. and Fitch Investors Service Inc. Lewis said the Moody's rating meant that the purchasers of the new $1.25 billion issue likely would have to be the same investors who were willing to take a risk on the earlier $4 billion in bonds. Traders had hoped to see a bigger market for the new bonds, he said. ``The perception is, now you've shifted the major buying responsibility to the junkier section of the market,'' he said. RJR Nabisco said months ago it planned the new issue to refinance some of its debt after completing $5.4 billion in asset sales required under its loan agreements with major banks. Moody's said uncertainties about the cash flow of RJR Nabisco's tobacco business over the long-term led it to lower its ratings, although Moody's analyst Gloria Vila said, ``We recognize that certain near-term risks have been alleviated.'' She credited RJR Nabisco for successfully completing its asset divestiture program and selecting a good management team. But she said the firm _ like other tobacco companies _ faces the problem of fewer smokers and possibly lower profits in the years ahead. Furthermore, she said RJR Nabisco has had more success with some of its lower-priced brands, such as Doral cigarettes, than with higher-margin products, such as Winston. RJR Nabisco spokesman David Kalis said the company could not comment on Moody's action because the firm was required to remain silent while the $1.25 billion in bonds were awaiting approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Standard & Poor's said it had completed a review of RJR Nabisco and had affirmed its rating of the company's debt. William Wetreich, a Standard & Poor's spokesman, said his firm had no plans to further review RJR Nabisco's rating. Standard & Poor's noted concerns about the tobacco business, but ``the company's strong tobacco cash flows are still expected to continue growing.'' The rating service also gave the new bond issue a speculative grade. Fitch assigned the new issue its highest rating for speculative, or high-yield, debt. This was the first rating Fitch has made of RJR Nabisco bonds. The company only recently began evaluating the high-yield market.

The U.S. economy slowed almost to a standstill in the last three months of 1989, registering a barely perceptible 0.5 percent annual growth rate that was the poorest since the spring of 1986. The Commerce Department on Friday blamed the big drop-off in growth from October through December on a rare decline in consumer spending, a deteriorating trade deficit and a slump in business investment spending. For the year as a whole, the GNP grew by 2.9 percent, following a much more rapid 4.4 percent increase in 1988. It was the slowest annual growth rate since a 2.7 percent rise in 1986.

Revco D.S. Inc., the first big company to seek bankruptcy-court refuge from debts incurred in a leveraged buyout, has announced plans to sell 712 of its 1,873 stores in a costly restructuring. The company, one of the country's largest drugstore chains with a work force of 26,800 people, said Friday it would refocus on operations in Eastern states where sales are strongest.

Neil Bush says his father, the president, told him to ``do what's right'' when the younger Bush said he intends to fight conflict-of-interest charges leveled by federal thrift regulators. The decision may put the president in the awkward position of appointing the official likely to decide the case, but Neil Bush said after talking to his father that he did not believe the matter would pose a problem. The Office of Thrift Supervision said Friday it will issue a ``notice of charges'' alleging that actions by the younger Bush as a director of a Colorado savings and loan ``amounted to conflicts of interest.''

Brazil's president-elect has promised to make proposals for renegotiating his country's $110 billion foreign debt, biggest in the Third World, the week after he takes office March 15. Brazil has paid no interest to foreign banks since September, and much of what it has paid in recent years has come from new borrowing. More than $19 billion of the debt is owed to U.S. banks. The announcement was made Friday.

Emission control and fuel efficiency standards in a Senate clean air bill would drive some dealers out of business and give consumers a drastically narrower selection of cars, automakers said. In an unusual move, representatives of fiercely competitive domestic and foreign manufacturers on Friday criticized portions of the Senate bill that would set tougher anti-pollution requirements than President Bush recommended. The Senate standards also exceed what a pending House bill would require.

RJR Nabisco Inc.'s junk bonds, previously a stalwart in the volatile high-yield debt market, fell sharply after Moody's Investors Service Inc. lowered its rating of the company's debt. Analysts said some of RJR Nabisco's junk bonds fell 10 percent in value Friday. The rest of the high-yield market also declined, but not as severely. Moody's lowered its ratings on RJR Nabisco's outstanding debt and assigned a lower-than-expected rating to an upcoming $1.25 billion bond issue the company plans.

McDonnell Douglas Corp. reported a 58 percent decline in fourth-quarter profits as major write-offs in several divisions plagued the nation's largest defense contractor. For the three-month period ending Dec. 31, the company said Friday it had profits of $60 million, or $1.56 a share, compared with $145 million, or $3.79 a share, for the same period a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter totaled $4.29 billion, up slightly from $4.14 billion for 1988's final quarter.

The government has announced the recall of three million cans of an aerosol string confetti because the propellant used in the product may be highly flammable. The product, ``Extra Thick Super String,'' often used at children's birthday parties and other celebrations, is hazardous if sprayed near an open flame, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Friday.

Former Grabill Corp. Chairman William Stoecker was acquitted on six counts of bankruptcy fraud in connection with the collapse of his financial empire. A U.S. District Court jury deliberated for six hours before returning the not-guilty verdicts Friday for Stoecker, 32, who was charged with failing to disclose $255,000 to the bankruptcy trustee appointed to oversee his estate.

Stock prices declined slightly in an erratic session Friday as rising interest rates and recession worries kept the market under pressure. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.81 to 2,559.23, stretching its loss for the week to 118.67 points. The dollar finished mixed. Bond prices slipped. Gasoline futures prices rose sharply; pork belly futures fell, while livestock futures were mixed; precious metals advanced; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Huntsman, GE Division Propose Joint Venture To Acquire Aristech
DOC.TEXT: Utah chemical magnate Jon Huntsman and a General Electric Co. division said Friday they are attempting to form a 50-50 joint venture that could acquire Aristech Chemical Corp. for more than $899 million. Huntsman Holdings Corp. and GE Plastics of Pittsfield, Mass., said the proposal could enable Huntsman to boost his offer for Aristech from $25 a share to at least $26 a share, according to a letter the Salt Lake City businessman mailed to Aristech board member R.S. Evans. Aristech spokesman David Higie declined to comment Friday. Huntsman is in a bidding war for Aristech with Mitsubishi Corp. of Japan and Aristech's senior management, which last week offered $26 a share. The senior management group is led by Aristech Chairman Thomas Marshall. Aristech has about 32 million outstanding shares, or the equivalent of about 34.6 million fully diluted outstanding shares. Aristech stock dropped 12{ cents Friday in New York Stock Exchange trading to $25.12{. Huntsman's $25-a-share offer, worth about $865 million, was rejected in November. Aristech's board in effect rejected the Mitsubishi-management bid on Wednesday when it announced it would seek bids from buyers willing to pay more than $26 a share. The board set a bidding deadline for 5 p.m. Monday. In his letter, Huntsman asked Aristech to extend the deadline until Feb. 20 to give him more time to review Aristech's financial condition and form the joint venture. ``Unfortunately, the 5 p.m. Jan. 29 deadline for the submission of bids, as set forth in your Jan. 24 letter to me, will not afford us an adequate opportunity to conduct the necessary review,'' Huntsman wrote. ``In view of Mitsubishi Corp.'s and Aristech management's lengthy period to conduct a complete review of Aristech, fairness dictates that we be afforded a reasonable due diligence review period,'' the letter said. Huntsman has signed an agreement not to accumulate additional Aristech stock unless he offers to buy all outstanding stock for $25 per share or more. Huntsman currently owns 8.7 percent of the company's stock, according to Huntsman spokesman Joele Frank. In Securities and Exchange Commission documents filed Thursday, Huntsman said he has signed a confidentiality agreement in return for receiving confidential financial data about the company. Much of Aristech's holdings are former USX Chemical Corp. properties. The company employs about 1,800 people at 10 plants in eight states.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Newman, Actress Streep to Appear in American Express Commercials
DOC.TEXT: Actor Paul Newman and actress Meryl Streep will be making their first appearances ever in U.S. TV commercials later this year in ads for American Express Cards, the financial services company said Thursday. Newman's commercial will debut on the CBS broadcast of the Super Bowl football championship game this Sunday, American Express said. Streep has been filmed for a commercial that is expected to be aired later in the year, according to spokeswoman Gail Wasserman of American Express Travel-Related Services Co. Inc. Wasserman declined to say how much the actors had been paid for their appearances. The commercials are being billed as ``Video Portraits,'' and are the first video takeoffs on the highly-acclaimed series of print ads that American Express has done in recent years, featuring distinctive photographs of well-known people who have been longtime cardholders. Former House Speaker Thomas P. ``Tip'' O'Neill, for instance, was shown seated under a beach umbrella playing cards in hand in one ad. In another print ad, former basketball star Wilt Chamberlain and jockey Willie Shoemaker were photographed together, each dressed in white suits. Actress Candice Bergen was in another ad, riding a horse. The use of famous stars on TV represents a notable departure for American Express. Until a few years ago, the company was best known for its long-running campaign featuring obscure faces introducing themselves by saying, ``Do you know me?'' Newman doesn't say a word in his 60-second commercial, which will be run during the fourth quarter of the Super Bowl broadcast. The ad opens with Newman, a racing car enthusiast and cardmember since 1966, zipping up his leather jacket, pulling on some racing gloves and heading for the track. He is handed a miniature motorcyle, and it soon becomes evident that he is expected to ride it in a race against a high-powered car. Can you guess who wins?

DOC.HEAD: Rorer's Net Income Up 40 Percent in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Rorer Group Inc., which last week announced plans to merge with a French pharmaceutical firm, said Thursday its earnings rose 66 percent in the fourth quarter and 40 percent in 1989, in part because of a fee for terminating an earlier merger pact with another drug company. Net income jumped to $44.7 million, or $1.38 a share, in the fourth quarter from $26.9 million, or 85 cents a share a year earlier. Sales grew 24 percent to $403 million from $325 million. For all of 1989, the suburban Philadelphia company reported net income rose to $86.5 million, or $2.67 a share, from $61.8 million, or $1.96 a share, in 1988. Sales increased 13 percent to $1.18 billion from $1.04 billion. The 1989 earnings include a pre-tax gain of $19.9 million. That reflected a fee paid by A.H. Robins Co. Inc. in the fourth quarter for breaking off a merger agreement with Rorer in favor of one with American Home Products Corp. On Jan. 18, Rorer announced it agreed to merge with the drug operations of Rhone-Poulenc. The $3 billion deal would give the French company 68 percent of Rorer's stock, leaving the rest in public hands. The resulting firm would be one of the world's 10 largest pharmaceutical companies. The gain was partially offset by almost $10 million in restructuring costs for Rorer's European facilities. ``It was an exceptionally good year for us around the world,'' said Rorer's chairman and chief executive officer, Robert E. Cawthorn. ``We achieved strong results even though we invested heavily in marketing programs and research and development to ensure a prosperous future.'' Cawthorn said results benefited from a 46 percent increase in sales of Rorer's calcitonin drugs, used to treat the degenerative bone disease osteoporosis. Sales of Maalox antacid, the company's best-known product, grew 19 percent in the fourth quarter compared with a year earlier, he said. Rorer stock closed unchanged Thursday at $61 on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Corp. Announces Record Net Income for Quarter, Year
DOC.TEXT: Fast-food giant McDonald's Corp. said Thursday its earnings rose 13 percent in the fourth quarter and for all of 1989, a year in which it opened the most restaurants in its history. The quarter ending Dec. 31 was the 99th consecutive quarter of record operating results, the company said. ``I can think of no better testament to our growth strategy than our achievements in this decade,'' Chairman Fred L. Turner said in a statement. Earnings in the fourth quarter rose to $171 million, or 46 cents a share, from $151.5 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 9 percent to $1.58 billion from $1.45 billion. Net income for 1989 was $726.7 million, or $1.95 a share, compared with $645.9 million, or $1.71 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 10 percent to $6.14 billion from $5.57 billion. ``McDonald's performance in 1989 reflects several milestones,'' President and Chief Executive Officer Michael R. Quinlan said. ``The 11,000th restaurant opened in Hong Kong and we added 649 restaurants, which was more than in any year in our history.'' The restaurant company, which has franchises and affiliates in many countries around the world, opened in 1955.

DOC.HEAD: Producer, Company File for Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT amount for Orion Pictures to $6.2 million, sted $16.2 million. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Producer Francis Ford Coppola and his film company filed for protection from creditors under bankruptcy laws Thursday, court officials said. Coppola and Zoetrope Productions filed separately under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, said the clerk's office at U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Santa Rosa. Zoetrope, based in San Francisco, listed assets of $22.2 million and debts of $28.9 million. It identified its largest creditors as Hot Weather Films-Pony Boy Inc., $16.2 million, and Orion Pictures, $6.2 million. Coppola, director of ``The Godfather,'' did not total his assets or liabilities in his filing, which was also under the business names of Sophia Properties and Niebaum Coppola Estates. He listed a $3 million debt to Darion Development of Los Angeles. Zoetrope said it would issue a statement later Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Cray Research Board Authorizes Repurchase of up to 3 million common shares
DOC.TEXT: Cray Research Inc.'s board has authorized the repurchase of up to three million of the company's common stock, the supercomputer maker announced Thursday. The Minneapolis-based company said it had more than 28.1 million common shares outstanding as of Dec. 31. Cray purchased a total of 3,232,300 shares under a previous repurchase plan, the company said. Cray common stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed Thursday at $43 a share, up 25 cents. The buy-back plan was announced after the close of trading. On Tuesday, Cray said its profits dropped 41 percent in the fourth quarter and 43 percent in 1989 because of the costs of product transitions and development of its new Cray-3 computer.

Teledyne Inc. said its board of directors had approved a plan to spin off its insurance and finance subsidiaries to shareholders. The board also declared a 5-for-1 stock split. Shareholders of record on Feb. 8 will receive four new shares of Teledyne common for each share held. The aviation and electronics company has about 11.1 million shares of common outstanding. The spin-off of a company to be named Unitrin Inc. is expected to be effective March 31 if regulatory clearances are obtained, Teledyne said. Shareholders will receive one Unitrin share for each Teledyne share held. The shares will be distributed on a post-split basis. The insurance and finance units accounted for $1.1 billion of Teledyne's $3.5 billion in sales in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Gaming Commission OKs Holiday Corp. Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: The Nevada Gaming Commission on Thursday gave final approval to a restructuring of Holiday Corp., clearing the way for the hotel and gaming company to sell its Holiday Inn chain to Bass PLC of Britain. Under the restructuring, Holiday Corp. will retain three other fast-growing hotel chains and its Harrah's casinos in Nevada and New Jersey and operate under the new name of Promus Companies Inc. The gaming operations will account for 80 percent of Promus' revenues, with the Embassy Suites, Homewood Suites and Hampton Inns chains making up the remainder. Holiday Corp. had agreed to sell Holiday Inn to Bass for about $2.2 billion pending regulatory approval. Shareholders endorsed the plan Jan. 17, and Nevada's Gaming Control Board and New Jersey's Casino Control Commission gave their approval previously. ``Promus will have a more concentrated commitment to the gaming industry ... and increased financial strength,'' commission Chairman John O'Reilly said following Thursday's vote. ``It appears it's not only in the best interests of the shareholders, but in the best interests of the gaming industry of Nevada.'' Holiday Corp. officials said the firm decided to sell its interest in more than 1,400 Holiday Inn hotels because they were competing for capital against its casinos and other hotels. Harrah's President Phil Satre said the company is committed to its casinos in Nevada and New Jersey, and the restructuring would allow it to continue with capital improvements at each in the future. ``We are proud of a record of success in gaming in Nevada and New Jersey,'' Satre said. ``We are confident of the future and we are confident we can do it in the form of the Promus companies.'' Commission members approved the plan after Holiday officials said their legal and accounting experts assured them the transaction would be tax-free. Holiday officials said they didn't want to wait for an Internal Revenue Service ruling because it could take up to eight months. Holiday officials also told the commission that the deal with Bass PLC places no limits on Promus' ability to construct new casinos. Under the restructuring, Promus will borrow about $900 million to give shareholders and top company officials a special dividend of about $30 per share. The deal is expected to net company officials millions. New Jersey gaming regulators raised concerns that management might profit unduly from the plan, but Nevada gaming regulators did not raise the issue during special hearings this week.
